description:
What an impressive meal!!!  I really, really loved my dining experience at La Ciccia.  It's one of those almost impossible to get reservations in SF so I came right at opening and got a seat at the bar (there are 5 seats for walk-ins).  I asked about their signature dishes and the bartender recommended the Baby Octopus, Sea Urchin and Tuna Heart Pasta and the Saffron Ricotta Cake.  

All of the dishes were just the right combination of unique and tasty.  I found myself asking for a lot of bread so I can soak up all of the wonderful sauces in both the baby Octopus (that tomato sauce had just the perfect amount of spice for that nice "kick") and the sea urchin and tuna heart pasta. The sea urchin and tuna heart pasta was definitely one of the best plates of food I've ever had (it's going on the last supper menu).  The chef gave a sample of the tripe - I've only had Asian preparation but I really liked this. The saffron Ricotta cake was very unique from a texture perspective and was the right amount of sweetness.  Lemon soda and mint tea were my beverage pairings for the evening. 

The service was spectacular and they really gave me a warm family vibe. From an ambiance perspective, this place made me feel like I was vacationing in Italy. I'll be coming back. Highly recommended!!!
author: Andrew S.

description:
This was a great meal!!! We were lucky to snag a reservation (well, maybe not too lucky since I woke up at midnight 30 days before to get it) as we love pasta and are constantly looking for a place. 

We got two pastas: the fish roe and squid ink. HANDS DOWN the fish roe pasta was the better of the two and we would definitely get that again! It was incredibly delicious, maybe one of the top 5 dishes I've had in SF. The pasta had a lovely texture as well. 

The squid ink was a bit disappointing - I think next time we will plan on getting the sea urchin pasta instead.

The restaurant itself is tiny and has a cute mom and pop feel to it - and definitely feels very authentic. Noe Valley is very quiet with lots of parking which we appreciated. We will definitely be back!
author: Michele L.

description:
I was REALLY excited about this place, and it just didn't quite meet my high expectations. I think the flavors were interesting, but nothing wowed me. The place is tucked away in Noe with a super unassuming exterior, and usually that would mean you step inside and it's totally different but it was pretty plain inside too. But busy! Place was packed. As uncharming as the setting was, the service wasn't that much better.

We picked this place for a small birthday gathering, started with a bottle of wine, the sardinian flatbread ($10 for a crisp is kinda steep) and the baby octopus stew. Then the squid ink pasta and sea urchin pasta, maybe the lamb, probably also something else? It was unfortunately pretty forgettable and I don't think we talked about the food at all. We were a chatty bunch about all sorts of other things in our life, so maybe we just were too busy to talk about the food but I think it means we weren't impressed. I'd give it another go though, since the menu is so interesting and boyfriend loved it so much. 

$300 for 4 people.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Food here is really good!
I love the octopus stew - and I could eat a loaf of bread with the sauce. 
The lamb is always perfect, and definitely order all the vegetable sides..they are all amazing. 

Wish it was easier to get reservations here but it would be gluttonous to eat here often...
author: Mimi T.

description:
Great as always. 

This time we were 4 people and ordered the octopus stew, doubled down on the bottarga pasta, and had the squid ink fettuccine and the pork gnoccheti. Everything was delicious but the pork was a bit salty and again, the others just overshadowed it. What we ordered was more than enough for the 4 of us. 

Ordered the carignano 6 mura bottle which was delicious once again
author: Laura D.

description:
One of my favorite meals in SF! I made reservations for 2 about 3 weeks in advance online after an Italian friend recommend La Ciccia. We had the baby octopus stew as an app and 2 pastas to share for the main course. We ordered the linguine with lemon zest squid ink and the sea urchin pasta. Honestly couldn't decide which one was better as they were both excellent. 

The interior is small so it feels homey and cozy. Service was excellent. I can't wait to go back and try more dishes.
author: Thu P.

description:
This is some of the best food I've eaten. Nothing fancy. The ingredients speaks for itself. Honest, unassuming, and simple.

The Bottariga is a crazy simple dish. Crafting simple into art is a different level of genius. This dish is an umami explosion in your mouth.

The squid ink pasta uses real squid ink in the sauce. This isn't a weak version where it's used to color the pasta. No. This is in your face squid ink. So hard to find in USA. 

The shrimp is yet another simple but unexplainably amazing. The only thing I can think of is the quality of the ingredients and the respect it's given.

The Semifreddo was the best dessert but the squid ink panna cotta was the most interesting. The panna cotta was very light and the squid ink added umami to an otherwise sweet dish.

Definitely want to RTE!
author: Dominic C.

description:
The baby octopus stew is truly the winner here. Slightly spicy, excellent flavor, tender baby octopus. I like to pair it with the flatbread, so that I can scoop up every last drop of stew!

I've also tried the squid ink pasta and the spaghetti with cured fish roe. Both featured perfectly cooked pasta noodles; however, the taste was a little too salty for me.

I would definitely come back for the baby octopus stew and flatbread! Note that you most likely have to make a reservation exactly 30 days in advance (when reservation slots open).
author: Celia K.

description: The best restaurant in SF!! The food is incredible and the staff is so friendly. We had the best pasta I have ever had in my life. Their wine list is amazing!! I wish I could give this place more than 5stars.
author: Ghissy U.

description:
Such an amazing quaint, homey Sardinian spot in Noe Valley- a must try if you can nab a reservation!  Perfect for a date night- came here on a Friday night 8pm reservation.  

Venue / Service: hope you aren't claustrophobic, because this area is "cozy" / tight.  Not a great place if you have a large bag / suitcase b/c tables are really close to each other, mind you.  Surprisingly wasn't too loud though, which is a plus.  Also helps that the servers are very attentive and we had no trouble asking for anything.  

Food: overall, a lot of bold flavors with less components.  My date and I split all dishes so we could taste everything.
-- Calamareddusu Arrustiusu cun Frabia (Roasted Monterey Calamari, Basil Oil Greens)($16) - very clean tasting, allowing you to taste the calamari.  This one was recommended by the waiter (after the spicy octopus), and the basil left a nice light feel to the palette so you don't feel like you have fishy mouth.

-- Pasta Longa cun su Nieddu de Seppia (Fresh Linguine Seafood Sugo Lemon Zest Squid Ink)($20) - of the two pastas, this was our favorite.  The addition of the lemon zest added much-needed acidity to the dish, especially when dealing with squid ink.  Pasta was cooked well and not a huge amount of sauce, but still tasty.  

-- Maccarones de Busa cun Arrizonis (Sardinian Macaroni Sea Urchin Tomato grated Tuna Heart)($24) - this is highly recommended by the staff and I agree that this is the most interesting flavor combo I've had.  The tuna heart added a nice, rich flavor to the macaroni, and the sea urchin, while subtle, added a bit of brininess.  This one is on the richer side, and I don't think I would have been able to finish this dish alone.  

-- Pezza de Angioni a sa Saba (Seared Lamb Tenderloin Tagliata drizzled with Saba)($29) - the lamb itself was cooked very well (medium rare, how we like it)!  Though I tend to prefer just simple grill / salt + pepper, the saba (grape must reduction) drizzle was a great hit of acid to the gamey lamb.  My date wasn't as crazy for it as I was, so perhaps this is a hit or miss.  

Meal came out to ~$45 / person excluding drinks, which seems reasonable given portion sizes and how we finished all of the dishes!  
All in all, I think this is an awesome spot for a cozy date night.  Probably not for those who are claustrophobic or have a really big party.
author: Audrey H.

description:
We made reservations here on my birthday around 9:30pm and It was the last reservation that they would take. I was so happy they did. I honestly never heard of it until my girlfriend booked it for me. The service here was not bad, they were always checking in on us and asking us for a refill. The bar tender was kind enough to let us sample different kinds of wine for our likings.
It was a really small place and very compact. Dim light setting, great for any occasion. 

I've never been to a fine dining Italian restaurants so the dishes were a little complicated, but the server was nice enough to give us recommendations. She recommended us I couldn't remember if it was fettuccine or alfredo pasta, anyways it was really delicious! I enjoyed having that dish and definitely complimented our other dishes. I recommend this !

We ordered the calamari dish and wow, that was pretty different from what I ever had. I totally did not expect how it would be cooked. I normally have fried calamari and I would be able to tolerate it. The way they cooked it was as if it was almost raw. That was definitely quite the experience.

Lastly, we had the lamb! The lamb was so gooood! You guys need to try this. I know lamb may sound weird but it was so tender and juicy. They cooked it medium rare and tasted perfect. Chewy, consistent and a lot of flavor. They added bell peppers on the side, eat it together with the lamb! I wished they brought this dish out at the same time as the pasta. I didn't like how they wouldn't bring out any other dish until you were finished with your current one. 

Thank you for having us La Ciccia!
author: Alex L.

description:
My girlfriends and I got really lucky and got a table at 9 PM after a happy hour event. I've been meaning to try this place since a friend told me how the pasta here is as good as Italy, maybe even better. Let's just say that it didn't disappoint.

Sidenote: skip out on the free bread they give you, it's dry and unappetizing. My suggestion is to order the side of flatbread which is served with the most fragrant, delicious olive oil ever! 

We ordered four dishes: the calamari, octopus stew, squid ink linguine, and pork spaghetti (which was a special that evening). ORDER ALL THESE THINGS. The calamari was perfectly roasted and tender, the octopus stew came with the best tomato base and we just had our spoons in there trying to get the last scoop. 

I have dreams about the squid ink linguine people! The slight hint of lemon makes an ordinary dish, extraordinary. I can't wait to go eat it again. 

I would suggest sticking with the seafood dishes and don't forget to peek at the extensive wine list. I can't wait to go back to this place and try the other things on the menu. So delicious!
author: Eunah T.

description: Great restaurant located in an area that isn't very busy or popular, hidden away from the more bustling neighborhoods. The restaurant had a very homey feel to it, with the employees being very attentive to you and willing to talk to you about the food and wine selections. Food was very good as well, though note that it may be different from the Americanized pasta taste that people are used to, as some people felt as if it needed a little salt. But the food was made properly the way that the chefs intended to cook it and was still delicious.
author: David K.

description:
This is one of the best dining experiences I've had in SF. I would most definitely come back. The pastas (especially bottarga one) were disgustingly tasty. In the best way possible. 

Standouts:
1) Bottarga pasta - the money maker here. It's just SO GOOD! I couldn't stop inhaling it. The pasta was perfectly al dente and topped with just enough olive oil and seasoning with that umami flavor from the bottarga flakes.

2) Pork sugo pasta - I feel like any pasta other than bottarga is like the less impressive sibling in a family of overachievers. I really enjoyed this dish - the shape of the pasta was super cute, the pork itself was crumbly and soaked up the tomato sauce so well. I think it was a good balance to the bottarga pasta but... you just can't outshine your older sister when she's like a Harvard MD. If you know what I mean.

3) Ricotta honey cake - Yes. Just do it. It's the best way to end the meal. Not too sweet, not too rich.

Great service the whole night! Not super pretentious for such a nice establishment. Place a res here! Otherwise, you have to sit at the bar and wait like we did.
author: Cindy W.

description:
I love love love food here. A hidden gem in our neighborhood. It takes a month to take a reservation. Luckily I went there twice in a month. I had the best pasta of my life. I ordered flat bread, uni pasta, squid pasta, lamb and fish. 
Starting with olive oil with their homemade bread. They charge $2 for the olive oil but trust me it's worth it. Their flat bread is really good, it's like a thin crispy bread with cheese, olive oil and rosemary on top of it. I would recommend to request for the half size(they do that). I think we should leave some space for the yummylicious pasta and other entree. Then we got the sea urchin pasta and squid spaghetti mmmmmmm soooooo good, very rich in flavor but very heavy. You can easily share one pasta dish with 3 people. I order the lamb medium rare and fish, it's as delicious. They both were cooked to perfection. 
Highly recommended place. 
Nice people, good ambiance, quite and warm!!
author: Sumbal A.

description:
I love how unique this restaurant is! There's a lot of Italian restaurants out there but this is specifically Sardinian specializing in seafood pasta dishes. 

It's pretty hard to get a reservation, since it's tiny (more on that later): we tried to get one a week in advance a few times with no luck. We finally went for Valentine's weekend after booking one month in advance.

The two of us ordered:
-Roasted Monterey calamari with basil, greens and oil: this was a great appetizer! I love not-fried calamari appetizers and this was well cooked with excellent flavors.
-Fresh Spaghetti Spicy Garlic Oil Salt Cured Fish Roe: This is their signature dish and was our favorite dish. The fish roe flavor is great -rich but not too fishy. The portion isn't too big so when you split it for 2, it's just the right amount. The spaghetti is a pretty chewy/borderline al dente. I like that but if you like your spaghetti softer, you might want to mention it.
-Sardinian macaroni with Sea Urchin Tomato Shaved Tuna Heart: We chose this dish since it seemed so exotic and was recommended by the waiter. I love uni and expected a lot but honestly it was like a vaguely fishy tomato cream sauce pasta. Not bad but the flavor was very subtle.

-Wine: we were really impressed with the wine selection from the waiter. Of the two we had, my favorite was the Monica di Sardegna Superiore Azienda Agricola Podere Parpinello 2013, a lighter red wine. Highly recommend. 

The staff here is polite, welcoming and professional. The biggest con would probably be how small the restaurant is. The tables are very close together and I didn't enjoy listening to my neighbor's conversation. I'm honestly shocked how well the waiters managed to get around between the tables. I also liked that this is a bit off the beaten path of SF so parking is not as hard to find. 

All in all, a great, unique restaurant -- we'll be back!
author: Ninette C.

description:
I had the privilege of dining at this cozy neighborhood restaurant in Noe Valley last night at the recommendation of a local friend who loves it, and I also loved its charms. The restaurant reminds me of one of those local Italian restaurants in Jersey or Long Island that is upscale and where the local Italians flock. What is unique about this restaurant is that it specializes in seafood pasta and Sardinian cuisine. 

Because I am on a ketones diet, I stayed away from the pasta but loved the two dishes I chose which they also graciously agreed to make according to my diet specifications. I had the required squid tomato stew (which is like a spicy bisque with squid) and the scallopini (unbranded) with a wonderful sauce and pancetta. I accompanied it with a delicious red wine that was similar to a Primitivo (glass, $15). The total for the dinner was around $65 per person with a shared appetizer. 

Our server was very hospitable and accommodating, and perfectly attentive. The food was served at a nice pace. My only recommendation would be that they provide bowls for sharing the stew -- we were given plates to share the soup, and it was difficult to enjoy the deliciousness from a plate. 

It is difficult to find these hidden gems in San Francisco, and I'm glad that I did. I don't even have to go to Jersey.
author: Todd B.

description:
This place is my sanctuary.

For special occasions, dates you want to take home, or if you just need to balance the craziness of this life. Eat here.

The wine list is ridiculous. The service is impeccable, and you're greeted by the owner every time you come.  Just take my advice, eat these things and leave incredibly satisfied.

Start with baby octopus in spicy tomato sauce with fresh baked dipping bread.

Make sure you order whatever the special is

Include the lamb at some point

You're welcome.
author: M H.

description:
What a wonderful dining experience. The restaurant was cozy and intimate. It was a welcoming and warm atmosphere. From reading other reviews, I was worried the smaller-sized venue might be uncomfortable, but it was perfect, no issues at all. 
The food was delicious. We had the baby octopus stew, the bottarga pasta, the squid ink pasta, pork sugo pasta, the lamb tenderloin, and semifreddo for dessert. 
All dishes were thoroughly enjoyed and the service was friendly and attentive. Would definitely come back!
author: Elaine H.

description:
Food: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Space: 4/5

One of my better dining experiences in SF. Since this was my first time visiting La Ciccia, I stuck with a lot of their classics -- Baby Octopus stew in a spicy Tomato Sauce, Fresh Spaghetti Spicy Garlic Oil Salt Cured Fish Roe, and Pork Sugo, among others -- and everything we ordered was delicious. Wine list was really impressive and the service was extremely patient and thoughtful as well. Really glad SF has a restaurant like La Ciccia and I can't wait for my next meal here.
author: Derrick F.

description:
My recent dinner at La Ciccia was one of the most memorable meals I have had in the past few years. Every aspect of the meal was perfect. 
We were warmly welcomed, seated immediately, had an excellent server who had deep knowledge of the long wine list and every dish was delicious. At no time did we feel rushed. The noise level was comfortable. The unisex restroom was very clean.
Others have posted photos and written beautiful descriptions of the food. The food is beautiful to the eye and to the palate. 
I will definitely return. Love love love La Ciccia
author: winnie r.

description: I'd wanted to try the place for a long time so I was excited to go. The menu seems limited. I was surprised by this. The bread wasn't accompanied with oil or butter. We tried a breaded pork which we didn't enjoy and didn't finish. The pasta special was delicious. We also got the prawns and although difficult to eat were also delicious. The interior is simple. We would go back for a pasta dish.
author: David H.

description: Really loved the calamari - it was flavorful without being too heavy, and the leftover sauce was great for dipping bread into too! The gnocchi special with fondue cheese was delicious and not too over the top. It's always tough to get a reservation here, but when you can, jump on it!
author: Lisa M.

description:
Such a delightful date night spot! La Ciccia is a small, family-owned Sardinian restaurant tucked away in Noe Valley with cozy but moderately upscale vibes. Definitely make reservations here, because the space is super small.

We ordered the baby octopus stew, bottargia, and lamb as our mains. The octopus was delicate without a rubbery texture, and the soup tasted like a thicker tomato soup, but still very rich and a great start to the meal. LOVED the bottargia; I was afraid that it would be too salty but it was a perfect balance of flavors. I wouldn't say it was the best pasta I've ever had, but definitely top 5. Lamb was tender, but I would probably try another pasta next time.

Got the honey & ricotta cake for dessert to share between 2 people. They put a candle on it for my birthday, and the owner came by to wish me a happy birthday, which was sweet. Maybe I just had a dud of a cake, but I felt like I was just eating cheese and almonds. It was a weird texture and the flavor combo seemed odd. I would order one of the chocolate-based desserts or a dessert special next time. 

I'd definitely come back again to try other dishes, except I will definitely order the bottargia again!
author: Denise L.

description:
A great restaurant focusing on Sardinian cuisine. It's a small restaurant so make sure to make reservations ahead of time. The best appetizers are the octopus stew and the grilled calamari. Make sure you have lots of bread handy to sop up the sauce from the octopus stew. 

For the pasta their signature dishes are Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga and Fregua cun Arrizzoni e Cori de Tonnu. You have to get both. They are amazing. 

For the main, get the lamb. Perfectly cooked and really big portions.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
This place is the best!! We were only able to snag reservations for one of their last seatings. Definitely a neighborhood spot with not much else going on in terms of nightlife. We were quickly seated and the amazing smell of Italian food won me over. The restaurant was small but full of energy. 

We started with a bottle of Sardinian wine which was described to be light similar to a Pinot Noir. It ended up being a nice complement to our meal which consisted of pretty heavy pasta dishes. We started with the calamari salad and Sardinian flat bread. For entrees we shared 2 pasta dishes. The food was amazing. They have something for everyone - traditional comfort food to unique Sardinian specialities. They even gave us a small dessert with a candle to celebrate our anniversary which we had noted in opentable. It's these small gestures that are so often overlooked and the personal touch really made our night special. SOOOO Looking forward to coming back :)
author: Yin H.

description:
After all these years living in San Francisco, La Ciccia is still one of my favorite restaurants to go to. The food here has always been consistent, and the service is now much improved. When I'm craving for pasta, this would be my spot!

This place serves amazing seafood. Here are some of my all time favorite dishes:

- Roasted Calamari: so fresh and tender, and that sauce that comes with it is just so delicious. It's a perfect appetizer if you are looking for something light

- Baby Octopus Stew: tender octopus in rich and tasty spicy tomato sauce. It's so good to eat this dish with the house bread

- Spaghetti bottarga: the texture of the fresh pasta is just perfect and and the flavor combination of Spicy Garlic Oil and Salt Cured Fish Roe is just simply amazing. My favorite dish here.

- Seared market fish: it's usually branzino aka mediterranean seabass, which is seared perfectly and served with some nicely cooked vegetables. This dish is perfectly seasoned and the vegetables have a little kick.. so tasty.
author: Sam M.

description:
So delicious. We arrived on time for a 9pm reservation and waited about 10-15 minutes for a table to clear. It's a tiny restaurant, and it feels warm and bustley. Good atmosphere for a more casual date or get together, but it would be difficult to accommodate big groups. Nice and cozy ambience. 

Fantastic wine list for Italian wine lovers. For pasta- we actually all loved the gnochetti with pork ragu more than the famed spaghetti with fish roe. The prosciutto was melt-in-your-mouth good, and there were some good specials of the day (including a lovely burrata and arugula salad that I did not partake in). My friends ordered the lamb and the breaded pork entrées-- they were excellent, and I found myself craving more than the bite that I had of each. 

For anyone who avoids lactose -- I learned from our server that Sardinian food doesn't really use cow products, so it's nice to know that most dishes use sheep or goat cheese. They don't even have butter in the restaurant!

Desserts were devoured- pistachio gelato, raisin gelato, Sardinian ricotta and honey cake, and the chocolate semifreddo. DELICIOUS. I couldn't stop eating dessert, I wanted more afterwards. 

Portions were just enough to make you feel full but still leave the semblance of "I could've had more of that" just because it was so good, not because you *needed* more. 

Thank you, La Ciccia! Lovely night.
author: Rose K.

description:
Hard to get reservations, but you need one. Place isn't that big and I hear it's always busy. I don't know much about Sardinian food, but it was good. The pastas were my least favorite so that was a little disappointing, but everything is really fresh and they don't skimp on their portions. 

Calamareddusu in Inzallada cun Olia (Calamari Salad Bosana Olives Celery Radishe-gorgeous presentation and excellent flavors. 

Prupisceddu in Umidu cun Tomatiga (Baby Octopus stew in a spicy Tomato Sauce-I heard this was a must order. Lots of octopus. It's never ending. This is very filing. 

Pasta Longa cun su Nieddu de Seppia (Fresh Linguine Seafood Sugo Lemon Zest Squid Ink)-black pasta, but a little bland for me. 

Fregua cun Arrizzoni e Cori de Tonnu (Sardinian Fregula Sea Urchin Tomato Shaved Tuna Heart)-I always say I'm not a huge fan of sea urchin, but I'm always willing to try it more now. Since having EMC's Uni Pasta and it was to die for this was just way too much. Very overpowering...a little too much, but the waitress did warn us that it is very strong uni flavor. Even my gfs that love uni thought it was a little too much. 

Gamberoisi Arrustiusu cun Tomatiga (Seared Prawns on a Rich Tomato Sugo-shell on, but they butterfly it so you don't need to use your hands to peel. Great presentation and it was so good. 

Pani Guttiau (Traditional Sardinian Flat Bread baked with EVOO and Pecorino)-this is a must get. I can eat this for days!!!

Didn't get dessert because we walk to Mitchell's for ice cream!
author: Karen H.

description:
Nom Nom Nom Nom Nommmy!

We had reservations Friday night at 6pm. Reserved it 2 weeks in advance and it was one of two reservations left available. Such a good sign with promising Yelp reviews. We arrived promptly at 6 and our table was ready for us. We sat in the corner of the restaurant near the door which was a little cramped, but the restaurant itself is not that spacious.

Ordered:
x Prupisceddu in Umidu cun Tomatiga (Baby Octopus stew in a spicy Tomato Sauce) - OMG so good... the octopus was SOOO tender and the stew was so flavorful with some heat. We ended up eating 2 loaves of bread with this dish because the bread soaked in the stew was AMAZING. I would eat this everyday if I could :P A little heavy for an appetizer, but so worth it.
x Roasted Calamari w/ Basil Oil Greens - So simple yes SOO delicious. I've never tasted anything like it. Even the presentation was so appealing... light and perfect for an appetizer. I recommend dipping your bread in the extra oil on the plate :)
x Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga (Fresh Spaghetti Spicy Garlic Oil Salt Cured Fish Roe) - The pasta was perfectly cooked and the slight saltiness of the cured fish roe really made the dish. Usually, fish roe could be overpowering, but it was perfectly done. I believe this is one of their speciality pastas so DEF recommend.
x Uni Pasta - This was their special of the night which we did not order, but kept anyway. We wanted the sea urchin pasta with shaved tuna hearts, but the server misunderstood us so we agreed to keep it if she added shaved tuna hearts. Best decision ever! This pasta was so rich, creamy, and delicious. AMAZINGGGGG. I'm only used to eating uni with sushi, but this was a pleasant experience. 10/10 would recommend if they have this special.

We had such a fun dinner here. Everything was AMAZING and the service was pretty quick. Can't wait to go back to try their squid ink pasta... MMMMMM!
author: Anna M.

description: Walked in and got really lucky with seats at the bar at 7pm on a Thursday! Wow - what an incredible meal. I had this place bookmarked for a while appealed by Sardinian cuisine. The flatbread was actually my favorite. Spaghetti with garlic cured fish roe.. I'm still dreaming about this meal.
author: Susan A.

description:
Had an excellent meal at La Ciccia! 

Located in a quiet stretch of Noe Valley, the ambience is cozy and welcoming. It was a great place to spend a chilly fall evening. 

The most memorable part of the meal for me was the pasta! I had the special, which was pappardelle with seafood ragu, and omg it was so good. The sauce was flavorful, rich and comforting and the pasta was cooked perfectly. The portion was just right, too; from previous reviews I was worried, but I was completely satisfied and I'm not a light eater. You can buy a pound of the pasta to cook at home too!

Our server was accommodating when we wanted to split the bill with exact amounts on each card (although he made a quiet remark that indicated he wasn't thrilled about it). The service was good overall though, they are very helpful and make an effort to create an upscale feeling experience. The meal didn't break the bank either -- a glass of wine, pasta and shared appetizer + dessert were about $50/pp.
author: Christine G.

description: Came by here for a work dinner with a colleague who lives in the area. The place is very small and cute, the decor is nice. The wine list was excellent with lots of Sardinian wine. The waiter was extremely knowledgable and very nice. I had a pasta dish. The food was superb overall. I would come back for sure.
author: Jonah K.

description:
Elizabeth's Star Rating System
1 star = Terrible, would not recommend, will tell family and friends to avoid
2 stars = I won't be back but you might enjoy it
3 stars = I'll be back eventually
4 stars = I'll definitely be back
5 stars = I'm telling my friends and family about this place! 

GETTING THERE:
Easy to spot the restaurant, found parking around the block. 

ARRIVAL:
I had called before getting there to ask if bar seating was self seating. Lorella, manager and one of the owners, told me yes it was first come first served and asked me how many. I told her two people and she said yes, there was bar seating available. 

When I got there, I asked if we could just grab whichever seats at the bar, nothing that there were place settings on one leg of the bar. Lorella recognized my voice and said you just called right? I saved you these two seats. How thoughtful! Dinner is already off to a great start. 

FOOD/DRINKS:
Everything was amazing! We went to Italy over the summer so I had a craving for good Italian seafood. We were not disappointed. We got the spicy baby octopus, fresh spot prawns, spicy garlic oil cod roe pasta, and the macaroni tomato uni pasta. Everything was exceptionally prepared and fresh. 

The baby octopus was so tender and I was so happy that the dish, because of the deep bowl, stayed hot the entire time, down to the last spoonful. 

The prawns were so tender, sweet and fresh. 
The cod roe pasta reminded us of Rome, pasta cooked al dente. 

The uni pasta with the tomato sauce was perfect! I love uni but typically do not like uni pasta because I find it too rich. The preparation here with a tomato based sauce was perfectly balanced. It was excellent and left a lingering uni taste. 

SERVICE:
Excellent service! See my comments under arrival. 

AMBIENCE:
Nice for a date night, noise level okay/ambient

OVERALL:
I wished I lived in SF just so I could come here weekly! And honestly, I'm not a pasta lover! I thought Rome was okay, even though I went to a number of reputable places. The flavors of the dishes were all spot on! I would DEFINITELY come back next time I'm in town.
author: Elizabeth A.

description:
I visited Sardinia a dozen times from my base in Tuscany when I lived in Italy from 1999-2003 and took up residence in the island's capital Cagliari for 6 months while updating the Cadogan travel guide to the region in preparation for the publication of the 3rd edition in 2004. 

Now that I'm back in the US I try to return as often as possible and have averaged a trip every other year since then. Sardinia is a remarkable place from its rugged inner terrain where millions of sheep graze to the hundreds of beaches that circle the island like a pearl necklace that attract both Italian and international visitors on holiday. 

Its people are unique within Italy - a truly separate breed living on an island whose southern tip is closer to Tunisia than the rest of the country (natives refer to the rest of Italy as "The Continent."). As with any distinct culture Sardinia has its own cuisine and at last count there were 8 Sardinian restaurants in the US - 2 in NYC and 1 each in Dallas, Houston, Chicago, Miami, Washington, DC and San Francisco. 

La Ciccia in San Francisco's Noe Valley district is as close as you can get to savoring authentic dishes without traveling there. It took me a while to finally eat there because it is basically always booked until around 9:30 and closes at 10 (its regular appearance on top-10 lists of the best restaurants in San Francisco - including a the latest published by Open Table - is one of the reasons). Of course dining at 9:45 pm is normal in Mediterranean lands but I live about 20 miles south of the city and would rather not get home after midnight. But I'd made the decision to take what I could get and landed a table at that time. I was not disappointed and it was worth the wait.

The husband and wife team of chef Massimilliano Conti (he's the Sard) and Lorella Degan have created a spot that - were it not for the street car running on tracks nearby - would hold its own on the restaurant row on Via Sardegna in Cagliari's Marina District. Knowing I wouldn't finish everything but that I could take what I didn't finish home, I cerated my own tasting menu and when I closed my eyes and savored the flavors of various dishes was transported to a place I consider my second home.

I was offered an amuse bouche of a few strips of bottarga - the compressed mullet roe that is one of Sardinia's staples -mand ordered a plate of the crisp flatbread affectionately referred to as "sheet music" which was served warm, drizzled with olive oil and had a few rosemary leaves that added a subtle fragrance. 

For an appetizer I order the octopus stew in a spicy tomato sauce that has been cited repeatedly as a favorite by web reviewers and it lived up to its reputation. Then half portions of both spaghetti with bottarga and fregola (little pearls of pasta that) with a seafood sauce. The spaghetti dish was different than any other of the literally hundred times I've had it and I was told it was because they use fresh rather than dry pasta. So a first for me. Then I devoured grilled squid and grilled jumbo prawns - both fresh and locally caught. Unfortunately I didn't have room for dessert.

The night I ate there the renowned Mexican chef Gabriela Cámara was dining near by with friends visiting from out of town. I can rave all day and all night about a restaurant but there's no better tribute than being a place where a city's other acclaimed chefs come to eat on their rare nights off. I plan to return as soon as possible!
author: Mitchell F.

description: La Ciccia serves the most delicious Sardinian/Italian food in SF.  I always make it a point to dine here every time I'm in town.  Make sure to make a reservation about a month out or you will be out of luck.  The pasta here is chewy and delicious and the sauces are impeccable.  Try some Sardinian wine with your meal it's great with your food.  The wine and food are priced right.  The staff are friendly and professional.  Be sure to check this place out, you won't be sorry.
author: JP M.

description:
Only Sardinian restaurant in SF.  Wife is from Venice and husband Sardinian.  The food was delicious, sea urchin and squid ink were my wife and my favorite.  Service was well managed and owners are up and about engaging and working the floor.  It does feel stuffy when house is full so dress casual (depending on seating).  

One dish the pasta was under cooked but was corrected and tasted al-denta.  

Planning a future dinner date here again.
author: Rich L.

description:
My husband took me here for our 10th wedding anniversary dinner.  It was such a nice surprise. 
If you want to go somewhere for a dining experience, this is definitely a great place. It's an intimate restaurant with top notch service and the food is amazing.  I had a wonderful time.  
Our waitress provided excellent service from beginning to end, and made several suggestions from the menu.  She helped us with the wine pairing as well and the wines paired perfectly with our meals.  We were in absolute awe of the place.

To start, my husband ordered the Prupisceddu in Umidu cun Tomatiga (Baby Octopus stew in a spicy Tomato Sauce)  and I ordered the Zupetta de Pisci (Seafood Stew of Clams Mussels Shrimps Calamari Sea Greens). Both were hearty and a perfect start to our meal, especially since it was a pretty cold night. 

Then for our first course, my husband orderd the  Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga (Fresh Spaghetti Spicy Garlic Oil Salt Cured Fish Roe) and I ordered the Pasta Longa cun su Nieddu de Seppia (Fresh Linguine Seafood Sugo Lemon Zest Squid Ink). If I recall correctly, I think the pasta is made in house.  For our main course, my husband ordered the Pisci de Mari Arrustiu (Seared Market Fish and Vegetables)  which he loved and I had the 
Gamberoisi Arrustiusu cun Tomatiga (Seared Prawns on a Rich Tomato Sugo). The prawns were huge and cooked to perfection! 

Definitely a wonderful experience and we will definitely be back sometime. I forgot to mention that they do have a no camera or cell phone message on the menu but my husband and I managed to sneak in a few pictures.  Just thought I would give you a heads up.  Service is outstanding, food is unique and wonderful and ambiance is intimate.  Perfect for a date night or even a small group of friends.  Highly recommend.
author: Christine P.

description: Date night in the city and I was able to score reservations at this very popular restaurant.  The reservations were for 9 PM on a Saturday night. We were out at a family event earlier in the day and didn't have lunch so we were starved when we arrived for dinner.  We started with the Sardinian flat bread with the rosemary and olive oil - the flatbread is extremely thin and very crispy- with a slight touch of cheese on it, this was really good.  We ordered the stewed octopus with the spicy tomato sauce - the octopus was really soft and the sauce was really good - I used some of the bread to get the sauce up.  We then had the signature dish of the restaurant - the fresh spaghetti with spicy garlic oil and salt cured fish roe - I liked the dish but thought that it needed a touch more salt.  We then had the special fish of the day - the branzino with tomato sauce and olives and the fish was done very well - it came with braised cabbage.  The last dish we shared was the pork scaloppine with mushrooms. The pork dish was nice and crispy but we were so stuffed, we took the rest of it home.  This restaurant is worth the trip to try the local specialities of Sardinia.  I'll be back again.
author: Susan C.

description:
I adore this place and our wonderful energetic waiter.

Sit wherever you want.  

Take hella pictures if you want. 

Stuff your silly face all you want...

From our appetizer of seafood stew filled with clams, shrimps, mussels, calamari to a rich dish of Sardinian Fregula sea urchin with tomato shaved tuna heart pasta to a comfort bowl of Bolognese fettuccine. Everything was freaking D-E-L--I-C-I-O-U-S!!! Portion wise was more than enough, I ended up taking half home to eat the next day for lunch and it was still tasty!

I highly recommend making a ressie for this place. It's tiny, it's small, and it's very busy!

Would love to come back here for casual dining, date night, or a catch up dinner session with friends. I hope you give this place a try! Cheers!

The simple things in life!
author: Owie N.

description: La Ciccia is our favorite date night / special occasion spot. The food is always delicious, but the service and ambiance is what makes this resturant truly special. You must get the Bottariga pasta and the lamb. For wine, try the Terre Brune.
author: Steven B.

description:
Hands down, it's safe to say that La Ciccia is one of the best Italian restaurants I've been to! Every dish that we ordered was spectacular and did not disappoint. The restaurant is extremely small and crowded, and you have to get a reservation. Reservations are usually made a month in advance so I'd start planning if you want to dine here.

All of the dishes are small enough that I'd recommend sharing everything so you get to try multiple things. We started with the Prupisceddu in Umidu cun Tomatiga (Baby octopus in a spicy tomato sauce). There was a good amount of octopus and I loved the tomato sauce. It wasn't spicy at all and had a really hearty taste. A little tip would be to dip the house bread in the sauce!

For our pasta dishes, we opted for the Pasta Longa cun su Nieddu de Seppia (Linguine seafood sugo with lemon zest squid ink) and the Malloreddus a sa Campidanese (Gnochetti Pork Bagna Pecorino Sardo). Both were FANTASTIC!! Both pastas were cooked perfectly al-dente and I loved how chewy the pastas were. The linguine seafood was packed with this savory flavor that had a hint of sweetness from the lemon zest. I love squid ink pastas and this one was top-notch. The gnochetti was amazing as well. I loved the texture of the pasta and you could definitely tell that the pastas have a real homemade feel to them. 

We were still feeling a little hungry so we decided to order the Gamberoisi Arrustiusu cun Tomatiga (Seared Prawns). If you're ok with getting your hands a little dirty from peeling the HUGE prawns, then you should definitely order this! 

If you're looking for a restaurant to "wow" you, I'd definitely consider making a reservation at La Ciccia!
author: Jason L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place especially since the hostess was so pleasant and welcoming. We had one really good dish...the baby octopus stew...but everything after there was just significantly worse. It's unlikely we would return other than to try the semifreddo which they ran out of. Additionally the servers did not appear to be that knowledgeable about the wine selection to effectively make recommendations. On the other hand the pasta was very well cooked to a nice al dente texture.

Baby octopus stew - get this. The octopus is very tender in a spicy tomato broth 

Pasta with uni and shaved tuna hearts - this dish came out smelling very fishy and on top of that had an offensive fishy taste as well. I've had uni sashimi before and it's never smelled or tasted fishy so I wasn't sure if it was the uni or the tuna hearts or both that was causing the offensive smell and taste. 

Pasta with fish roe - this also came out smelling very fishy too but the taste wasn't as bad but was still not very exciting. I wouldn't bother getting this dish.

The pork shoulder stew was nice but nothing significantly note worthy to warrant a return.
author: Mai C.

description:
I went to La Ciccia right after I moved to SF, without knowing what to expect. 

The food was fantastic and the freshness of their ingredients made every bite flavourful, delicious and memorable. 

The restaurant has a true Italian/European vibe and atmosphere that is a welcome change to the typical restaurant scene one can find around. 

I am keen on coming back and I will provide a full detailed report with pictures then :-)
author: Rodrigo B.

description:
Went there last night for a double date dinner. It was a great experience. The food was amazing. The reason I gave 4 stars instead of 5 are because of the service and the bread. Our waiters were okay, a bit impatient and unfriendly. The bread tasted stale.

Anyway, for food, we did a family style and we ordered 6 dishes in total. 
1. Anchovy salad (4.5/5): I'm not a big fan of anchovy because I find them to be a bit too fishy. But my friends all loved it. I like the citrus they put in to go with the salty fish. 
2. Tomato based soup with baby octopus (5/5): love this appetizer and after we finished the octopus, we dipped our bread in, and it was delicious (wish the bread could be fresher)
3. Sea urchin pasta with shredded salmon heart (5/5): love this creamy (creamy because of the sea urchin). Really creative and flavorful .
4. Linguini with black squid ink (5/5): whenever I go to an Italian restaurant, squid ink pasta is a must. La Ciccia did a great a job making this dish. The linguini was cooked perfectly and the sauce was amazing.
5. Shrimp with sauté peppers (entree) (4/5): the shrimps were huge. Not my favorite because the taste was kinda bland and nothing too much going on with this dish.
6. Marinated Lamb steak with Brussels sprouts (5/5): LOVE LOVE LOVE this lamb. Probably the best I have ever had in sf. It's not gamy, super tender and juicy and flavorful. Highly recommend.
author: Clare L.

description:
Probably closer to a 3.5 star review but to deserve 4* I would want to come back.  There was nothing wrong with La Ciccia but perhaps my expectations were too high, or maybe we ordered poorly since having three tomato sauce based dishes became a little tiring.

We started with the baby octopus stew -- the octopus was tender but didn't have much flavor.  The stew had nice concentration of flavors but was heavy on the tomato paste.   Nice light touch of spice.  3.5/5

I ordered the Malloreddus a sa Campidanese, which is mealworm-shaped seminola pasta in a pork ragu sauce.  The sauce tasted like a weaker version of the octopus stew but with tender chunks of ground pork.  3.5/5

The husband ordered one of the daily specials:   Fettuccine with crab and sea bass.  Again a tomato based sauce but lighter and sweeter from the seafood.  4/5

For dessert we had the gelato:  a trio of one small scoop each of Marsala raisin (hubs thought it reminded him of rum raisin ice cream), chocolate pistachio and goat cheese with figs.   Interesting flavors -- I didn't enjoy them all but appreciated the uniqueness.  4/5

Service was cordial with a strong wine selection.  Prices for the pastas were a little high for how simple they were; not as pricey as SPQR but not as tasty either.
author: Alice C.

description: They did it again! Get the saffron seafood stew special (not the one on the menu), the special flat bread, and the burrata. The starters actually outshined the entrees for us. We got the squid ink seafood dish, the semolina gnochetti, bronzino, and lamb entrees. The best one was the lamb for sure, we weren't super pumped about the pastas this time around.
author: Shabnam E.

description:
Went to La Ciccia last night (Tuesday). Bonus points for having a Bernal/South Mission pad is being able to have dinner at popular places without the wait :P I called in around 5PM and was able to get a reservation for 8:45PM (they also had other openings on OpenTable but it's easier to just call). 
Throughout the night, the restaurant was 95% full with no wait at the door. You'd probably score a walk-in as well. 

We unknowingly ordered two pasta dishes from the First Course section of the menu, thinking one would be protein and one would be pasta/carbs. They ended up both being pastas but we finished both down to the last drop of the sauces.

Pasta #1 (Squid Ink) 5 stars
Pasta #2 (Sea Urchin) 4.5 stars
Gelato as dessert 5 stars and above **


My recollection of the dish name: 
Squid Ink Linguine 

Menu Title:  
Pasta Longa cun su Nieddu de Seppia (Fresh Linguine Seafood Sugo Lemon Zest Squid Ink) - $23

The menu names were a little hard haha. But this dish was a solid 5 stars. The most delicious squid ink pasta I've had. The fresh linguine hugs the sauce so well, and they were not stingy about the sauce either - we had a little bit of leftover to wipe down with the breads. The dish overall was savory but not too salty, rich but not overwhelming. The lemon zest brings sooo much to the plate, waking up my taste buds every time.
- note: complimentary bread was kind of bland though.
I'd definitely recommend this dish, and it's easily shareable!


My recollection of the dish name:
Big couscous like pasta with uni, pancetta and tuna heart

Menu Title:
Fregua cun Arrizzoni e Cori de Tonnu (Sardinian Fregula Sea Urchin Tomato Shaved Tuna Heart) - $21

OK. Saw "sea urchin". Saw "tuna". We were like yes we want this one. hahaha us noobs had no idea what the dish was, and we were a little intimidated to ask the waitress. Anyways.. thank goodness La Ciccia makes everything delicious cuz we fell in love at first bite. This dish was probably a 4.5/5 for us, since it got a little too rich at the end. If we weren't sharing, or if we had ordered any other dish, we wouldn't have been able to finish this.

What did it taste like? Imagine uni / sea urchin pasta, where the pasta are like small pillows of porous, light dough (it's called Fregua, a Sardinian specialty pasta). Creamy, rich, packed with umami flavors from the shaved tuna heart (like a stronger version of bonito). It was quite exotic but also resonated with some Japanese/eastern flavors as well. I highly recommend this if you like sea urchin pasta.

** Now.. onto dessert.
After hearing the flavors available, we opted for two scoops of gelato, and man, it was the best ice cream I've ever had in my life. That's a huge statement cuz I like ice cream, but no ice cream has ever made me stop and savor the moment for it. 

The goat cheese and fig gelato was such an amazing combo. Mild goat cheese aroma lingered between tiny icy bits, and small chunks of figs were soft and delicious. And the other flavor: marsala wine with rum raisins was absolutely wonderful. I can't explain enough how the alcohol was actually present in the gelato, and it was the perfect balance of lightly creamy / extremely cold, nitrogen-like ice cream. Every bite led to wide-eyed delight.

.. tl;dr don't skip out on the gelato. :D'

Total was about $55 before tax for two and we didn't order alcohol.
author: Maggie G.

description:
3.5 stars. 4 for service but 3 for food. Nina Y. and I decided to switch our weekly Sunday brunches to dinner and as such, we needed to curate a new list of restaurants to tackle. After a broad sweep of Yelp for the best places to eat Italian food, I came across La Ciccia (technically Sardinian) as one of the mostly highly rated spots.

We made a reservation, which I would highly recommend, just seeing how busy this place gets. I arrived a bit early, so I sat at the bar, where the bartender offered me a drink. When a table opened up, the hostess started me.

To be honest, one of the main reasons I picked this place was to try the whole squid appetizer, which had been frequently posted in photos on Yelp. Sooo disappointment #1 was the fact that this was not on the menu. I was heartbroken! Oh well. Instead, we started with the Calamari Salad, which had olives, celery, and radish. This was okay. Tastes fresh, but not exactly my type of salad.

Nina and I decided on two main entrées, the spaghetti with fish roe and fregula with sea urchin. I can see why this is a top place to eat seafood, but we weren't impressed by the flavors and textures of either dish. My favorite dish between the two was the fregula with sea urchin. Nina thought it was too salty, so I ended up eating most of it.

We were craving dessert this particular day, and I think if we had liked the food better, we would have stayed here, but we walked to Mitchell's instead. I'm appreciative of the wonderful service at La Ciccia, and I would be open to give this another try if someone suggested it, but I wasn't too into the food the first time.
author: Stefanie C.

description: Excellent dinner this past Saturday with my family and we were all impressed with the unique Sardinia menu. We shared two starters - the grilled baby squid, baby spicy octopus stew and shared an order of the Sardinian flatbread - and they were all excellent. We then shared two pastas - the squid ink spaghetti and the spaghetti with spicy salt cured fish roe and both were sublime ! Seriously top notch. We then split two entrees - the seared lamb tenderloin (spectacular) and the pan roasted pork loin pecorino and saffron salsa (good not great). We ended with an assortment of three home made gelato and they were yummy. Our waiter helped us pick a pretty solid Italian red which paired nicely with this great dinner. I think we found our new go to Italian restaurant in SF. Grazie Massimiliano and Lorella !  Nicely done and we plan to start being regulars. We'll be back !!!
author: alan c.

description: Note to self: Amazing calamari, roasted shrimp, and squid ink pasta. Mediocre flat bread.
author: Gokhan T.

description: If your looking to have a great meal a one of the top five Italian/Sardinia restaurants in the USA this is the place.  Does not matter what you order it will blow you away.  The wine list in 180 bottles strong and don't forget the desert.  Great food, service and atmosphere.  Parking a bit difficult so UBER/Lift there.  Yes will take some time to get a reservation on weekends but weekdays are not to bad but worth the effort.  We will be back soon.
author: David B.

description: Truthfully, the best Italian food I have ever had! When I walked in I was immediately welcomed! Don't know if she was he manager but the lady at the front was so sweet and accommodating. She made us feel like we were at home. We didn't have a reservation but she happened to get us a table in 15 mins! What's crazy is that the place closed at 10 but they still took people in until 11. The food was absolutely amazing. Just to start we got the calamari and it was the best grilled calamari we have ever had, so fresh! We ordered two pastas and the prawns as well! Every time you took a bite of the pasta you could taste every flavor! The pasta was made fresh and had the perfect texture. The prawns were large and had a large amount of meat so make sure to get them. The waiters and waitresses were also so amazing. Great customer service and food! When I come back to visit SF, I will be sure to stop by again.
author: Rod D.

description: Came here about a week ago with my girlfriend to celebrate her birthday, I really don't have to tell you how amazing the food was, and service was wondering as well, had the prawn, braised octopus, and the highlight of the night was the special of the day, swordfish. The texture of the fish was amazing. Would definitely go back again
author: John W.

description:
The good: excellent service, very homey Italian atmosphere. It's also hard to find a restaurant that specializes in Sardinia. It's won many awards. Wine is excellent. 

The bad: being vegetarian I had very limited options. I had their vegetarian pasta which flavors did not pop and not did it taste fresh. I was also very disappointed by the cauliflower stir fry (quite oily, and flavorless). The cheese platter was slightly better. I wish the food quality was fresher and had real vegetarian options. Perhaps this place is better for pescatarians. I also felt a little out of place as the patrons tended to be much older, with one guy wearing a tuxedo.
author: Christine P.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants!  It's no wonder my Italian friends raved about how authentic this Sardinian restaurant is relative to the chains in North Beach.  Everything is cooked perfectly tender and juicy.  Start off with the fresh burrata salad and calamaria.  My favorite pastas are the fregula sea urchin tomato shaved tuna heart and seafood linguine with squid ink.  Try their fish because it's always got a crispy skin even though everything else is moist, smooth and drooling with flavor.

I could eat their bread all day even if it's not warm.  It has a crust with a soft center that makes it great to soak up the sauces from your bowls.  

However, save room for any of their desserts.  Whether it's the refreshing ricotta with saffron cake topped with toasted almonds, trio of gelatos (e.g., black currant, wine and raisins), or abbamele (aka chilled mouse + flan), you're bound to end on a sweet note.

Service is impeccable.  I never had to ask for refills and the wait staff are friendly, helpful, and fast when it comes to service.  Best of all, a meal for six is less than I'd normally pay for myself at any Michelin star restaurant and just as good if not better in terms of execution and service.

This place is cozy and small, so book your table in advance.  Parking can be challenging, but it's worth it =D
author: Jenny L.

description:
Costumer service is terrible. We walked in at opening without a reservation. At least 5 tables were open and we were told we had to eat the bar. Throughout our dinner at the bar, at least 3 or more tables remained consistently open. 

The host did not smile once nor did the bar tender who barely made eye contact. 

My meal the spaghetti cun cabefrori e bottariga was subpar and lacked flavor. You can buy better bread at Safeway. 

The fregua cun Su neiddu de seppia was very flavorful with a lemon zest taste. 

Would not go again. Too many good places with friendly faces in SF. 

Not to mention the host at the end of the meal yelled at us saying we "have no class". The only reason they get two stars is because the meal was then compensated by the owner.
author: Kindra W.

description:
La Ciccia is such a special spot in San Francisco. It's small, cozy, intimate, and unassuming, and until you look at the menu, it's hard to believe that behind the thick fabric curtain guarding the entrance, friendly waiters are serving up plates of pasta topped with shaved tuna heart.

For appetizers, my table of 3 shared the seasonal burrata salad and spicy baby octopus stew. My experience with appetizers is why La Ciccia doesn't get 5 stars from me. The burrata texture felt strangely gritty and unfamiliar. The spicy baby octopus stew was pretty good, though I didn't find it as phenomenal as our waiter had suggested it should be.

But beyond appetizers, everything was delicious! We ravaged the pasta menu, choosing all but the pork pasta (and that was only because my two friends are essentially pescatarians). The uni pasta with shaved tuna heart was creamy and flavorful. I'm still not sure I can tell you what tuna heart tastes like, but the overall dish was great (though maybe a lot to handle). The spaghetti with fish roe was INCREDIBLE. The sauce was lightly spicy, incredibly delicious, and very memorable. The spaghetti was also cooked perfectly. The lemon squid ink pasta was tasty as well. The lemon worked well with the squid ink, and the pasta, fregula, was like nothing I had seen before (it was cut so small that I initially thought it was a grain).

We were so full that we were ready to pass on dessert, but our waiter had told us the honey/almond/ricotta/saffron cake is the one thing on the menu he never skips, so acknowledging that it had been so difficult to score a reservation, we decided to treat ourselves, and I'm so glad we made the right choice. It's something of an elegantly spiced and flavored custard/cake lovechild. I was too full to order anything else, but I can see this dessert working so perfectly with a hot cup of tea.

Last note: Make a reservation well in advance. My friends and I had to make our reservation over a month in advance to book a reasonable meal time.
author: Kelly R.

description: Holy uni pasta. My favorite restaurant besides French Landry and Nobu. Yes that good. Simple, high quality and passionate.
author: Tammy L.

description:
Delightful place for classic Italian/Sardinian food. Place is a bit old school and traditional in that they ask you to please keep phones away and not take photos inside the restaurant.

We ordered the fish of the day and the semolina gnochetti. The fish was good, not spectacular, but the gnochetti was incredible. Although the bread is complimentary, olive oil is not and they charge for it. Definitely leave room for dessert, they have some classics.

Parking is amenable in the area, definitely make a reservation!
author: Tim X.

description:
We dined on a Saturday night with a reservation at 8:30 pm. We called and told them that we would be late by ~10 minutes because of traffic, and they were very accommodating of this.

We had their pasta with fish roe and their market fish of the day on chard. I've never enjoyed chard as much as I did here. The pasta and the fish although cooked to perfection could have  used a little more flavors. 

The ambiance was great. Although tables are very close to each other, that didn't really bother us. The restaurant is among residential buildings so it can be easy to miss on a dark night. 

Special shout out to the  head waitress - she was very gracious and had a large warm smile the entire time.
author: Sharanya A.

description:
Love this humbly-priced, exquisite family run spot. I've traveled extensively in Italy over the past 20 years, and La Ciccia is the closest experience I've had to the restaurants over there. Unpretentious, inventive and authentic, you don't have to even ask what's good--everything is. Sardinian food is amazing when done right, especially if you like creative, traditional interpretations of excellent seafood.

My only problem is the wine list is so stellar, I can't pick just one bottle. Their knowledgable somm/owner patiently describes the dozen I'm lucky to narrow down to.

TIP: book a resie well in advance, this place is popular. If you arrive early, check out their sister spot La Nebbia (across the street) for a quick glass of great wine.

PS  I can't help but comment on the recent review from Kindra W...really, you gave two stars for a dinner that was graciously comped which otherwise you would have slammed with the lowest rating possible? I've been coming to this place since it opened, and have had the completely opposite experience every time. 

Maybe I'm wrong--but so too would be Zagat (who proclaims this "Sardinan wonder" "well worth getting to"), the SF Chronicle (Bay Area's Top 100 Restaurants), Trip Advisor (with a perfect five stars) and every other notable publication to step foot inside--but I think the service is among the best. Zagat gives the food 4.8 out of 5.0 (see photo), on par with the best chefs in the world.

Perhaps you put off an unfriendly vibe when unable to have one of the tables that were surely reserved at 7:30 on a Saturday? Let's hope you're not another bully Yelper venting their self-perpetuated experience at the cost of a treasured eatery's reputation.

No loss, a shorter wait to get in for the rest of us!
author: A N.

description: I know it's practically blasphemy to criticize La Ciccia, but here goes. My wife and I went there yesterday evening for our anniversary dinner, and the service was terrible. First of all, the waiter didn't bring our wine until we had already finished our appetizers. When I pointed this out to him, he "apologized" in a huffy manner. We ordered the squid appetizer and a couple of pasta dishes. Instead of asking us whether we wanted the pasta dishes brought simultaneously or in sequence, they simply decided on the latter. Ok fine, except that there was a 15-minute wait between when they cleared the first dish and brought the second. And then the vegetable side dish we ordered arrived after the second pasta dish. It was described as kale with anchovies but it clearly wasn't kale--chard, maybe. The food was fine--not outstanding, which it would have had to be to make up for such inattentive and frankly unfriendly service.
author: Richard H.

description: Our cousins who live in SF have been wanting to go here for a long time, so we joined them recently and found La Ciccia to be a very nice, tasty and comfy experience. It gets a bit loud at dinner time and the tables are situated fairly close together, but their creative menu more than makes up for those relatively minor issues.  Don't expect a huge number of choices here, but there is definitely something for everyone and the service is great as well.  Don't expect any bargains, but that's not what makes this restaurant so popular.  It's definitely a cul8nary experience and they also have a nice l8st of Italian wines.  Delizioso!
author: Rick B.

description:
A cute small restaurant in Noe Valley. The service was good but I can not say the same for the food. There are plenty of excellent Italian restaurants in SF.  I would give it a 3 1/2 stars if I could. 

I ordered the baby octopus in a spicy tomato sauce. The sauce was good but octopus had a weird texture. The burrata arugula salad was good but how can you go wrong with this dish. The pasta with uni and grated tuna was too creamy and bland. The white fish of the day was ok. Overall, all the savory dishes were par. The herb panna cotta for dessert was good but it wasn't smooth, it was actually very grainy.
author: Ann S.

description:
San Francisco is a small city - 7 miles x 7 miles to be exact. Tiny in comparison to where I hang my hat (now), Los Angeles. 

Everything is close in S.F. and takes no time to get to where you want to go. Then why (I asked myself) does it always feel like a trek to drive to La Ciccia? No matter, as the drive is definitely worth it.

La Ciccia's intimate farmhouse setting in the Noe Valley section of S.F. is the epicenter for some of the best Sardinian food you'll get anywhere except maybe Sardinia!  With a home made taste and feel, the dishes served here are as representative of that small island paradise off the coast of Italy as you'll ever get.

Excellent pastas, great appetizers and a short but sweet main course selection are added to everyday with incredible specials. Pay attention and listen to these specials as you will probably end up with one.

Their wine list is eclectic and really good.

Resys are tough to get, so plan ahead and be flexible - it's worth that time and energy believe me!
author: Sidney Z.

description: Fantastic food, very friendly atmosphere, professional service and an excellent wine list. All that we tried was delicious, and the time spent here. I hope to return soon!
author: Alden S.

description: Little octopi were amazingly tender but stew almost seemed canned. The service was nice, parking easy, and prices are quite reasonable.
author: Asa H.

description: My husband and I had a date in this place since his restaurant friends highly recommend the food. We had the burrata with anchovies and arugula salad - huge fan of burrata and truffle oil, so this was a good start! We shared the spicy baby octopus stew - a little too spicy for me but was delicious nonetheless. For pasta we ordered the bottarga and fregola with seafood - loved this! I've never had fregola, but after trying it tonight I'm definitely a fan. Ended with semifredo and ricotta cake with almonds I believe. Excellent selection of wine as well! Would definitely come back. We got complimentary desserts too! Grazie!
author: Marielle D.

description: Came here for dinner last weekend. We thought it was just a quiet night but when you walked in you could tell this place was the place to be. It was packed. We were greeted by warm delicious smells and happy conversation. We didn't have a reservation yet they managed to sneak us in. We sat down right away. The waitstaff was curteous and professional. We had shared the burrata to start. The cheese was so tender with such flavorful tomatoes my mind was blown. We then shared the lamb entree. The meat was so perfectly cooked medium rare and so soft and flavorful. I am not a big meat eater. This was so good I couldn't help myself. We finished with the panna cotta which was light and just the right amount of sweet. I highly recommend this place!
author: Anne S.

description:
No. Resist. Don't be lured by the 4.5 stars coming from 900+ reviews. That's how my dinner companion got suckered and we ended up here.

They're busy and have high praises, giving false hope.

Seafood stew appetizer was ok - broth was mild which needed a heavy pinch of salt. Seafood was cooked perfect tho - soft, tender octopus which is oftentimes overdone but nope, not here. The pasta dishes fell short, particularly the one w/ uni. My bottarga was ok but not for $23 sans meat. Pasta noodles needed another minute or so. I did appreciate the fact that it wasn't overly salty. Bottarga did carry a heavy fishy taste. If it wasn't expressed on the menu that this had uni, you'd never guess. Also sans meat and around the same price, this was incredibly disappointing considering we had a super delicious uni pasta last weekend. The uni was blended in to the red sauce hence aside from not being visible, it was overpowered by the tartness of the red sauce. Round little tapioca-like balls as the pasta of choice. It was an interesting mouth feel but did not go w/ it. Perhaps a bucatini would've been better. Still can't save it though. Well, maybe cheese but it doesn't appear that they give you any. There was also a lack of butter and/or balsamic vinegar for the bread.

1 app, 2 pastas and 1 glass of wine plus tip will run you a hair shy of $100.
author: Julie L.

description: No complaints! Your meal will be delicious. The only reason it's is not a 5 is simply because it doesn't fit my ideal vibe. It is a very "serious" feeling restaraunt. Not a place to walk in and grab food. It is a proper Italian restaraunt. Kind of intimidatingly quiet but the food is bomb. As I write this I've decided to change my vote to 5. Just be aware that it is a "serious" restaraunt. They did everything perfectly it is simply a little too intense for me. I prefer a more laid back style but they deserve 5 stars. They were attentive and kind and the food was perfect. No exactly my style but if you want an amazing Italian meal they provide it. The food was perfect. Some of the best pasta I've had and the best lamb I've ever had. The side component to the lamb was weak but honestly I didn't care. Everything was beautifully executed
author: Alex R.

description: Well what can you say about a restaurant that offers such unique food that is also so delicious and beautifully prepared and presented.  The aroma of fresh olive oil hits your nostrils as you walk in the door calling your taste buds to attention. The wine list was extensive and even though we didn't have a bottle, the selection of wines by the glass was excellent.  We shared everything and were both full and happy at the end of our meal.  We tried the special flatbread, anchovies with oranges and arugula, along with the soup and amazing prawns.  We topped it off with three little scoops of gelato: marsala/raisin,  chocolate hazelnut,  and goat cheese fig. Who'd of thought goat cheese could make such an amazing gelato. It was a devine dinner and a place we would heartily recommend.
author: Tina G.

description:
The Bottariga pasta was EXCELLENT! Will definitely go back for that.

We ordered the Seafood Lemon Zest Squid ink - it was good but the pasta wasn't a linguini...

Nice, cozy place. Good wine!
author: Cay A.

description:
I really really really wanted to like this place. Very disappointed for the price.

For two people it was around a Benjamin; the service was a bit abrupt and not the most friendly.

So besides that everyone was fairly attentive and nice though the place is very small and cramped beyond belief even for San Francisco... Might be a fire hazard in the making.

Food was okay. Nothing spectacular except for the baby Octopus soup but it made me cringe chewing on their delicious little heads and disembodied arms. Came out nice and piping hot and was super tasty. Went well with the fried crunchy bread.

That was about it ; the main course of lamb was undercooked and disgustingly chewy. The dish was a letdown and the sides were nothing to write home about. I guess this is a product of their fame that they can either let people down or maybe people like me expect too much for a well known restaurant to keep up their standards and innovative taste.. Rather finally dining at La Ciccia was like when my parents told me I was going to Disneyland only to take me to a playground.

At their prices I would not make the time or waste my time getting a reservation here or coming back. Pomelo around the corner seems like a better choice.
author: David T.

description: Love this place. The baby octopus stew, Sardinian fregula with sea urchin, and pani guttiau (flatbread), are incredible Sardinian dishes that are unique and not to be missed. My only regret is that the menu doesn't change. So, I don't want to go more than once a year. But, I savor every delicious morsel and love the excellent wine list every time I go.
author: Valerie Z.

description:
This is my second time coming back to the restaurant and liked the dishes that I had better this time around. Excited to move to live in an area that is pretty close to this restaurant.

Prupisceddu in Umidu cun Tomatiga (Baby Octopus stew in a spicy Tomato Sauce) - this was the best dish that I had at Ciccia so far. Very tender octopus, the spiciness in the tomato sauce is just right to enhance the tomato flavor. Sadegna has some of the best tomatoes I have ever had so it's not surprising that they know how to get the tomato sauce right at La Ciccia.

Flatbread - always solid.

Malloreddus a sa Campidanese (Gnochetti  with Pork Ragu and salty Pecorino) - quite good. The Gnochetti is cooked el dente, just right, and even though the sauce is a bit more than what italians would serve in Italy, I like this version since it gives more flavors to the dish

lamb shank - this reminded me of the middle eastern or turkish/lebanese version of lamb shank - it was more of a tomato based version. Pretty good but not exceptional. I still like the middle eastern version better.

Cute cozy place. Not large and quite popular (the italian wine menu is probably one of the most extensive in SF.) So at least reserve 2 weeks ahead or try your luck last minute on opentable (when others cancel). We scored one last minute on the saturday at 8pm and it was quite lucky.
author: Rebecca C.

description: A charming restaurant specializing in wonderful Sardinian cuisine. Everything was so delicious here, even just simple mozzarella cheese and arugula. Ordered the calamari salad, anchovies, spaghetti with salt cured fish roe, and Truta de Arrescottu, all of which were perfectly done.
author: Dex Y.

description:
Really excellent!!  Very thoughtful food, complex and balanced.  What a treat!  Met the chef.  Recommend a meal here very highly.  
Service could use a bit of polish, but still first rate across the board. 
Can't wait till next time.  
Thank you chef!!!!
author: David M.

description: A fabulous, classic and classy Italian restaurant that serves delicious entrees and has a ravishing wine list. The space inside is small but they make the most of it.
author: Thalia G.

description:
I had this place bookmarked because it looked like this great pasta place. Don't get me wrong, it wasn't bad, but it wasn't great either. I had wanted much more from my experience here. 

First, it's a small place. From the outside it looks decent sized, but there isn't much space to once inside to walk around with comfort. I know that part of a great restaurant is the constant switching of dishes, but there should be some great constants. 

We had seen this great calamari appetizer dish but when we got there, they didn't have any. Instead we did get calamari, just in salad form with some celery. The dish we saw was beautiful with all the calamari whole and stuffed with something. Instead our dish, which was still nice, had it all chopped up. There was still quite a bit of calamari, but not as beautiful as the one we had seen online. 

For pastas we decided on the spaghetti and the sea urchin pasta. The last spaghetti I had was from Delfina and this one definitely didn't beat it. It was alright, but nothing as good as Delfina's. The sea urchin pasta was good, but my friend just couldn't taste the sea urchin. I personally think it's this salty briny goodness, but I just couldn't have a huge whole plate of it. 

Service was decent but nothing to write home about. Good, but not amazing. We did get recommended great glasses a wine. Stef C. got a red and I got a white. Both great! 

Pro tip: get a reservation and try the pastas.
author: Nina Y.

description:
It wasn't easy to get a reservation here and I finally know why! Because this place is amazing! It almost felt like I was in a mom and pop place in Italy. They do take walk-ins, but you have to be there before they open. I had reservations at 5:30pm on a Thursday and saw many people waiting outside the restaurant before they opened at 5:30pm.

Food/drinks- that bottarga spaghetti: not to be messed with, soon amazzing, the flavor is exquisite and the house-made pasta is cooked perfectly al dente. Sea urchin fettuccine: creamy and rich, but interesting and uni flavor is not lacking, recommend to share; octopus stew: flavorful and you could tell that it's been cooked very stew like to soak in all the flavors; jamon: one of the specials that day and solo glad we ordered it, it was so good, melted in my mouth and tasted better than the jamon I had in la boqueria in Barcelona! Vegetables of the day was broccoli/chard in garlic chili oil. Nougat semifreddo- tasty and very nougat-y. Wine and beer were tasty.

Ambience/Decor- homey and a bit dimly lit, but comfortable. Small cozy space with counter seating also available. 

Staff/service- warm and friendly. The lady owner greets you when you enter and check-in. Waitstaff are attentive and our order was taken accurately. The waiter very skillfully split our spaghetti for us at the table to make room for other dishes. 

Food was so delicious and I was happy that I was able to take photos of their food secretly because they ask that you don't use your phone, camera, or computer at the table. Perhaps they just mean to discourage patrons to not do work while having a good meal. Highly recommended for delicious, authentic Sardinian/Italian food!! Will surely be back!
author: Iris H.

description: Great Italian restaurant that serves delicious entrees and has a ravishing wine list. Pleasant staff. Everyone was friendly and attentive.
author: Alayana W.

description: The food was delicious, sea urchin and squid ink were my wife and my favorite. Service was well managed and owners are up and about engaging and working the floor
author: Boris T.

description:
