I really enjoyed the service but the food was okay. Maybe I didn't ordered the best thing on the menu but I was a little disappointed on the squid ink pasta. Although the portions were pretty good and filling. 

Things I ordered:
- Calamareddusu Arrustiusu (Roasted Monterey Calamari Basil Oil)   
- Prupisceddu in Umidu cun Tomatiga (Baby Octopus stew in a spicy Tomato Sauce)  really good
- Pasta Longa cun su Nieddu de Seppia (Fresh Linguine Seafood Sugo Lemon Zest Squid Ink) 

The server did mentioned these two items that were good but we were just way too full to order more:

- Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga (Fresh Spaghetti Spicy Garlic Oil Salt Cured Fish Roe) 
- Malloreddus a sa Campidanese (Senatore Capelli Gnochetti Pork Bagna Pecorino Sardo)  
- Pezza de Angioni a sa Saba (Seared Lamb Tenderloin Tagliata drizzled with Saba)
author: Jenn L.

description:
To be truthful, I'd heard such great things maybe my expectations were a little _too_ high. Everything was fine really, but nothing extraordinary like I had imagined based on the hype. 

Solid renditions of rustic Sardinian cuisine (hope you like your pasta very al dente), fine service - although a little pushy when it comes to recommendations, a little snug as far as seating and comfort, especially with the noise and crowds. One of those experiences to where you're like "did I order the wrong things? Maybe it was an off night?" Except I'd since heard similar feelings from others who'd been there. La Ciccia is just... fine.
author: J M.

description: A perfect place for a date that likes to be impressed. Nice atmosphere and comfortable setting also made the night perfect. One of the pasta dishes we tried was very tasty!
author: Jazlyn F.

description: This is a long overdue review. My first time at La Ciccia was two years ago. The food, service and ambiance were lovely and I thoroughly enjoyed it. We returned in May of this year for my husband's birthday and love it even more. Wonderful wine selection, freshly and deliciously prepared food, excellent service. Check them out if you haven't already.
author: Anne L.

description:
Had dinner here and got seated a little after our reservation time, but given how small the place is, I figure it is pretty hard to predict exactly when people are going to finish eating.  We had two appetizers, plus I had a pasta and a meat for dinner.

First, the charred squid appetizer...superb.  Tons of herbs and oil...just a great flavor and very fresh.  Second, the spicy tomato octopus stew...excellent.  A little spice and no fishiness at all.  I had the special pasta for the day, which was some type of cavatelli looking pasting with various meats and olives...man was that good.  Perfectly cooked and tons of meat and flavor.  For the second dish, I had the pork, which was actually just ok.  I did not care for the creamy sauce and some of the flavors were not my favorite.  It was not terrible but I did not love it.  For dessert, the special panna cotta which was excellent as well.  Great flavor, texture, just perfect.

Overall, the portions were a healthy size for the price, and the food was fresh and flavorful.  My only real complaint was that I could have used more bread, especially with the tomato stew, which was screaming for bread.  On balance though, the place was well priced for great food, and the portions were good size, and the food was almost all uniformly excellent.
author: A. L.

description: Just didn't work out this time. Prices are way up, check Yelp reviews from just a few years back, but more importantly, quality is shockingly down. Not only is this place not really Sardinian, sure there are some seafood dishes, but it just isn't good anymore, at any price. My octopus stew was watery and overcooked, and they now are using small octopus instead of the large tender ones they used to use. It was a chore just to eat and we didn't even finish.  Their fish was decent, it's not too hard to cook a white fish, but it was simply on top of some chard. Seemed like a lot for $40. The Sardinian cake desert was terrible. It tasted like it was made three days before and had been sitting in the refrigerator. There's no way they would have served this to their own house guests. Corkage was a ridiculous $35. Service was good, otherwise I'd one-star it. It's really too bad because I used to love this place, but I guess it's a victim of the time, like Tony Wheeler once said, "Good places go bad, bad places go bankrupt, nothing stays the same"
author: Brian J.

description: Best Italian food we have had in the city. Hard to get a reservation but completely worth it. The owner is a complete sweetheart.
author: Oona Q.

description:
Hands down one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. 

I've been to La Ciccia twice -- once on a date night and once with my work bestie when we were both celebrating our promotions. The vibe was perfect for both occasions, as the service is personalized, the ambiance is rustic, charming and intimate, and the food is simply to die for.  

The owners are from Sardinia (an island off the coast of Italy) and specialize in traditional Sardinian cuisine, which is in my opinion even more delicious than traditional Italian. I've never felt so much homemade love and authenticity in a restaurant before. Absolutely every single thing on the menu is simply fantastic but I recommend sticking to the classics. 

The must orders are: 
1) Fresh Spaghetti Spicy Garlic Oil Salt Cured Fish Roe. Absolutely impeccable, creamy without being overly rich, and beyond flavorful from the Fish Roe. 
2) Fresh Linguine Seafood Sugo Lemon Zest Squid Ink. The perfect blend of savory dish with a tinge of sweetness. The seafood sugo is simply oozing with a magnetic seafood flavor. 
3) Baby Octopus stew in a spicy Tomato Sauce. I'll preface this by saying I don't like octopus and I almost never order it. However, my coworker convinced me to order it and I have to admit that it was one of the highlights of our dinner! The octopus meat is so tender, juicy and covered in such a hearty and homey tomato stew. 

In addition, definitely check out their daily specials -- we ordered several additional pastas and a lamb dish from there and loved them as well! 

Our waitresses from both nights were amazing and picked out the perfect wine pairings for what we ordered. We had some Sardinian wine as well as some traditional Italian favorites and were in love with how well they paired with the appetizers and entrees. 

So when you're craving an intimate dinner with a close friend or family, or are seeking the perfect date night spot in Noe Valley, look no further than La Ciccia. 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description: La Ciccia is hands down the best Italian restaurant in the City. The owners and their staff absolutely love what they do -- making people happy with high quality, delicious food. This is a true neighborhood gem, well worth booking a month in advance and traveling to from all parts of the Bay Area!
author: Munia P.

description: Great seafood and also the lamb was made to perfection. The restaurant is extremely small and crowded, and you have to get a reservation.
author: Zeke M.

description:
We went by here one evening for dinner. Their reservation system was not working so we had to call and still had to wait for three weeks before getting a table for 5:45 p.m. The restaurant is small so I understood the difficulty in getting a reservation.
Once seated, we found that our table was wobbly. A nice worker tried to balance it without success so they moved an adjoining table into our space. It was also wobbly but we decided to live with it.
We decided to split a bowl of the baby octopus soup and it was delicious. The broth was excellent and the octopus was just a little overcooked.
For the main course, my partner had the prawns in a rich, tomato broth.  The prawns were huge so my partner was very happy, although he wished the prawns had been shelled.
I had the special which was fusili cooked with proscuitto and other tasty bits of meat and fish. It was perfect, particularly with a sprinkling of Parmesan cheese on top.
We were too full for any dessert.
I recommend this restaurant very highly for the food.  But be prepared for a wait to get a table and make sure your table is perfectly balanced.
author: Philip C.

description:
My husband and I came here on a recommendation and had high hopes for a mid week date night. Unfortunately- dinner didn't go as hoped.

It started off well - we shared the baby octopus on the waiters recommendation and the Sardinia macaroni. Both were good and we were enjoying our meal.

For my entree, I ordered their suckling pig special with tomato sauce. What I got was a bowl of fatty stew. Seriously- I was picking out huge pieces of fat and putting them on the side of my bowl. As the waiter had recommended this dish - I told him I wasn't pleased and he offered to take it off the bill. I maybe had 3 bites. Ok - no harm, no foul.

Until the bill came and we were charged for the dish. Thinking it must be a mistake, we reminded him that he'd said he'd remove the $30 charge. He then told us that the chef refused to take it off the bill and said he must charge us and there was nothing he could do. The chefs wife is the hostess and upon leaving she said she had to "side with her husband" and the waiter was out of place trying to make it right.

Needless to say we won't be returning. If you decide to eat here, make sure you order well.
author: Danielle A.

description: Love the Sardinian source, spicy tomato flavor . Love the wine paring as well. The seafood dishes are my favorite, though the pasta remind me of true Italy pasta as well. Highly recommended.
author: Blue B.

description: Perhaps this restaurant is slipping.  I tasted three entrees on a evening there; none were outstanding and one was really to send back: large prawns, over-baked in their split shells, that literally had to be scraped out of the shell.  Seafood linguine in squid ink was fairly tasty, but very light on the seafood.  Would not go back.
author: David H.

description:
Fantastic! 

I had the Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga (which is one of the dishes that is prominently displayed on their website), the fish, and the panna cotta (not on the regular menu). All three were beyond outstanding. But to make things even better, the owner suggested a Sardinian wine that paired beautifully (S'Elegas Nuragus di Cagliari). The wine had so much fruit and a light honey sweetness. 

I can't recommend this place high enough. San Francisco is so lucky to have such authentic, elegant food run by owners and staff with such passion for their craft. Very well done!
author: Brad M.

description:
The two noodle dishes we had were unquestionably 5-starred, and on par with -- if not above -- what's on offer at Cotonga and Locanda. Other dishes were hit or miss.

We started with the Zupetta de Pisci and octopus stew. The octopus stew was solid and hearty, and very generous in its portions of tenderized octopi. The Zupetta de Pisci (seafood soup), however, was nearly too fishy to finish drinking -- the seaweed / kelp was a regrettable inclusion, since it was far below par for even budget miso soup and stank up the whole bowl.

We had two pasta noodle dishes -- linguini with squid ink and lemon zest, and daily special linguini with boar ragu. The squid ink pasta was unquestionably the star of the night, so perfectly seasoned and toothsome to chew. The boar ragu was excellent as well and very generous with the meat.

Service was timely, warm and knowledgeable.
author: Ken H.

description:
Been to La Ciccia for two times already. It's extremely hard to get a reservation on weekends unless you pick some unfavorable time - 9:45pm in my case for both experiences. But I wouldn't mind to do a 3rd time with such time slot again because this place is just so good!

For my latest experience, my friend and I actually arrived 20 mins early but a table was saved for us already :) Seated promptly and picked a bottle of wine (huge wine list selection by the way). This place seats around 30 people, it's dim and not noisy, pretty suitable for a romantic date.

La Ciccia is generally recognized as an Italian restaurant but officially they serve Sardinian food - which means seafood-focus, and you would instantly be able to tell from their menu. The staff was very attentive, and our server did a very nice job in introducing us his recommendations.

#Prupisceddu in Umidu cun Tomatiga (Octopus stew): A.
First of all, this dish is spicy. However, for people that can't eat spicy I still highly recommend you to try this dish, because it's so good that you will just keep eating! Very very rich tomato-based stew, a lot of small whole octopus - try it with the free bread that they serve, this appetizer will definitely turn on your appetite.

#Calamareddsu Arrustisu: A-.
This dish came with 6 pieces squid, I'm not sure about the cooking style but the main point here was the sauce (slightly oily) - kind of refreshing and unique at the same time. Squid was pretty fresh.

#Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga: A.
Simply put, this is a garlic + peperoncino salt + fish roe spaghetti. Sounds like a simple spaghetti but once you have a first bite you will go nonstop. Strong garlic taste (not to a point that is bothering though), the salt definitely brought slight chilly taste to the dish, the combination was just very, very good.

#Pasta cun Arrizoni e Cori de Tonnu: A.
Very different from the spaghetti, this is an Uni-based pasta so the sauce was a lot more richer. Personally I am not a very big fan of Uni, but surprisingly I loved that Uni flavor - it didn't have that unique ocean-Uni smell/flavor, I felt like it was the texture of the sauce that Uni contributed the most. Plus this pasta was also slightly on the chilly side, the combination was just heavenly.

#Gellausu Mistusu: B+.
Three scoops of Gelato. One was cheese flavor, one was chocolate, and sorry can't remember the 3rd one. But I liked the chocolate one the best - it was actually very good. But the other two were meh.

#Truta de Arrescottu: B.
It was basically some kind of sponge cake? However the texture was very different from the ones I usually have..... had some weird feeling after eating it. The taste was not bad, I guess I just wasn't used to the texture.

Overall, I love this place very much because of all the main dishes. I don't mind repeating all these dishes again and again every week but there are quite a few more options on the menu that I haven't tried yet, I guess I will have to go back few more times!
author: Simon C.

description:
Highly recommended by my sister-in-law and her husband and given its popularity, I had high hopes for La Ciccia but left feeling underwhelmed. The two of us shared:

Tripe stew (appetizer special): extremely tender tripe cooked in a delicious, hearty, tangy tomato and pecorino cheese based sauce. While we've enjoyed better tripe elsewhere, that sauce was great - I would have been happy eating a bowl of that with pasta or bread!

Fettuccine in creamy tomato sauce with uni and tuna hearts: based on the components, we thought we would enjoy this dish; instead, it tasted unpleasantly disjointed and jarred. If you're craving uni-based pasta, check out SPQR instead for a great rendition!

Ravioli with veal and prosciutto ragu (pasta special): tasty and heavy, I enjoyed this dish but didn't find it particularly memorable. Which is a little sad, considering that you're paying $25 for ~4 raviolis.

Ricotta and saffron cake with honey and toasted almond: airy, moist, and not too sweet. We didn't care for this dessert.

Gelato: you're given a cute plate with tiny scoops of 4 different, tasty, interesting gelato flavors. We enjoyed the gelato, but thought the $9 price tag ridiculous.

The service seemed friendly but inconsistent. Our waiter would disappear for long periods of time as our water glasses sat empty, and our food came out painfully slow compared to the diners around us.
author: Steve L.

description:
The food is just ok, a little greasy, but the menu makes an effort to be interesting with regional offers. It's probably pricey for the quality tho. 

(sort the reviews by date and read the review right below to understand the kind of practices of this business)

A reservation had been a day earlier, we showed up on time, the place was pretty packed except for one table. I had dined there before and sort of remembered that one thing about this place is that they don't take space efficiency lightly. I have no doubt they would consider vertically stacking tables if their ceiling was higher.

So boom, we get in and my first observation is that the area we are at, near the window, is actually way more pleasant. The vibrant creativity of table arrangement in the main room undoubtedly found a bound here: geometry. It's two tables of two, period. The second thing is the lighting, much more pleasant there than in the main room.

We're about to make our order from nice table and BOSS shows up and asks if we could move to another table. It seemed nicely pulled off initially since we got cornered in like 5 seconds. BOSS talked to my date directly who perhaps, she thought, would be easier to deal with than I. Textbook case of leveraging the expectation that most people have a difficult relationship with the word 'no'. BOSS's handling of the situation is impressive at first. In fact, she knows full well we obviously don't want to go in the middle of the cave, but her targeting is perfect since in like 2 seconds, I'm basically having to chose between 'yes' and looking like an asshole to my date as well as engaging in a conflict with a person with access clearance to the kitchen where food I am going to eat will be prepared.

BOSS knows people generally fear conflict and we do in fact not event just accept, but attempt to pretend it's ok. It's just a bit awkward as something fishy is almost palpable. At this point, for some reason, BOSS decides to provide some arguments. It initially consisted in a confusing sequences of words making little sense, eventually snowballing in some kind of BS that even herself seemed to be embarrassed about.

To give you an idea, at this point we are in this area of 2 tables of 2, the couple next to us still has a significant amount of liquid in their bottle, but BOSS is telling us that she needs our space, that's why we have to move to table of 4 in the main room (cave). BOSS is now in a bad place, angered by the possibility that despite being dumb, we might be able to do the math about her space plan, and perhaps we might potentially feel that our intelligence is being insulted. BOSS knows that 4 people will eventually be pissed, either now and at the same time, if she comes clean by admitting the plan also includes kicking out the couple next to us, with a risk of a scene in the restaurant, or 2 now, and the 2 other later, but on their way home, it's easier.

The thing BOSS doesn't realize is that the picture has been crystal clear since the beginning. It's not like it didn't notice when FRIEND entered the restaurant, he's apparently an acquaintance given the way he greeted the staff. The place is basically a cave but nice area has a window that I am facing, and during BOSS's performance, I could see FRIEND and his buddies waiting outside, and I knew full well he was going to dine in nice area. BOSS was only making the whole thing more embarrassing that it needed to be.

And this is exactly what happened. Nice area was cleaned up for FRIEND and buddies, the two tables were sandwiched in one, group of 5 party started. Over the next hour, from the cave I could see STAFF and BOSS drop by the table to greet FRIEND. I noticed how increasingly louder it was getting, I would bet the tab ended up with many orders from the back side of the menu, which could be evidence of a second, more basic incentive for this very low class move.

Just a pathetic circus.
author: Ho N.

description: Delicious food, but the service could have been friendlier. Intimate, friendly atmosphere. A perfect place for a date that likes to be impressed.
author: Elizabeth R.

description: Checked out this place. They have quite an extensive nice wine selection. The place is small and cozy. Started with a special that was off the menu. Tripe in a tomato based sauce. It was excellent! The tripe was nice and tender. The sauce had a spicy kick to it which was nice. We then moved into the Prupisceddu in Umidu cun Tomatiga ( Baby octopus in spicy tomato sauce). The octopus was tender. Sauce wasn't spicy to me. Not a bad dish though. We then moved onto the Spaggittusu cun Ally Ollu e Bottariga ( Fresh spaghetti spicy garlic oil salt cured fish roe). For me this was a very nice dish. Interesting. The flavors of the roe and garlic went well together. We then had the Pisci de Mari Arristiu ( Market fish and Veggies) . The fish was a light white. Sautéed with veggies and cooked to perfection. And lastly dessert. Gellausu Mistusu ( gelati). I felt the gelati was more like ice cream. Very creamy. We had 3 flavors-goat cheese and fig- okay I did not like this one. It tastes like goat cheese. Just cold and in gelati form. Honestly goat cheese is my favorite, but I'm not a big fan of it in gelati form. The next was hazelnut and The last was Marsala wine and raisins. These 2 were not bad. Oh and I can't read , but the menu does state no cameras to be used at the table. I didn't see this until it was too late. I guess my eyes just go straight to the food :)
author: Angela M.

description:
"You can be skinny when you die. For now, enjoy life and eat pasta." That's what our server told us yesterday at dinner when one of my dining companions beamed that the food was so good he was getting so fat. Been here a few times now, and La Ciccia has never disappoints. The only restaurant I've experienced with such authentic Italian (and in this case Sardinian) feel is Angelini Osteria in Los Angeles. But La Ciccia takes it even one step further. They don't mess around, and you want to abide by their rules (cuz the food is so darn good). There's a fair warning at the top of the menu to not use your cell phone or computers. Apart from that, the hospitality is as warming as the plates of food served. Each time I come here, I see diners coming by and giving the owner (manager?) a hug -- regulars in the neighborhood, I presume. Last night, we had the anchovies, baby octopus stew, and grilled calamari for appetizers. If you are open to anchovies, I would highly recommend this dish. It's very bright flavors and not as fishy as you'd think. They plop a basket of bread and no butter or oil down on the table for you, and usually you wonder what it's for, until you see the baby octopus stew arrive. The tomato sauce of this stew is so flavorful -- spicy, tangy, delicious. I love grilled calamari, and this was perfectly sized squid, grilled and sauced with an olive oil-based sauce. I also had the arugula salad with burrata that was more butter than cheese (= sinfully delicious). My favorite dish here is the fresh spagetthi with bottarga -- cured fish roe. It's not as heavy as one would think, and like all their pasta, the spagetti is perfectly al dente. 

Come here if you want to have juicy, uninterrupted conversation over good wine (the list is HUGE) and unbelievable pasta.
author: Taya V.

description: After being to Sardinia many times, I know that this is authentic Sardinian restaurant. Great Italian wine selection.  This is the only place in the city that has bottarga.  Service is superb!   You feel like home.  I crave their food.  Strongly recommend!
author: Elena M.

description: My favorite Italian meal in San Francisco. Dishes are packed with flavor, and there is a great Italian wine list. Would highly recommend.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Unfortunately, we did not have reservations, but we were able to sit at the bar. What a treat we had in store for us... We had the pasta with spicy garlic and fish roe as an appetizer and it was really good along with the fresh baked sourdough slices of bread. It was truly al dente! I had a glass of white wine (a Pinot Bianca 2012) that was recommended and it did not disappoint. My main dish of seared prawns with a carrot dish with olives accompanying it was really tasty as well. Now my husband's lamb was uh-may-zing!!!! Seriously, I don't even like lamb and I was having entree envy, which I rarely have... The customer service was 5 stars. They were so accommodating and down to earth and just joyful to be around. I strongly recommend reservations so that you can eat there, but if you end up sitting at the bar, you won't be sad about it! This place is a great date night place!
author: Zandra P.

description:
I was blown away by everything about this place. 

I was able to walk in around 6:30pm on a dreary Tuesday and snag two seats at the bar without a reservation. 

Octopus Stew - perfectly cooked. 

Special - Sunday Sardines - fresh Monterey sardines with olive oil, garlic, parmesan cheese. Good but not great. 

Fusili with Sea Urchin - totally outstanding. Creamy, rich, with a nice saltiness from the tuna heart. The owner/chef again came out and talked with us. He was very proud of the fact that there was no cream or butter in the dish. The tuna heart is salt cured and imported from Sardinia. You can't find it in the US.
author: K R.

description:
Went to lLa Ciccia for a date night and overall had a great time. Highly recommended and I'd definitely go back.

AMBIANCE: 4.5* Simple, romantic setting. Very nice ambiance for a date. Good noise level where it is lively but you can easily talk.

SERVICE: 5* Top notch. Servers know the menu very well and can also recommend good wine off a very extensive wine list. No complaints here.

FOOD: 4* Authentic Sardinian food with super fresh ingredients. We had the following:

1. Octopus in spicy tomato sauce: awesome appetizer; highly recommended. Good portion size with several baby octopi and a sauce with a good kick. Definitely can be shared between 2-3 people.

2. Fish roe spaghetti: this is one of their specialties and is so simple yet amazingly flavorful. They make the pastas fresh from scratch and it was perfectly al dente. Must get dish.

3. Uni pasta: wasn't blown away by this one...very one-dimensional taste. A bit too creamy (though all the creaminess comes from the uni, not cream) so while it was good, I expected a bit more. Would order something else next time. Also the only pasta dish where they don't make the pasta fresh from scratch.

4. Semifreddo: I have a weakness for semifreddo so we ordered it right away. Good overall but nothing to write home about. Wouldn't order again.

I think overall this place probably deserves 5* but this time around didn't quite get there with a so-so dessert. Will definitely be back!
author: Farid V.

description:
La Ciccia is one of those places where I'd most likely sell my soul to eat here once a week for the rest of my life.   

Service: Service is phenomenal. The thing I appreciate a lot is that each staff member is extremely knowledgeable about their wine offerings. They treat you like family. La Ciccia IS my family.

Food: I highly recommend the roasted Monterey calamari, baby octopus stew, salted roe spaghetti and the sea urchin + tuna heart pasta. There -- I've provided you with the go-to items to order! 

The roasted Monterey calamari nails down the texture and the taste. I love the basil olive oil they put on top. It's light and flavorful. Definitely get it when it's on the menu. 

The baby octopus stew is tomato-based with a kick, so foodies with heartburn take note! If you haven't overloaded yourself with the bread, be sure to use it to finish off your stew. 

The salted roe spaghetti is the love of my life. Don't fret about the "spicy" garlic oil. It's hardly spicy and I'm very sensitive to spiciness. My spaghetti was cooked al dente (which I love), but for those who don't, it's something to keep in mind. This is a much lighter pasta. 

A heavier, yet equally delicious alternative is the sea urchin + tuna heart pasta. The sauce is created with tomato and sea urchin, while the pieces of tuna heart are garnished on top and mix into the sauce nicely. It's a more flavorful dish, so for those who like dishes that tickle the taste buds, don't miss out on the sea urchin + tuna heart pasta. Lately, I've had it with fettuccine, but they've used other types of pasta in the past. 

Affordability: With tip and feeling extremely full after ordering a good amount of food, I spend approximately $130 for 2 people. It's definitely not the cheapest joint, but I think it's absolutely worth it. 

Parking: A hassle between 5:30 pm to 8:00 pm. After 8:00 pm, it's much easier to find a spot in the area. 

Other Notes: You can easily get a 9:00 pm ish reservation a few days or a week in advance, but if you want something closer to 7:00 pm and on the weekend you'd better make your reservation 3-4 weeks in advance. 

Keywords: Sardinian, Romantic, Good service, Delicious, Seafood, Award-winning wine list

Justification for rating: The food. The wine. The experience.
author: Belyn L.

description:
Oh! yes! I really love this restaurant's La Cicia. especially for the foods that the serve. 
Excellent :)
author: Team M S.

description: I was really excited to try this place with all its great reviews. Not too many places have squid ink or uni pasta dishes. Finally got to try it and was disappointed. I don't know if the reviews over hyped it but it definitely wasn't to my expectations. The ink linguine was on the sour side and the sea urchin didn't have any sea urchin taste. If you haven't tried some of the dishes they have to offer, it's at least worth a try. However, if you had some of the dishes elsewhere and felt that it was really good then you'd probably be disappointed like me. Wait staff was nice and friendly but took forever to refill our water.
author: J L.

description:
Chef Massimo is a very friendly guy. Flavors are bold, and dishes are the real deal. Wait staff is friendly and prepared. Lorella follows the dining room attentively. 
You will find ingredients that are unique, very high quality, and real Italian. 
Cannot miss Bottarga di Muggine, SeaUrchin, tuna hearts, etc. 
We will be back for more.
author: Bruno S.

description:
Finally made it back here, (due to a friend raving about it.)

We were a party of 3, I made reservations several weeks prior, (this place is VERY busy, I highly recommend making reservations.).

The octopus salad was AMAZING. It seriously has me craving octopus again. 
(I was pretty over it, since it's always too chewy everywhere.)

The flatbread was good, but it's hard to go wrong with that. 
If you've never been here, don't expect what you think of as flatbread, this is more like a cracker.

We shared the; Senatore Capelli Gnochetti Pork Bagna Pecorino Sardo, Pan Roasted Pork Loin Pecorino and Saffron Salsa, and a pasta special that day. 
Everything was fantastic. Pasta and proteins were cooked perfectly. Really glad we all shared, since we got to try a good variety of dishes.
My only gripe about the food, it was VERY salty. I drank about 8 gallons of water in the hours after.

Service was ok, food took quite awhile to come and our server wasn't very attentive. 
I  was annoyed that when we were picking a wine, we asked to taste it, but when he brought a taste he only gave it to our friend and basically ignored us.

I'd definitely come back . This is the best pasta I've had in a long time. 
( I never order pasta out, it's usually mediocre, and I can make it better myself.)

*The menu changes often.*
author: Amanda G.

description: Pleasant ambiance...nice date restaurant. Good service because it's small and waitress was awesome. We ordered the specials and had a bottle of prosecco and it was nice! Can't take photos tho! Actually menu said not to use phones and even tho I forgot a couple times I kind of liked that rule! :)
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Last night we dined at La Ciccia. We had no reservations, but sat at the bar. Our appetizer was Zupetta de Pisci  which was a seafood stew with an abundance of mussels and calamari which was followed by Semolina Gnochetti Pork Bagna  and the Pan Roasted Pork Loin Pecorino and Saffron Salsa and a side dish of Brussel sprouts.  The food was rich with flavor and the freshness of each ingredient was noted.  We look forward to trying more of their signature dishes. 

Though we were reluctant to sit at the bar, the friendliness of the staff made the experience pleasurable.  Our waitress made us knowledgeable of our dishes and the history of the restaurant.  We also made the acquaintance of the chef, Massimiliano who was gracious as we discussed his plates.  We left feeling happy and satisfied.

I highly recommend this hidden gem of a restaurant.
author: Jasper D.

description: Wow. Their Uni HomeMade Past is to die for. The chef and his wife run the place and their service is implacable. You feel like you are back to Italy at your best vacation.
author: Michael R.

description: Very good food.  And *very* expensive for the style of restaurant (especially the wine).  I was not familiar with any of the dishes, as I have never been to Sardinia, but the waiter was able to patiently explain all of them.  A party  of 4, and everyone liked what they ordered immensely. For dessert, I had the Sardinian ricotta and saffron cake - it was absolutely delicious.
author: robert l.

description:
La Ciccia, I'm pretty enamored by you. Your food is flavorful and sapid. Your ambiance is cozy and dim. Your service leaves nothing to be desired.

As soon as you open the doors to La Ciccia, a huge, lush, velvet curtain greets you momentarily making the restaurant a mystery, but only for a quick second. Brushing the curtain off to the side, you're greeted by a cozily romantic place that not only smells wonderful, but is inviting and warm. 

Because we had reservations (for 9:30pm- so late, but it's all we could get for booking a week in advance), we were promptly seated. Menus were brought immediately and specials were told within few minutes of having a chance to glance at them. 

Because I had drooled at photos of the food prior to coming here, I pretty much knew what I wanted. 

We started off with the following:

Prupisceddu in Umidu cun Tomatiga (Baby Octopus stew in a spicy Tomato Sauce)
Risotto cun su Nieddu de Seppia (Fresh Risotto Seafood Sugo Lemon Zest Squid Ink)
Pani Guttiau (Traditional Sardinian Flat Bread baked with EVOO and Pecorino)

The risotto was my absolute favorite. You will be missing out if you don't get it. I know many rave about the baby octopus stew, but it fell a little short for me. While flavorful, was a tad too sweet and not savory or thick enough. The Sardinian flat bread was delish! I really enjoyed the fresh rosemary on it. 

and moved on to: 

Pezza de (insert Italian word for steak) a sa Saba (Seared Filet Mingon Tenderloin Tagliata drizzled with Saba)
Pisci de Mari Arrustiu (Seared Market Fish and Vegetables) 

The fish of the day was branzino. It was prepared so delicately it literally just flaked. Lots of well rounded flavors. The steak was melt in your mouth delicious and the winner of the two. The way they cooked down the balsamic drew out such complex flavors, I really enjoyed it. Absolutely delicious.

then finished up with: 

Truta de Arrescottu (Sardinian Ricotta and Saffron Cake Honey and Toasted Almond)
Gellausu Mistusu (Assorted Artisanal Gelati)

The cake isn't an actual "cake" as we know in America. It's more just lovely ricotta. The flavors were good, just not what I was expecting. However, the toasted almonds on top gave it the perfect nutty flavor and best crunch. The gelato came as a flight of three. The marsala raisin, fig goat cheese, and chocolate hazlenut were all delicious but the marsala raisin was my favorite. 

No pictures because the menu asked for no photographs to be taken (it was so hard not to want to photograph beautiful food!) and will just have to live in my head.

4.5 stars and will probably be back!
author: Shereen A.

description:
I've been trying to go to La Ciccia for what seems like forever. Reservations were either so far in advance or at 9pm. I finally bit the bullet and just made a reservation a month out. WORTH IT.

As others have mentioned, the restaurant is small. So expect to get friendly with your neighbors. 
 
Talk about an extensive wine list! It was a bit overwhelming, but luckily our server steered us in the right direction.

We ordered the octopus stew, bottarga pasta, squid ink linguine, and V really wanted to try the lamb. 

EVERYTHING WAS AMAZING. The octopus stew was so tender. The bottarga pasta was the star of the night. So simple, yet so bold!! By the time the other pasta came out I was stuffed so i took the majority of it to go. V enjoyed the lamb and licked the whole entire plate clean.

By the time we were done we were stuffed, so no dessert. 

Service was attentive and helpful. I really enjoyed that they timed the courses out perfectly. A pet peeve of mine is when they bring all the dishes at once.

Highly recommended if you love pasta and seafood!!
author: Noelle H.

description: The atmosphere is OK. I felt the tables are too close together and does not  allow intimacy. You're perhaps one foot at most from the next table. The space is small and since it is so popular, it feels confining. The service was standard; our waiter friendly, so no problems there. Now to the food, the reason we all go out is to eat. There was one stand out dish. The octopus in a spicy tomato sauce. It was so good with the bread, A perfect appetizer which could stand alone as a main. All other dishes did not impress. Lamb tenderloin, while good, was not great. Fish with olive tapenade tasted like something Blue Apron would send and you could whip up in a flash. We didn't get any pasta and think that perhaps that was what we should have had. You cannot go wrong here, but perhaps all the hype (Check Please! guests were gizzin' in their pants) needs to be deflated.
author: S. G.

description:
What more can I say that has not already been said about La Ciccia?  I knew going in the menu would not be traditional Italian, but I had no clue whether I would like it. I absolutely loved it. Everything is fresh, unique, and super delicious. Just be aware many of the dishes are a bit on the spicier side, but nothing too hot.  Otherwise the wine menu is a bit tricky since they feature unique wines from Italy and particularly Sardinia. 

Oh, unfortunately we recommend passing on desert.  We were only able to have one bite of the desert. Otherwise the place is amazing. Must try!
author: David L.

description:
I was supposed to go to Sardinia, visit a plastic molder and review the molding tools issues. Instead they sent a manager who went to meetings and drank Sardinian wine. How do you cuss in Sardinian? I make up for it by going to La Ciccia in Noe Valley, a small Sardinian restaurant run by a husband and wife team.

On the Bill of Fare:

Traditional Sardinian Flat Bread baked with EVOO and Pecorino

Calamari, whole squid sauteed and not deep fried

Home marinated olives.

Senatore Capelli Gnochetti Pork Bagna Pecorino Sardo.  Minature Gnocchi with pork and a red sauce. The sauce was good, better then the best marinara you will taste.

Sardinian red wine, I guess we were not having chianti. What was ordered was a blend , similar to Pinot Noir blend. Smooth.

Everything was reasonably priced and the server was very knowledgable. She had lived in Sardinia for 2 months recently.

All the food was heavenly, not the Italian food I'm used to. Buon Gusto!
author: Jim D.

description:
While La Ciccia may look like a typical, unassuming neighborhood restaurant from the outside, and is rather intimate inside, it nevertheless deserves its strong reputation, which far exceeds its modest digs. The ingredients are fresh, pastas well-executed, and larger seafood-based entrees well worth the spend.

A fresh prawn entrée, for example, was so large that it was almost mini-lobster sized. Despite the fact that it was a bit messy, because I had to extract the prawn meat myself, it came with a wet napkin on the side, was cooked just right, and came in sauces that managed to neutralize any excessively fishy flavors without being too overwhelming.

Service is also warm here, and overall this is a nice, cozy spot for date night.
author: Vincent L.

description: This place feels like the old-style San Francisco restaurants out in the avenues; small, full and bustling. No waiting to be seated for our reservation.  It was loud when we arrived, but as the tables turned, conversations became easier.  Our server was very friendly and helped us select a nice Sardinian wine to accompany our various dishes. We started with the white anchovies, calamari salad and marinated olives, and a small basket with slices of homemade Italian bread.  All were delicious, especially the mild white anchovies!  Next, we had the malloreddus (rich and a generous portion), the prawns (also a good portion), and the fish of the day, branzino, split and boned, topped with a sort of tomato sugo and sliced toasted almonds, served over a bed of agrodolce raisins, celery and onions.  We split the ricotta cake, light and fluffy, not too sweet and several dessert wines.  All in all, an excellent meal, this place is a keeper!  The only thing that surprised me was the hold on the credit card for the reservations, the only other places I've been to with that policy were Chez Panisse and Isayare.
author: Rosemary M.

description:
Went to La Ciccia at 9 pm on Saturday night. No reservations and we sat at the bar. The place was full from the time arrived to the time we left. I ordered 6 dishes because I wanted to try so many of the items. The best a mind blowing dish was the grilled lamb on a bed of cauliflower. Wow tender lamb with a mild crust medium rare so good. We had the squid ink pasta, the octopus stew, the fish roe pasta, the Calamari and artichoke salad and the flat bread. 

The service was beyond the top excellent from the time we arrived to the packing of the leftover food. It's worth circling the neighborhood 5 times trying to find parking.
author: George F.

description:
I've been hearing about La Ciccia for quite some time and finally got a chance to do a Friday evening date night there (thanks dear). I'm glad the menu has English translations because I had no idea what any of the Italian words meant. The same could be said about the wine list. We were recommended some sort of dry red wine that was excellent but I really can't tell you what it's called.

We started with the famous Baby Octopus stew in a spicy tomato sauce. I've never had anything like it before and we soaked up the yummy stew base with bread.

We each ordered a pasta for our entree: she had Fresh Spaghetti Spicy Garlic Oil Salt Cured Fish Roe and I had Fregola Tomato Sea Urchin Smoked Pancetta. I definitely had pasta envy. While both were delicious, hers was lighter and not as rich.

Even though we were stuffed, we had to try the Sardinian Ricotta and Saffron Cake Honey and Toasted Almond. It's not exactly a "cake" in the way you might think. I liked that it wasn't overly sweet and it was a great ending to an intimate girls' night.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Okay Italian place. Authentic feel, though I wasn't too impressed with the ambiance. We were seated too closely to a couple strangers, the small room was crowded and, as a result, a little noisy, and nothing about the decor particularly stood out. The staff didn't pay a lot of attention to us. Food was pretty good. Not amazing. I had the spicy tomato octopus stew and the spaghetti with row. 

I can't give more than three stars because we ended up with a 9:45 dinner reservation despite booking a week in advance, and, frankly, the experience didn't do justice to the obscene dinner time.
author: Paulina F.

description: One of my favorite places to go to in the city. Been to it many times! You can taste Sardinia in their wine and food. Chef and waiters are friendly and helpful in suggesting the right food for your occasion.
author: A B.

description: Dined here Saturday evening with friends. There were four of us. We had early reservations and were seated on time. We had an excellent waiter. My wife has a few allergies and the kitchen accommodated them easily. We ordered a lot. I started with Pasta Longa cun su Nieddu de Seppia (Fresh Linguine Seafood Sugo Lemon Zest Squid Ink). Arguably the best pasta dish I've ever had. For my entree I had Pezza de Angioni a sa Saba (Seared Lamb Tenderloin Tagliata drizzled with Saba). Absolutely perfect. I tasted the Pezza de Proccu cun Pecorinu e Zaffaranu (Pan Roasted Pork Loin Pecorino and Saffron Salsa) and it was also spectacular. Having started earlier socializing over Pani Guttiau (Traditional Sardinian Flat Bread baked with EVOO and Pecorino) and a special of the day buratta, despite my best efforts, I simply couldn't finish the entree. We had two bottles of the Chiavennasca Sforzato "Corte di Cama" Mamete Prevostini 2011. The meal, service and wine were unbeatable. It's not a cheap meal but given the quality of everything the value is off the charts. Cannot recommend highly enough.
author: Gary C.

description: Delicious food, nice atmosphere. Run by husband and wife. Really enjoyed wine selection - the barolo was excellent.
author: Kit F.

description: It's been far too long since my last meal here. But I dream of octopus stew nightly. Don't miss this charming, five star experience.
author: Nancy J.

description:
I've never had "Sardinian" food, so it's hard to say that it's "best-in-class" and worthy of 5 stars, but rated as just "food", it's pretty darn good. The ambiance here is great. It's a great date spot where the tables aren't so close that you can hear other people's conversations (although I guess you could, if you're not talking at your table) and the lighting is not too bright and not too dark. 

We took mostly the server's suggestions, and I can't remember what they are (worst reviewer ever), but this is now one of my favorite spots in the city. I'm mostly writing this just so I remember I've been here and the name.
author: Kevin L.

description: A real gem in SF that specializes in Sardinian cuisine, with a very well curated (and sensibly priced) wine list to match. There are no bad dishes in this restaurant. I always bring a few friends and order my favorites dishes plus one or two special of the day. My favorites: Octopus stew, Fregula with urchin tomato sauce topped with shaved cured tuna heart, and Spaghetti with garlic oil and topped with shaved Bottarga. Sardegna is an island so you'll find the menu to be very seafood-centric, however, the lamb tenderloin is fantastic if you crave something other than seafood. Pro-tip: Corkage is $35 per 750ml, 2 bottle limit per table. However, they will waive one corkage for every bottle purchased from their list. I typically bring an older/aged red and order a white from their list. Vermentino (white) and Cannonau (red, otherwise known as Grenache) are popular pairings with Sardinian food.
author: Puay K.

description: I came here years ago, and decided to see if it was as good as I remembered and was not disappointed. High end Sicilian Italian food - not what you get at your typical American Italian restaurant. Not cheap but worth the price. Street parking that is way easier than most of San Francisco. This is a little out of the way gem.
author: Anita P.

description:
Very disappointed.

Went here for my birthday last night. It took over 30 minutes for my starter - seafood stew - to get to the table. Aside from one clam and one mussel, the seafood in the stew was entirely comprised of squid. One of the rare occasions in recent memory when I've had to ask for salt. My companion's octopus stew was nice, though.

An hour after ordering, our pasta/mains still hadn't show up. Asked the waiter to either cancel them or box them to go. He disappeared for a bit and then came back, offering to cancel our food. He asked if the food had come out too slowly, genuinely surprised that it took so long, as if he hadn't really been keeping track of our orders. We paid and left.

The woman who had been running the front of house earlier was nowhere to be found on the way out, so there was no manager/host to offer feedback to. Definitely not going to return for a retry due to the unapologetically slack service.
author: Robert R.

description:
There is nothing else to say other than: the pasta I had tonight was the best I've had in my life. 

The waitress was amazing and extremely accommodating to my vegetarian needs. Initially I wasn't going to order much because most items on the menu either had meat or sea food, but she suggested that  a dish that was amazing. 

Thanks for the really great food and experience. And again, thanks for being so accommodating to my needs.
author: Adam S.

description:
Very authentically italian...and really good. Everything was delicious! We had an octopus special that was great -- perfectly cooked octopus with garlic on a bed of arugula. Also had the fish soup -- delicious broth, lots of different shellfish inside. We had a couple of pastas-- all were excellent, very flavorful. The fish special was delicious as well. The portions were very generous. They also had Sardininian wine!

The only drawbacks:
(1) Not good for vegetarians. There was one vegetable side dish. I don't think anything else was fully vegetarian.
(2) The menus is difficult because it needs some translation. But it is worth it to have the server explain things because everything is great!
author: Jen G.

description: We went there for the first time, due to the fact that some of our friends love the place. we arrived and the place was packed and once you start eating the food you know why. Everything was delicious, my wife had lamb and I had squid pasta dish, both were excellent in taste and quality. The wine list is huge and expensive, by the glass wines were $13 and came mostly from Sardinia. However our waiter had some solid wine recommendations to go with our food selections. Service was initially a bit slow, but improved over time. I thought they cramped to many tables into the small place, which kind off killed the atmosphere. This and the just ok service is the reason for 4 stars. The food is fantastic and we will definitely eat their again.
author: Thomas W.

description:
I'm VERY tempted to give them 5 stars... our favorite dishes were out-of-this-world (with one slight relative disappointment) & the service was GREAT. But it's incredibly pricey & so hard to get in (though we completely lucked out). I loved my meal but wouldn't necessarily go regularly - a good special occasion spot for the splurge!

SERVICE/WAIT
Amazing! At 5pm on a Saturday, I called them on a whim & was able nab their last available table at 7pm. The hostess just said the table was reserved for another dinner at 9:15pm. We were running about 5 min late & I called to let them know - they were very thankful about that. And the hostess actually remembered me from our first phone call when I came in! Even though this is a really nice restaurant, I like the casual vibe of the servers wearing La Ciccia t-shirts. Our server was super genuine & friendly - we had a great dinner.

COST
Luckily my bf treated me, but this was definitely pricey, easily in the $$$ range.

MUST-HAVES
Baby octopus stew, Veal linguine (special), Lamb tenderloin!!

APPETIZERS
* Free bread - 3 stars
Nothing amazing, plain regular bread. Our second basketful was a little cold & wet, as if it'd been frozen & hadn't thawed all the way.

* Prupisceddu in umidu cun tomatiga (baby octopus stew in spicy tomato sauce, $14) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-ciccia-san-francisco?select=K6uFe-Qvb1eYdwWHNEWoXg#E3eeSyP6HKi_Cq_VDzKzsg
Amazingly spicy kick to the sauce, loved that it was thick & chunky. The octopus had absolutely perfect texture, was tender.

SIDE DISHES
* Pani guttiau (traditional sardinian flat bread baked w/ EVOO & pecorino, $7) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-ciccia-san-francisco?select=K6uFe-Qvb1eYdwWHNEWoXg#dVW00-2ADtIPFKsTelegvQ
Not "flat bread" as you might imagine, but looks like a giant potato chip the size of the plate that you break apart. It looks simple, but it had this surprisingly amazing sharp salty/olive oil flavor.

1ST COURSE
* Spaghittusu cun allu ollu e bottariga (fresh spaghetti garlic pepperoncino salt cured fish roe, $19) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-ciccia-san-francisco?select=K6uFe-Qvb1eYdwWHNEWoXg#zPw1FZgNULwn1lHNgQTMUg
I tend to like my pasta softer so this was a little too al dente for me, but the flavor was great.

* Fregua cun arrizzoni e cori de tonnu (toasted fregola tomato sea urchin cured tuna heart, $19) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-ciccia-san-francisco?select=K6uFe-Qvb1eYdwWHNEWoXg#0VK9mPuSDyW2jOq3fy-oEw
Our curiosity about this dish got the better of us - our server had described ti very well as having a strong fish flavor, & some people love it while others hate it (love the honesty). This wasn't as fishy as we thought (or maybe we just weren't the type to hate it), & the uni wasn't overpowering at all (my bf usually hates uni but liked this!). The texture of the fregola was a little hard, like slightly stale/undercooked tapioca balls, but the sauce had this wonderfully thick texture & was delicious.

* Special: Linguine with veal ragu - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-ciccia-san-francisco?select=K6uFe-Qvb1eYdwWHNEWoXg#9cmjl6MoWXILpTlrbgdxtA
My favorite pasta of the night by far! I'm guessing it was made in-house because the linguine was a little uneven - I love these imperfections - and the texture was a great balance between soft & being al dente. The meat sauce was crazy delicious.

MAIN COURSES
* Pezza de angioni a sa saba (seared lamb tenderloin tagliata drizzled w/ saba, $27) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-ciccia-san-francisco?select=K6uFe-Qvb1eYdwWHNEWoXg#K6uFe-Qvb1eYdwWHNEWoXg
Overall, everyone's favorite dish. The lamb was super tender, seared on one side & raw in the middle. The greens were plain, too soft, & seemed to be just thrown together. But that meat - amazing!

Dinner menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-ciccia-san-francisco?select=o4j3MUlezmDd4ARUutmWsA#o4j3MUlezmDd4ARUutmWsA
author: Ziyan C.

description:
This review is overdue.... dined here about 9 months ago. Overpriced, mediocre food. The bill for two people came out to a little over $200!
Very disappointed. I came here with my husband to celebrate my birthday, since I saw The five star reviews on yelp. 
First of all, we went to get a drink at the bar while waiting for our table. My husband stated we here here to celebrate my birthday. The lady bartender suggested a glass of champagne. She didn't inform us of the choices; she poured us two glasses.
The bartender was also our waitress, which was a surprise to us. 
We ordered the octopus stew and seafood soup as starters. They were very similar .
I had the lamb, which was OK.  Kokkari has a better lamb dish. My husband had a pasta dish, which was very average. 
When we got the bill, we were surprised that one glass of champagne was $35.
All in all, $200 for a mediocre meal in a small , crowded restaurant.
author: maria J.

description: One of the best meals I've ever had in San Francisco, and there have been many over the years. The intimate and familial ambiance, warm and attentive service, and delectable meal (dinner, dessert, and wine) made for a truly memorable experience. The combo of freshness, simplicity, and bold flavors is hard to master, and the ability to transport guests to another country in a meal is a thing of magic. Thank you, La Ciccia, for reminding my husband and me of why we adore Italy. You are a gem, and we will be back soon (with friends!).
author: Lauren B.

description: I love this restaurant so much. I give it 5 stars in every real respect. They're so attentive and the food is amazing. Tonight on my anniversary, they didn't care about refilling wine not asking us how we were doing. I come here all the time. Disappointing.
author: Charlie D.

description:
A great little gem of a restaurant serving fantastic authentic Sardinian food. Rich, tasty seafood dishes galore. A friend and I split the following dishes and were well satisfied.
Starter was a nightly special of sardine filets served in an incredible savory and slightly spiced sauce of olive oil, garlic, hot pepper, and olives. Second was the pasta with bottarga, again -amazing; the main course was giant shrimp served in their shell with olive oil garlic and spices with a side dish of radichio. The Sardinian bread is incredible, super thin crusty sheets of pastry like the thinnest pizza dough you could imagine-with a light sprinkling of cheese on top. A huge  list of Italian wines to choose from,  we had a well balanced white from Campagna.
This place has great friendly service and I cant wait to go back again. My best meal of the year by far. I can't say enough about what a great place this is. 
The prices, while not inexpensive, certainly seem fair. 
Bravo!
author: Gianni P.

description:
A solid 4 or 4.5.  The two of us walked in on a Saturday night without reservations but were lucky enough to find two empty seats at the small bar, with no wait. I had:
- Oven roasted calamari (4/5) - Whole calamari drizzled with a surprisingly spicy sauce.  The sauce was also great for dipping the bread.
- Fettuccine with uni tomato sauce and shaved tuna heart (4/5) - Perfectly al dente pasta smothered with a rich uni sauce.  The dish had a great, fishy (in a good way), tangy flavor that was very unique.
- Zucchini with basil and pecorino (4/5) - Just the standard side of vegetables but actually really tasty.
- Ricotta and saffron cake (4/5) - Great coarse but soft texture with nice, subtle flavors.

The service was amazing and the space was small but charming.  Only reason this is not a 5 is because, although everything we had was really good, there wasn't one dish that I still crave a day later.  We'll definitely be coming back to try some of the other menu items.
author: Simon L.

description: Excellent! A friend recommended me this place. The calamari salad, garlic spaghetti and beef stew with vegetables were delicious!
author: Tristan S.

description:
After dining here twice, I can't wait to come back again.

La Ciccia is an incredible intimate spot in Noe Valley.  It's hard to believe a place like this exists in this corner of the city.  While it's not priced for an every day meal, there's nowhere better to go for a fine meal.

We were lucky enough to find a last minute Sunday night table for 3.  After being welcomed by Lorella, we started off with some sparkling wine.  For the meal's wine, we were recommended an incredible bottle- I don't recall the name or vintage.  

For appetizers, we tried the house made burrata and the seafood stew.  Burrata as always was delicious, but this is something you could have all over the city.  The seafood stew was incredible.  Generous amount of creatures inside.  The broth was delicious and smooth on its own without feeling heavy; it's the tastiest seafood soup I've had.

My favorite item here was the sea urchin pasta with shaved tuna heart.  It's perfection, and the only way I've enjoyed sea urchin.  We also tried the pasta special of the day- if I recall correctly this was fettuccine with veal and lamb.

For main courses, we tried the lamb tenderloin and the pork loin.  The pork had some sort of breading on it, and was served in a rich sauce.  I loved it, but beginning to fill up I had to move onto the lamb after a few bites.  The lamb was impressive- it almost melted in my mouth.  So tender, cooked to pink perfection, served with a bit of sweet balsamic.

I'll definitely be back here, it's the best around.  I have yet to make a trip to Sardinia, but for now I figure this is as close as I could get!
author: David K.

description:
Amazing lamb, one of the best lamb dishes I've ever had, and I've had the lamb in Iceland. Also had an worth-trying sea urchin pasta dish with tuna flakes on top. Wine selection was great and our waitress was patient, friendly, and fun! 

This is the kind of neighborhood San Francisco restaurant every local is proud of.
author: Stephen H.

description: Calamari were excellent. Prawns were good but I have had better. Cute restaurant. Staff is very nice and service is fast. Maybe a little bit pricey but overall had a good experience.
author: Simona C.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in town. The service is outstanding, the food is superb and the vibe is humble and charming. Cat beat the fish special and pasta special. Great wine selection.
author: Ashley K.

description: One of the most memorable dinners in my lifetime.  Amazing food and wonderful hospitality.  This is an amazing restaurant with no pretentiousness and great service.
author: Ali C.

description:
I was so excited to check this place out . I went with my girlfriend and we decided on this spot as our first place to try without our boyfriends who do not like seafood. This would be our first weekly outing so far.
We arrived and were shuffled to a tiny table by the door. Stuffed in like sardines. The place was not cozy or cool . Terrible art.
We had 3 different waiters and the last woman was downright rude. 
The appetizers were underwhelming , and the main courses were as well. Flat bread for 8 was a joke.
I am a local San Franciscan and I eat out often . I was hoping for so much more. 
Crappy service , mediocre food, and terrible cramped atmosphere.
author: Chris L.

description:
It's been impossible to get a reservation  at La Ciccia at a reasonable hour on weekends. Therefore, after two years of being on the outside looking in, a foodie friend and I decided to just show up without a reservation on a Friday evening for the coveted bar seats.  Alas, a dash of patience and a mere 30 minutes later, we were seated for our seafood feast.

We started with the oven roasted calamari in basil oil.  It was tender, served on a bed of arugula and just enough to whet my appetite for the sea bream with olives and spinach.  The sea bream was filleted, boneless, and roasted to perfection.  After eating extremely well (in terms of taste and health), we finished with the ricotta and saffron cake with honey and almonds.    I usually head straight for anything with chocolate, but I'm glad my friend talked me into trying something different.  The ricotta/ saffron cake was light, fluffy, and not overly sweet.   Such an amazing meal, and surprisingly affordable.  And in SF too! Who knew?  Apparently, everyone who booked up all those reservations so that we were never able to get anything earlier than a 10pm booking, that's who. 

P.S. If you're partial to reds like me, the bovale is a light red that goes very well with seafood.  

P.P.S.  Sardinian food is amazing with all the fresh seafood and vegetables.  That is all.
author: Nancy C.

description:
They purposely said on the menu "no cameras of phones" on their menu.  Either they wanted us to talk, or didn't want photos of their food...  Not sure which, but we had a pleasant anniversary.  I would post photos except I'm a rule follower.  

Tried several things.  

Celery squid salad (tasty!) light, zesty and citrus flavor

Black ink soup with octopus and olives.  THIS was fantastic.  It does not look as appetizing as it actually is.  My husband actually thought it was dinaguan (a Filipino pork blood dish), and I said no.  

Pasta with fish roe- this flavor was wonderful.  The paste was a little al too al dente for me, but the flavor was nice.

I ordered the grilled prawns with a nice tomato sauce finish over it and it was my delicious!  Prawns can be overlooked and this one was done just right.  

Entire bill with a glass of wine $140.  Nice job La Cicca!
author: Barb B.

description:
FINALLY!  I can finally cross La Ciccia off of my list!
I don't mean to be redundant, but La Ciccia is just as fabulous as it's reputed to be.  Small & intimate.  Old world cuisine in simple, modern & clean elegance.  This was just a beautiful meal from start to finish.  

While my man looked for parking, I was promptly greeted & seated at our table.  Arguably the best table for 2 in the house; at the front window.  

Our server was informative, pleasant, & soft spoken.  Totally on point with the surroundings.  It's quiet & romantic.  

The players...

Buratta & mushroom special appetizer to start.  Divine.

Spaghetti bottarga.  Sublime.  Spicy & decadent.  Perfectly rich, not overtly rich.  I actually used bread to sop up ALL of the remaining sauce after I finished all the pasta.  No shame.  You should too.

The Lamb.  Exquisite.  This lamb was remarkable.  Perfectly cooked.  A fantastic balsamic sauce.  I mean, honestly, this lamb was so good it was like eating CANDY.  CANDY!!!  The best lamb dish I've had in years.  Easily.

I was full now, but this meal was so fabulous that I was AFRAID to skip dessert!  And it did not disappoint.  I ordered their house made gelato assortment, which is 3 flavors...

Goat cheese & fig.
Chocolate & hazelnut.
Marsala & raisin.
All creamy & luscious, but the goat cheese & fig was my favorite.  The goat cheese flavor really shined through.  A real treat.

Superb.  5 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
The rating is based on my wife's view, not mine.  I would be between 3 or 4, but I am not a big fan of fancy places.

The location is in a very nice neighborhood and the outside is unassuming.  As you enter, you realize it's not particularly large, yet they manage to fit relatively comfortably about 15 tables.  By 6:30, it was packed.  

The waiter is bona fide Italian and the menu is selective and authentic.  They provide the titles of dishes in Italian, with English in parentheses.  Of course,it's the type of menu where I don't know at least one of the things in the description, so I might as well read it in Italian.

There are like 4 choices of everything - appetizers, salads, pastas, main courses, deserts.  

My sister ordered something minus all the stuff.  The waiter commented at that point it's just pasta and butter to which my sister said "exactly".  She eats nothing.  She went crazy and had some cheese on top of it.

My future brother-in-law had the baby octopus stew as appetizer and I don't recall what for the dinner.  Wife had a salad and then the baby octopus stew as her meal - apparently this is the specialty there.  I had a greens salad (wife said it was outstanding, I was just okay with it - go with her view).  And I had the lamb.  The lamb was very good in my view, amazing in the view of my wife.  Go with her view.

I learned they don't offer gluten-free pasta, but if you call ahead a few days before your reservation, they can try to buy some at the store.  Others bring it with them.

Nice wine pairings (all Italian) and two desserts.  All for about $230 before tip.  

Hard to argue the service was awesome.  I could easily skip going to this restaurant again, as it's too fancy for me, but my wife thought it was amazing.  Go with her view!
author: Marc F.

description:
Amazing service, great food, very traditional sardine food. 
Try the grape from Sardinia I font remember the name just ask them for a  traditional wine from Sardinia.
author: Paulo F.

description:
Coming from a Sardinian family, I had very high expectations of this restaurant. Wow, did they deliver! We shared our plates: 

* Inzalara de Birdura cun Acciugasa e Casu: The dressing... holy sh*t. #amazeballs
* Calamarusu Arrustiusu- Tender calamari with a punch of basil (great to dip bread into)
* Prupisceddu in Umidu- Unbelievably flavorful octopus with a spicy kick (also great to dip great into)
* Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga- This was the showstopper. The spaghetti was perfectly "al dente" and the flavors were so bright. If heaven exists, it definitely has this spaghetti as a main course. (also great to dip bread into... who am I kidding?! Everything is great to dip bread into when you are Italian). 

We also got the marinated olives. Needless to say, we were STUFFED by the end of our meal & had gone through four baskets of bread. I definitely recommend this spot.

Worth. Every. Damn. Cent.
author: Alexander C.

description: I love the ambiance of this place, I made a reservation two weeks previous to going and it worked out great! We had a great time and their staff are really informative and helpful! the food is great and decent amount for the price.
author: Rocio L.

description:
Uh. Ok. Wow. My mouth is still watering from the spaghetti dish topped with roe. We ordered 2 because we couldn't get enough of it.

The service was special as well and the wine list was perfection. Go here and have one of the best meals of your life. Please.
author: Stacey S.

description: Superb. NOT Italian.  Sardinian, which means a lot of seafood, often with tomato-y  sauces, and unique wines you won't find elsewhere. We shared a starter ( anchovies with arugula and orange segments.  Excellent.   Octopus stew listed as another starter was strong flavored and a more than sufficient main course.  Fettuccini special (suckling pig, pancetta, etc) was grand.  Sardinian flatbread (super thin cracker-like texture, baked in a wood fired oven, topped with rosemary and pecorino) much better than the usual house breadbasket. Wine was a cannanau (Sardinian Grenache), a perfect light red for $46 ( the list is humongous and a trifle pricey).  All told:  $130 plus tip.
author: david w.

description:
The food was great. My husband and I ordered calamari salad and octopus stew as appetizers, one flat bread, olives, and seared prawns as main course, and Nougat semifrrddo as dessert. 

We really enjoyed the two appetizers and if we come back again we will definitely order these two again. My only compliant would be that I expected the prawns would be deveined. It was a bit unpleasant to see the whole black vein when finishing peeling the shell. 

Overall our experience was positive.
author: Yc C.

description: La Ciccia is a beautiful example of food cooked with passion and love. Maximiliano and his wife are warm, welcoming and have created a restaurant that embodies their views on cuisine; passionate, authentic and with care. Look forward to returning!!
author: Holden B.

description:
La Ciccia is a homey little restaurant serving Sardinian fare. It was my first time having Sardinian food and it definitely won't be my last. Most of the dishes are seafood which I'm assuming is because Sardinia is located on the western coast of Italy. The restaurant had a rustic feel and everything was excellent. 

My boyfriend and I started with the octopus stew in tomato sauce, which was one of our favorite dishes. The octopus was very tender and the tomato sauce had a kick. If you can't hang with spicy, I would advise against ordering this dish. 

Next we ordered the squid ink pasta which was the perfect after eating the octopus stew. It was a bit tart and the pasta was cooked very well. To finish, I ordered the roasted prawns and my boyfriend ordered the lamb. The prawns were some of the best prawns I've ever had. They were cooked in a garlic sauce topped with a pepperoncino sauce which gave it a nice little kick. My boyfriend usually doesn't like shrimp heads, but he was going to town on these little heads. It was a little messy to eat since you had to use your hands to peel the shells (but at least they also provide you with a moist napkin to wipe your hands with while you eat your prawns), but so worth it.
author: Cindy A.

description: The garlic oil spaghetti is very good.  We had wine recommendations from our waiter and they were very good.  We also had the Sardinian Friska beer.  The tomato soup calamari appetizer and the calamari salad were very good.  Dip the bread in the soup and it is delicious.  I loved the service here and the spaghetti!  The gelato trio had egg nog, chocolate and one other flavor.  The saffron pudding with almonds was very good.  This place looks like a residence but has brick in the front so you can recognize it.  Street parking was not bad.  I'd definitely recommend this place over SPQR.
author: Chris L.

description: La Ciccia continues to "rock it"! Excellent food, wait staff are incredibly trained and savvy about the Sardinian wines. Phenomenal from start to finish. Congratulations to Massimiliano Conti and Lorella Degan - home run!
author: Nancy M.

description:
Inbox: 1

* click * 

"Vesper,

Come as you are -- that is sexy and elegant. The dinner location is secret. Just know this: I'll be speaking Italian to you all night.

Mr. Bond"

I LOVE surprises.

Also, I love to think that I'm an undercover spy, so I immediately researched which Italian restaurant Mr. Bond will be taking me to ;-) 

Walking into La Ciccia, I'm ecstatic to finally dine here. It's a wonderful neighborhood restaurant that's cozy, authentically Sardinian (MMM, seafood!) and a joy to dine in -- because cellphones, videos and cameras are not allowed at the table. A rarity these days. 

We toasted my birthday with a floral, crisp Vermentino di Gallura. We caught up on each other's life happenings: him gambling away M6's billion dollar funds to lure a drug lord in; me posing as an accountant in a top secret mission that led me on a wild goose chase, eventually ending up in Venezia. 

Our locked gazes were interrupted by a parade of dishes: Monterey calamari nicely sautéed in lemon, garlic and black olives; fregola with sea urchin, tomatoes and cured tuna heart. For our entrees: lamb tenderloin for me, grilled prawns for him. 

Aside from the obligatory water refills and "how's everything tasting?", we were left alone. To savor our meal, to talk, to connect. Even though your neighbor is close enough to hear your whole conversation, it was the stolen glances between forkfuls of pasta; the kiss on the back of the hand which made this evening spectacular. All because we weren't too busy staring at our phones. 

SF should have more restaurants like La Ciccia, all I need is 2 hours of sublime moments to dream and smile. 

Because tomorrow, we're back to blowing people's heads off for dinner.
author: Janice C.

description: Mmmm.... So authentic so tasty. Me and my family went there a few weeks ago. I still remember how good it was. Every dish was spectacular and did not disappoint. Reserve table in advance it's a small restaurant and gets crowded.
author: Kevin W.

description:
I've been itching to come here for quite some time and so I was ecstatic when my boyfriend surprised me for my birthday with Friday night dinner reservations! Nestled in Noe Valley, La Ciccia is a small, quaint Sardinian restaurant with a nicely curated menu w/ an emphasis in seafood.

++Ambiance 
Intimate setting with dim lighting, modest decor and tight seating. Restaurant is pretty small and likely ideal for dates or small parties of 4. I was a little bothersome with our table as I felt like it was in the middle of the hallway where everyone passes by, but was quickly forgiving as our host & server were both very attentive and accommodating. Although it was a full house, it wasn't loud and my boyfriend and I were able to pleasantly have conversations without any problems. 

Just a tip: I would try to get the counter seating if you're on a date as it looked a lot cozier and intimate!  

++Food 
The arugula salad with fresh mozzarella was surprisingly delicious for such a simple salad and we honestly just ordered it to have some greens in our dinner. Now moving onto the good stuff... There are 2 different stew appetizers on the menu and although we heard about their baby octopus stew before, we instead decided to go with the assorted seafood stew (clams, mussels, shrimp & calamari) w/ sea greens and boy it did not disappoint! This was definitely my favorite dish of the night as the broth was amazing and the sea greens added a nice complimentary touch to the rest of the seafood! Think a lighter, slightly creamier and elevated version of a cioppino - mmmm yum. 

For our main entrees, my boyfriend and I decided to stick with pastas and so we ordered the fish roe pasta and uni fettucine in tomato sauce with tuna hearts. I was a teeny bit disappointed in the latter as I was hoping it would have more uni. Bummer, but still good and preferable over the fish roe pasta in my opinion. Both pastas, however, were cooked perfectly al dente.

++Wine
There is quite an extensive wine list and the servers were more than happy to help suggest suitable pairings for your dish. Also, just FYI I think the corkage fee was $35 for 2 bottles.

Overall, my experience was pleasant and I would definitely come back to try their baby octopus stew and other main entrees. For those of you looking for a not so typical, different kind of Italian, La Ciccia is the place for you!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
After reading all the rave reviews my friend and I thought this place was going to be really great. It was good but not great. 

We started off with a seafood stew. The seafood stew was pretty good. The broth was flavorful and a bit thin. Had a good amount of seafood in it. I was glad it didn't taste fishy.

Next we had a pasta with roe and cheese. It was okay it terms of taste but it was definitely on the heavy side. Too much cream sauce but I did like the fish roe and bread crumbs. That gave it a great texture!

We also had a great white wine that they recommended. I forgot what it was but it was good and worth another try. 

Would definitely come back again to try other dishes. 

Total for 2: $100
author: Stella J.

description:
Recommendations:
Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga (Fresh Spaghetti Spicy Garlic Oil Salt Cured Fish Roe)  

For Dessert:
Gellausu Mistusu (Assorted Artisanal Gelati --Marsala & Raisin; Goatcheese & Fig
author: H O.

description:
Ambience: 5 Stars. Service: 5 Stars. Wine List: 5 Stars. Food: 3 Stars. 

Note: This restaurant was recommended by a friend with discriminating culinary taste, which makes me wonder if our six-course experience was an anomaly.
author: Phoebe W.

description: good eats in my hood. old fashioned but good italian food. sardinian is a bit different.
author: Brian M.

description:
La Ciccia is one of my favorite restaurants ever, and I was impressed this past weekend that all aspects of what I fondly remembered from my first meal there a few years ago were just as good as I remembered them.

As soon as you walk in, it feels like you are visiting a restaurant owned by your Italian relatives. You are greeted warmly after passing through the red velvet curtains, then seated at an intimate table that feels all your own in spite of being pretty close to your neighbors. 

The service is professional and knowledgeable. If you don't have an opinion or are having trouble deciding between the many wonderful things on the menu, just ask. 

Everything is well-suited to sharing, so you can enjoy a variety of dishes. The calamari, octopus stew, spaghetti, fregua and market fish that my friend and I ordered were all incredible.

The wine list is also quite impressive, with many unique offerings at affordable prices. Here is where I think the service really shines, as many of us won't be familiar with quite a few of the offerings.
