One of my favorite things about this place is that it still feels like a special, hidden gem even though it's not at all. The space, staff, and food are all unassuming, warm, welcoming - and outstanding. I'm so glad to see that a place like this can remain special for so long in SF, and can't wait to go back again.
author: Jessica H.

description:
5 stars for the Spaghetti Bottarga.  Scraped the plate clean.  

Everything else was not what I anticipated, good, but not keeling over in my chair good:
-Baby Octopus stew, super tender, but the flavors of the stew, murky, fresh herbs please?
-Bread was an afterthought and $2 charge for EVOO?  Figured we were going to have enough oil throughout the meal and was right.
-Lamb tenderloin was REALLY gamey and a bit tough, loved the lightly pickled slaw of cabbage, cauliflower and broccoli
-Fregola is not my favorite pasta, in fact, it's my first and last time probably, very mealy, could be the toasting/roasting process it goes through, flavor of the dish was great, squid ink and seafood sugo, lots of sea critters and FRESH!!!
-Mixed greens had a nice age balsalmic vinegar
-Veal linguine was another favorite, good, one of the specials of the evening
-Fusilli with sea urchin and tuna heart, good

The sauces overall were more like paste, I like mine a little looser.  

Snapped some photos of our doggy bag.  No photos in the dining room, but I caught some in the bathroom.  I am such a rebel!

Parking is a cinch if you dine early!  

Lovely selections of wines from Sardinia, $10 a glass, bring it!!!  Definitely needed a couple glasses to wash down all the rich and oily foods.

I would just go back for the SPAGHETTI!!!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Amazing experience. Best restaurant ever!

We shared the special burrata salad. 5 stars

Then we shared the gnocchetti. 5 stars

We finished with the pork scallopine. 5 stars. 

House made Sardinian bread. 5 stars. 

Service. 5 stars. 

Sardinian red wine. 5 stars. 

Bill just over $100. I would have paid more willingly everything was so good.

It's small and we got the last reservation for the night the day before, which from the other reviews is pretty lucky. We arrived at 5:45. It wasn't busy but when we left at 7:30 it was crowded and getting loud. 

Can't wait to go back!
author: Patricia H.

description:
First time trying Sardinian food. It was awesome!! I was lucky to go with my cousin who is a regular and was able to make a last minute reservation. This place was packed!

Loved every single thing I tried. For appetizers, the calamari came out completely intact- not in pieces and fried like I'm used to. It was oven roasted, and so good! We also got a plate of the prosciutto which was excellent. The flat bread is amazing!! I love anything crispy so of course this was my fav. I got the special pasta of the day which was basically the best gourmet rendition of spaghetti-o's you could ever have. I forgot the name, but it was hand-rolled of two spaghetti noodles together to create these little round noodles. It has sausage and veal and the sauce was just perfect. Definitely tasted like home-cooking and I could imagine I was in Sardinia.

They have a crazy extensive wine list, the font must have been 8 pt to fit everything on one page, so best to ask them to recommend what to get. The gelato for dessert was the best! We got to try a variety of flavors. Definitely get this! The Truta de Arriscottu- ricotta and saffron cake was good- but reminded me of fruit loops. Still good!

Wish there were more authentic regional cuisines like this around in the East Bay. Would come back if it wasn't so far away!
author: Vivian D.

description: Great place! The seafood roe pasta is crazy-good. I wish they would offer smaller portions or half orders, so 2 could sample (or 1 guy alone) more than 1 dish. When I come back solo, i will try the gnocchetti. That looked great
author: Scott F.

description: Top shelf from start to finish- La Ciccia is a unique Sardenian/Italian restaurant in it's own category.  Different enough to differentiate the menu from the legions of other Italian restaurants- La Ciccia focusses on seafood specialities and provides unique and delicious offerings from course to course.  Pastas were not your 'standard' Italian fare- they all had unique combinations and most had a seafood tie-in. Stewy and hearty! Plan ahead, they are always packed, and bring an appetite and save room for their awesome desserts and their fabulous espresso.  I will be back asap!
author: Andy S.

description:
Came here last week for a gf bday celebration. They've been praising about this place for weeks so I was super excited to finally try it out esp since i just visited Italy recently, dying to eat Italian food again!

Here's our menu:
Bottle of Rocca Rubia to start
Calamarusu Arrustiusu (oven roasted calamari) super soft and juicy!!
Zupetta de Pisci (stew of clams, mussels, shrimps) too much good stuff
Prupisceddu in Umidu cun Tomatiga (baby octopus) a bit spicy but great with bread
Pasta Longa cun Arrizzoni e Cori de Tonnu (linguine iwth the tastiest uni sauce!!!)
Fresh fish of the day
Bottle of Bortolotti 
Yummiest decadent desserts: trio gelato flavors
Ricotta and Saffron Cake served with honey and Almonds

Corner of church and 30th. Staff are friendly, the owner even nicer...go try it out.
author: Vee V.

description:
I dont know much about Sardinian food.
Seems I dont know much geography either....but I do know (now) that Sardinia is an island (second in size to Sicily) pretty far from Italy, although a part of Italy.

I was expecting last night's meal to be pretty much Italian, and I love really good Italian. Well I did love it, and it was Italian, with maybe some Roman and North African influences? A lot of seafood (yay) as well as pork, lamb, saffron, honey, raisins, flat bread. 

We had calamari in basil oil to start, followed by flatbread,lemon ricotta ravioli, then lamb,  and finally an espresso ricotta cake. And wine ( huge wine list. ) I was very happy with everything, except the dessert which was only ok. Bill was about 100 for two which I think was pretty fair for the quality of the food.

And here is how we will order next time:
-prosciutto to share
-octopus 
-salad 
-ice cream or goat cheese with honey

And a glass of whatever the waiter recommends I drink.....

And I will be very very happy. 
This is a good place.

PS Not a hipster in sight. Average age of diners was 40+.
author: El B.

description:
If you don't know anything about Sardinian food (which I didn't) you should at least know that most of it is seafood based. Strong sea flavors. So if you're not into that, then you won't like this place.

I love seafood. Hubby doesn't. So we compromised and ordered:

   * Pani Guttiau ($7 side order) - a nice crisp flatbread with rosemary and pecorino cheese, way more exciting than the complimentary bread they bring to the table

   * Octopus stew in a spicy tomato sauce ($14 appetizer) - very tender baby octopus in a thick tomato sauce, I thought it was really good, hubby thought it was okay but too "fishy" though he gamely ate some, complimentary bread is good for sopping up all that sauce

I could have just stopped my meal there. Even though they list all these courses on the menu, this isn't one of those restaurants where you're expected to order from each course and therefore each course is tiny. The dishes here are hearty. The flat bread must have had 7-8 pieces. The octopus comes in a bowl that's definitely meant to be shared. But then we went on and got:

   * Semolina Gnochetti with Pork meats Sugo and 12 Months Pecorino ($18 first course) - which was normal pasta (not gnocchi) with ground/crumbled meat sauce, very good, average portion, could have been eaten on it's own though we shared it

I really wanted to get the spaghetti with bottarga but when hubby read it was salted fish roe he put his foot down. The gnochetti were still good but the spaghetti is typically Sardinian. At this point we definitely should have stopped but it was too late because we also ordered:

   * Pan roasted Pork loin w/ cauliflower ($26 main course) - the low point of the meal, nothing wrong, just nothing exciting, would skip the main courses next time

We also split a Sardinian beer for $18. They do have peroni for $5 but it's not on the menu. 

Because hubby doesn't like seafood he'd only give this place 3 stars. We agreed the pani and gnochetti were good. I liked the octopus, he was unconvinced. We both thought the pork loin was boring. All of it was well done in an "authentic" rustic home style way but nothing was super fancy. It's very different from the current style of restaurants. Total including tax + tip = $105 for two.
author: Jean K.

description: Wow, tonight the food and service was amazing. Filed calamari salad, anchovies salad, and baby octopus stew. Delicious and rated in that order. The pasta something specialty with the fish roe was so good I was scooping up sauce with the bread. The squid ink pasta was perfect, tried the uni pasta finally tonight and it was delicious, but still prefer the squid ink pasta. The semi fredo or spring line that dessert was good, I don't care for the ricotta saffron thing, or the goat cheese figure ice cream Gelato. I'm going back for the first roe pasta, it reminds me of garlic noodle, but better.
author: Gessa C.

description:
I've gotten pickier and pickier after 10+ years in SF, and it had been a long time since a place really surprised me with how flat-out good the food was.  

We went there with another couple last year and from start to finish, we were really impressed.  Service was warm and professional, very welcoming.  The space was dimly-lit and cozy, but also bustling with some energy.  

The food, all of it, was spectacular.  They do miracles with olive oil here, hadn't had Italian food this good since Italy itself.  Even the wine, and I am not a huge Italian wine fan, paired perfectly with the food.  Really made for a wonderful evening dining out with friends.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Eating here is like stepping into someone's personal kitchen. There's the husband cooking up a storm in the back, and his sweet wife charming guests in the front. 

Summary: Real fresh seafood and clean flavors that compliment the ingredients without overpowering them. 

The lamb was also to die for and tasted of rosemary. Definitely the most surprising meat dish I've tasted in a while. 

The spaghetti was highly addictive. I could probably down a good 5 plates of that before I keel over and die happy. 

The prawn dish was also really good and had a fresh tomato flavor. I bet the sauce was just so irresistible that the prawns just jumped in the sauce themselves!

Basically this is the kind of food that you crave, attempt to make, and fail miserably at. The success of this food is in it's perfect simplicity and probably recipes that have been passed down for generations with a touch of genius from the chef. 

Last but not least, we had the lemon ricotta cake with toasted almonds and honey. I've been dreaming about it ever since I left and I will no doubt be back very soon for more good home cooking.

As a side note, the restaurant has a pretty incredible wine list (I wish I knew enough about wine to truly appreciate it!) and they've received awards for it. If you are a wino, this place definitely deserves a try. Then again, if you're a wino, you've probably already been here. 

The point is, go to La Ciccia on your next date night and you'll be treated to first class food and hospitality.
author: Heather T.

description:
Best kept secret in SF (not to foodies) but they rest of you!
roasted prawns*** Fish***
author: Sean K.

description: Looked forward to dinner. Service was terrible and ruined dining experience. Will never return. There are many great restaurants in San Francisco who have professional wait staff without attitude.
author: Charlie T.

description:
We stumbled into this gem after attending an author presentation at Omnivore Bookstore. We figured the foodie bookstore 
staff would be pros at recommending delicious food...& we were right! Casual, cozy, charming. The meals were incredible. Highly recommend. Probably not great place, however, for young children or folks in a hurry.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Solid four stars for this super adorable restaurant quietly tucked away between two houses in Noe Valley. 

Scored a last minute reservation and we were seated promptly. Service is actually five stars. Our server was very attentive; he neither took too long nor checked in too often. He also gracefully split our dishes for us at the table which was a really elegant and unexpected touch. 

Special prawn appetizer - 3/5. Actually, this was pretty over priced. The flavors were fantastic, the plating beautiful and they cooked the prawns perfectly but there were only three for $16.

The pasta with roe - 4/5. Pasta was al dente, had a hint of saltiness that really complemented the richness of the sauce. I would get this again. 

Sea bass special - 4/5. Very simply seared sea bass, but cooked to perfection. Definitely fresh and was tender. The olive tapenade went great with it. The braised kale that came with it was fine but I would have preferred something else less bitter. 

Overall, a very satisfying dinner. I would love to come back and try more things!
author: Mira N.

description:
This place was worth a visit at a national level for me. 
1. It's unique. It's the most actually-sardinian restaurant I've been to across the Italian joints I've been to in 10+ cities in the US.
2. Everything is done perfectly: seasoning, texture via kneading/ cooking times, etc. The results are mind-blowing! The seafood stew is uber-rich, unctuous, not "fishy" but loaded with ocean flavors. The pastas were also rich, warm, with layers and layers of flavors and chewy silky pasta. I didn't have a SINGLE thing that I could nitpick here. 
3. Service is warm, honest & straightforward, and there's definitely a ton of pride & enthusiasm to have visitors try their food.
author: Jungmin L.

description: I loooooved this restaurant so much the first time I went, that I came back the weekend after! Their Bottarga Spaghetti is simply amazing. Aside from their delicious fresh pastas, their wine list is crazy and the service is on point. They were also nice enough to make us an affogato at our request even though it's not on the menu (ask for the chocolate hazelnut gelato!)
author: Jane P.

description:
Very solid, well-prepared food, in a cute and intimate setting.  The dishes are very thoughtfully put together and, even though I don't know a thing about Sardinian food, I felt like the chefs were staying very true to Sardinian food culture.  

My friend and I came here around 6pm on a Tuesday, and the place quickly filled up.  Says a lot for how popular this place is.  We ordered the flatbread, the octopus stew, the prawns, the spaghetti, and the gelato trio and ricotta cake for dessert.  

Each dish was excellently prepared.  My breakdown of each dish:

+ Flatbread: so, this was a surprise to me.  It's not at all like what I imagined it.  It's not like American flatbread.  It's this paper-thin, almost crepe-like consistency.  There was pecorino on it, but the flavor was ever so subtle.  It was fun to eat, and a good vehicle to put the octopus stew on, but otherwise, it didn't blow my mind.

+ Octopus stew:  this was my favorite dish of the night.  Generous portions of octopi, and that stew was hearty, spicy, tomato-y.  Warm, hearty goodness.  You should put some stew on your flatbread, or on the free bread that comes at the beginning of your meal.  Or dip the bread in the stew.  Highly recommended.

+ Prawns: so, this was an entree, but the awesome waitress allowed us to get just a half-order as an appetizer.  It tasted very fresh and light.  

+ Spaghetti: Man, this was REALLY interesting!  Not at ALL like what you'd expect from the name "spaghetti."  There was this thinly shaved powder all over the dish that I think was cured roe, and the dish had this wonderfully unique and almost bitter kind of taste!  Very subtle bitterness, though.  VERY interesting, but in a good way!

+ Gelato: Do get! The three flavors tonight were goat cheese + fig, chocolate hazelnut, and marsala wine.  The first and third were AWESOME!

+ Ricotta cake:  pretty good, but I could've done without.

Even though I didn't love every single dish, I still recognized that each dish was so very thoughtfully prepared and cooked well.  They really know what they're doing.

Also, the service was so great.  Our waitress was super helpful, and she even let us cancel an order in the middle of the meal after we realized we were too full to eat it.  

I so want to give this place 5 stars, except that I wasn't blown away by the food.  However, that said, this was a wonderful, new experience, and I'm glad I got to try all these interesting foods that I've never tried before.  And I can't help but feel like I got a really great, authentic introduction to Sardinian food.  

One last note, this place tends to fill up quickly and is quite popular, as shown by the fact that it was full on a Tuesday at 6pm.  Come early or make reservations.  Also, it's good for small groups or intimate dates.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Some of the best Italian food I've had in the city. As others have mentioned, it's Sardinian style. Simple dishes executed extremely well. So much depth to the octopus stew (the spiciness has so many layers to it). Most people seem to share an appetizer and some pastas, but the mains were also good. We had trippa (which was an appetizer special) and octopus stew for the appetizer shared a few pastas (loved the uni one) and a main (Mediterranean sea bass with olive tapenade that was a special for the night). Was absolutely delicious.

Extensive and good wine list - we got one of the Chianti Classico (Belvedere) - went very well with the trippa and other tomato based dishes!
author: Food E.

description: Spicy octopus starter was fantastic.  Bottarga pasta and uni pasta were amazing.  Lamb and shrimp were incredible.  The owner was so sweet to come by and say hello and thanks.  This evening the Warriors lost, but we won with this jewel!
author: Henry L.

description: it's in a cute quiet SF neighborhood. The food is Sardinian and very different from what we're used to. Service was excellent and the dishes very tasty.  Octopus and seafood in general is awesome.  Highly recommend for a special occasion!
author: Christine A.

description:
Well this is the kind of place I wished I could give 2 stars to so people stop going then I can actually get a table once in a while ;)

The food is just superb,service is awesome, wine list OMG. 
Although the place is famous for its seafood, the lamb was just amazing. Not to say the fish and other seafood dishes weren't great, they were awesome in fact. You will have a great experience there, just be open, relax and taste what Sardinia has to offer.
author: Lo F.

description: The bottarga pasta is a thing I dream about; an obsession; something I want to make on my own so I don't have to order two in one sitting.  It's that good. What makes it better is the graciousness of the staff, the white linen draped on the counter before me, the beautiful attention to detail of the ambience and the frequent visits from the chef. You've surpassed 5 stars. I love this restaurant.
author: taylor p.

description:
A friend and I'd stopped in for 7pm dinner sans reservations and were told that they were slammed that night: no reservations, no seating. No problem, we tried something else that night.

A few weeks later, I stopped by with my mum for a very early dinner. We were seated immediately. Must've been a slow night. That, or they liked my mum. (I'm banking on the latter.)

The menu's pretty clear about setting aside phones, so I didn't snap any photos. There are loads on Yelp, so I'll just refer to them:

+Spaghetti with bottarga (thanks, Andy W. for this shot: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-ciccia-san-francisco?select=V2Ti927FbBeSYmbC5LWbgw#G5hn2kKQDB669EOmvfhBAQ). Bottarga's essentially salted, cured fish roe (fish eggs) which is then grated onto the pasta. The dish was salty and oily, but not overpoweringly so; I mean, I ate the whole thing.

+Mama got the fish of the day, which was striped jack, served over a bed of whatever vegetables the chef decides that day. Apparently, he was in the broccoli and golden raisins mood, among with a medley of other indiscernible foodstuffs. It was pretty good.

Wine was... just OK. Since their wine-by-the-glass menu's scant, we had to make do. (Ugh, "make do," I sound like such a snob.) I wasn't a huge fan of the red, nor the white that mum had ordered.

Chef Massimiliano Conti must've been the one to let us in as he took to my mum immediately and brought over some excellent baby octopus stew (served in a spicy tomato broth, great shot Kai Y.: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-ciccia-san-francisco?select=V2Ti927FbBeSYmbC5LWbgw#-VaarFekOAL4Mrmj1Mc-UQ). I'm kidding, I know he's married, but still, it was very kind of him. That broth, though! I could've sopped it up with bread forever. Speaking of bread, it's complimentary, but served cold and without butter or olive oil. Not what I expected from an Italian joint, but it is what it is.

Decent service though fairly pricey. At two entrees and two glasses of wine, we're looking at a bill after tax/tip.
author: Adena B.

description:
My friend and I finally made it to La Ciccia!  We started with a lovely burrata salad - the burrata was so creamy soft and so fresh in the middle of a circle of fresh arugula - mmm!  A wonderful start to our meal!  We ordered the squid ink pasta next - wonderfully flavor with just the right amount of saltiness on house made pasta.  I had the salmon as my entree but I only got through some of it as I was getting full and we wanted to save some room of dessert.  So we packed up our entrees and ordered the saffron cake with almonds and the trio of sorbet which included lychee, rasberry and basil mint - great combo with the cake.  

Service was nice, attentive and our courses came at just the right time.  La Ciccia is a busy little place so make your reservations for sure, and enjoy such wonderful Sardinian food.  

The only request is that could you please put the mirror in the ladies' room a little lower as I am short and I can't see in the mirror where it is now - haha, kind of funny but true.  

Other than that, all was great!  I can't wait to come back!
author: Maile N.

description:
A beautiful dining experience. 

La Ciccia might be my favorite Italian restaurant in SF. One of the best things about it is that they serve regional Sardinian cuisine, meaning you will get a chance to try a lot of unique dishes you might not have previously encountered. 

Another great thing to point out is that service is AMAZING. The staff is super friendly and knowledgeable. I got recommended a very tasty Sardinian wine go go along with our choice of dishes. The timing of when the dishes came out was perfect. 

We started with a generous serving of prosciutto. The flavors were subtle and it was sliced so thin it simply melted in your mouth. We then tried the octopus in tomato sauce. The sauce was a little spicy and rich with seafood flavor; the plate was left clean as the sauce begged to be soaked up with bread. 

We then tried the very traditional spaghetti bottarga and the fettuccine with ragu. Both dishes were made with homemade pasta cooked al dente. The ragu was good, but the duck gizzard in it added texture more than flavor. 

I really recommend you try their daily pizza. That day it was a white pizza with zucchini blossoms, ricotta, and salami. It was great. It had amazing ingredients and amazing dough. 

We ended dinner with a main course of prawns. The dish was nicely plated and not bad, but I preferred all the other dishes we tried. 

I strongly recommend La Ciccia; the money spent will be well worth it. 
I can't wait to return.
author: Augusto T.

description:
I'm not really a fan of Italian food but a good friend of mine is so I was looking to surprise them. This place did not disappoint! The wine list is a little intimidating, lots of options of varying prices. We started with the spicy octopus soup which was just great. The gelato we had for dessert was also pretty good as well. 

I highly recommend making reservations at least 2 days in advance. My gut tells me this place stays packed but for good reason.
author: Cory I.

description:
Took me a while to figure this out so I'm putting it out there for everyone, the restaurant's name is pronounced LA-CHEE-CHA. 

I've been hearing rave reviews about this place for a while so my expectations naturally were set pretty high for my first visit.

While the meal didn't blow my socks off as I expected it to, it was overall a great meal. 

I'm a sucker for fresh made pasta; and a sucker I was. The spaghetti with bottarga ($17) was to die for. I don't think I ever had pasta cooked this perfectly before. It was truly al dente and simply delicious. I didn't want this dish to end.

We also ordered the pasta special that night, rigatoni with beef ragu ($17). It was good but not as good as the spaghetti with bottarga. And of course we had the famous octopus stew ($12) and oven roasted calamari ($12). Surprisingly with all the hype about the octopus stew has gotten, I actually preferred the calamari. Not that the octopus stew wasn't good but it was simply overrated.

As for service, the staff are warm, friendly and knowledgeable. Our waters were never empty and plates and utensils were changed after each course. 

The only two things I didn't like about this restaurant is how close the tables are and on the menu it "thanked" everyone for not using their cellphones and cameras at the table. Shocked? I was too. After the initial shock, I just ignored it. How else was I going to post pics of the food for y'all? =) Oh and yes, we were practically sitting on our neighbor's lap. Yeah, tables were THAT close. Other than that, the meal was great.

Reservation is a must. This place gets really packed even on a weekday night.
author: Andy W.

description:
I am mad for restaurants that shun Western influence and stick to what they know their cuisine should taste like, the ambiance they provide, and the way you feel after your experience. 

Yes, I called my dinner here an experience. 

This is a small intimate restaurant - similar to what you find in Europe so don't mess around with your reservation time. 

Our server was friendly, helpful, and professional. He told us the specials, helped me pick a bottle of wine to match everything we ordered, and got us in and out within an hour. 

I am baffled by people who are afraid to ask for help ordering wine. Don't pick the most expensive one thinking that is going to be the best because more often than not isn't what you want and you overspent for your dinner -  leaving wine a vicious cycle of negative emotion. 

It has been my experience Bay Area Italian and French restaurant servers are adept at steering you in the right direction to a bottle that you will enjoy based at the price point you say you want to pay. Ask for help, tell them what tastes you enjoy about wine and the price you want to pay...there is no judgement, they want you to drink wine with your dinner!  We had an excellent recommendation and left that bottle bone dry. ::sigh:: It was so good! I was happy to avoid my usual Italian picks - Barolo or Sangiovese. 

We enjoyed the smoked prosciutto and balsamic vinegar special of the day. The spicy octopus stew was deliciously tender, rich, and memorable. The large couscous style pasta covered in cured tuna heart shavings was fishy, briny heaven. The days special fettuccini with pancetta bolognese style sauce was delicious!  

The trio of gelatos? Ha! He didn't stand a chance getting a bite! I savored every bite all to myself. 

Like a courteous diner and Yelp Elite Ambassador - I did not take photographs out of respect for the restaurants printed menu request to refrain from taking photos, talking on cell phone, and using laptops.  It was really nice to focus on the food, wine, and company at my table. I didn't mind that request at all. 

Parking can be frustrating. Our server said we were smart to come for first seating at 5:30 because after 7 - the parking situation is dismal. 

I highly recommend...I can't wait to go back!
author: Jennifer C P.

description:
This is a pretty good place to go for pasta and seafood.  The dishes are what I imagine a home-cooked meal to be in Sardinia.  We ordered a fettuccine with spicy tuna sauce -- pretty simple flavors, but satisfying.  We also ordered a pizza with salame and arugula -- the arugula dressing had anchovies in it, but I liked it.

1 star off: The baked shrimp entree was disappointing.  For $26, we only got 4 shrimp and *nothing else* on the plate.
1 star off: The bread was cold.  Dipping oil was extra.  My interest was low...
author: Ally W.

description:
What a lovely neighbourhood gem!

Prupisceddu in Umidu cun Tomatiga (Baby Octopus stew in a spicy Tomato Sauce) is a must have.

I will most definitely be back for more! :)
author: Daphne H.

description:
Pretty good. 4 stars for food but -1 star because it was overpriced for what you get/the quality. Shrimp were a bit overcooked and dry, on a bed of veggies (kale?) that had no flavor. Boyfriend's lamb dish was not very good, the sauce was not tasty at all and it didn't have a nice browned/seared crust. Octopus stew pretty good, even though Im not a big fan of octopus, the sauce was great (but octopus chewy). And the special pasta of the night was the best part. Wines very expensive. It was 930 pm to get a reservation. And it was still packed. Tables so close at one point the waiter had his butt so close to my face while he was taking another diner's order.


I would stick to the pasta and the appetizers if you do go as entrees were not impressive.
author: anna j.

description:
Superb.

 I had the lSeared Lamb Tenderloin Tagliata drizzled with Sabaand we also tried Gnochetti Pork Bagna Pecorino Sardo. We finished our meal with Ricotta and Saffron Cake Honey and Toasted Almond.
author: Gabriel B.

description: La Ciccia was well worth the wait. I had tried perhaps 10 times to get reservations for a group of 6 or 7 without success, but a group of 3 dined there mid-week with reservations only 2 weeks in advance. The food, the service, and the quiet ambience are all absolutely wonderful. It is now one of my top restaurant choices in SF, along with La Folie. The tables are small, not crowded together, and the Sardinian food is unusual and truly excellent--it is not some fusion, unless one from 2 centuries ago. It has integrity. The Sardinian wines are also terrific.
author: Michael S.

description:
36 month aged prosciutto - Amazing ($36)
Sea Urchin pasta - good but will not get again ($25)
Lamb main course - literally the best lamb I've ever had. ($29)
Saffron Ricotta cake - mellow flavor and a nice way to end a rich meal. ($9)
author: Rob W.

description:
I'm not sure what has not been said about La Ciccia, so I'll just agree with what everyone else said plus the following:

+ super romantic but not pretentious (the place to take that special someone you want to impress!)
+ octopus stew will blow your taste buds away
+ the sea urchin fregola dish is A-M-A-Z-I-N-G (but avoid if you don't like anything briny)
+ awesome wine recommendations/pairings

The meal will leave your bellies full and your soul yearning for the Mediterranean sea breeze.
author: Sherry L.

description: We just had dinner here and it was excellent. We were here from out of town and just came from the beach and were not dressed accordingly and had no reservations. They graciously made a place for us at the bar and made us feel welcome. Thanks to the staff for being so generous.
author: Jeffrey F.

description:
The main reason I came here is to try the spicy baby octopus stew (#26 on the top 100 eats). Then I read some article that this is the best Italian restaurant in SF. I figure I had to try it especially since reservation wasn't that easy to get. I ended up with a 5:30pm slot on a Saturday night.

This has to be one of the most unique experience I had with Italian food. The octopus didn't disappoint at all. I never had Italian food this spicy. I wish I could order baskets of bread just so I can dip into the stew, then lick every inch of that bowl.

The next item I ordered was the fregula seafood sugo with squid ink. This dish didn't look too appetizing but actually tasted good. It was rich and had a slight tang. Next, we had the fresh spaghetti garlic spicy evoo cured mullet roe. I don't think I had pasta made this well since my visit to Rome. And finally, we had the oven roasted prawn. I am surprise how juicy the prawns were. I love it when the head is still in tack, got to suck all the gooeyness. 

I am saving the 5th star on my next visit.
author: Kien M.

description:
My friend brought me here to celebrate a birthday. This was one of the best meals I've had in San Francisco and potentially ever. This was definitely the best Italian restaurant I've been to in the city, and I live in North Beach.

The service was great, but the food was what made the meal (in addition to a great bottle of wine that the server recommended and good company). We split four dishes: the calamari, the octopus stew, the fresh linguini in squid ink, and the lamb. My least favorite was the linguini in squid ink and even that was a great dish. My favorite by far was the octopus stew...the best sauce I've had in my life. I also loved the tanginess and freshness of the calamari and the sweetness and texture of the lamb. To top it off. we ended with a ricotta, saffron, and almond dessert. Even though I don't like almonds, this was still awesome and I ate all the almonds. I will dream about this meal for a long time, and I will definitely be back.
author: Rami R.

description:
AMAZING! AMAZING! going again tonight for our Anniversary! The octopus soup is calling me again~~~ So quaint and romantic.. WE love it!

Thank you La Ciccia!
author: Kirk M.

description: This is a great place! Its small and cozy but the food and the service is excellent. They do a great job of wine pairings or suggestions. Try the octopus stew and the pasta with fish roe. We finished with their cheese selection with honey and coffee for dessert..it was an overall excellent experience and we look forward to going back! I like that they write on the menu to not use your cell phones and take photos at the table. I wish more restaurants enforced that rule/dining etiquette.
author: Lotika G.

description: I spend every summer in Italy and the best Italian wine in San Francisco is at La Ciccia. Our second time here last night, the pasta dishes were delicious and hot, and the lamb so very tender. As for the wine, I have asked them chose the pairings both visits and they've been outstanding. The waitstaff and owners take care of you as a team. Wonderful, attentive service. Our new favorite restaurant!
author: Shannon W.

description: Love this family run Italian.  Intimate seating great wait staff and the food never disappoints. Only down side is it can be tough to get in.  Plan ahead and you'll be rewarded with a great experience
author: M W.

description:
I get a lot of flack for being a "Yelper" sometimes. I get it from people at work, I get it from friends.... It gets redundant. You know what I'm talking about? And then sometimes people tell me I've eaten practically everywhere in San Francisco (so not true) so they don't know where to take me to eat. 

Well. Someone did a good job of taking me here for my birthday for 2 reasons
1). I had never been here
2). I had an excellent birthday meal. 

Prupisceddu in Umidu $13 (Octopus stew in a spicy tomato sauce) - This dish lived up to the insane Yelp hype. The spicy tomato sauce for the base of this broth was not too spicy, but definitely had a little kick to it. Okay maybe not a kick. Like a bunt to it. The octopus was amazingly tender. No rubbery chewiness here. I had just come from getting a temporary crown at the dentist and the Novocaine just wore off. Still, my jaw was a tad sore but I had no problems eating this. THAT is how tender the octopus was. I would come here again and again just for this dish alone. 

Sardella a Schiscionera  $10  (Fresh Sardines Sauteed in EVOO, Garlic, Parsley and Bread Crumbs) - I'm a fan of sardines. I especially love it when they're in season and eating it sashimi or nigiri style. This was just ... okay. Nothing spectacular. You can skip this 

Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga $17  (Fresh Spaghetti with spicy Oil and Bottarga) - They definitely do al dente at La Ciccia. Although this spaghetti was spicy and plentiful with the bottarga (fish eggs), I preferred the fusili more. That was the true star.

Pasta Cruzza cun Arrizzonisi e Cori de Tonnu $17  (Fresh Fusilli with Sea Urchin Tomato and Cured Tuna Heart) - Ahhhh ... I can't decide if this was the best part of my meal OR the dessert. It's a toss up between the two. I loved this dish. If you are a sea urchin lover, this is for you. The sea urchin must be blended into the tomato sauce with an immersion blender or something because you get the sweet, nutty earthy taste of sea urchin in every single bite. A must try and a must return for dish.

For dessert I had a trio of gelato that changed my life. Which one? The goat cheese and fig gelato. Out of this world.  A kind of dry, creamy taste from the goat cheese and crunchy bits of candied figs all wrapped up into this tasty ball of gelato. Party in your mouth! The chocolate was okay (I'm not a chocolate fan) and then there was a scoop of madeira raisin (like rum raisin). The madeira was strooongggg but tolerable in small bites. 

:)

P.S. They ask that you don't take any pictures or use your phones while you are dining here. Therefore, I have no photos to show. This is for you Hen A, because I know you will ask where my pictures are!
author: Susy C.

description:
Why La Ciccia Is "Our Italian Place in Noe Valley"*:

1)  The answer for a spontaneous craving for Italian / seafood / something a lil' different.

2)  Our early walk-in was warmly greeted and promptly ushered into the cozy space.

3)  No phones, camera, or computers at the table.  (Bad for food photos, great for conversation!)

4)  An anniversary glass of bubbly is just the tip of an iceberg of a wine list.

5)  Gorgeous fresh burrata encircled by bright green fava beans and arugula and sprinkled with EVOO and pepper.

6)  A "deserving-of-the-hype" Octopus Stew.

7)  Paper thin crispy flatbread sprinkled with pecorino and fragrant rosemary.

8)  A simply cooked and delicious Sea Bream that didn't need the tapenade.  (The Better Half enjoyed the hearty Fettucini with Veal / Pork / Porcini Ragout.)

9)  A nougat and chocolate Semifreddo dessert reminiscent of a Drumstick and a Vanilla-Chocolate-Hazelnut gelato trio. 

10)  A desire to jump on a plane to Sardinia (but until then a return trip to La Ciccia will have to do!).

* We've only been here once so far.  It's that good!

8/12  

AJ3
author: Amy C.

description:
This restaurant serves flavorful food!  Some dishes were very bold and others were subtle yet distinct. There is an Old World tone and a comfort food style of cooking that resonates well and is very much appreciated by this diner.  My favorite of the evening was the Malloreddus a sa Campidanese for $16.
It is a semolina gnochetti with a pork meat sugo (sauce) and topped with a 12 month aged Pecorino grated cheese. The gnochetti resembled a cavatelli type of pasta.  The pork sauce was rich, meaty, very flavorful and completely satisfying. Our server told us that this is an original family recipe that the owners use here at La Ciccia. 

We shared the following two as starters:
Zupetta de Cocciula Cozzasa e Calamareddusu $13                    
(Rich Soup of Clams Mussels Calamari and Sea Weeds)
You'll want to dip your bread into the broth at the end!  This is a soup and not one of their stews that they also offer.
 
Calamarusu Arrustiusu  $13
(Oven Roasted Monterrey Calamari drizzled with basil Oil) 
I was surprised at the number of good sized calamari there were.  There were six calamari and the tentacles were snipped off and ready to be eaten too.  They were fresh tasting and served with mixed greens.

The breaded and fried pork cutlets will also be my go-to choice the next time I dine here.  They were seasoned perfectly--I believe there were four cutlets.
Fettinasa de Proccu a sa Sapa $23
(Pan roasted Pork loin served with Saffron Onions)

The funkiest dish that we had was the spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e bottariga for $18 
(Fresh Spaghetti with spicy Oil and Bottarga)
If I'm correct, the bottarga are dried fish eggs that are grated over your pasta.  The spicy olive oil was rich, thick and did have a kick to it!  I was apprehensive about this dish but it was daringly different and with each bite, I enjoyed it more and more.  This is not served with a red sauce.


We shared the gelato ( three flavors) and a Sicilian cheese cake for dessert.
 Truta de Arriscottu $8 
(Ricotta and Saffron Cake served with honey and Almonds)   
The cake wasn't as moist as I had hoped and the flavors were very subtle.  The honey and slivered almonds offered more taste than the cake itself.

If you're new to La Ciccia and aren't sure what to order, then I would reccomend these safe choices:
The gnochetti and the pork cutlets.  If there are two of you dining, then this would be a perfect pairing to share.
There are quite a few wines by the glass to choose from too--your servers will gladly help you navigate that area.

This is a wonderful restaurant.  Hope you enjoy it too.
author: Thomas D.

description:
VERY DISAPPOINTING
1.  Server opened wine bottle and smelled the cork up his nose and then placed it down our table.  That was a first for me since every time I purchase wine I am the one that should be smelling the cork but maybe he smelled something wrong so that's why he smelled it which would have been fine. But to leave it on our table after it's been on his nose and say nothing that is DISGUSTING

2.  I don't remember the name of dish but it's the whole shrimps dish. I took a bite to see if it was cooked right because it looked raw but wasn't sure and sure enough it was.  It was recooked but they could have given another shrimp that I took a bite at to replace but didn't.  It would be right to serve a full amount of food when it was sent raw. They did comp for one glass of champagne that my gf was having but it's only right to because she had to wait while we ate for her dish to be recooked that should be not be a reason tho for it to be ok to not have them place a full serving amount of dish ordered 

3. It's nice and cozy but there is also a down fall to it. When servers from other tables are catering to their table we had their butts directed to us as they bent over to talk to their customers.  There were times that it was very close to our faces and I didn't want to make a scene since it wasn't my celebration. I know it wasn't intentional but it should stated "pls know your surrounding"
author: L U.

description: Went here for my friend's birthday, had a 7pm reservation. Didn't have to wait to be seated, service was prompt and attentive and the servers were very knowledgeable and friendly. We shared the stracciatella salad (on special) with heart of burrata, the baby octopus stew, the spaghetti with cured fish roe, the sea urchin fettuccine, the pan roasted pork loin, and the Sardinian ricotta and saffron cake honey for dessert. Everything was delicious and easily shareable. We also shared reasonably priced bottle of wine, it was very nice. I had mentioned it was my friend's birthday when I made the reservation and dessert came with a candle in it :) Will definitely be back!
author: Sarabeth L.

description:
Mr. NSS "What does the third line on the menu say?"

Me *reads*: "Thank you for not using your camera, cell phone or computer at the table."

Mr. NSS: "Please don't embarrass us."

Me: "WTF? You're ALWAYS on your phone!!!"

Mr. NSS: "That's because you're ALWAYS on yours; Yelping, checking in on Yelp, taking 6969 food pics for Yelp and talking notes for Yelp."

Me: "Fine, I won't even touch my phone because I wouldn't want to God forbid... 'embarrass' you."

*Sulkingly throws phone into purse* 

Mr. NSS: "Damn, is it that time of the month again?"

Me: Excuse me?!?! *EVIL EYE*

So we ate in silence. Complete silence for 90 minutes.

La Ciccia is an absolute neighborhood gem in San Francisco's Noe Valley. Fitting about 35-40 people, it's a small intimate restaurant that's perfect for foodie dates and small group dinners (no more than a party of 5). 

La Ciccia serves purely Sardinian cuisine. Think Italian with a bit of Mediterranean flair. Like fine dining meets rustic home-style, comfort food, you can tell each dish was made with both precision and love. Everything was superb from start to finish. Don't forget to check out their Sardinian wine list (Pinot fans, try the 2010 Bruni 54 Colli Maceratesi Azienda Agricola La Montata). Service was just as fantastic as the food; very warm, genuine and attentive by all the staff members. 

We started with the Octopus Stew in Spicy Tomato Sauce ($13) which was filled with uber tender octopus in a deliciously thick dark and comforting tomatoey sauce perfect for dipping the crusty bread into. I also enjoyed the Tripe Stew ($12) which was a special appetizer of the night. Rich and hearty, the stew had an abundance of buttery soft honeycomb tripe. Think Italian rendition of menudo but so MUCH better; I never had such soft tripe before. 

We silently shared entrees as well. My Seared Lamb Tenderloin ($26) was perfectly cooked to a medium rare, sliced and drizzled with cooked grape must (syrup). The lamb tenderloin was the best I've had; delicately tender and a bit gamey with lovely licorice, caramel and coffee notes from the grape must. He had the Oven Roasted Whole Wild Prawns ($26) which were four jumbo prawns that were halved and showered with a mouth-watering garlic parsley sauce that was given a nice kick from the pepperoncino. 

He doesn't care for dessert but I was "PMSing" according to him so that gave me an even better excuse to splurge on the Ricotta and Saffron Cake ($8) which was like a super moist and crumbly sponge cake topped with lip-smacking honey and crunchy sliced almonds. I was annoyed with him enough to even order the Assorted Gelati of the Night ($8) which showcased their divine homemade ice cream.  Rum, chocolate and figs and goat cheese (my favorite) were the flavors of the night. (I tell you, there's nothing like hitting a guy in the jugular by inflating the dinner bill even more. *Hmmmph*)

*Mr. NSS comes back from the bathroom*

Mr. NSS: "Did you check FB?"

Me: "No, now WHY would I do that?!?! You want me to 'embarrass' you?"

Mr. NSS: "Just check it...please."

Me *grunts*: "Ugh, fineeeee."

*Grabs phone and checks FB*

https://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/photo/6v1WNo_vmIQ7EP9n4njG_A/l.jpg

*HEART MELTS*

Nothing like good food bringing couples "back" together. 

Thank you, La Ciccia!
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Had a wonderful dinner at La Ciccia! Started with the octopus then had a fettuccini pasta special which was delicious. Then I had a sea bass type fish special with an olive tamponade and my husband had the shrimp. Both very tasty and the sauces were perfect. The only downside was the service. Our waitress,Flori, was pretty much vacant during the whole meal. No one checked in to ask how our meal was either. I think the staff helps each other out,but she was vacant except for the very beginning and the very very end with the check. Service should be at a notch above what we experienced especially when we spend $100 each.
author: Brian M.

description:
Amazing food and service. No wonder they are so difficult to get a reservation. You may only get your reservation a few weeks out or sometime late night. But DO IT because it's totally WORTH IT.  

I had the octopus stew for appetizer. This is the best octopus dish I've ever had. It could be a bit too heavy as an appetizer, but oh my, the flavor of the stew was unforgettable. I could have had a whole bowl of it. I would come back to the restaurant just to have this stew.

For my second course, I had the squid ink pasta. Sometimes I find squid ink pasta a bit too fishy, but their sauce was well balanced in flavor and the home made pasta definitely gave the dish an additional layer of flavor and pleasant texture.

As my main dish, I had the pork loin. This dish didn't have as much impact as the first two, but there was nothing bad to say about the dish. Plus I was getting full by the time my main dish was served, so I guess I couldn't enjoy the dish as much as I would have - i.e. the portion of their food was pretty generous considering the quality of the food, which to me is a good thing.

Servers were friendly and attentive. Quick serving and cleaning tales, and yet they did not give us the feeling of being rushed.

Awesome!
author: K N.

description:
Great Place, good food, good service. Interesting food.  Took a while to realize the menu isn't in Italian.   Not heavy, gloppy Italian food, good quality food done right, (though I'm not really sure what is right as it applies to Sardinian food this being the only time I've ever eaten it)

It's a great place, and the staff really makes you feel at home.
author: Dennis N.

description: authentic food, well prepared, great wine list.  Well worth the price!
author: B W.

description:
I LOVE La Ciccia! best italian restaurant in SF!
The ambiance is perfect and the staff super friendly and helpful :)
author: Dorinda L.

description:
Went here with 2 girlfriends who had lived with me in Italy a number of years ago- we'd heard great things from fellow friends who had lived in Rome, so we were excited to trek out to La Ciccia and enjoy a Saturday night meal. 

Right as we walked in, we noticed it was warm (actually warm, temperature-wise). It was inviting after walking in the cold, but the heat did seem a bit much once we sat down at the table and throughout the dinner. I imagine this is because the place is small and the kitchen gets hot. The ambiance however was great - the decor is upscale but doesn't overdo it - the tables have simple white linens and flatware; The walls and decor are minimal and the vibe is intimate and authentic. 

The staff was absolutely wonderful. Everyone was approachable and friendly, especially when walking us through food and wine pairings for dishes we were unfamiliar with. Our waiter was charming and attentive to us, and even at the end of the meal when the ceiling started leaking (long story short, an upstairs neighbor fell asleep in their bathtub and caused the ceiling to leak into the restaurant), the staff kept their cool and stayed positive throughout! 

Regardless of the ceiling mishap, the food was amazing. We split 1 appetizer, 2 pasta dishes and a dessert, as well as bread and wine. It was definitely enough food for three women. We ordered:

Bread + Olive Oil - The olive oil tasted light and fresh. The bread was dense and soft in the middle, it reminded me of being back in Italy. They make their own bread in-house and import the olive oil, so it was authentic and delicious. I wish I hadn't eaten so much of it up-front though, because I could have used it later to dip more in the stew and sauce! 

Baby Octopus Stew - The octopus was so, so tender. It was cooked well in a red sauce that wasn't too acidic. It was kind of hard to finish the sauce because we didn't have spoons or bowls, but it was great for dipping bread into (and I would have finished it all if I could!). This one is a must-order for sure. 

Spaghetti with Fish Roe - This was recommended by everyone, both by yelpers and word of mouth. Our waiter split it up for us and plated it at the table, which was a nice personal touch. The flavor and texture (the roe added nice texture) of the pasta was amazing, and the noodles were cooked perfectly. The lingering creamy flavor at the end of each bite was perfection, and it lived up to the reviews. 

Sea Urchin Fettuccine - We were skeptical of ordering this because of the urchin, but we ordered it after seeing the table next to us eating it... and it was my favorite dish of the night! They actually puree the urchin into the sauce so it's more approachable, and the sauce is red with some sort of cream in it (so it's not as acidic as plain tomato sauce). I savored every bite, and also dipped my bread in this one too. Would highly recommend this. 

Lemon Ricotta Cake - This was actually not a cake in a traditional sense, but it was great nonetheless. It was more of a lemon ricotta mousse with almonds and honey on top - not overly sweet, it reminded me of baklava in it's nuttiness and texture. I'd order this again, though I was very full! 

Overall very happy with the meal, and would be more than happy to go back at a later date!
author: Claire S.

description: Getting a table here was quite difficult, which is strange; I had an easier time booking Coi than this place. it was worth it though, as the meal was wonderful, the wine selection and recommendations spot-on, and the price tag very much more palatable. I would definitely come back if it were easier to get in, and I did see a few spots at the bar, so I might just sneak back by myself one day and eat at the bar chatting with the staff.
author: Josh H.

description:
This is one of my favorite Italian restaurants in SF, and a hidden gem tucked away in Noe Valley. If you love pasta and seafood, this is the place for you.

The squid ink pasta ($17, Pasta Longa e su Nieddu de Seppia) is a definite must-have and one of the best squid ink pastas I've ever had. Price is reasonable and it has a rich flavor that is not salty, and the seafood and lemon finishing is perfect. The pasta noodles were chewy and fresh.

The salad ($9) was good, but nothing too memorable. I probably wouldn't get it again. My friend got the Camberonisi Arrustiusu ($26, Oven-Roasted Whole Prawns) and it was a bit of a pain to deshell and eat. 

I'm looking forward to coming back here again for more pasta! Make a reservation on OpenTable - you can usually get a table here a week in advance, but you'll most likely be out of luck if you're looking to walk in and get a table or book a table during the week you want to eat there.
author: Christina L.

description:
It was a very special treat having dinner at this place. We went out for my boyfriend's birthday (he had been to this place before and he picked it for his special day) and it exceeded all my expectations!! The food, the vibe, the cosiness and family feel of this place made it an exceptional night!! We ended up spending 3 hours devouring every single bite of our meals and every single sip of wine!! Everything we tried on the menu was perfection!!  Calamari with squid ink, baby octopus stew, the fish entree, seared lamb, and the recommended wine pairings!! And delicious ice cream with espresso to top it off!!
The staff was really nice and knowledgeable and what a treat it was to have the owner of the place stop by and chat with us!!
This place is above and beyond what I had expected! It was a truly authentic experience which will stay a special memory and I can't wait to come back!!
author: Irena S.

description: not worse the wait if you reserve it and is not worse $140 for a 2-people dinner. Very dissapointed
author: Ekaterina L.

description:
We came into La Ciccia with high expectations - my boss has raved about it for years for the amazing seafood and fabulous wine list. The exterior looked super-cute tucked into a Noe street and the interior looked warm, cozy, and romantic. We thought we were in for a great night!

We were seated quickly. The next 2.5 hours, however, were not so smooth. Each of our group of 4 ordered three courses (app/first course, entrees, and desserts) as well as 1 bottle of wine & 3 glasses of wine between the 4 of us. We were well-dressed and excited for a celebratory dinner. However, throughout the dinner, we noticed that we basically got ZERO service from the staff. When we ordered the wine, I had asked for bread and the server coolly noted that "it will come with the food." It was downhill from there. My companions raved about the famous seafood stew, but I found the pasta first course to be a bit bland in texture/flavor. Before my friend had finished the seafood stew, the waiter came and cleared her plate even though she was still working on it. We thought that meant that the entrees were coming soon, but in fact we waited over 45 minutes for our entrees. We struggled to find a waiter to flag down to ask about our food. When we did, he said that the entrees would be out shortly. When they arrived, they were lukewarm and may have been sitting out for a while. The entrees were ill-balanced - 5 giant delicious shrimp heads but not much else on the plate. My husband got the steak with cauliflower which he said was forgettable. 

Meanwhile, we noticed that the two servers were totally being monopolized by two high-maintenance tables. They were chatting up the waitstaff for our entire dinner but unfortunately this caused them to neglect our table and many others. The experience was uncomfortable - we wondered, are we not getting service because we're too young? Not spending enough money? Not older and white? No establishment should have its patrons walk away feeling like that. 

We enjoyed delicious panna cotta for dessert and the check came. Throughout the meal, there was no apology for the poor service. I wanted to love this place, but I found the service poor and the food to be average for the high price. We will not be returning unfortunately.
author: S. L.

description:
One of my favorite Italian restaurants in SF....  As usual, I have ordered spicy Octopus for appetizer and squid ink pasta (sadly I can't remember the official names for these dishes).  
This place is not trying to be hip and modern.  It still keeps the feel of neighborhood to it.  The menu probably hasn't changed for years.  But if it works, why change....  Good to see something or some place remain the same in this fast moving city.  

Thank you La Ciccia for another wonderful meal!
author: June K.

description: I am sardinian and I love my region food. La ciccia is an authentic gem. I loved the spaghetti bottarga (shouldn't be that spicy though) and all the starters. I am so glad to have found la  ciccia. A bit pricey but good value
author: Giulia S.

description:
Better than the reviews!  Probably one of the best meals I've ever had, and right here in Noe!  We went for my birthday a few weeks back and because we didn't know how popular/good this place was, we didn't get to make reservations until the day before (ie, at 9:30/9:45pm) but had no problem on Open Table and when my husband called directly, they got us in at 9:30.

The ambiance:  Adorable and tiny, but not stuffy.  Probably 16 tables, all close together so watch your wine when the water is talking to the table next to you so he doesn't knock it over :)

The food: Out of this world. We started with that octopus stew and it was so good that I grabbed the bowl from my husband and was practically licking it (yes, in public..it was THAT good).  He got the lamb (yum, but too rare for me) and I got the fish (light and flavorful).  For my bday he surprised me with the trio of gelato and OMG, the goat cheese and the madeira (or was it marsala - IDK) were sooooo good. There was also a chocolate one, but meh...not a chocolate person.

The service: We had this nice waiter (Michael?  Rick?) and he and the entire team were attentive without being in our faces the entire night.  

The wine: I don't know Italian wines, so I explained what I like (a nice Zin) and he was spot on. Same for hubby, who started with white and then had a red...spot on.

The price: Not sure, it was my bday, but I am guessing pretty pricey, but so worth it!

I would definitely recommend this place and plan to come back and bring friends.  10/10 for sure!
author: Sheryl K.

description: Actially, 3 1/2 stars.Wife and I had a rather mixed experience here despite the rave reviews.  We made a Saturday 6 PM reservation and when we arrived, it was already rather crowded (it opens at 5:30 PM0.  We were seated promptly and the service was initially quite prompt and solicitous.  We started with roasted calamari which were quite delicious with wonderful sauce, and also their special arugala and tomato salad which was fresh.  We also had the baby octopus stew, which had a rather thick tomato sauce- wife liked it a great deal, for me it was a little too tomato thick.  Wife had their special lightly broiled Norwegian salmon, which was wonderful, but my Sardinian fregula (VERY small droplets of pasta)  with sea urchin and shaved tuna heart was again in a very thick and sour tomato sauce almost completely obliterating other flavors- the tomato sauce here is VERY thick, which I did not know.  We also had their Sardinian flat bread with evoo and pecorino, which was wonderful- light and crispy and cheesy.  We also had a small portion of their extra virgin olive oil, which was fine, but not outstanding.  As the evening progressed, the restaurant became very crowded and noisy and the service slowed down to a crawl- about 30 minute wait between the last of the appetizers and the long-awaited arrival of the main course.  They have a very extensive wine list and some artisanal Sardinian beer- I enjoyed the "diavolo."  Overall, an interesting mixed dining experience, but we will probably be back for the calamari, flat bread, and some other of their interesting dishes sans tomato sauce.
author: Hoyle L.

description:
Authentic Sardinian, with a menu that's written with Sardinian dialect. Good sign!

Squid and the fish soup were so tasty I would've licked the plates. 

Pasta is a must try! Sardinian pasta is a unique style, different from any other regions in Italy.
author: Yuchi C.

description: Very nice pasta and flavors. good for a special occasion. Unlike any other Italian food I've ever had.
author: Lee X.

description:
La Ciccia is family owned and operated Italian restaurant on the edge of Noe Valley in San Francisco.  The husband and wife team, Massimiliano Conti and Lorella Degan serve regional Italian cuisine from the island of Sardinia.  

We've been anxious to try La Ciccia for several months.  Reservations through OpenTable have been hard to come by, but we finally got in last night.   Street parking can be challenging in the area so budget some extra time for finding a spot.  

The restaurant's understated exterior and quiet street belie the bustling scene once you walk inside.  We were surprised to see that every table was occupied save the one where we were to be seated.  The atmosphere was vibrant and the aromas gave insight into the delicious meal that was soon to follow.

Here's what we ate:

Calamarusu Arrustiusu (Oven Roasted Monterrey Calamari drizzled with basil Oil)   $13

Prupisceddu in Umidu  (Octopus stew in a spicy tomato sauce) $13

Pizza Special - Salame and Arugula

Pasta Special - Ravioli with Ricotta and Lemon Zest in Tomato Sauce. $17

Pezza de Angioni a sa Saba  (Seared Lamb Tenderloin drizzled with cooked Grape must)  $26

Camberonisi Arrustiusu (Oven Roasted Whole Wild Prawns Garlic Parsley Pepperoncino) $26

Overall, we were happy with every dish.  In several cases, the simple flavors of olive oil, vinegar, and citrus left us wanting more complexity.  Our sense was that the food was often simple but authentically Sardinian.  The dishes that really stood out were the one's with more spice and complexity - the Octopus and Lamb.  The Pizza was very good as well.

The service felt a bit rushed and abrupt at the beginning of the meal.  Possibly just authentically European as well.  By mid way through, we had our server Petra warmed up and enjoyed getting to know her better the rest of the evening.  The prices seem slightly high for the portion size and simple ingredients.  

Please click on the link above to view my photos.  La Ciccia asks that guests not take pictures of the food which seems out of touch with the modern social dining community here in San Francisco.  I'm sure they were thrilled to see my big Nikon D800 sitting on the table all night.  Anyway, I took one for the team, so enjoy the photos.

If you are looking for authentic regional Italian cuisine, La Ciccia is a great choice.  It's a little slice of Sardinia in a San Francisco neighborhood gem.
author: J.D. B.

description:
How did people get all these pictures.  On the menu, it states no cameras or cell phones.  I was sad because I wanted to document my meal!  It was excellent.  I am not a huge fan of italian food but La Ciccia was a delicious surprise. I almost wished I had tried more things on the menu because they all sounded delicious

We started with Sardinan flatbread.  It is like a chip, thin, crispy, cheesy. We also had an appetizer of the day which was a shrimp. I don't remember what kind of shrimp they were or what the sauce was but it was delicious.  The shrimp meat was tender and fresh and the sauce had a bit of spice but did not overpower. We also had a giant plate of salume of the day which was proscuitto. 

We then moved on the pastas or primusu or first courses.  We tried the special pasta which was a fettucine with ragu of veal and pork.  The pasta was so fresh.  it was perfectly cooked and was the perfect consistency for the sauce.  We also had a spaghetti with squid ink and lemon sauce.  That was also delicious.  It was lighter than expected and the lemony tartness was a good complement for the dark sauce.  We were also hoping we had room for the salt cod roe pasta or the sea urchin tuna heart pasta.  maybe next time

We then shared one main or segundusu. It was a sea bream with olives and zucchini underneath. Also light and delicious.
author: claudia y.

description:
5 stars just for the Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga!
(Fresh Spaghetti with spicy oil and bottarga)
author: Helen Y.

description:
A great neighborhood place where bottariga and squid ink party down!

2nd visit to La Ciccia, after way too long of a wait.  A warmly welcoming experience with very high standards.... La Ciccia is a gift to San Francisco.

Incredible wine list, a whole page of fine print.  Bring your readers and enjoy.  

Daily adventures are excellent. We sampled a rabbit confit with a fine pasta and a reduction and baby octopus in a rich tomato-based broth.  The confit had a symphony of flavors going on from a slight smoky note to a little bit of heat on the finish.  Very very nice.  The octopus was served in broth that if featured in a blues song, would make the lame dance and the sick healthy. The octo was slightly overcooked but totally enjoyable.  Had to order more bread to "honor" the broth and reinforce the boiler (for you Kruk and Kuip fans).

Contorni, verdure - eatcha vegebles kidz, not because Mama said so but because you LIKE them.  On offer was "braised cabbage"... a wholly insufficient label.  I had a premonition this would be good. Well, more like great.  Tender, and succulently sauced but not covered up.

We both ordered bottariga... it is so essentially great, a perfect poem of garlic, butter, just-right al dente pasta and the unique flavoring and texturing of the bottariga.  So glad that La Ciccia keeps this delight on the menu.  It took a lot of willpower (and the extra boiler bread) to set aside some for next-day enjoyment.

We're not big on dessert, but the gelato trio was seductive.  A tangy fig-goat cheese creation flanked a chocolate hazelnut centerpiece, with a delicate vanilla-marsala rounding out the hat trick.  A really nice composition!

The owners really made us feel welcome and comfortable, like being part of a family you'd want to be adopted by.  It's rare to see such high standards in creativity and execution matched with such genuine warmth.  A gem.  Bravo!
author: Bob K.

description: Amazing Sardinian food and wine in an intimate but casual setting. Have every Squid and Octopus dish they a offer!
author: Hari J.

description:
Went to La Ciccia at the recommendation of a friend and gourmet. It was just stupendous! 
Place is small and a little noisy, as a neighborhood restaurant ,but the service and food makes up for that.
The portions are large ( you might consider sharing an appetizer) and tasty and prepared to perfection. Try the lamb and the fish. Don't skip the opportunity to sample the flat bread which is unlike any others. Ask the waiter for help with a wine selection as there are many different choices that do not often appear on wine lists.
Reservations are a must. 
Note that the location is a little out of the way but a simple trip on the J train will get you to the front door.
I write this as an Italian too who knows a little about Italian food! 
You will not be sorry.
author: Sil O.

description:
Waiting game.

Love Andy Caldwell's version: http://open.spotify.com/track/4bDzhaHprZrXSvg30NyHpA

Irritated by La Ciccia's version: Twenty minute wait for our table. Another twenty for our order to be taken. Thirty minutes for bread. Twenty between finishing and the bill.

Things happen. An apology here or a complimentary glass of wine there would have gone a long way. Neither occurred.

Which made little things like water glasses that were hastily filled yet not placed in front of us and an out of place air dryer in the bathroom more noticeable.

Fortunately the food worked hard. Octopus stew was plentiful and rich with tomatoes and spice. Roasted calamari chewy and tasty. Squid ink linguine almost worth the wait.

Everything was a reasonable $10 - $20 appetizer/pasta and $25 - $30 entree price. Wine seemed expensive at $40+ bottle but this isn't my area of expertise. Hope it's worth it.

All said had we waited longer my 83-year-old grandmother might have turned another year older. There is no telling how much longer she'll be around for grandkid nights out.

Let's not waste her time. Or mine. Or yours.
author: Jason B.

description:
What a great place.  A couple of months ago I went there for my birthday dinner while I was in SF for some hospital tests.   Reservations are a near must, but we got in by chance when they opened at 5:30.  Often you have to reserve a month in advance.

This is a Sardinian restaurant and it is cozy and family run.  Typically I ordered a bowl of olives and they were the best I ever had.  We shared dishes of a smoky/spicy octopus stew (absolutely superb), very lightly oven roasted calamari (sublime), a nice seasonal green salad, homemade pasta with a veal and prosciutto ragu and we finished with a tray of 3 different gelatos. They were fig with balsamic, chocolate hazelnut and another fruit based one I cannot recall.  Light Italian mineral water.

Reasonably priced, excellent service.  One of the best meals of my life.
author: David G.

description:
I used to eat more pasta than before (gluten sensitivity). I had the fish when I first ate dinner here, and it was above average, very little seasoning; in other words, fresh.
The wine was alright, but what I enjoyed the most was the atmosphere. Never encouraged to leave, or speed up; the staff embraces everyone like family. It's cozy and warm and lively until closing. And I hear, for those who eat more pasta, that this is where they shine.
author: Kristina B.

description: Ate here a while ago for dinner after hearing about it. The food is flavorful and strong and special. Service is great. Setting is intimate but casual works. Overall, an amazing and memorable experience!
author: Jon C.

description:
Wish they would have told me the portions were huge. If so, I wouldn't have $40 worth of leftovers in the fridge. I was expecting much smaller portions and would have adjusted my order accordingly if I had known.
Not sure why people think the octopus stew is so good. The pork was pretty boring. The pasta was the best part and I found the sauce very comparable to my own italian sauce. Not worth the $97 I dropped tonight, that's for sure. Disappointed.
author: Oriane R.

description:
Absolutely amazing what else can I say.  We had a great meal here with some friends and everything we had was fantastic.  At the end the staff said they were actually surprised with how much we ordered and that we all finished it too.  

I think we ordered each special since they sounded so good and they really were.  The service was great too.  Order a sampling of small and large plates and share.  Best way to get a little taste of everything.
author: Blake B.

description:
Just your usual intimate neighborhood joint, serving up consistently delicious Sardinian specialties. 

I have had the good luck to have dined at La Ciccia several times over the years, and it is always such a treat.

This is not your average red sauce, checkered tablecloth Italian restaurant (that's a different review).  But if you don't mind your protein being a little off-the-beaten-path, the folks at La Ciccia have a deft hand with non-glamorous sea beasts and their parts (octopus, tuna heart, roe... mmm!).  Don't forget your reading glasses for the wine list - the tiny print hides a lot of regional Italian gems.

Dessert was a little plate of house-made nougat.  Just a tad sweet, pleasantly chewy, and the perfect way to end a memorable dinner.
author: Audrey L.

description: This is a small restaurant that has ample staff to attend to questions, suggestions.  Cannot wait to go back.
author: John K.

description:
Incredibly full-flavored...the fish roe pasta: supreme. 

The service, though relaxed, is absolutely spot-on.

The waitstaff is extremely knowledgeable.

The owner orchestrates the entire environment from the cuisine and the kitchen to the decor to the staff to the diner: and it shows, in spades. This is a true, fulfilling, dining experience.

An added plus: no phones or photography allowed!
author: lance l.

description:
I went here with a group of friends, and we loved our evening here!  The waiters were extremely friendly and welcoming, and the atmosphere was warm.  I had a tasty salad, salumi of the day, delicious spaghetti with meat ragu (house-made sausage, beef...), a flat bread with pecorino mmmm, and at the end some Sardinian cheeses and honeys.  (I'm a honey freak, and these were delightful)  We all split a few bottles of an elegant yet powerful Sardinian wine (Tanca Farra).

Would happily return my next time in San Fran!
author: Mark H.

description:
Hey SF peeps, you know this place is great, so forgive if I'm going to write this review for my Italian Expats Friends!

Gli Spaghetti con la Bottarga non si battono. Lorella e Massi sono veramente fantastici. C'hai presente l'atmosfera in cui ti senti a casa appena entri? Si mangiia bene, si beve bene con una lista di vini molto interessante.

Cucina sarda di grande qualita', quanto vorrei avessero un giardino dietro dove scavare una buca e fare il porceddu come fanno in Gallura,

Andateci non ve ne pentirete.
author: Riccardo F.

description:
What I ordered : squid ink pasta, the gnocchetti, baby octopus in spicy tomato sauce and a tripe stew. 

What I must get again : the tripe, absolutely amazing, tender and extremely flavorful. Featured as a special appetizer added onto the menu for the night, I was definitely impressed by the wonderful authentic Italian flavor this dish had. 

After studying abroad in Italy for three months, I know what authentic Italian food is the La Ciccia took me back to Italy for the night. The flavors were on point in terms of being flavorful but not too overpowering. It had the right amount of sauce, not completely drenching the pasta. The gnocchetti wasn't the usual squishy soft gnocchetti I get everywhere else but had an amazing texture to every bite. The baby octopus was absolutely amazing as it came in a nice spicy tomato broth. The squid ink pasta had a wonderful lemony taste to it and for the first time since Italy, squid ink pasta actually tasted a bit like squid. Everything was done wonderfully, and the truffles they offered us at the end of our meal wasn't half bad either! 
 
What I loved most was the amazing service! All the waiters had amazing hospitality and asked us once every 20 minutes if we liked the food. And like any authentic Italian meal, be prepared to stay and sit for at least 2 hours! Highly recommend it and would definitely come back!!
author: Sharon L.

description:
Excellent Sardinian (regional Italian) food, with a strong focus on seafood - both fresh, and cured. Very good wine list.

On our most recent visit we had an arugula salad, a burrata special, mullet roe pasta and grilled prawns. The arugula salad and the prawns weren't particularly special, but the burrata was absolutely delicious and the mullet roe pasta was deeply flavorful.

We also very much appreciated the excellent (and very reasonably priced) wine recommendation from our waiter.

Food has also been excellent on prior visits.
author: Amy D.

description:
I made it back here 2 years later and it's still so good!  
My girlfriends & I shared several dishes:
Soup w/ Clams Mussels Calamari - good for dipping break
Octopus stew in a spicy tomato sauce - soo good!  and great for dipping!
Fresh Spaghetti with spicy Oil and Bottarga - all time favorite and can't find anywhere
Toasted Sardinian Fregola with Sea Urchin Tomato and Cured Tuna Heart
Fettucine w/ Lamb, Beef Tomato Sauce 
Ice cream trio: goat cheese & fig, chocolate and one other delicious one

Yum - I'd highly recommend their pastas.
author: Meredith K.

description:
This was a solid meal beginning with our suggested glasses of red and white wine to finishing with desserts.

First of all, we abided by the written request printed on the menu not to take photos of the food, but to me, taking photos is a tribute to the food and the essence of the chef's cooking. Oh well.

From the get go, we thought our server was rushing us through our meal.  As the evening went on, we discovered he was aiding us.  He was told by the hostess we had to get to a show.  We said no.  Big misunderstanding.  We thought he was pushy borderlining on being rude when he in fact was ensuring we would be on time for our next engagement.  We all had a good laugh.

For starters the four of us went with -
*the octopus stew - spicy in great tomato sauce
*the roasted calamari in olive oil - yummy
*the flatbread - very thin and crispy and lots of flavor

For our main entrees, three of us went with the wild trout (aka steelhead salmon) dinner special while the fourth went with the bream.  We also wanted to try the fregola pasta with squid ink so the server said he'll bring with our entrees.

Get the pasta!  Was like tiny round pellets.  Don't eat as your entree.  Very heavy but yummy.  Went well with our fish special.

For dessert, our server suggested the three scoops of gelato and the saffron cake.  Get the cake if you like spongy eggy yellow cake.  I loved it.

It was a great meal and we  were actually there 2 1/2 hours.  

Tab inc tax & tip $67 p/p.
author: Shirley N.

description:
This is a neighborhood restaurant for us. It is small and quaint. I also like how they have a curtain at the front of house to prevent drafts from coming into the restaurant.
