We've been told that this is a favorite by many. Maybe it was the hype and the fact that I could only make 5:30 pm reservations weeks out in advance, but my husband and I came out of it disappointed. 

The hostess was very friendly. I had to call and push my reservation back by an hour and she was very accommodating. The server I don't remember being as hospitable. They were nice enough, but certainly nothing that stood out for what seems like a family-owned restaurant. 

I had the squid ink pasta. Perhaps I was expecting the pasta to be made from the squid ink, but instead it was just stirred in with the squid. I felt by serving it this way it took away from the strong flavors of the squid. It was just another seafood linguine dish this way. 

My husband had the risotto. It was good, but I didn't go back for seconds (and I normally "share" from his plate a lot). 

We did try the appetizer specials that day - Sardines. They were absolutely delicious. 

As a warning, this is not your typical Italian restaurant. It is Sardinian, so the flavors and the takes on food are a little bit different. 

Glad we finally tried it after eyeing it for a year, but don't think we'll be racing back.
author: Winny F.

description:
Overall: cute place for Sicilian food

Pros
- squid ink pasta, *drool*
- octopus stew, I'm a chicken when it comes to spice but this had great flavor
- gnochetti

Cons
- spaghetti with bottarga, not my cup of tea


Sidenote
- bread comes with no olive oil, that's extra $
- portions are big
- pasta with uni and tuna heart definitely has that ocean-y taste
author: Michelle D.

description:
Delicious!

This place is such a gem. It's cozy, but not obnoxiously cramped. The service was also excellent. The server gave us two great glasses of wine when we had no idea what to choose.  I would totally come back here! The prices are decent and the food is remarkable. 

Baby Octopus in Spicy Tomato Stew: probably the favorite dish of the evening. The octopus was tender and the stew it came in was just a phenomenal taste bud sensation. How is it possible to make something this tasty? It was packed with flavor, had just the perfect amount of spice without being overly salty. I wanted to lick the plate clean!

Pasta dishes: Fusilli with smoked trout, fava bean and Rigatoni with veal ragu. The pastas were cooked perfectly and the sauces were just amazing. 

Wild Shrimp with Squid Ink: the shrimp was cooked perfectly and tasted juicy and sweet. 

We were also impressed with the saffron ricotta cake with almonds. It was light and fluffy and infused with the aromatic, almost floral flavor of saffron.
author: Amber M.

description: This restaurant located in an unassuming neighborhood was a little hard to find. It blended in with all the home nearby. I almost walked past it. I arrived at 8:30pm and was seated without reservations on a Saturday night. The place was pretty full and had only 1-2 tables vacant. We shared the seafood soup which I thought was salty and the anchovy salad which I liked but my hubby had to pass because it was too fishy for him. We ordered the uni pasta and the fish roe spaghetti. The uni pasta tasted like tomato sauce quinoa and was not great which left me disappointed. I was really looking forward to this dish and was the reason I came. The fish roe spaghetti was the highlight for dinner. It was very tasty and I ate every bite. Perfect combination of garlic, olive oil, and fish roe and didn't taste fishy at all. Their recommendation for white wine by the glass was good too. I had a few glasses my waitress recommended and enjoyed them. Nice restaurant for a date night but the place is cramped. Don't expect to have any personal conversations because the table next to you can probably hear. Oh and they have a no taking pictures of your food rule but don't think any one listens haha.
author: Wendy L.

description: It's not like La Ciccia needs anymore raving reviews but here i go.  This place is seriously a gem, not only because the food is amazing beyond comprehension but also because the staff make you feel like you're part of their family.  The chef and his wife are absolutely incredible and extremely friendly.  It seems that almost everyone there is from Sardinia so it definitely has an authenticity to it.  As for the food, well everything is absolutely delicious! My favorite so far has been the botarga pasta and the sea urchin risotto! yum yum yum! If you can snag a reservation for this place you must go because your taste buds will thank you immensely.
author: Krystal L.

description:
Thank you, dear waiter, for suggesting the perfect wine to complement our food choices.

Thank you, dear baby octopuses, for sacrificing your little lives to be smothered in one of the best spicy tomato sauces I've had in my life.

Thank you, owner and chef, for giving us a taste of Sardinia in Noe Valley. I've never had Sardinian food before, but it's quite incredible. Very fresh, very healthy.

What a nice surprise! Great food, pleasant atmosphere, reasonable prices. This is why I love San Francisco: finding a neighborhood gem at which you simply want to try everything. 

Came as hungry as a bear after winter. Left as plump as an IT worker after Diwali. I highly recommend La Ciccia.
author: Russell H.

description:
We finally got to try La Ciccia after reading many good things about this place.  I thought it was just ok.  We took the J Church Muni & it stops right by the restaurant.  It's on 30th & Church.

I made reservations via Opentable, they had my table but it didn't say reserved on it and it wasn't by a window - bummer.

Place is small and a bit cramped.  

FREE bread but not tasty ones.  No FREE olive oil.  There's a $2 charge, so we didn't get any.  

We tried:

1. fresh sardines sauteed in EVOO, garlic, parsley & bread crumbs $9 - 3 sardines, I thought they were fine, they leave them whole w/ bones & head - be careful.

2. bottarga pasta w/ garlic, EVOO $16 - small portion since it's First Course-really enough for 1, but we shared it since we weren't that hungry.  A bit too al dente & doughy, fish egg flakes when all mixed in didn't have much taste, though was creamy.

3. side of veggie B. picked cabbage $5 - fine for me, B. thought it was very salty.

4. seafood salad w/ lemon oil dressing $12- very tasty w/ lots of calamari, shrimp, mussels.  This was good.

5. assorted artisanal gelati $8 - 3 different scoops were goat cheese w/ fig, saffron, & marsala w/ raisin.  All were fine.

6. B. got a glass of wine $8 - he liked it.

Another table got the $2 olive oil (small amount on plate) & then he wanted to buy a bottle.  The lady owner asked the chef (her husband/owner) & customer was able to buy 1 bottle for $15 + tax.  So if u like the olive oil, ask to buy one - maybe they'll sell it to u.

I had a $20 gift certificate so my bill was $43.51 before tip!  That was great.  They take credit cards.

One unisex bathroom in the back.

Hrs: Tues-Sun 5:30-10p
author: Ann L.

description: Fantastic Sardinian cuisine. We started with the pani guttiau and prupisceddu in umidu, which were both excellent. Next, we had the spaghittusu, fregua, and malloreddus. All three were among the best pasta dishes I've ever had, especially the fregua, which tasted strongly of sea urchin and was absolutely fantastic. Finally, we had the market fish, which unfortunately I can't remember the name of, but it too was top notch. The wine selection was great as well: absolutely massive selection, and the one we had (I believe the capichera) was rich, smooth, and wonderful.
author: William P.

description: Three stars for food but adding one for our waiter. I can't remember his name but English guy with glasses. He REALLY knew the all-Italian wine list and got us two exceptional bottles. Regarding the wine program they utilize my favorite corkage policy - buy a bottle get a bottle of corkage waived - very civilized. Food - the calamari was prepared perfectly, tender, but frankly just bland. I tried the fish roe pasta and that was just okay. The salume was excellent. My main was the grilled fish and the best part of that dish was the tapenade and the chard - the fish was simply overcooked. The star of the show for me was the octopus soup - great flavor! All in all too expensive for what you get, they need to raise the game to justify the prices.
author: Michael L.

description:
Food was great and different, and prices average (well, maybe better than average) for SF.

Don't really have more to add to the other reviews regarding the excellent dishes.

But I think we struck out in the server department (thus 3 instead of 5 stars).   Our server, Phillip, seemed arrogant and brash.  Before making reservations, we had heard about the warmth of the restaurant's owners and staff, so were disappointed that we were stuck with the one (hopefully) waiter with a bad "attitude."   

In addition to addressing us throughout the meal in a patronizing and dismissive manner, Phillip abruptly removed our appetizer plates (to make room for our entrees) without first asking if we were finished with the food remaining on them.  It was very unprofessional.

If we come back (for the food), just hope we are served by someone other than Phillip.
author: Jane D.

description: Nice mom-pop shop type restaurant. Good service. The octopus soup was tasty, but rest of it was OK - we ordered the sardinian bread, fish roe pasta and saffron cake (which was interesting)
author: Ashutosh T.

description:
I say: order the Bottarga + the white wine they pair with it. 

Stir it up when it arrives, and as you take in a forkful of this simple yet complex most traditional Sardinian dish, understand just a little more: Love of the Sea. Then, taste your wine - which echos the elements of the pasta - and appreciate that this unique pairing exists in San Francisco.

The waitstaff was so engaged and thoughtful - from finding the perfect glass for the bouquet of flowers we carried in, to snipping the bottoms and then arranging them at the table - they were equal parts extraordinarily kind, and real. Eye contact and presence was appreciated. 

If you don't order the Bottarga (which you should) ask for a wine recommendation with whatever you order - they will know the perfect glass to match. 

Thank you La Ciccia!
author: Maria A.

description:
Do you like delicious Sardinian/Italian food served to you in a cozy neighborhood place where the service is excellent? Oh, you do, eh?

La Ciccia has become my favorite restaurant in San Francisco and has taken the top spot on the podium. It's a bit hard to get a reservation, but the small restaurant will NOT disappoint your foodtastic cravings.

La Ciccia's wine list is packed with italian wines of every varietal - if you are looking for something specific, the knowledgeable staff can pair you up with something that will promise to meet your needs.

For restaurants like La Ciccia, it is the little things that make it standout. They always have a few daily fresh specials and the daily salume plate and fresh made in house ricotta / burrata will impress any one from the old country.

The pastas are my favorite place to focus my time. The #1 dish on the menu is easily the Spaghettini with the sea urchin roe. The thick and paste like sauce with it's spicy zip and light textures will drop the hammer on your taste buds.  My second fav is the gnocchetti and the squid in pasta. Both dishes are well balanced and packed with fresh flavors.

After every meal here, I walk out a satisfied guy with an immediate desire to return again ASAP!
author: Justin O.

description:
Pastas were decent but service was horrendous. Our waitress was rude and condescending. Even if our meal had been more memorable, it would have been overshadowed by the pathetic service. 

We really were looking forward to dining here, especially since we love so close by. We were disappointed and definitely will not return.
author: K V.

description: OMG so delicious. Tiny Italian place, very old school, a bunch of tiny tables crammed into a space with a bar. I loved it! The food was fantastic, the wine was delicious, service was prompt and friendly. We tried a bunch of dishes as a group of 4 people, and they were all good: octopus stew, calamari (which was literally huge pieces of octopus expertly cooked), the lamb was exquisite, the sea bass was excellent, the pasta ragu of the day was delicious, and the pasta our server recommended as their most popular (with asparagus) was solid but I'd try something else next time.
author: Tasha D.

description: another delicious, intimate experience at la ciccia!  the best seats in the house are at the bar. lovely meal and ambiance!
author: shana m.

description:
I can't say enough amazing things about this place. I can't believe we've lived down the street for 7 years and never went. I'm kicking myself now that I'm moving.

We're really spoiled for good food in San Francisco, and this is, hands down, the best meal I've had in five years.

Everything was incredible, the service was lovely, the owners both came and talked to us (they knew the friends we went with). Because one of the people at the table was a chef, she ordered and I set the menu down and simply ate. I chose nothing. The food just came and I enjoyed everything.

I've never cared for sea urchin, but it was delicious. All of the pasta dishes were terrific and I got to try Fregola and bottarga for the first time (the former is kind of like giant couscous, the latter is pressed fish eggs that are salted and shaved). Loved it all.

The wine was great, the food was fantastic, and the company was even better. 

Just go. It's not cheap, but you totally get what you pay for, amazing food, and great service. An wonderful romantic place for people who aren't afraid to say "sure, I'll try that."
author: Mike F.

description:
wow this place was expensive! $90 total for two people. App - spaghetti was size of a fist was NOT even al dente' took a bite , it was hard. yuck. Then the funny thing is in 20 mins i had to go to bathroom. 

some bread came - but asked waiter for butter. He said 'no butter' . HUH? REALLY? 

Ordered the 'pork chop' which i really liked but waiter said 'typo' NO PORK CHOP! i was sad. Only pork loin my main dish was salty. 

Things that annoy me: Waiters that kick my chair when they walk by and tables that are uneven (when i use my knife to cut I don't want the table to be shaking!)

I've experienced wayyyyy better restaurants for the price i've paid! I won't be back.
author: Thomas C.

description: My favorite restaurant. I love it here, authentic Sardinian food. We ordered the octopus stew, sea urchin pasta, and the lamb. We asked for a glass of wine to be paired with each dish.  The food was amazing, perfection. The wine pairings were perfect for each dish, their wine list even by the glass is quite extensive.  Service is great, everyone is friendly and has a great personality.  You feel like a guest vs a customer.   One thing is that they order everything fresh and daily.  I recommend trying for an early reservation as they will sometimes run out of their specials which are worth getting.
author: JJ B.

description:
BOOM!

This place definitely lives up to the hype, and here I thought we had pretty good Italian in Sydney! Staff were friendly, and I especially recommend getting dishes to share so you can have a taste of everything.

Recommendations: Octopus Stew and Gnochetti stood out for me.
author: Brian N.

description:
I really don't know where some people reviewed this restaurant comment that the waiters at this restaurant are rude???  Actually I found them all very friendly team with authentic Italian cuisine.
The  traditional spaghetti bottarga is one of the best spaghetti I ever eaten Excellent red win but the restaurant is very busy so it is a good idea to get a reservation before headind to La Ciccia other than that don't worry about the quality and test of the food and all  prices are very reasonable.
Love this place.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Din. Last min resi. Weeknight. 
Food: 4/5
Uni special pasta: 5. (Not tomato based main on menu). Amazing. 
Gnochetti with some tomato based meat sauce: 3.5. Plain, too salty
Wine pairings by waiter.
$93 post tip for 2.
author: Olivia Q.

description: Impeccable service and delicious food!  Ordered the lamb which was very tender, prawns were huge and enough to share between two people and spicy spaghetti w fish roe had enough spice with every bite. All dishes superb! Workers were extremely friendly with genuine smiles on their face and never let my glass run empty of whatever it was I was drinking. Enjoyed the dining experience and will be definitely be returning!
author: Jae S.

description:
My favorite restaurant in the city. Love the food, the people and the consistency. Amazing dining experience with Massimiliano and Lorella being always ready to make you feel at home. You can't go wrong with any choice here,- even though my favourites are the calamari, squid ink pasta, the bottarga pasta and the fish.
Enjoy!
author: Marios B.

description:
No I am not from San Francisco or even California, 

Where I am from Is Sardinia, Italy. Living in Dallas we are lucky to have some Sardinian restauranteurs here, and I enjoy exploring and discovering all the other Sardinians representing our food culture in America.

La Ciccia does it in class and style. The food here is a trip back home. When you step in through the doors you are no longer in San Francisco anymore.
Welcome to Sardegna! Buon Appetito!

You can not go wrong with anything you order I recommend anything with Bottarga, and the Malloreddus alla Campidanese my favorite dish as a kid.
author: Alessio A.

description:
In my one year living in SF, trying as many highly-touted restaurants as possible, La Ciccia is one of the TRUE 5-star ones in my book. It has such a neighborhood feel, with an incredibly friendly and knowledgeable staff, and lots and lots of repeat customers.

We started with the ricotta and arugula salad - the ricotta was the freshest I've had. We had the sardines (from Monterey, but they are a Sardinian must!), which were delicious. To drink, we had an Italian red from Calabria (one of the ~180 on the wine list) - excellent recommendation from the server.

The absolute highlight of the meal was our pasta (spaghetti with spicy oil and bottarga) - my fiance and I have not stopped talking about it. Perfectly cooked with fish roe, chili flakes, garlic and oil - truly a must-have.

The fish special was salmon with carrots and onions, which was very well done but nothing to write home about.

We made another reservation before leaving!
author: Julie I.

description: The only bad thing about this place is how hard it is to get a reservation. The food is awesome and the hosts are gracious. The Prupisceddu in Umidu cun Tomatiga appetizer is a great start to a wonderful meal.
author: Boris K.

description:
We went there the night before amateur night..... I mean valentines day. Which was great. 
First the wine selection is extensive but perfectly proper for their food. Ask for help if needed it can be overwhelming.
The food was simple and incredibly tasty. Of course the octopus stew was on point, well balanced flavors with a nice kick of spicy and perfectly tender. The calamari in basil oil was a great amount but needed to be seasoned a bit better. The fregola with uni and tuna heart was excellent definitely a dish to share. The lamb had a bit too much Saba and the shrimp was simple but well cooked. Semifreddo or more of a fullyfreddoo tasted like a snickers bar so good!!! But the ice cream was really hard. 
Service, was my favorite part. Petra you are awesome. She was funny and not fake at all which I always appreciate in a sever. 
Thanks Ciccia we will be back soon.
author: Estefany C.

description:
AMAZING!!! I came from Vallejo just to try this restaurant. I was not disappointed one bit. The food is fresh and very well prepared. You MUST order the zupetta!!! The gnocchi was insanely good! The chef gave me an anchovy on top of a dollop of ricotta with toasted almonds, which blew my mind. I ordered Sardinian beer which punctuated the meal very nicely. 

The staff are all great. Acomodating, generous, and attentive. They really made the meal fun for me. 

I met a delightful woman seated next to me at the bar who made my meal as enjoyable as the staff and the food.
author: billy v.

description:
I've been to Italy 3 times and stayed in Rome, Venice, Tuscany, Florence and Sicily. 
Of course, I have enjoyed the food everywhere and this place brings me back. 

La Ciccia serves authentic food from Sardinia and it is divine.
You really have to have reservation unless you want to risk sitting at the very small bar but usually they will have to turn you down. 

Some memorable highlights: 
Calamarusu Arrustiusu - just delicious 
(baby calamari with olive oil)
Fregua Sarda cun Arrizzonisi e Cori de Tonnu $18  
(Toasted Sardinian Fregola with Sea Urchin Tomato and Cured Tuna Heart)     

The service is top notch. Knowledgeable about the wine list without being snobby. 
This place is my all time favorite Italian seafood gem in San Francisco. 

Just make a reservation now and go and you will not regret it.
author: Kristina A.

description: Amazing dinner and service.  Can't wait to go back! Loved everything we had, but my favorite was the octopus stew.  It was a real pleasure eating here and well worth the long trip from SoMa.
author: Rob B.

description: Food taste great but 18 bucks for 4 ravioli's! C'mon man! One of those restaurants where you have to go to another place to eat after you eat dinner.  The bread filled me up.
author: Tony F.

description:
Wow the spaghetti and lamb tenderloin were amazing! That spaghetti, by far the best I've ever had. I was so impressed by the lamb. It is just bursting with flavor. The lamb was cooked medium rare and I highly recommend it that way. The crust on the bottom and the soft meat at the top make it a texture delight. 

The staff was top notch and the owners were so sweet! Our waiter was very informative and picked an excellent white wine for my fiancé and I. Clean, smooth and fruity taste without that dry finish. Although I did forget the name of the wine. 

The calamari was our appetizer and I would say it was good. It tasted very fresh but I just wanted a little bit more flavor. It was definitely nice to have the fish as the main focus but I still think they could of snuck in some more seasoning.

Desert was fantastic, lemon ricotta cheesecake...Delicious! Crunchy almonds on top, just ridiculous!
author: Rob B.

description:
Got a last minute spot here.
Everything was distinct and spot on delicious.
From the salad, to the calamari, to the fruity olive oil - we loved it.
We loved our helpful waitress and the expansive wine menu.
The sea bream was the highlight - a meaty, flavorful fish of the Gods.
author: Andrew K.

description:
WOW.

We managed to get seated as walk-ins, we just happened to show up when a reservation was a no-show, so we got their table!  Lucky us.

Everything was beyond delicious, especially the baby octopus stew.  I could have eaten 12 bowls of that stuff and been happy as a clam.

We were ordering mostly seafood, but we wanted red wine, and our waiter had an excellent suggestion for just that conundrum.  Excellent.

We were too full to have dessert so I can't say anything on that subject.

Bottom line: make reservations, order the baby octopus stew.  Now.
author: Rachel S.

description:
I am kicking myself for not eating here before now. Even better the picky French Spouse loved everything here and proclaimed the best meal they've had since we were in Barcelona a couple of months ago (putting it higher than their own native food in the south of France as well as Florence mind you that we've had since Barcelona).

While the French Spouse is quite familiar with Sardinian food, I was not and we took our server's suggestions and got Fregua Sarda cun Arrizzonisi e Cori de Tonnu $18  (Toasted Sardinian Fregola with Sea Urchin Tomato and Cured Tuna Heart) if I was a poet I would write a love sonnet to how wonderful this tasted. Being sea urchin it is like eating the sea so if that's not your thing skip it but I am fast learning I love the taste of sea urchin. Our second dish was the Spaghetti with peperoncini and fish roe $18.

What was so great about dishes were while the ingredients and preparation were simple, there was a great depth of flavour.

We started our meal with the Calamarusu Arrustiusu - just delicious
(baby calamari with olive oil) which was served with some dressed greens and was just right in terms of grilling and dressing

as well as some of the sardinian flat bread, crisp thin layer with a dusting of cheese and chives.

We finished the meal with 
-Truta de Arriscottu $8 (Ricotta and Saffron Cake served with honey and Almonds)  which was an excellent way to end the meal.

I really like how not trendy the decor was. The place was full and it was a bit hard to hear but there was enough light to see the menu easily and for ASL.

The tables were close together but we could still move around and it's accessible. The service was very helpful with picking our dishes and I was surprised by how quickly even with a totally full house our food came. Love how while the food is high quality, the atmosphere was relaxed and comfortable. Now to try the rest of the menu.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: My favorite Italian Bay Area restaurant.  Always fresh, great service.
author: Paul C.

description: This is my favorite Italian restaurant in San Francisco! A visit to San Francisco is never entirely complete without dining at this exquisite Sardinian Restaurant! Owner, Lorella, is fantastic, as are the wonderful, friendly and knowledgeable staff. The flatbread is a must, as are the delicious pasta dishes, always served perfectly al dente. The wine list is extremely rich and is an adventure in itself, so I always ask the helpful servers their recommendations to help pair the wine with the dishes.
author: William H.

description:
Calamari was good (sauce was fantastic when soaked up in bread), pasta was good, not great (mine also had a hair in it), and the ricotta / saffron cake with honey was fantastic (sponge-like, not too sweet, really unique flavors).

Service was completely unmemorable, space was clean - but not noteworthy otherwise.

Perhaps we hit an off night or perhaps our expectations were too high going in (because Yelp / Zagat / etc. reviews are so good) - but will probably not be going back.
author: Helen D.

description: Baby octopus stew was spicy and tensor. Seafood soup was so fresh. Great pasta and pork. Deserts were wonderful, too.  Reservation is necessary.
author: Roy Z.

description: I learned about this place from "Bay Area Check Please " show and I completely agreed with the guests on the show who recommended it .. Small out of busy SF, abit hard to find , but well worth the drive.. All the dishes were original, full of flavors and well presented .  Having travelled on my job to Italy and vacation near Naples region - I have to say the food is as good and fresh as you get there .  Had squid salad , pasta with shaved tuna heart and several other dishes .. Will bring friends back here for sure
author: Tom V.

description:
La Ciccia is one of those neighborhood gems that you brag about to your friends but on the other hand you wish it remained a secret so you can easily snag a table.  Well, the "secret" is already out and the place has always been full in the 5 years I've been in Noe.  I guess it's time for my review.

This is a small, intimate place where you are as likely to hear Italian as you are to hear English.  Nearly every time I've dined here I've felt like an American visiting Italy and the hostess and chef couple have enthusiastically greeted patrons like returning old friends.  These are all good signs.

One time I asked about the bottarga and the chef came out with a piece of his home cured mullet roe.  He sliced some off for me to sample and then spent the next 10 minutes discussing the minutia of making the perfect bottarga.  Legit.

It's hard to go wrong with this Sardinian menu.  A couple of favorites are the baby octopus braised in a spicy tomato sauce and the fregola with sea urchin and tuna heart (taste of the sea as the waiter called it).  This last dish packs quite the oceany punch. It might be too much for some, but if you love that distinct flavor... it doesn't get much better.

I can't wait for their sister enoteca to open.
author: Alan C.

description: I've never been to Sardinia but it felt truly authentic. I'm a picky eater but I loved my bottarga pasta dish. Hope to come back soon.
author: Josh L.

description: Not really sure what all the hype is about. Food was just okay here. We had the octopus stew, ravioli, squid ink pasta, and prawns. All were just okay and none I would order again. Disappointed.
author: Jenny L.

description:
This place is solid. 

Everyone raves about the octupus stew and the stew deserves the rave. i was afraid the texture of the octupus would be weird but it was perfect. it's flavorful and super tasty. We kept it on the table the entire meal because i kept using the bread to soak up my stew.

Everything else we had was pretty good as well. We asked for recommendations and tried a couple of pasta and the lamb. i don't normally like lamb since it can be gamy, but this was not. The sauce that accompanied the dish balanced the meat and veggies really well and there was a hint of sweetness.
author: Terry C.

description:
I won't be saying anything that hasn't already been said. La Ciccia is a great neighborhood restaurant with amazing food, wine and service. We were a group of four and collectively tried a wide range of their dishes. All were spectacular. 

We started with two starters, the burrata salad and roasted calamari. Both dishes were nicely done and yummy to dip their warm bread into.

I had to try one of their signature pasta dishes, the spaghetti with fish roe and pepperoncini and it lived up to expectations. It does have a little kick to it so my husband being senstitive to spicy food didn't try it. He and I split the prawns as our main dish - very very good and fresh. One of our friends had the rack of lamb as a main and he said it was the best lamb he's ever had.

Our server recommended a nice Sardinian red wine which complemented the meal. I had never had Sardinian wine before so his help to pick something out was very helpful. The wine is a little on the sweet side, very low tannins.

Oh and we loved the huge pile of olives that were complimentary before our meal.

Thank you La Ciccia, we'll be back soon!
author: Miki C.

description: Ambiance was horrible. Food mediocre at best.service that night was lame. 0 for 3. Not sure how it got the reputation as the gem of noe valley.
author: ashton a.

description:
Seriously?
We read the reviews and were really excited to have gotten a 7:30PM same day reservation on opentable. We literally ran to the restaurant to get there on time and then....  WTF? The food was crap. Boring crap. We were so excited to try the octopus stew. Crap. The fusilli with uni. Crap. All of it? Crap.  (except the wine, the wine was great). We had a long discussion about whether we tried La Ciccia on an off night, or whether you (the reviewers) are @#()$* morons. Sorry, but you're morons. There is far better Italian seafood in SF than this place.  We're not going back.

(edited to add that our server was very nice. clueless,  but nice.)
author: Da Wei S.

description:
The two of us had four dishes together: octopus stew, roasted sea bream, sardine over arugula and sea urchin pasta. Every dish was boring, boring, boring. The octopus in the famous stew was over cooked, and the flavor was one dimensional. The sardine and the other fish dish? Uninteresting, and, where was my sea urchin in the pasta? I couldn't see it, I couldn't taste it! 

Not going back.
author: C J.

description:
Amidst all these 5 star reviews, 3 stars might seem on the rude side, but it was - as yelp states - A-OK. 

My boyfriend and I came in for a special occasion, which I noted on the reservation. Could they save a spot for us on the more romantic side? The "more romantic side" turned out to be in the center of the restaurant, by the bar. We spent our dinner being bumped around by people trying to maneuver around us (and listening to the guy at the table next to us talk like a frat boy...ugh). Awkward. But ok, no big deal.

We ordered the specials (pancetta, ravioli) as appetizers, they were tasty. The shining star was my sea bass main entree. It was light, buttery and was brilliantly paired with my wine, as recommended by the server. My boyfriend and I agreed his lamb was "pretty good." 

Service was great, the hostess and our server were very welcoming and hospitable. I spilled some sauce on the white tablecloth and the server covered it up with a napkin so my sleeves wouldn't get dirty (aww)!

We didn't order the clear Yelp standouts, we blazed our own trail and it was still good. Timing between our dishes was on the longer side, but the restaurant was completely full. All in all, an A-OK experience.
author: Liz M.

description: Hands down my favorite restaurant in SF for food taste and quality. I have never been disappointed. I love the owners and the ambience and the fact that they are crowded and people are still coming in at 10 pm, even some older couples. I consider this a treat so I come here with my husband about once every 5-6 weeks.
author: Lynn R.

description: Yes the food is good, is authentic, but compared to European restaurants of this quality, this is a poor value.  Wines are overpriced.  Our third visit, first two were quite good; however, some of the dishes this time were boring.  Won't be back.
author: Eugene N.

description:
La Ciccia is uncomplicated and excellent.  The food here is simple - as I sampled the five or so dishes we tasted, what stood out most was the sensation that everything was where it should have been.  Nothing unnecessary.  The flavors were clean, and the ingredients high quality.

My favorite dish was a squid appetizer, perhaps the most simple of everything we tried.  We asked for wine recommendations from our server, and these too were delicious (and relatively affordable).  Eat here, especially if you like unadorned food.
author: Craig M.

description:
Oh my word delicious.

I am no Italian expert, and I'm vegetarian. However..

This was one of the best meals I've had in San Francisco. They were incredibly accommodating of vegetarians, had amazing food. Every bite I was making a sound. It may be that I know enough about what Italian/Sardinian food can be, but this was awesome.

Randomly, a bunch of italian wine vendors were eating there at the same time (for italian wine week or something?), it was quite an experience. Apparently they were from Sardinia, and had great things to say.

PLEASE visit. Note: there is very little parking, take taxi or J-Church.
author: Jeff M.

description: Great find.  Awesome seafood.  Great front of the house.  Good way to spend a Valentine's weekend.  Can't wait to go again!
author: angela l.

description:
La Ciccia???

How 'bout, 

 Laaa,,, Never going back!!


  On the drive home I found myself wondering, how on earth does La Ciccia have 4.5 stars on Yelp?? The only conclusion I could come to is that they must have, for a solid week, stood on the corner and passed out $100 bills, for in return, 5 star Yelp reviews from San Francisco citizens.

   Even more unexplainable is the fact that the octopus stew is on the 7x7 list!!?

   HOW IS THIS POSSIBLE?!  THIS PLACE MISSED THE MARK ON EVERYTHING.

Here's the recap:

   Octopus stew = Chewy sea creature, death by tomato soup drowning.

   Olive oil = Best thing produced all night.

   The pasta = Al dente'?  More like undercooked.

    Dessert = Hard, spongy cake topped with slivered almonds.

Uuugh, ok I know I am being super harsh, but I was just so disappointed in this place.  The whole thing just doesn't make sense.  Won't bother giving it a second chance.  It was just that bad.  Sorry  :(
author: Krissy P.

description:
You should go to this place.

I had no idea what Sardinian food was before going here. Sardinian food is surprising. And salty seafood. But not too salty. And not salty in the bad way that means cranky. The good salty. Anyway, seafood.

The menu is mostly made up of Italian words that don't mean anything to you, followed by parentheticals that contain other, similarly useless non-English phrases. So ask a lot of questions. The servers, who are excellent, will steer you right. We had the specialty of the house, a fresh spaghetti (spelled Spaghuttu or something, because that's helpful) with olive oil and fish roe. It was incredible: perfectly prepared pasta, genius flavor pairings. Then there was the Sardinian flat bread. Which is very, very flat. And yummy. I had some prawns, which were butterflied after being roasted in shell, and topped with a small amount of sweet tomato sauce. I could probably do without the tomato sauce, but only because the prawns were so excellent. Then we had the daily fish special, which was grilled and simple and lovely. 

The only downside was the dessert: a semifreddo that was way too cold, and hence brittle. Plus there was some fruity (fig?) shit on the plate which I chose to avoid. And way too many pistachio chunks.

Oh, also, the wine. Let the server drive. There is some batshit weird Sardinian shit on there that makes for a very memorable bottle.
author: J B.

description:
This place is amazing. Probably no need to expand much beyond the content of the other reviews (which also seem to be universally positive), but in summary: 

What a wonderful and unique menu! Had the octopus stew, oven roasted calamari,  gnochetti with pork meats, and pasta with sea urchin tomato and cured tuna heart. We paired our dishes with a bottle of Cannonau. All dishes were absolutely delicious. The octopus stew deserves special mention: I think I went through an entire plate of bread in order to soak up all the sauce. I'm craving the dish right now as I type this! The pasta was perfectly cooked.

We also ordered the Sardinian flat bread. That was probably an unnecessary move. I didn't care for it, and we were unaware that fresh bread was on the way.

The service was reasonably attentive for a very busy night but not the best I've ever had. It also felt lacking in the realm of recommendations. This would be the only 'negative' on the night.

Overall the price was well in line with the quality of the food and the experience.

Next time want to try the other pastas and some of the mains. Hopefully I won't have to wait another month for reservations!
author: Greg K.

description: Most authentic Italian restaurant in San Francisco. I was born and raised in Italy until I was 30 and I can attest this is the closest to Italian cuisine (though limited to the Sardinia region) you can find in the Bay Area.
author: Laura M.

description:
I was quite impressed with the ambience, the wait staff and the wine list. Not a big fan of being inside a stuffy restaurant that has a noticeable fish odor nor being next to the kitchen entrance. Nonetheless, I was up for an adventure since I was totally unfamiliar with Sardegna and both the inland and coastal cuisine. We shared the octopus stew which had a richly aromatic and flavorful tomato based broth and fish that was a bit too chewy for my palette. The burrata with mixed greens and fava beans was satisfactorily seasoned. I chose the tuna which was served on a bed a greens (red swiss chard? perhaps?). It was seriously overcooked but very flavorful. There were four in our party and one had the pasta with squid ink which was to my thinking a bit too overpowering in fish flavor and bit too gummy. 

The ricotta cake had a lovely presentation and texture but seemed to have reached its expiration date or had been stored in an inappropriate metal container. Not sure which.

Nonetheless, it was a fun experience thanks to the staff. Would I go back if I were here in Noe again? Perhaps.
author: Kathryn R.

description:
Overall, I think it is a 3.5 stars. 

We start with the Monterey calamari and the Sardinian bread. These two starters were ok, not very well seasoned. So starters are 2.5 stars as they are not very special.

Pasta course is my favorite as I got the squid ink fettuccine, and my hubby got the spaghetti. 4.5 stars.

For main course, I got the fish of the day and he got lamb. These were good enough though nothing to write home about. 3 stars.

I had a glass of red wine and he has prosecco.

The bill came to $185 with tips. Service was spotty for a white linen restaurant.
author: Tracy L.

description:
Great service and amazing food.
We love their octopus stew, flat bread, pasta and cold cuts. Their whole fish of the day is superb! They also have an extensive list of Italian wine, a large selection of which are Sardinian, at affordable prices. 
The place is small and gets pretty busy. The atmosphere is lively and fun. 
Well worth the trip to Noe.
author: Yan W.

description:
It's like...you are at your Sardinian friend's house whose family makes just the best food in taste and quality (like when my mom makes dinner and it's just the best Thai food anybody will ever eat -- even in Thailand).  Every dish was sincere, earnest, balanced in flavor and texture.

I also liked that this restaurant is filled with patrons enjoying the company they're with and the food in front of them, as opposed to those easily caught staring at everybody else.

The night's highlights were baked squid, burrata, uni fusilli, trout.
author: Grace V.

description: Overpriced. Resting on their laurels. Wine is crazy expensive. Pasta courses not seasoned well. Perhaps inexperienced cook in the kitchen? Waitress substituted two of our wines without telling us and charged us the highest price on the menu.
author: Arthur M.

description: I have never eaten at a better Italian place in my life. Mind blowing octopus stew, lamb and squid ink linguine. Wine list is amazing too. If you are in the bay, I suggest making a reservation today
author: Raj K.

description: Love this place! My favorite italian restaurant in the city! I mainly come here for their Bottarga and seafood/octopus stew. Super good! Tried pretty much all the appetizers in the menu and love all of it!
author: T K.

description: Delicious fresh pasta, great atmosphere and service, and 2 blocks from my house.  Only downside is the popularity!
author: Janelle F.

description:
It was ok.  It wasn't great, it wasn't horrible, it was ok.

First off, we had dinner reservations and the boyfriend was a bit late.  I got chastised by the hostess because of it.  I understand that you're turning over tables, but it wasn't super busy that night because you still had a few empty tables.  Secondly, you shouldn't be chastising me...feel free to yell at him when he gets here, but I am the one on time.  I already feel like an idiot standing in the rain waiting for him to show up, you do not need to chastise me too for something I didn't even do.

We ended up running into our friends who were also on date night there, so we decided to make it a double date night and join forces together.

I thought all of the food was way over salted.  We started with the octopus stew.  I'm not a huge seafood person, but I can appreciate the deliciousness of the sauce/stew here.  Sop it up with the bread please!  We also ordered the smoked pancetta, pretty basic...you can't really go wrong there.  And we ordered the buratta, also it's hard to go wrong there.

Our next dish we ordered was the fusilli with the sea urchin and cured tuna heart. WAY WAY WAY too salty.  I didn't enjoy it one bit at all.

For our entrees, I really wanted the gnochetti.  The boyfriend got pork loin.  Our friends got the lamb and the prawns.  When my gnochetti came out I just stared at it for a second.  All I could see on my plate were what looked like tiny maggots.  Not an appetizing thing to be faced with when hungry.  I hesitantly took a bite and found it to be...salty.  I ate maybe 1/4 of the dish because it was just a bit too salty for me.  The boyfriend agreed too.  Look, I'm not one that is all crazy about salt, but I just felt that night everything was a little oversalted for my taste.  The pork loin was also salty and my friend complained about her prawns too.

I wasn't impressed.
author: Quynh-An P.

description:
Wonderful place!! Came all the way from Mexico just to try it, and every dish was perfectly crafted, not only that but the attention was more than perfect! 
Will return to La Ciccia for more!

Thanks Massimiliano and Lorella for this amazing dinner and not only that but your food transported us to Sardinia for the night.
author: Diana R.

description:
The perfect indulgence.

First and foremost, the spaghetti bottarga is a must, must must. And if you are planning on sharing it--don't. My boyfriend was kind enough since it was our anniversary but deep inside i'm sure he was sad to see the half the dish consumed by me, and plus the serving is just enough to fill one tummy, not that large of a portion to share. The spaghetti is unlike anything I've tasted, it was perfectly doughy and sprung back with every bite, idk just try it...and the sauce (bottarga) was so full of flavor...the entire dish was perfect.

Seafood linguini with squid ink/lemon-I'm trying not to compare it with the bottarga because they are completely on different taste levels, but this dish is worth the try if you don't want the bottarga.

For the entree we got the lamb- it was pretty, good flavor, nothing particularly amazing like the pasta dishes but if you like lamb i'm sure you'd like this.

after much contemplation of whether or not to order another bottarga...we settled on dessert! Our very insightful server highly recommended the Sardinian Ricotta and Saffron Cake-- it was perfect. A flavorful, light dessert that didn't feel too indulgent but was suffice for the sweet craving. Saffron wasn't as strong but the dish had a wonderful flavor overall. 

As far as ambiance-- it gave me a romantic/modern rustic vibe. It is a smaller place so it's intimate for two or a close group of 4-6 would fit perfectly there. Nice lighting, clean and it has semi open kitchen, there is also bar seating. 

Parking--good luck! Came on a Sunday night and scored with a meter, but it is a residential gem so parking is a challenge I'm sure for the busier nights.
author: Megan A.

description:
I'm jumping on the La Ciccia bandwagon! I had an excellent dinner last week and I can't stop thinking about the octopus stew!! 

I was really excited to go to La Ciccia because my best friend's mother is from Sardinia and she owned a restaurant in Cassino, Italy that was amazing. 

I loved every aspect of our meal at La Ciccia and the staff was wonderful as well. 

We had a lot of food and a great bottle of red wine, it wasn't cheap, but the food was memorable and worth every penny. 

We started with: Calamarusu Arrustiusu (grilled calamari) and Prupisceddu in Umidu (stewed octopus). Both of these dishes were excellent, but I thought the spicy octopus stew was heavenly and sopped up every bit of the sauce I could with the great salty bread they serve. 

Then we shared the Fregua cun Pisci e su Nieddu de Seppia (fregola with seafood and squid ink). This dish was also excellent. 

For entrees we had: Camberonisi Arrustiusu (grilled prawns) and Pezza de Angioni a sa Saba (lamb). Both entrees were great, but I loved the first 2 dishes even better. 

For desert we had: Prattu de Casu Isolanu (Sardinian cheese plate) and Semifreddu de Turroi e Ciululatti (semifreddu frozen desert). I am a big fan of Sardinian cheeses so I was really awesome to have 3 or 4 great cheese with Sardinian honeys to eat. The semifreddu was good, but I wasn't really in the mood for something sweet. 

I loved the bottle of Sardinian red wine the waiter suggested: Vino: Carignano del Sulcis Riserva "Rocca Rubia" Cantina Santadi 2007

I am now a big fan of La Ciccia and can't wait to go again! It may be the best Italian food I've had outside of Italy. I can't wait to bring my Italian friends there the next time they are visiting. Grazie La Ciccia!
author: Yvette K.

description:
5/5/16

We have dined at La Ciccia half a dozen times in the past.  We were celebrating a special occasion and made reservations weeks in advance for 6:00PM and requested a window table.  When we arrived we were escorted towards the back of the restaurant and mentioned that we had requested a window table. Lorella responded that she had not read the reservation and there were no window tables available.  We decided to take the table in the back corner since the restaurant is very small with the tables very close together.   We ordered the tripe, which was tender but too heavily sauced for the dish.  Green salad was average.  Lamb shank was well prepared.  The other main dish was orata or sea bream which was served over chopped swiss chard.  The chard was over salted and the fish tasted bland.  We ordered the ricotta cake for dessert which we enjoyed.  Even if it had been prepared as well as in the past, its now overpriced for a neighborhood restaurant.
author: Sylvia H.

description:
By far my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.

The menu is simple, sophisticated, and absolutely amazing. The staff are equally as excellent as the food and they truly want you to have a pleasurable experience. 

The food, the food, the food. 

I had the prosciutto with aged balsamic (MUST ORDER), the Octopus Stew in Spicy Tomato Sauce (I practically licked my bowl), and the Fusilli with Sea Urchin and Cured Tuna Heart (so rich, yet so delicate- I dream about this dish). Everything far exceeded my expectations! I can't wait to go again and I recommend you visit immediately! (Make a reso, or hope for a bar seat -- very small restaurant)
author: Kelsea A.

description: Yummy! Not my favorite pasta ever but I'm glad I tried it out. Had the octopus soup and it was very flavorful. The uni pasta I loved but you have to be a huge uni fan to appreciate it... Very rich but the breadcrumbs on top balanced out the richness. Definitely delicious and very different
author: Sarah A.

description:
My wife and I went to eat dinner at La Ciccia on Saturday. We didn't have any reservations and they were kind enough to put us at the counter. We had an amazing time. Probably best dinner we have had in a long time. I highly recommend La Ciccia. 

We had the ravioli and the prawns with the salume as a starter. Everything was delicious and we met the chef. It was just an amazing dinner and a great experience.
author: Jan W.

description: Enjoy the pasta dishes. Fish portion was a bit meager for the price tag. Our server knew what was up for the most part. Cute little spot that definitely had a LOCKhold on that NOE 45-67 demo.
author: Anthony R.

description:
La Ciccia has been quietly waiting there in it's tiny space for a long time now, to welcome me into its arms.

It's been patient as I have run all over the city trying this restaurant, and that restaurant.

It has heard me complain that I can't seem to get a decent plate of pasta anywhere, and has smiled and shook its head.

Did it hold any of this against me?  Not a chance.  As I slipped into my chair in the cozy surroundings, it knew that I felt right at home.

We tried beautiful calamari, displayed so perfectly on the plate that it was almost a shame to ruin the presentation.

And then...the Spaghetti with Bottariga.  Oh my gosh, the flavor.  The perfectly cook strands of pasta.  Next time, no sharing.  A big plate, all for me.

Lamb Tenderloin for my main.  Melt-in-your mouth savory delight.

It bowled me over in such an understated, tender way - no trendiness, flashiness or pretentiousness to be found anywhere.  Just delightful food in a welcoming space by people who clearly love what they do.  

From "new to me" to "new favorite" in one visit - now that's something.
author: Liz S.

description:
La Ciccia has some of the best authentic Italian food I've ever had.  It is hard to get a table here because it is beloved by its longtime patrons.  Unfortunately, the restaurant is small but the service is great along with a great menu.  

Make a reservation, or you will be waiting a long time for a table.  

They also have take out and pizza, if you can't get a table.
author: Tom W.

description:
Why has it taken me sooooo long to come here. All their seafood appetizers are amazing. I'm drooling just thinking about the deliciousness of their whole grilled calamari, prawns, octopus tomato stew and sardines. 

Pass on the tuna heart pasta. Not what I expected n didn't date for it much.

The staff are truly Sardinian. Their friendly, know their wine pairings, accommodating and have heavy accents. 

Great food, great wine and great company makes for a very fun evening with friends and date nights.
author: Maggie L.

description:
Best Italian restaurant in the bay... I would say in California.
I've been here twice and the food is unique and delicious.
The pasta with bottarga is absolutely fantastic! Sardinian food is damn good!
author: Perda P.

description:
Fairly priced food, welcoming setting, awesome family-oriented service, and food was memorable. It felt like I was going over to my neighbor's place for a home cooked meal with the exception that my neighbors were from Sardinia.

Standout dish: arugula burrata salad. This is a MUST.
TIP: Make reservations. This place is fairly small and looks like it gets a lot of traffic. It wasn't that difficult to make a reservation for 7PM on a friday night 2 weeks in advance.
author: Paul C.

description:
Holy tortelloni. 

I love La Ciccia. It's super authentic Sardinian food. I personally think they have the best pasta in the city, and it's even better than what I've had in Italy.

This last time, I branched out from my love affair with the tortelloni and got the lamb. That, too, was great. You can't go wrong with anything here.

A few other things to note:
-Great wine list. Everyone who works here knows what they're talking about.
-This place is tucked at the end of Church St. in Noe Valley. It's cute, and is a great place for a date or dinner with friends. 
-They keep one table open outside of their reservation list. If that's taken, you might be able to find a seat at the bar. 

Skip North Beach if you want Italian. Go to one of the places in Noe Valley -- especially La Ciccia.
author: Paulette B.

description:
Fortunately La Ciccia is a little bit off the beaten path, otherwise you'd never get a table.  Nevertheless, the two times we've visited this little resto it was packed.  For good reason.

On our last visit we showed up an hour early for an 8pm rezo and instead of being rebuffed, we were put at the bar and treated to full table service.  Fine by us.  We started with the Burrata special, a gooey, delicious cheese that oozed buttery notes all over our palates.  Next up was the oven roasted Monterey Calimari that was tender, tasty and drizzled in basil oil we lovingly sopped up with the remains of our bread.  Our last course was the Gnochetti with Pork Bagna, a meaty, to-the-tooth dish, cut with the sharp bite of year-old Pecorino.

By the time we'd finished, there wasn't a crumb remaining, nor was there room for dessert.  No matter...we'll be back.
author: Paul K.

description:
Reservations was easy to make!  Dinner for two on a weekday at 6pm. 

Food: Sardinian food blew me away.  My first!
Quantity: Perfect
Price: Average, but depends on how much you order
Ambience: Romantic
Noise Level: Average-Loud
Attire: Casual
Service: A little slow, but not too bad
Parking: Street, but easy to find
Recommendations: Try the Spaghetti with Bottarga and anything with squid ink (because no one else serves it...very atypical, yet unpretentious).

Overall 4.5-5
author: Annie T.

description: Absolutely amazing! Everything on the menu is fabulous! I love the squid ink pasta, the gnochetti, the pork, the saffron ricotta dessert and about a million more things on the menu. The wine (ask Lorella what she'd suggest) is wonderful.
author: Laura S.

description:
Very good food from Sardinia, simple decor, feels like being in Italy. Just hard to get a reservation early, because of that haven't been there in a long time.

The owners husband (the cook) and wife are super nice.
author: Irina T.

description:
Awesome dinner dishes, loved the seafood they have as specials, and the spaghetti is just as it should be , "al dente", overall food had a great flavor, specially the Sardines.

Restaurant people were very very friendly and recommended a very good not so expensive wine, never felt in a rush to leave the restaurant even though does not have that many tables. 

It may seem expensive but skip the bottle of wine and it would be just as any other restaurant in SF.
author: Rafael G.

description: We've been looking for a local place that serves great pasta and great Italian food
author: James I.

description:
Great food and a different wine list that you cant  find  anywhere else. 
The food to try :
My favorite dishes:
Calamari
Octopus stew
Pork gnochetti 
Spaghetti with botarga
A remember always ask to your waiter whats the special of the day.. Have fun , ciao
author: Cris V.

description:
Fantastico!  I just may have new favorite Italian restaurant in San Francisco!  Was looking for a late night eatery not too far from SFO airport, and found La Cicca on Yelp (thanks fellow Yelpers!).  This place is a hidden gem!  It's not every day that one finds an authentic Sardinian restaurant in the US!

Started with a plate of a local speck in the style of Trentino - not your typical prosciutto, much closer to something you'd find in Austria or Germany (not surprising given Trentino's history), and a side of Sardinian sheet music bread.  Both were excellent, and the fatty, smoky ham paired with the salty and crunchy bread gave me a pretty good sign that I was in for a spectacular meal.

Moved on to spaghetti with bottarga.  Now, if you have never had bottarga, you absolutely have to try it! It is a Sardinian specialty that is made from dried fish eggs which are then grated like parmesan over pasta.  The taste is absolutely incredible!  Like they figured out how to preserve the ocean.  And it is very hard to find in the States.  This rendition was perfect, with a very nice al dente pasta, and just enough garlic and oil to complement the other flavors. I felt like I was back in Italy!

The staff was terrific too, spoke with several of the waiters, all of whom were recent Italian immigrants, and all of whom were delightfully friendly.  I will most definitely be back, and you should go too - but I would recommend reservations, as it is quite a small restaurant.
author: Frank W.

description:
Every morning, I drive by this place which has a group of google (or is it facebook) employees congregating in front of the shop to catch a work barge.  Hmm, I wonder how many Google/Facebook employees have frequented this great Sardinian restaurant.  It must be quite a few, because it's kind of difficult to get reservations here.  

So, we were able to check this place out for my wife's birthday.  It was pretty good!  It wasn't out of the park, omg, spectacular, but it was a great experience.

So, we went with the calamari and stewed octopus for our appetizers.  I don't know about you, but I sort of like the semi-raunchiness of a chewy octopus.  The octopus was so soft and tender, that it could've been squid in that briney sauce.  I guess that's a great skill and testament to the chef, but I may not be considered a true foodie, because I actually like slightly chewy octopus.  Or, I'm just kinda raunchy?

The pasta with grated tuna heart was super rich with iodine, that it initially was over powering, but afterwards, we started to have cravings for it.  It's sort of like the same effect of the heat in spicy foods which releases some level of endorphins to make someone addicted.   

Our server seemed new to the place, or sort of green to the restaurant's menu, as she didn't remember the specials and forgot a couple of requests.  But that was fine, she was very nice.  

Overall, it was a great experience in a gem of a restaurant in our neighborhood.
author: John L.

description:
I would give the food 3.5 starts. I've definitely had better Italian food. All the waiters were really nice, however one the waitress ticked me off. 

It was the young female waitress. I took a photo of the "Spicy Baby Octopus Soup", because it was on the 7x7 Big Eat list, and I'm keeping a photo of them. She comes by and tells me to not to take photos, which I told her, "I am sorry, and tried to explain why I was doing it." She then said, " It doesn't matter, and that there was lots of photos online." Excuse me? Did you see your yelp page? There are barely any photos on there!

This wasn't the part that made me mad. 2 minutes later another table took a photo, and she DOESNT say anything! Then worst part comes.... THE OTHER WAITER ASSIST ANOTHER TABLE IN TAKING THEIR PICTURE! Stupid waitress doesn't say anything either! How do you expect one not be mad?

At the end of our meal, she comes over and tries to be all friendly with us. Gosh, so obvious, trying to earn your tip money back. Psh. 

I ordered the Fettinasa de Proccu a sa Sapa (Pan roasted Pork loin served with Saffron Onions) which was very salty.  But still very good. 

So overall, service was like a 2. Since all the other people were nice. 
Food was probably a 3.5.
author: Mo W.

description:
I think you really have to like Sardinian food in order to love La Ciccia - lots of olives, tomatoes, red pepper, and seafood.  If you don't, you are sh*t out of luck.

I was sh*t out of luck ;-)  Otherwise, the service and ambiance were nice...
author: Burrito M.

description:
This place is one of the top-rated places with Michelin stars in San Francisco for Italian food.  It's also incredibly highly-ranked on Yelp.  So I gave this place a try.

Appetizer: I had the house salad.  Amazingly seasoned and tasty. 5/5 stars.

Entree: I had the prawns and tried their pizza of the day and tried their fish.  All perfection - it was like eating great food in Italy.  5/5 stars.

Dessert: Tried their gelato.  Soo good.  Really a great experience to eat that.  5/5 stars.

Water / Sparkling Water: I don't think they use tap water - I think their "tap water" is filtered water - it tasted better.  And their sparkling water is excellent.  5/5 stars.

Waitng: I had a reservation and arrived early.  Seated immediately.  5/5 stars.

Ambiance/noise level: Perfect, even though every table was full.  5/5 stars.

Service: Nearly impeccable.  Everyone was friendly, polite, helpful, refilled water so often I lost track of it.  I bumped one server walking by with my elbow, accidentially, because the tables are close together.  He apologized immediately.  5/5 stars.

Size: I bumped my elbow into a waiter.  3/5 stars.  This place should be bigger, I think.

Parking: There isn't a big parking lot nearby, but I found parking easily and a block away.  4/5 stars.

Overall experience: Truly exceptional.  This place deserves its Michelin stars and place atop of Yelp for its true excellence.  5/5 stars (rounded up from like, 4.8/5).

I recommend getting a reservation and going to this restaurant.  Odds are, you will be very glad you did!  Everyone in my group raved about the food after we left.  A great end to a great day in San Francisco...and the prices are more than fair for the quality of food and excellent service.

I could rave on and on about this place, but this review is long enough already!
author: J S.

description:
Went here last night and it was a terrific experience.

Let's start with service.  I open the door and there is Paolo.  I know Paolo from his other life as a musician.  I've noticed in the studio and at sound checks, Paolo is obsessive about quality, so it was a good sign he is right there.  He never stopped moving the whole night, always taking care of things.  Not the type to stand around and chat with his co-workers.  Then there was our waitress. Despite a somewhat indecisive person at our table, she was patient, explained everything, and seemed to know every wine on the incredibly long list.  Her choices were excellent.  And then on of the owners came by after we finished and chatted about the meal.  You can't ask for better service.

And then the food.  I spotted a huge plate of prosciutto as we walked to our table and we started with that.  It was silky and delicious.  The waitress told us it was sliced to order and it tasted like it.  Starters, I had the octopus stew - a good quantity of tiny whole octopus in a rich, thick tomato base.  Very tasty.  Others had the roast calamari, which were perfect.  Tender and with an aromatic wash of oil and maybe herbs.  On to the main course - I had hoped to have the whole fish I have seen in photos, but it was not in so they substituted ahi.  Not my first choice usually but very nice on a bed of chopped cabbage with caramelized onions on top.  Again, super tasty.  I can't eat sugar, so I had the cheese plate for desert, the sheep's cheese was delicious, the other two quite good.

The wines were excellent, as I mentioned above, and reasonably priced.

Criticisms?  Well it's loud, and I don't hear that well, so that part is a little tough.  And it's a tiny space, although we didn't feel cramped even though we were at the back table next to the wine rack.

We had been talking about coming here for quite a while and it was far better than the talk.  One last thing - if you live in the city, the MUNI J line stops across the street.  Made it really easy not to have to think about parking.
author: Spike S.

description: We had the seafood stew and octopus stew to start. Tastes like the ocean but in a good way. So fresh and earthy. My main course was the squid ink pearl pasta. Delicious. Bright and citrusy. Very traditional. No phones at table. Eat and enjoy your company.
author: S. K.

description:
We were there on a recent Friday night, and this was by far the best meal we've had in a long while! Flavors are bold and adventurous, service is sublime. Here's a quick rundown:
1st
* octopus stew -- tender octopus in a rich, spicy tomato-based sauce with a hint of seafood flavor
* roasted calamari -- served with a pesto oil and also extremely tender
2nd
* fresh linguine with a sea urchin and tuna heart sauce -- this was a revelation! Strong flavors, but so delicious!
3rd
* lamb tenderloin -- also very tender and delicious (I know I'm repeating myself!)
4th
* ricotta cake covered in toasted almond flakes. Light and moist and a nice way to finish the meal.

We were very happy with our decision to let our waiter choose the wines for us. He gladly split a glass of wine for each of the first 3 courses, and the pairings were perfect, an on-the-fly degustation menu.

I highly recommend La Ciccia, and our only problem now is deciding which friends we'll bring with us next time!
author: Matt G.

description:
Knowing we wouldst get a table, my husband and i still made the journey on our first trip to San Francisco...  We we're looking forward to authentic Sardinian cuisine after having lived their for a year.  not only we're we pleasantly surprised with courses that overstepped our expectations, we were happy to relate and talk with the wait staff and owners.
A True San Francisco gem.
author: theresa g.

description:
I am always on the hunt for good Italian, and while there were highlights and lowlights,  La Ciccia's flavors and pasta wowed.

OCTOPUS STEW: Top-rated item that many other customers seemed to be enjoying. But the baby octopus had a mushy (isn't it supposed to be chewy?) texture inside a tomato stew that was good but extremely hard to share amongst 4 people. Pretty good flavors and good on bread :)

SEA BREAM: Very clean and fresh fish, cooked and seared perfectly. The seasoning was simple, but I wanted a little more flavor.

GOAT RIGATONI (daily special): Delicious, tender goat meat - similar to braised pork - in a tomato sauce. The rigatoni was cooked al dente and tasted fresh. Yum!

SQUID INK LINGUINE: My FAVE. I loved the mixture of fresh seafood in the al dente chewy linguine noodles. Usually squid ink kinda freaks me out but this was really delicious! The portion was generous, and I probably shouldn't have finished it (but I did. Oops). 

VEAL SCALLOPINI: This was the table favorite, although I don't know if I fully appreciated it because I don't like anything breaded. This compared to other veal scallopini's was good because it was not breaded heavily.

Highly recommend making early reservations because they were pretty much fully booked on a Sunday when I called 1 week before!
author: Jess C.

description:
+: I love salt but the squid ink risotto was too salty.

--: Rushed table turn over every other minute even though nobody was waiting.
author: Mandy T.

description:
If you want to know what amazing food is like, definitely check this place out.  The seafood is fresh, their pasta is homemade, and they have the most friendly staff.

Definitely get a reservation beforehand.
author: M W.

description: We had the seafood stew as appetizer, squid ink pasta first course, the daily special sea bass w tapenade w red bell peppers, and saffron ricotta w almonds for dessert. The stew was more like a soup, albeit delicious. Both the pasta & the fish were excellent. The dessert very airy and unique. The service was attentive but low key. They waited for us to finish the appetizer and asked if we were ready for the first course. The restaurant was very intimate & charming.
author: Sunny C.

description: The best! Super fresh food with fascinating flavors. Authentic, unique, wonderful sauces, excellent seafood ingredients and gorgeous meats. If ever on the menu you have to try the tripe. It will melt in your mouth. The wine pairings and service are a bonus. Enjoy... Take a friend ... And return as often as possible.
author: John Y.

description:
Very original and yummy Sardinian food. It's not like traditional Italian fare besides the fact that pasta is offered.

We had 3 dishes to share - the Sardinian flatbread, veal tripe in tomato sauce and pecorino cheese, and squid ink pasta.
The flatbread was light, crispy, slightly greasy, cheesey, and herb-y. I really enjoyed the pecorino cheese atop. It would make a great dipper for sauces (which we did use on the veal tripe).
The tripe came in a bowl drenched in a tangy tomato sauce and cheese. It was unlike anything I ever had before. I loved the tomato-y, cheesy flavor and the chewy softness of the tripe. Tripe is not for everyone, but if you enjoy it try it because the flavor is amazing and the preparation is totally unique. 
The squid ink pasta came slathered in black ink and had a nice touch of herbs. The ink itself tasted quite mild but the lemony flavor really stood out and the texture of the noodles. It can be a messy dish so eat it with care and lady-likeness =)
3 dishes were enough for the 2 of us. I also ordered a glass of wine and the bill came out to about 60 dollars before tax.

The wait staff were cordial and the owner was totally gracious by pulling up an extra chair and making room for us at the bar. We didn't have reservations and they were very accommodating. 

There was a nice pause between dishes, not too quickly so we could chat and enjoy the wine, but not too long where we were wondering where the food was. 

This is a great date night place since it's cozy and romantic, and the wait staff are attentive but will also provide you enough space to enjoy your food and company.
author: Brandy A.

description: Loved everything especially the bottarga which is rare to come by in these parts.
author: Paul M.

description: Took the hubs here for his birthday and had a shared meal for two (5 plates + wine) for a decent price (SF standards, of course). Better Italian than what I've found in North Beach thus far -- as a tip, the lamb is insane!
author: Rebecca P.

description: I can't believe I haven't review my favorite restaurant in SF. I have recommended countless friends here just for their spicy octopus stew! Soooooooo delicious that I want to bathe in it. Tender, flavorful, makes me drool thinking about it. There's a reason why there's no olive oil or balsamic on the table with your bread. It's meant to be soaked in this glorious sauce!
author: Jess N.

description: Went to LaCiccia on 4/30/15 for my boyfriend's birthday.  It was incredible and the service was top-notch.  I already have reservations in a few weeks again!
author: Maryn R.

description:
I have been dying to try this place eversince watching the Anthony Bourdain episode where he visits his wife's hometown Sardinia, Italy!  La Ciccia is the only Sardinian restaurant in SF, and what I heard, the only one in the West Coast!  I tried to get Valentine's Day reservations here, but they were completely booked weeks in advance!  

Appetizer:
Octopus Stew (must have) - nearly every table was having this dish!  You will want to lick the plate, we decided to just dip lots of bread with the sauce until there wasn't any left...so good!  There is some kick to it as it is made with spicy tomato sauce!

Entrees:  
1) Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga (Fresh Spaghetti with spicy oil and Bottarga) - this dish was featured on Anthony Bourdain's show when he was having a home cooked meal at a family friend's house in Sardinia!  I wanted to try this for a long time and it was sooooo worth it!  I loved it so much that I am going to learn how to cook it!  Best pasta dish ever! 
2) Pasta Cruzza cun Arrizzonisi e Cori de Tonnu (Fresh Fusilli with Sea Urchin Tomato and Cured Tuna Heart) - this dish was good, but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone who is not that adventurous with food and not a Uni (sea urchin) lover!  The taste is very strong and is an acquired taste!  

You must order Sardinian wine to have with your meal!  It is different from all the other Italian Wines that you have had...just like the Sardinian Food!

The restaurant is owned and started by a very lovely couple...the wife is from Venice and she manages the restaurant in the dining area and is a lovely host and the husband is from Sardinia and he is the Chef!  Dynamic dual!  The wife is so sweet, she likes to talk to the customers to see if they enjoyed the meal and to get to know everyone!

I recommend making reservations in advance as this restaurant is packed all the time!  Enough said about the quality of food!
author: Sandy L.

description:
If I knew I was going to die tomorrow, I would drive to San Francisco tonight and make sure the last thing I ate was from La Ciccia. That is how purely amazing their food is. 

My homemade pasta with crab meat was melt-in-your-mouth fresh and delicious. I felt like I was eating a dream... each bite was a succulent treat with no fishy aftertaste. 

The dining experience itself was very intimate. Although we sat in a table located in the middle of the room near the front door, we felt warm and welcomed. The owners, husband and wife, circled the room checking on tables, it was easy to feel the love they have for their customers.

If you want to wow the woman/man of your dreams, bring them here, and thank me later.
author: Tricia M.

description:
La Ciccia is my favorite Italian restaurant.  That is a bold statement coming from a foodie who eats out often. I started eating at La Ciccia 6 years ago when it opened. It was a hidden gem then and I am only writing a review now that everyone has figured out what a great place this is! I was hopingi t would by my little secret but now its hard to get a table.

Everything on the menu is made with high quality and fresh ingredients. The seafood salad appetizer is a must. The baby octopus in tomato stew is awesome. The octopus is so tender, and pairs perfectly with the salty and slightly spicy soup. The grilled calamari is fresh and delicious.  All of the pastas are made fresh. My BF always gets the gnochetti with pork sugo.  I like the squid ink pasta.  Sometimes they have a special ravioli stuffed with ricotta and orange zest and a wild boar or lamb ragu sauce This is to die for.  We also like the pork tenderloin pan fried and lightly breaded with saffron onions.

The wine list is great. All Italian wines and many from Sardinia. The staff is super helpful in helping you pick a great wine to go with your meal. They also let us taste many varieties to make sure we settle on just what we want.

The owners and staff at La Ciccia are so nice and friendly. The chef and owner always comes out to talk to customers and you can tell he takes a lot of pride in his work.   Its owned by a husband and wife and they love to chat about Sardinia and the food. We absolutely love them and their restaurant. 5 stars  for La Ciccia. I wish I could eat there every day.
author: Michelle T.

description:
I came here tuesday evening to celebrate my birthday. The atmosphere was very cozy and intimate, had a nice warm vibe to it, like you were at home. Service was impeccable. 

We started off with the Prupisceddu in Umidu (octopus stew) as I was told by many it was simply amazing. It stood up to my expectations 100%. The octopus was tender and the sauce was a nice deep dark red tomato spicy sauce with tons of flavor. I dipped my bread into it and I couldn't stop eating it. I would have probably drank it if I could!!! Delish!!

The next course was Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga. This dish was also done to perfection. The pasta was done al dente with just the right amount of sauce and egg roe. The portion was a decent amount for two to share. 

Our last course was Oratina in Padella Cun Olia Sarda. Again a good size portion for two to share. Two big filets of sea bream with some sort of olive tapenade on top. The fish was moist and flavorful and went down smoothly with my glass of white wine.

For dessert we had the trio of gelatos. My favorite flavor was the goat cheese with fig. The other flavor was chocolate and some sort of Italian liquor flavor, both were also very nice.

I was amazed at how delicious the food was, how cozy the ambiance was and how great the service was. I will for sure be back.
author: Kehaulani K.

description: We came in without a reservation at 6:30pm on a Saturday and were lucky to get seated at the bar.  We decided to eat light, but sample a variety of items on the menu.   We loved the burrata & pea appetizer (peas were very fresh).   My wife said the spaghetti with spicy garlic oil was the best pasta she had tasted in SF.  it was homemade, coarse, and quite satisfying.  We also enjoyed the Barolo and the Brunello offered by the glass.  Only complaint - the cheese/honey dessert could have used larger portions of honey.
author: Mighty M.

description:
We ate here for my boyfriend's birthday, and while the overall experience was generally good, I am giving less than 5 stars due to the service. 

Pros:
- Free bread at the table (decent bread, would have been even nicer if it was warm)
- The appetizer of octopus stew in spicy tomato soup was delicous!
- Fresh spaghetti with spicy oil and bottarga was delicous!!
- We had a special of the night that was fettucine with lamb ragu that was also very good
