- We ordered 3 pastas and asked the waiter to bring out each pasta in order so that it felt like we were eating multiple courses and could focus our attention on each pasta; the timing for this was done well.
- Waiter made sure our waters were filled the entire night and had good recommendations on wine choices

Cons:
- Our waiter lacked the warmth and hospitality you would expect for a small intimate italian restaurant.  While he was never rude, he barely ever smiled and was rather stoic in any interactions we had with him.   For example, when he first approached our table, his first question was whether we wanted tap or sparkling water.  There was no "Hello" or "Welcome" or "How are you this evening", just something small to welcome/greet a guest.  His lack of friendliness was almost intimidating in asking him questions about the menu and trying to get recommendations for various pastas.  I think when you are dining at a $$$ restaurant that is a small neighborhood joint, you expect to get hospitable service. 
- I greatly did not like the fregola pasta with sea urchin tomato and grated tuna hearts.  I am someone who loves sea urchin, and have eaten it in pasta form such as SPQR's sea urchin smoked fettucine (delicious!) but this pasta really missed the mark.  Creamy tomato, sea urchin, and tuna hearts do not go well together in a combo, and of top of that the pasta that is used are these tiny pieces of pasta which I think is the wrong type of pasta for trying to absorb all the creaminess of this dish. I felt like I was eating creamy tomato soup with a fishy taste on top.  This was a big miss in my opinion.  

 I would like to go back and try some other dishes like the squid ink, but would also like to get a different waiter next time.
author: Mary X.

description:
First of all, this place is the real deal.  We loved everything we ordered.   We enjoyed 4 appetizers, 2 pastas, and 2 desserts.  Our waiter advised us on an excellent wine.

Mrs. La Ciccia was stationed right by us and made sure personally our every need was met.  Gracious dining for sure.

Highlights were the so tender calamari I was so desperate to taste again, the fresh burrata WOW, and our 2 pastas.   Their servings are generous.  We were stuffed but we managed to devour our desserts only because we saved half of each pasta dish for a take home midnight snack.  My amaretto ice cream dessert was SO GOOD! 

Compared to our A16 dinner last Saturday, La Ciccia was definitely better though we did like A16 too.

We can't wait to return!
author: Kell M.

description:
Amazing. Italian perfection with a twist. 

The hubby and I went here on a date night. Yay for babysitters! We'd been meaning to try this place for a long time. And man are we glad we did! They know their stuff that's for sure. Yes the place is cozy and packed always but it's worth it. Make reservations and you're set. 

We ordered:
Burrata and fava beans on flatbread - simple but refreshing 
Baby octopus stew in spicy tomato sauce - lives up to all expectations and is on the 7 x7 top 100 foods of sf for a reason! I practically licked the plate! 
Fresh spaghetti with bottarga (mullet roe) - this was to die for!!! my favorite for sure!!! So creamy and yummy!
Lamb - cooked to perfection and served with cabbage.
Gelato trio- my favorite was fig and goat cheese! 
Saffron risotto cake - it was yummy but gelato was better


You must try La Ciccia!!! I want to go back!!!
author: Sarah Z.

description:
Finally.  I have been looking for a special Italian resto in the bay area and hadn't found it.  Until now.  You know what I mean.  There are many restaurants that offer similar platters of salumi, wood fire oven baked pizzas and pastas in the city.  But nothing really sets one apart from another.  They are not bad, just not special or memorable.

I took my bff from the east coast here for dinner.  I could not find a table through opentable for a Friday evening so I called, with my fingers crossed, and was advised to come early for walk-in seating.  I made my jet-lagged bff hustle despite his late afternoon meetings in downtown and long lines of tourists at the BART station and lucky for us beat the Friday evening rush.

It wasn't until after we opened our menus that I realized this place specialized in Sardinian cuisine.  My bad.   As can be imagined from Sardinia being an island, most of their offerings are sea food based.  The wine list was mind boggling and really requires a magnifying glass to go through everything.  A handful are offered by the glass.

We had salad with shaved pecorino and anchovies, sardines in spicy garlic sauce, fresh spaghetti with mullet roe in spicy garlic sauce, and fresh linguini with smoke fish in squid ink sauce.  I was blown away by both pasta dishes.  Initially I was a little skeptical about having fish egg sauce with spaghetti, but it felt more like creamy egg sauce than crunchy flying fish roe I associate with sushi, and the texture of the fresh pasta was just right.  The smoked fish pasta with squid ink sauce had the aroma of smoke but the taste was surprisingly mild and perfectly balanced with lemon juice.  For dessert we shared a ricotta almond cake with honey.  My bff commented that everything was on the noticeably salty side, which I agreed, but I had had the same experience when I was traveling in Italy recently so I am inclined to accept it as being authentic.  

The service was great.  I just need to figure out how I can be on the regulars list (or special guest list?) of the madame of the house so she will greet me with a warm hug (and sometimes kiss on the cheek) like she did to many who came that night.
author: Alice A.

description:
I wish I could leavet 5 stars for La Ciccia since I had heard a lot of good things about it and was really looking forward to it.
Overall, I'd give food a 3.5 with very mixed feelings. Although, Pasta are really awesome!
Apetizers:
Sardines: good but really nothing special and not super tasty. 3 stars.
Roasted calamari: very good. 4 stars.
Main:
Spagetthi with octopus: that was the highlight. Very good and I'd give it a 5.
Tenderloin lamb: was a disappointment. Meat was good, gamy (which i liked) and well cooked but it was a lot of meat with almost no side besides onions. Felt it was a bit too blunt (just eating meat) and I wish I would have known about it and order a side as well. 3 stars.
We did not take any dessert as nothing on the menu really appealed us.
Good choice of wine.Beware of a $35 corking fee (which is the high end and hence high for this kind of restaurant). 
Ambiance : 3 stars.
Lively but small hence too crowded and above all very loud.
Also, I had booked our table a month in advance for a special occasion and we were given the worst table of the restaurant: literally in the entrance. I asked the waiter if we could have another table and she replied not very nicely "no, as you can see we are full". Less than 5 minutes later,  a much better table in a corner freed up and i asked another waiter to change and he said yes with no problem. It was much better (i hate being in the cold and activity near the door) and I am glad we were able to change.
So overall, very mixed feelings, and if i go back I will stick to Pasta!! A much better choice I think!
author: Delf M.

description:
This place place was a big disappoinmet after reading good Yelp reviews.

To cut a long story short:  I ordered the sardines to start. Not bad, but gee, I have had just as good out of a can.

Moving on to the lamb. How bland can you get, and no presentation, just lamb strips on a plate with a little califlower in the centre - uncreative. Lamb was almost cold and advised the server. Manager (owner?) comes over. I explain the lamb is cold, probably either because the plate it it served on is like ice, or it sat there for quite some time before the server picked it it. Manager begins to argue that it would be impossible for the lamb to be almost cold. Says she can take it back but when it is reheated it would go from meduim rare to medium. At this point I dont care. just wanted to get the check and leave. Never coming back.   

Server was very nice so giving 2 stars.
author: Bobby J.

description:
Awesome Sardinian ambiance, but sadly, a poor fit for my palate.

Got a last-minute reservation for five at 9:30pm, which was a tight squeeze considering the kitchens close at 10. Considering my mild obsession with Italian culture, I was curious to see what Sardinian cuisine was all about. 

First impressions were good. The restaurant was small and homey, but not overly fancy. In true Italian style, the menu was split into appetizers, first courses (mainly pastas), and second courses (meats/seafood). The names of the dishes were written in both the Sardinian dialect, which added a nice rustic feel, and slightly garbled English that sounded like it was spit out of a menu-item generator. ("Semolina Gnochetti with Pork meats Sugo and 12 Months Pecorino"... huh?) In combination with the Italian accents of the servers, I almost believed was in Sardinia for real. :)

The food was more of a mixed bag. In an attempt to sample the more unique items on the menu, we started with the salume of the day, which turned out to be a beautifully presented plate of prosciutto (not unlike a sashimi rose), and the baby octopus stew. The prosciutto was decent, if a bit too salty, and the stew had an interesting spicy flavor that I couldn't quite decide if I liked. Overall, just okay.

Next up were Is Primusu (first courses): squid ink fregula and garlic pasta. Having eaten squid ink pasta once before on a trip to Venice and been completely blown away, I had high expectations! Sadly, the flavor of the fregula was nothing like I remembered: weirdly tangy, lemony, and rubbery, entirely unlike the rich, warm taste of that meal many years ago. The garlic pasta was tasty, but in the way that you'd expect any pasta alfredo to be - better than average, but not by much.

Not much to say on Is Segundusu (garlic prawns and lamb) here since I don't eat lamb, but the prawns weren't bad. They made them seem a lot bigger than they actually were by cutting them in half, but at least both dishes were nicely presented over tasty veggies.

By the time we polished off the last of the lamb, I was a bit disappointed -- maybe  my expectations were too high, but I just hadn't been impressed by any of the dishes. Luckily, the dessert ended up being the best part of the experience! We ordered the Truta de Arriscottu, a ricotta and saffron cake with almonds, and the seasonal sorbet: a small scoop each of passionfruit, black cherry and apricot. The sorbet was too sweet for me, but the Truta was an absolute delight! Nice and creamy with just the right level of sweetness. 

Best of all, just as we started to dig in, the chef swung by to say hi and explained how he made the Truta... then brought us a plate of gelato, on the house! We should have ordered it from the start -- each of the flavors (chocolate hazelnut, marcello wine and another I can't recall) was simply divine.

It was a memorable meal, made much better by the fantastic service and dedication of the owners. Unfortunately, I just wasn't impressed by the food. At $35 per person, it wasn't ridiculous, but I'd much rather spend that kind of cash on food that will make me happy to eat.
author: Grace K.

description: Order everything, you can't go wrong and share with the table. Make a reservation, don't think your special and can prance in with a table waiting for you. The Malloreddus a sa Campidanese  (Semolina Gnochetti with Pork meats Sugo and 12 Months Pecorino) --  will change your life.
author: Sara K.

description:
La Ciccia never fails to deliver.  I am not a tomato sauce fan, but at La Ciccia I not only eat it, but clean the remaining sauce with bread.  This restaurant is so what SF food is about: a husband and wife team who LOVE what they do and love their heritage.  Sardinian food is fresh and fantastic--for those of you not familiar, it is fairly seafood heavy and heavy on the olive oil.  Yum.  This is not a scenester restaurant but a place to take your time and really enjoy every flavor.  I have been multiple times but tonight we dined with good friends, one who knows the food inside out.  So needless to say for a table of 6 we dined like kings and queens.

Starts:  burrata with fava beans that made your mouth water
Seconds: octopus and calamari
Mains/pasta: Fresh Spaghetti with spicy Oil and Bottarga, Fregula with Sea Urchin Tomato and Cured Tuna Heart, ravioli stuffed with lemon ricotta and pork ragu , pork loin slices with a scallion puree and prawns.

Deserts: a trio of sorbet, farro (rice like) pudding and a mousse of vanilla with some almond base.

Seriously if you try NOTHING else at La Ciccia go for the octopus or calamari.  No one and I mean NO ONE makes it as well as Massimiliano.

Going to La Ciccia is like eating at one's Italian grandmothers house.  You always remember the meal and want to go back for more. Even if you are a nice non practicing Jewish girl who grew up in SF.
author: Monika S.

description:
Cozy restaurant, nice atmosphere and good food, no wonder why it's hard to get a reservation, even during the week!

We have been there last Thursday hoping that they still had that wonderful fresh (homemade) Mozzarella. Unfortunately they didn't but the starter special that day was a Anchovy salad which was even better. Haven't seen such good anchovies for a long time.

Very balanced wine menu, i even found some of my favorite wines from South Tyrol on there. It's probably hard to get those in the US (at least i have issues getting them), this tells me these guys really try to get some good stuff on their menus.

The anchovy salad was followed by a lamb tenderloin, which was cooked perfectly. Simply drizzled by some saba on a fluffy potato (celery?) mash, yumm!

Fast and friendly service staff, family style but very knowledgeable and experienced. I really love the way they host.
author: Ben O.

description:
I created a Yelp account just so I could share my frustration:

Unfortunately, we weren't able to have dinner there.  Our reservation was for 9:45pm on a Saturday.  We arrived at 9pm hoping for a chance to get seated early. When we saw how busy they were, we waited patiently -- the hostess told us we'd get seated closer to our 9:45pm reservation.

At 10:30pm, I got antsy and asked for estimated seating time.  The hostess apologized explaining that diners just weren't leaving although several tables had either paid or had their check on the table.

There was another couple waiting outside with us; I asked what time their reservation was, he replied 9:45pm.  Note: they arrived at the restaurant much later than us.  They got seated before we did.

The owner finally came out at 10:45pm and asked if she could get us "started" and offered two seats at the bar/ counter. We accepted because we were hungry and tired of waiting.  I sat at the middle corner of the counter where there's a large ass beam within 5" of my face.  Awkward.  My husband overheard that they were out of the spicy seafood stew as well as several other items we were looking forward to eating.  We left.

Note to La Ciccia -- don't be so damn greedy and overbook your dining reservations. You must know this by now: If a table orders bottles of wine, chances are great that they will linger. If you cannot seat your customer 30 minutes past their confirmed reserved time, you better have a contingency plan for them.  

Advise:  prepare to wait...a long ass time...take a snack with you.  Hell, pack an entire meal with you because your reservation will not be honored in the confirmed time. Hell will freeze over quicker than getting your reservation honored in a timely manner at this joint.
author: kijibe l.

description:
Came here because of the great reviews--plus it was highly praised by Gary Danko!

The restaurant has a very charming feel to it.  Small space but with a nice ambiance, it felt authentically Italian.

Unfortunately, the food ranged from amazing to average to subpar.  As mentioned by previous reviewers, the Baby Octopus in Spicy Tomato Stew is delectable.  It's a must-have!  My girlfriend ordered a pizza, which was good but not memorable.  I had a pasta dish (can't remember the name and I don't see it on the menu online) which was wayyyyy too salty.   I tried to enjoy it, and the pasta noodles itself were very delicious, but the sauce was simply too overpowering and overwhelming.  I was very disappointed.

Overall, a solid Italian place but in my opinion, does not live up to the high ratings.  Perhaps we just ordered the wrong things, but I probably will not be taking a special trip back here again, given I live on the Peninsula and reservations for this place are not the easiest to make.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I gave these guys a chance to respond to my direct feedback.  No concern, so here goes:
Good food.  Good service.  Offensive greeting.  Hostess was pretty, friendly, but "out to lunch".  We were on time for us 6:00 reservation.  She walked us past open tables in the front of the restaurant, and led us to the furthest, darkest part of the restaurant - net, next to the toilet!  Are you kidding me.  Rosa Parks would not even sit there and neither would we.  She then seated us at an acceptable table, but by then the mood had been tainted. I was born at night, but not last night!  Do you really think I'm going drop big bucks for dinner and sit next to the shitter?  Think again.
author: Douglas B.

description:
OK, one more five star review, and that's IT.

Just an added tip for insiders: a glass of moscato with the goat-cheese and fig gelato is a taste sensation fit for a God.

Take me now, Lord.  I'm ready.
author: Theresa B.

description: This was my first time trying Sardinian food and I really enjoyed it. The place is small, and has a very friendly staff. The bread was very warm and fluffy, the calamari was not fried as I am used to but was still delicious, and the soup also had a very strong flavor. The best dish of all was the bottarga it had a very intense fish taste, and I loved it! The gnochetti were also pretty good, but rather simple. As for the dessert.....you must get the gelato sampler! Wow, it was delicious, you can really feel all the flavor that is in every bite. And we got the riccioto cakes with almond and honey, also good, but not as great the gelato.
author: Nikita K.

description: yummy!  came here on a Sat night at 5:45, no reservation but got the last available table.  The two of us shared the octopus stew, urchin pasta, and branzini with veggies (Fish special).  Everything was excellent.  Baby octopus stew had generous amount of octopus in it, uni pasta was fishy and delicious (with a rich creamy sauce), and the fish was perfectly pan seared.  The waiter paired our food with a nice floral red wine that I thoroughly enjoyed. Ambience/vibe is on the older side (avg age 45ish).
author: T Y.

description:
We went to La Ciccia to celebrate my dad's birthday on a Friday night. Booked it a month ago as I know the place is always packed. Second time I have been here and it doesn't disappoint! One of my favourite places to eat in San Francisco.

We started out our meal with complimentary basket of bread. It didn't come with any olive oil so we had to ask for that. Kind of weird that it didn't come with the usual olive oil/balsamic vinegar but maybe that's the norm? Make sure you get another basket of bread to dip in the octopus stew sauce! So goooooood, I could eat that sauce all day.

Anyways, for the food, we ordered:

- Octupus stew ($13) - definitely a must! Octopus cooked so tender and stew is so good with the bread dipped in it.
- Oyster ($13) - the soup/broth it was in was a bit watery (I'm guessing from the oyster releasing it's own juices into the sauce when it was cooked). My mom really liked it though. I thought it was only okay.
- Fresh fusilli with sea urchin tomato and cured tuna heart ($18) - perfectly al dente fusili pasta. Love how they cook their pasta so well.
- Semolina gnochetti with pork meat sugo and pecorino ($16)  - also perfectly al dente. This one was my main dish and I ate it all. 
- Seared lamb tenderloin ($26) - you get 8 pieces of tender lamb slices. Cooked perfectly (my dad asked for medium).
- Roasted mediterrian sea bream ($26) - skin on the bottom and nice soft texture on top. 
- Nougat and chocolate semifreddo ($8) - we split it four ways as we were stuffed. Perfect way to end our meal. Light, almost tasted like ice cream.
- My dad also got a rasberry sorbet with a candle for his birthday as we told our waitress last minute that it was his birthday! So nice of them.

As I said before, one of my favourite places to go to when we visit SF! Very warm, inviting atmosphere with friendly and well trained staff. Food cooked to perfection. This is how it should be done. Other restaurants, take some notes. La Ciccia, je t'aime.
author: Jonny M.

description: So delicious and quaint! We loved our dinner experience here.   Our waitress was super sweet and helpful, the restaurant is really cute and the food was fantastic.   Our waitress recommended a lovely Sardinian red wine at a reasonable price range.  We started with roasted calamari,  delicious and unique presentation of small roasted calamari in a flavorful sauce.  Then we shared the gnochetti with pork. .. such a yummy sauce with just enough heat.  For main dishes we shared the fish special. ... super delicate and fresh and the lamb tenderloin. .. omg... so delicious and perfectly cooked with a balsamic sauce and roasted veggies.   For dessert we had the lovely saffron ricotta cake.   Fantastic experience and hope to return.   Only negative was pretty noisy with tables close together,  but the restaurant is very small so they fill the space!
author: Aimee Z.

description:
If you're from CA, would you take sushi advice from someone from NY?  Nope.  Well, it works in reverse too, especially in regards to Italian food.  This place wasn't bad per se, but with the rave reviews I was thinking I was going to get the Italian I've craved since leaving the east coast.  Didn't happen.  This place is average at best, 2.5 stars and I will not be going back.

The burrata app and the grilled calamari...eh to both and the calamari had a fishy smell.  The sauce was weak and the taste very rubbery.  A pizza and the squid ink pasta for mains and average again.  Actually the pasta was under salted and almost flavorless.  Didn't even want to splurge on desert as the best appeared to be a gelato taster; however, I have 3 Twins Cookies and Cream at home so no comparison there.  

Sorry people, the best Italian I've had in this city is Delfina, and that's more CA/Italian.  2 apps, 2 mains, 2 glasses of wine and $90 with tip...still left a bit hungry.  I respect the cordial staff and family atmosphere, but this place is way overrated.
author: A A.

description:
Tiring. This pretty much sums up my dining experience here.

Our party was seated over 45 minutes after our reservation time because "the tables are moving slowly." The restaurant should accept fewer reservations and not make people wait this long.

The quality of the food is excellent, but despite the pleasing taste, it was difficult to finish each dish. There was a "heaviness" in the food and a few bites were enough. It was as though one's palate became fatigued and the desire to eat more was curiously absent (I usually want to eat _more_ of food that I like). Maybe this would be a good place to eat if you're on a diet. It might be nice if the portion sizes (and prices) were halved.

I enjoyed tasting the food but I probably will not return anytime soon.
author: Jolie S.

description: My first time trying Sardinian food and I'm glad I picked this cozy yet elegant restaurant with such passion! Everything I tried was good but the best might be the hearty spicy octopus stew--soak up the sauce with the bread! The calamari appetizer was light and teasing. The pastas were spot on, although heavy. Cant quite remember the ones I tried but i do remember Squid Ink being a favorite!
author: Cynthia T.

description:
Wow.  I had heard the hype and read the reviews, but this place was actually as good as reported.  It was definitely crowded - even for a Wednesday night - but I can see why.  

We ordered the special salad (arugula with lemon anchovy vinaigrette and pecorino) and the flatbread as appetizers.  I had the octopus stew as my entree (definitely spicy), and my husband had the pasta special (linguine with seafood).  Our friends had the fregola and the gnocchi dishes.  Everything was delicious.  I would definitely return.
author: B. Y.

description:
This is the most amazing Italian restaurant in San Francisco and as far as I know, one of the only ones that serves regional Italian cuisine (other than maybe Locanda, which specializes in Roman classics like pasta with amatriciana, cacio e pepe, or carbonara) like you might find if you were to go to a local trattoria in Italy where only the favorites of the province and the family's recipes are made without compromise to American palates for clam linguini and spaghetti with red sauce. There's certainly a time and place for Italian American classics too, or new American/Italian places like Beretta or Delfina  - you just won't find those same menu items here. I think part of enjoyment here is amending your expectations before you come - this is uncompromising Sardinian fare and if you come in not enjoying seafood or al dente pasta, this restaurant will disappoint you, through no fault of its own. You could certainly eat Italian for cheaper in the city, but I reason that since I don't have the time or the money to return to Italy, this is the next best thing. 

La Ciccia is cozy, loud, and intense, both the food and the ambiance. Anything seafood will be stellar - especially the squid with basil oil and spaghetti with bottarga. I have never eaten anything as light or intensely savory as that bottarga. We also tried the fregola with tuna hearts and uni which I found too rich for me given the heaviness of the sauce and how compact and dense fregola is, but that's just me and my dining companion enjoyed it more than I did. Everything was simple, probably less than 5 ingredients in each dish, nothing extraneous in each plate. A plate of bottarga spaghetti and a glass of wine - it's as good as life gets.
author: Lijia X.

description: We tried two pastas, two soups and the cheese plate - amazing. We lucked out and got a seat at the bar. Fabulous and knowledgable service. A cozy night out. Nice wine list, too.
author: Vicki L.

description: This is the second time we've been here. We really like this place. The food is tasty. We had the octopus, which was spicy. We also ordered the two fish dishes, which were also quite good. My dad ordered pasta with veal. That was the most outrageous of the dishes. And the sommelier was able to pair the wines with the food in a really extraordinary way. The feeling of the place is nice, and the staff are friendly. I give this a solid five.
author: Chad H.

description:
We just had a baby.  This means I don't get to go to dinner so very often anymore.  The baby is good, missing dinners is bad.  However, since having the baby we have gone to three fancy dinners, the other two being at much more noted (some might claim famous) restaurants and La Ciccia was, by far, the best of the three.  

Their food is exceptional, the wine recommendation was perfect and the service was charming.  I love La Ciccia and cannot wait for another night with a babysitter so we can go back.
author: Mary S.

description:
I really like this place. It's difficult enough to find Sardinian food, and everything that La Ciccia offers is fantastic.

Small and intimate, homey ambiance with phenomenal service. The waiters and owners are very friendly and warm. They don't hesitate to give you suggestions on the extensive wine list and are generous with giving you tastings.

The dishes are all solid, authentic Sardinian foods. I love everything especially from the appetizers selection (calamari, octpus, sardines, mmmmm)

Looking forward to come here again. Great food, great wine list, Great service, reasonable prices, what more can you ask....
author: Veronica S.

description:
after several years of thinking about it, we finally managed to cross the GG bridge and go. WAS IT WORTH IT. dinner there is in serious contention for one of my faves. ever. including the meal my mama made my for my birthday last year. 

the calamari with basil oil and spicy octopus are a must -- so perfectly cooked, and so fresh and light. house-made salami A+. airy crispy flatbread. the fregola with sea urchin was a surprise since I usually prefer my sea urchin raw, but this dish delivered. husband enjoyed his gnochetti with pork sugo so much that he literally hid the leftovers from me the next day so that I couldn't finish them off.

oh and the wine. and the service. and the adorable chef-owner. all in all an amazing meal at a totally unpretentious gem.
author: Sasha R.

description: I have to give credit where credit is due. Was an excellent dinner. It was busy but our reservation was honored. The appetizers and pastas were perfectly prepared and delicious. We didn't have room for dessert.
author: Joyce B.

description: (+0.5) One of the more interesting and delicious restaurant in recent memory. Uni, fish roe pasta and pork baugu packed unique flavors and I personally loved it. Squid ink linguini and baby octopus stew are group'a favorite. Price are very reasonable and definitely worth a little trip to this quiet neighborhood.
author: George L.

description:
(See pics)

My lovely 600th review is to be special, with special people, joy, happiness, warmth in the heart, laughter, despite the fact that I have been very busy working and have almost 50 unfinished reviews. 

But this review is dedicated to someone special, someone who came to my heart and took me to great places (mentally too!) And this is one of the many that wakes up my inner soul! 

Great great Sardinian place with food that is subtle but really, really mouthwatering. And I really love this kind of place, not big, dim light, home feel service and excellent food. 

Seafood Salad with Lemon Oil Dressing was refreshing and light, a perfect starter for a great dinner. Sardines is a must have specialty, even thinking about it makes me drool. 

Fresh Spaghetti with spicy Oil and Bottarga is another specialty if you want authentic Sardinian cuisine! Sea Urchin Fregula is not anything I could imagine because I have only had it raw before and it is an eyeopener tasty dish. It's a very tomato dish and the sea urchin is very subtle that it is quietly telling you it's there. 

It also has a very extensive list of Italian wines and local wines that a couple of experts at the dining table were studying the lengthy list for a bit and made some good comments on the wines. Ventimontino is a great complement we picked to resonate the delicacy we all enjoyed. 

This place has a very similar setting like Chapeau! curtain entrance, packed table-clothed place and with very, very good service. The owner came and chatted about the food, remembered my date and greeted us almost like family. 

It's a fantastic place for small groups of people to enjoy some lively and uplifting conversations.
author: T L.

description:
Before visiting La Ciccia: 

Octopus are friends not food

After visiting La Ciccia:

Hmmm La Ciccia, Octopus Stew... hm mmm mm good! oh what friends? where ? In my stomach? don't know them :)

Before visiting La Ciccia:

What sardines, those are garbage smell old fishy and taste like foul fish!!!

After visiting La Ciccia:

Hmmm smell like sea, refreshing, clean and very fresh!

the rest of the food was wonderful! Not Heavy, always interesting, clean and taste fresh unlike usual italian american food!
author: Dan A.

description:
What a unique dining experience!

You won't find many restaurants in the country that has food like this. Here is the summary of our order.

Baby Octopus Stew - Best thing on the menu. Perfectly spicy and the octopus was really tender. (Maybe cuz they are babies) The stew is good to soak up with bread.
Calamari in Basil Oil - Simple yet nicely done.
Pork Gnochetti - Not the most unique item, but executed very well and is a nice classic savory dish.
Pasta with Fish Roe - Subtle, but very tasty. A slight hint of seafood.
Pasta with Shaved Tuna Hearts and Sea Urchin - Not gonna lie, I was shocked by this dish. When it was served, the fumes made it seem like I was on the California coast. It smelled like the ocean. The dish had a lot of umami flavor and salty shavings of tuna hearts. (weird, I know) This dish really grew on me and was really delicious.
Lamb Tenderloin - Perfectly cooked and melted in your mouth.
Sardinian Flat Bread- More like a cracker with some cheese on top. Worth skipping.
Saffron Ricotta Cake - Yummy!  Heavier than I thought. A generous serving of shaved almonds on top.
The wine and beer menu is also very impressive with a lot of Sardinian beers and wines that you cannot find everywhere.

Overall, it was a great meal that delivered unique food prepared beautifully!
author: Ryan M.

description:
I would give this place six stars if I could.  Though the space is tiny and it's difficult to get a table at a sane hour, the food is...I don't even think I know the word.  Exquisite?  Fantastic?  Superior to all other food?

We shared the Sardinian flatbread and calamari (best I've ever had, not kidding), then my date went with the octopus stew and I with the oven-roasted prawns - I have never seen prawns that big nor cooked that way, and I was...in heaven.

We also had a completely reasonably-priced ($38) bottle of Sardinian wine...also exceptional.

While I can see why others may have found the service lacking (there did seem to be too few servers), ours was actually great.  No complaints here!
author: Jillian Y.

description:
The spicy baby octopuses is where it's at. It's a pretty pristine, up-and-coming (wow People awards anyone upsetting Delfina and Flour+Water?) pasta haven in Noe Valley. 

Tips: 
- Get reservations, it's a pretty small venue. 
- Stick with the pastas and the octopus and you should be in great hands. 
- The parking situation is actually acceptable in this neighborhood...for now. 

Bottom line, I'm glad I checked out this place, and for any Italian aficionados, this is one of the spots in San Francisco to temper your palate. Real talk.
author: Abel L.

description:
We arrived promptly for our early reservation, but instead of being offered one
of the many nice, vacant tables for two in the front of the restaurant, the hostess 
marched us to a dark, crowded table all the way in the back adjacent to the restroom.  .  This did not set the right tone for a "special occasion" dinner.  When we asked for a better table, she looked a bit sheepish as if she knew what she had offered was a poor choice.    We certainly did not get the warm welcome we were
led to expect.
When we were eventually seated at a nice table,  our waiter was great -- service was perfect, clear explanations and delicious food.   A bit pricey, especially the wines available by the glass,  and a poor selection of beers.
author: Ann B.

description: Service was spotty, wine glasses came with lipstick stains and food is overrated!
author: Gene H.

description: SUPERB food.  Some of the dishes are good, some are excellent, but enough are outstanding that this should be a destination for you.  Off the beaten path.  Strongly recommended: Squid ink pasta and any flavor of their homemade gelato.  Both are mind-altering.
author: harold k.

description: If you are coming from Europe, and are familiar with real Italian food, you'll find this place very disappointing :-(
author: Ziv Z.

description:
One of the best italian food that I ever tasted. It was tuesday night around 8:30 PM and the restaurant is busy. All the seats are full so we have to wait to sit at the bar. We had the octopus stew, seafood salad(special for the night), fresh linguine with squid ink and the special linguine of the night. 
All of them are delicious. The chef was there and he is down to earth. Will definitely come back here soon.
author: Ronny B.

description:
Hands down, the BEST Italian food I have ever had outside of Italy!  I was in town recently to run the Nike Women's Marathon and my brother in law suggested La Ciccia (he lives in SF, is a regular here, and has always given great food recommendations) for my Friday night carb up dinner.  We had a table for 6 people with reservations at 6 pm and even though two in our party were a half an hour late, the staff never once made us feel rushed or guilty that we had two empty seats at our table for so long on such a busy night.

Now for the good stuff -- for appetizers we had the octopus stew, pumpkin soup, sardines, burrata cheese plate, flatbread, and calamari...did I mention we like to eat?!  Everything was delicious...I love when you can taste the freshness and high quality of the ingredients in each bite.  Particularly delicious was the octopus stew...it just had this really homey flavor...I'm not sure how else to describe it.  Also, the burrata cheese was rich but light and tasty...loved the arugula salad on the side of it.  

For entrees we got the gnochetti (not sure of the spelling), spaghetti with bottarga, squid ink pasta, rigatoni with veal sausage (special of the day), and seared lamb with balsamic sauce.  Again, everything was delicious, but especially delicious was the spaghetti with bottarga...creamy and rich with just the right amount of fish-bottarga flavor.

Our table also had two bottles of wine.  The bill with 20%+ tip came to $62/pp...not bad at all considering how much good, quality, yummy food and wine our table had!  This is definitely a place where you feel like the dinner is well worth what you pay.
author: Susan W.

description:
I went here for my birthday and it was simply one of the most increadible meals I have ever had.

When you look at the pasta portions, you might think you are being slighted (I mean come on, when you have places like Cheesecake Factory, any portion short of gargantuan makes most people feel they are being shorted, but I digress) but the flavor...oh...my....goodness....the FLAVOR! Every bite is rich and savory and causes you to make those "oh wow this is good" moaning sounds. 

Dessert was absolutely fantastic. I don't even think words can do justice to how wonderful this place is. It is one of those rare places where you really can choose ANYTHING off the menu and won't be disappointed in the slightest.

When you walk in it might seem a little loud (since it is a relatively small space), but I had no problem conversing with the other people at my table. Lorella's hospitality is unparalleled, the food is spectacular, and if this place doesn't get listed as one of the best in San Francisco there must be something gravely wrong with the rating system.
author: Vanessa J.

description:
I finally got the chance to try this place out! 
I figure I would take my boyfriend here to eat before our show to wicked since he LOVES italian food. 

We got the baby octopus for our appetizer and it was well executed. The broth that came with the octopus was amazing!  We got the seafood linguine with squid ink and the fish. They were both delicious! 

My boyfriend loved the squid ink linguine and would of course drive back all the way to the city for it! For desserts, we got the Sardinian Ricotta and Saffron Cake, it was perfect. A flavorful, light dessert that didn't feel too heavy but was suffice for the sweet craving. 

As far as ambiance--it gave me a romantic/ intimacy vibe. It is a cute little small place so it's intimate for two or even a small group of 6 would still fit perfectly at this restaurant. If you want to come here just for a small bite and a glass a wine-- feel free to! They also have bar seating!

Parking kind of sucked....so good luck with that! We had to park at least 5 blocks away. I'm pretty sure it's more of a challenge on a busier night like a friday or saturday.
author: Li Z.

description:
Only recently discovered this restaurant after watching Check Please.

Had a really amazing meal here last night.  Highlights were the roasted squid, linguine with grated tuna heart (right up there with Incanto's) & the gelato sampler!

We aren't big fans of Italian wines.  Our server recommended 3 different reds, all were delicious!  

Definitely a new fav restaurant!
author: Cheryl B.

description:
This is the best Italian restaurant in SF as far as we're concerned.  It took us about a year and half to get here since we moved but La Ciccia blew us away.  We walked in without a reservation and were seated immediately (a rarity but, . . . timing is everything).  

For our appetizers we had a Sardinian prosciutto, shaved by the chef himself and cheese on Sardinian flatbread.  Both were amazing.  For the main course, I had a lamb tenderloin and my wife had the special ravioli.  I have a bias against upscale ravioli as a restaurant food choice but the quality here changed my view.  The lamb tenderloin was so good it should be a controlled substance.

We will come here again and again.  We will bring out of town relatives here.  I will bring clients whom I'm trying to impress here.  

My mouth is watering just remembering our dinner.
author: Jim K.

description: First time having Sardinian food. I'm a fan.
author: Noah F.

description:
I am an Italian American of 100% Sicilian ancestry. I grew up in a home with my Sicilian immigrant grandparents and they spent a lot of time impressing upon me the supreme importance of hospitality in Italian culture. Italian food is half food and half ritual without both components you have either bad food or an experience that satisfies the palate and not the soul. La Ciccia is so authentic that I have lost the will to go to any other Italian restaurant in San Francisco. I'm sure there are other great Italian places in the city but it's a 70 mile drive and I don't have the time to be disappointed. It's a known quantity. 

 Lorella the wife of the husband and wife team runs the front of the house and has the ability to project hospitality, passion, positivity and respect in marathon sessions. Massimo, the husband half does the food, it's regional and distinct and executed with remarkable consistency. The octopus stew is brilliant. If they are not there the place is closed.

La Ciccia is small and very popular, be patient when it gets crowded and don't let anyone fool you if they had a bad experience there it's either a fluke, they don't understand Italian food or they are the type that are difficult satisfy.

This is the best in SF
author: Joey C.

description:
Best Italian in San Francisco.  Bar none.

The must-haves are the octopus stew, calamari starter and the pasta with sea urchin and shaved tuna heart.  The lamb loin is also super-duper well executed.

For the wine, try a Turriga from Sardinia.  The 2004 - 2006 are impressively good and drinkable right now.
author: Ben G.

description:
Weekly Cheat Meal Alert!

Rating: 9

Dish(es): Octopus Stew, Grilled Calamari, Spaghittusu Cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga, Lamb Dish, Gelato, Wine

Review: Very simple and refreshing. All dishes were prepared with no more than 4-5 ingredients. Perfect combination of flavors. 

  - Octopus stew lived to the hype, very tender and the sauce was ridddicilously good. 

  - Calamari - Mediterranean style with fresh herbs dressing. Tender and light.

  - Lamb was perfectly cooked, the condiments were good. 

  - Among gelatos, goat cheese and fig was one of a kind, worth a trip by itself.

Cheat meal well spent.
author: Athlete W.

description:
The food here is amazing. Anything one orders on the menu will NEVER be a bad choice.
The only reason why i gave it a 4/5 is because 1) it gets busy really fast and since the place is somewhat small, there is always a wait when dinner time comes and 2) it is somewhat pricey especially for the portion you get.
Overall it's an amazing place to try and occasionally indulge at.
author: Kevin W.

description: It's a popular cute restaurant in the Noe valley, reservations are a must for a busy Saturday night. When it comes to service I would say it's very good, when it comes to food - mediocre and overpriced in my view (increasingly common experience in San Francisco for me unfortunately). We shared an appetizer special - which included few sad pieces of commercial grade mozzarella (kind you buy in the supermarket in plastic tub filled with milk serum) with a tiny Arugula salad so overdressed with oil and vinegar it was impossible for me to tell if it's Arugula or lawn grass. That was $16. We also had sardinian flat bread for $8 and I am sad to report that you can get better one in Trader Joe's (imported from Italy, for $3). On to pasta dishes, I ordered their Fresh Spaghetti Spicy Garlic Oil Salt Cured Fish Roe for $22. Pasta was indeed fresh and cooked well. Unfortunately it was also drenched in some sort of cheap industrial oil that formed a large pool at the bottom of the dish. It also had unpleasant artificial aftertaste. My companion ordered Sardinian Fregula Sea Urchin Tomato Shaved Tuna Heart also for $22. Grain size pasta was probably ok but I couldn't tell because it was drowned in heavy tomato cream based sauce. I see no point in using Sea Urchin or Tuna Heart in this dish because ground fish tales would taste just the same overpowered by the sauce. For dessert we shared Sardinian Ricotta and Saffron Cake Honey and Toasted Almond for $9. It was basically sandy dry 'ricotta' you get in the plastic tub at Safeway with some almonds on the top. Thanks to very attentive service I had plenty of water so I didn't choke. My mood was not helped by a next table where grown up daughter and her father proceeded to drink a bottle of wine and their loud conversation turned from artificial pleasantries to nastiness I would rather not listen to. At the end of the day I have a simple choice if I want a decent pasta dish - Michelin level place in San Francisco (SPQR or Acquerello) or a trip to Italy. So sad!
author: Mikhail K.

description:
Don't go here, or take your friends here if you are not a seafood-faring type.  My bf, "the pescetarian" (ha!), almost had a turn around and run reaction when we got the menu.  Anyway, dinner worked out quite well despite all the sea-creature squeamishness.

-Spaghetti with bottarga - tasted pretty good (although I would've gone lighter on the bottarga; it's there for dimension and texture - not to be the spotlight), smells pretty funky LOL
-Seared lamb tenderloin - best lamb I've had all year.  Seriously. Tender, juicy, flavorful, yum. Honestly, this is the reason I'm giving 4 stars, if it wasn't for the lamb I'd probably go with 3.5 stars
-Sauteed shrimp with tomato sauce - bf gave this one a big thumbs up

Really long wine list as well. Enjoy!
author: Priscilla T.

description:
We had been looking forward to dinner at La Ciccia for a few weeks after seeing it featured on Check Please!  We had the Sardine appetizer, seafood pasta, salmon special and almond cake.  I loved the olive tapanade topping on the salmon and cabbage--very very tasty.  The salmon was fresh but nothing special.  All in all we were a bit disappointed because La Ciccia did not live up to the reviews on Check Please.  While the food was just OK and expensive, the service was outstanding.  The woman that took the last minute reservation on the phone was kind and accommodating.  The woman that greeted us was delightful and our waiter was fantastic--well informed, attentive and full of recommendations!

We won't go back because the food was just ok but are tempted because the service was exemplary!
author: Jeff P.

description:
Finally, a review after at least 5 visits to this restaurant. The food here is consistently delicious, the atmosphere is cozy, and the wine list is so long you should just let them pick for you. Highly recommend the calamari, octopus, and the spaghetti with the cured fish roe. You need to mix the roe into your pasta after they serve it to you so you don't just get a big mouthful of it at once- it is freaking amazing. I have dreams about this pasta and always end up ordering it every time. The owners are lovely and they treat their guests like family. 

This is not a super fancy scene or hipster hotspot; authentic, regional food is the star here. I started making reservations about once a month at La Ciccia well in advance because they book up very fast, especially on weekends. I don't get some of the comments about the prices being high; they are reasonable and the portions are generous. I have never tried the pizza so I can't vouch for it!
author: Mar D.

description: This is hands down one of the most authentic Italian restaurants in San Francisco with two owners who put their love, art and passion into each 'piatto' they prepare. And what keeps me coming back, aside from the most delicious and mouth watering spaghetti alla bottarga I have ever had (and being the owner of an Italian travel and language school I have traveled all over Italy - and Sardegna - in search of fine foods), is the hospitality and personal attention that I feel each time I enter this little jewel of Noe Valley.  A big grazie mille and cinque stelle (5 stars) to Massi and Laurella for bringing some old world amore to our neighborhood.  Juztino
author: Juztino P.

description: The most delicious authentic Italian restaurant in the city with very generous portions. We tried spec, burrata salad, calamari (WOW!), and pasta. Everything was fresh and perfectly cooked. They also have good selection of olive oils to serve with your bread, and a solid wine list. All the staff is very friendly and helpful, and the ambience is very relaxed and homey. Outstanding food and service without being prohibitively expensive.
author: Ekaterina M.

description:
My boyfriend took me here on my birthday.  I always crave Italian for special events and he did an absolutely great job at selecting a nice restaurant to celebrate my big day.

We made reservations at 8:30, but didn't get seated till 9:00.  The hostess seemed like she had forgotten about our reservation, but we have already  looked over the menu and saw some sample dishes on others tables.  We had an idea of what we wanted.

What we ordered:
- Octopus Stew ($12)
- Roasted Calamari ( $12)
- Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga ($17) 
- Rigatoni with beef ragu ( about $18 )
- Seafood Linguini with Squid Ink ( about $18 )
- Gelato Sampler ( Goat Cheese, Chocolate and Lavendar? - on the house since it was my birthday! )

We had so much food and every dish was amazing.  My favorite was the octopus stew and the squid ink seafood linguini.  I was blown away by how tasty the goat cheese gelato tasted.  I know, it sounds a little off, but the combination with some raisins took away the after taste of goat cheese after the first bite.  

Overall, I was very satisfied with our meal and I would love to come back again!
author: Nancy S.

description: This place was absolutely adorable. I came on a Sunday night so chef Massimo wasn't there unfortunately, but we had a phenomenal meal and great wine. We started with the calamari with basil oil (amazing). We took the awesome bread and soaked it up in the fishy oil juices. Omg, delicious. Then we had a bottle of a Tuscan blend with our gnocchetti and spaghetti with bottarga and spicy oil. For dessert, we had the sorbetti and the ricotta cake with saffron. Pure perfection. The service was amazing, everyone spoke Italian, and the Sardinian culture was beautifully portrayed through the excellent cuisine. Can't wait to come back.
author: Sheeva G.

description:
A bit of a wait. But great food generously served and well seasoned. 
Very rustic sardinian and quite authentic.
Loved it.
author: Russell N.

description:
Wow - this place is AMAZING!

I came in with a party of 4 and ordered all of the following: ricotta appetizer, baby octopus stew, bottargia pasta, squid ink pasta, whole prawns, special lamb/porchini mushroom pasta, trio of gelato & trio of sorbet.

I was DD, but my party said the wine was excellent and the sweet marsala was incredible.

Everything was absolutely delicious and perfectly cooked.  Service was great and the staff was super nice.

We'll be back for sure!  Thank you!
author: C S.

description:
When I try a place that is mind-blowing on the first go-round I tend to worry it's a fluke.  Next time the kitchen will be asleep at the wheel.  Or the most talented cook got hit by a bus since the last visit.  Whatever.  Bad karma happens.

Not here.  La Ciccia is really just un-freaking-believable.  

The fresh linguine with fava beans and sausage is **what pasta is about**.

The pasta is fresh, still immaculately al dente, the sauce is thin enough to make the noodles the star, and there is enough starch to ensure it *sticks*.  And, most importantly, the fava beans and sausage have absorbed enough of the sauce to be *integrated* into the dish properly.

Let me reiterate the basic point here:  this is *what pasta is about*.  A good pasta dish is complete on two levels:  texturally it is about the *pasta*, and flavor-wise it is about the *total integration of all elements*.  Getting both of these elements right is very, very difficult, a high-wire act, and here it is pulled off elegantly.  They make it look easy.

It's just very rare to see this level of execution in Italian food; I haven't seen it in two-Michelin-star places in New York City run by certain men in clogs, and most certainly never here in San Francisco.  

The best way to describe the lamb dish is "magical."  I was a little worried when I saw the squeeze-bottled balsamic on the plate (IMO balsamic as a garnish of any sort is a very mid-90s affair).  But this dish is no bullshit.  The lamb is sliced thin, perfectly cooked and seasoned (including nice hints of fennel seed) and served with this long-cooked red pepper and broccoli business that belongs in the finale to a certain Pixar movie.  

What more can I say about La Ciccia?  

Well, first off, please, if this review makes you want to go here, please, erase it from your mind.  Here, let me get out my neuralizer and zap you.  This place is hard enough to get into already.  What am I doing here on Yelp at 1am trying to convince more people to come.  Move along folks, nothing to see here ...
author: J W.

description:
OVERALL:4.4   FOOD:4.5   SERVICE:5   AMBIANCE:4   VALUE:4
No Spaghetti Boring-nese here...just quality, rich, rustic, seafood-centric Sardinian fare you wouldn't typically find around these parts, least of all Noe Valley.  And a lot of it comes with tentacles attached or swimming in inky brininess...and it's all DELIZIOSO!

OCTOPUS IN SPICY TOMATO STEW: Kiss your rubbery octopus ciao!  Hearty, tender & soooo slurpable! (but please don't!).

LAMB TENDERLOIN: best lamb EVER.  Tenderness, texture & flavor to die for!  Perfectly done.

RIGATONI w/CHANTERELLES: homemade pasta & mushroom ragu that's sultry like Sofia Loren...with truffle oil drizzled on top!

Winelist is exclusively Italian, and servers are like the whiz kids of Restaurant-dom.  Upwards of 10 specials w/full description+prices, and not a stutter or um to be heard.  I was all, like...WHOAAA.

You won't forget this menu!
author: Amy K.

description:
A real keeper with great food that one does not find everywhere,given its focus on Sardinian fare. 

The size and popularity of La Ciccia presents its greatest challenge. Given the difficulty of getting a reservation at a desirable time and the understandable warnings about space, parking and being prompt, the thought going in creates a tension that is not the most pleasant way to start a meal.

However, the food overcomes the tension. One enjoys the fare. We had a rigatoni with veal/pork that was perfectly cooked, al dente, moist, flavorful and delish. The flatbread is amazing.

Given the space constraints the techie table behind us gave us information on private banking, venture capital funding and opportunities we would rather not have endured. The larger the table near you, the more the noise is heard.
All in all, the food and efficient service carried the evening...6 to 7:30.

Would have been five stars if not for the hurry to meet the requirements of the establishment.
author: Jim C.

description:
After reading all the good reviews about this pace, I was mesmerized and wanting to go. Therefore, I decided to have dinner there on my birthday. 

I have always believed in this saying: "high expectations bring out low results" ... !!! I really don't see what's the big deal about this place.

We have ordered four items from the menu (menu was slightly different from what I found online, so I didn't get what I really wanted ... )

1. Arugula Salad ($10): not too bad, just bit salty
2. Linguine with Squid Ink ($16): nothing suprising, I had this before
3. Tomato sauce Mozzarella and Basil Pizza ($12): I actually like the pizza crust very much, and the marinara sauce is pretty flavorful without the tangy texture; I liked it !
4. Pan Seared Bream served with Sardinian Olives ($26): you could tell it was fresh fish, but nothing really caught my taste buds

The worst thing of the night was my birthday complimentary dessert: it was kinda cheap and just simply lame. People spent time and money to go to your restaurant to explore on their birthdays ... Can u just offer something better to add-up some sparkle towards the end for the birthday girl ?!

As an conclusion, I was not amazed about this place; at the same time, I was a little disappointed. I am not a high-end customer, but you are not a high-end restaurant either. Therefore, there is no need to prohibit using of cell phones, cameras and computers ... !!!

Not recommended for newcomers or birthday ppl ... !!!

I am not going again ... !!!
author: Yvonne X.

description: Came back here last night. The foods are superb as always. Had the bottariga,special fettucine and fregola sea urchin pasta. It cooked perfectly and the octopus stew and calamari always be a winner. Moreover, Lorella would make you feel at home. Will come back soon :)
author: Ronny B.

description:
While its signature anchovy salad, octopus and tuna heart/sea urchin pasta were tasty enough, they were incredibly, fantastically over-salted.

All these seafood products probably came out of a can, imported, probably from Sardinia.  Hence they're highly salted.  Then the kitchen seems to add another layer of salt to boot.

Message to La Ciccia:  Salt isn't flavor.
author: V L.

description:
It's a cryin' shame I don't make it down to Noe more often.  (I thought I was allergic to strollers, but apparently not!)  I've waited too long to try La Ciccia...and I'm such a fan of Sardinian food.  Bah.  In any case...

Between the sardines (ohmygod...salty, yummy goodness...I could have LICKED that plate clean!), the daily special burrata (you love one, you love 'em all!), and the baked calamari (that's right, no deep fryin' here!), I was in heaven.

Add the pizza with capers (yes please!) and the gnochetti w/ pork sauce and you pretty much start to hear the choirs sing.  

BUT, do NOT leave w/o having the sorbet/gelato desserts.  Hazelnut, blood orange, fig/goat cheese, pineapple...(i have to stop now or I might start to cry.)

Go.  NOW.  

PS - we made fun of ourselves for having 5:30pm resi's on a Saturday night.  Uh...now, we're patting ourselves on the back.  That place was full and packed by 6pm.  Plan ahead.
author: Susan L.

description:
How good is La Ciccia?  Their reputation encouraged me to try pasta with squid ink.  Ever seen squid ink on TV?  And yet now I'm basically an evangelist for it - and the restaurant too, as you can see.  Every dish, including the free bread, was good and plentiful.  I went ahead and agreed to dessert too, even though I was full already.

This is a good date spot, though not within walking distance to much else.  I look forward to enjoying the food, service and ambience again.  Hopefully the proximate seating won't put you off.  In my experience, it isn't unusual among good and/or small restaurants located in large cities, SF included.
author: Mike H.

description:
We came here for my birthday and was very happy with all of our dishes. The restaurant is easy to miss from the outside, but very cute and modern on the inside. 

We had calamari to start (not fried, but steamed), seafood stew, and the flatbread. Both seafood dishes were delicious, but I would only recommend  1 of them because the calamari could also be found in the stew. The flatbread was delicious, very thin and crispy. A perfect appetizer to hold you over until the main courses arrive.

For our main dishes we ordered the trout and spaghetti. The trout was very clean and light and the spaghetti was super flavorful (it's a surprisingly yellow, not red spaghetti). I would highly recommend this dish! 

The sapphron cake for dessert was brought out with a birthday candle and the staff was absolutely lovely. Overall a great experience!
author: Tracy L.

description:
Yum. 

Extensive wine list. Very challenging to read. It's all squeezed into the back of the menu. Possibly hundred different choices. Or more. 

We had the fregula tomato sea urchin tuna heart, which was very tasty, and the squid ink pasta which was not as rich but quite tasty too. 

It's a small cozy restaurant. Be prepared to be in tight quarters. Flavors are different and definitely memorable. Don't come here expecting Alfredo or bolognese sauce.
author: Chloe L.

description: Perfect dining experience. Can't wait to go back. Excellent service. Knowledgeable wine recommendations and perfect pacing. We loved it.  Every dish we had was spectacular.
author: Roxanne M.

description:
This place is a gem. Went knowing very little about Sardinian food, and left feeling like it was another place among the many places I want to spend a week in Italy and the wider Mediterranean.

Go here and order anything you seem unfamiliar with. Shaved dried tuna hearts on your pasta. Embrace the metallic, earthy flavors dancing with olive oil in ways that jar yet please you. Order some Cannonau, my newest European value wine obsession. Everything is executed well, and done with simple yet powerful elegance. You'll leave understanding how little you really know about many of the best food regions in the world.

Watch Bourdain's episode before you go, wish I did, you'll appreciate it way more. The owners are also very present, and warm. Portions are also generous, so don't be bashful about sharing in a group.
author: Kevvy K.

description: If you do not like La Ciccia, you are wrong. And probably a bad person. Definitely a terrible lover.
author: Collin C.

description:
I came here, as it was recommended by a friend (who happens to be a great chef). He definitely steered me in the right direction. This has been one of the best dining experiences I've had in the Bay Area yet! 

I'd recommend making a reservation...this place is small, intimate, and tables fill up fast. The ambiance is effortlessly elegant, simple, yet comfortable and not pretentious. The service was attentive, relaxed, and sincere. The staff want you to experience their food and have an amazing experience, and they are super friendly. 

Now, on to the food. We started with the roasted calamari and shared a side of the Sardinian flat bread. The calamari were tender yet toothsome, and the basil oil was the perfect compliment; really light dish, and please sop up some of the basil oil with the bread (not the flat bread). The flat bread was good, simple, flavored well, great crunch. 
For out mains, I had the Spaghetti with Bottarga. This was amazing. Slight kick from the simple sauce, good saltiness from the bottarga, and the pasta was PERFECTLY cooked. I was so sad when my plate was finished :( My friend had the squid ink pasta which was perfect, well seasoned. Another friend had the roasted wild prawns, which i didn't try, but she loved them and they looked delicious. 
For desert, we had the famed Ricotta and Saffron cake and the gelato trio. Perfect end to our meal. The ricotta cake was light, airy, wonderful, and not overly sweet. The gelato was also amazing, but I can't remember what flavors we had...!
Our server also assisted us in picking a wine that went well with our meal, that was moderately priced. 

All in all, this was a wonderful dining experience from start to finish. I will definitely come back, as often as I can afford to :)
author: Salvina B.

description: Overrated. Nothing special about any of the dishes, even the bread was tasteless. It's not worth anyone's wait. Let alone needing to make reservations a month in advance.
author: Rami B.

description:
I can find no fault in this dining experience. Zip nada.

Upon entering, I was a little put off my the ambiance of the room and the closeness of the tables. It became irrelevant soon after sitting down.

Staff were all helpful in deciphering both the food and wine menus - likely you will need the same unless you have Sardinian bloodlines.

The menu changes regularly so no need to tell you what to order. 
Know this:
*a large number of dishes have fish or seafood of some sort in them.
*dishes are light, flavors are bright, combinations may surprise you
*everything is from scratch, in house.
*octopus, clams, pasta, risotto, pizza, squid ink tomato sauce (oh yes!)...
*save the bread for soaking up sauce
*order the flatbread with rosemary if you want a carby snack while you wait (minimal)
*share dishes
*save room for dessert

Come back soon.

(Or order ahead for take-out and don't sweat not having a reservation)
author: Alissa A.

description:
Oh man their octopus soup is yum yum. Although they give you almost a bit too much. Usually when I love my food so much that I want to eat the actual dish it's served in too, I'm left wanting more of the delicious goodness. This one definitely left me wishing I had eaten less. I felt like I had 10,000 baby octopi/octopuses/octopodes swimming around in my tummy for the next few hours. 

Fresh spaghetti with young garlic and roe = win. Super tasty. The roe adds an awesome and slightly unexpected crunch. Definitely no shortage of garlic. Probably my favorite dish of the night, even though the octopus soup was super tasty and tender.

Everything else was lovely...the service, the wine, the decor, but nothing else really stuck out as crazy memorable.

Whenever I'm offered a clearly visible table or told there's another option in the back, I always have an internal debate over which one to take. Usually the table I can see is just fine, but I'm always intrigued by the possibility of an absolutely fantastic mysterious tucked away find. 

Well folks, not here. I let my imagination get the best of me and chose the table in the back, which was definitely not so stellar. Right next to the bathroom and wafting smells of mop bucket = fail. Do yourself a favor and go for the perfectly acceptable front tables...there's no hidden gem that awaits you in the back.
author: Monica C.

description:
Fantastic, fantastic, fantastic! I went with my girlfriend last night and had one of the best restaurant experiences I have ever had.

We had the baby octopus in a spicy tomato sauce for appetizer, followed by the sardines (special) and the linguine in squid ink. All the dishes were well presented and marvelously tasty yet subtle.

The recommended wine went well with the lightly flavored food, and the service was friendly, helpful, and informative. I thoroughly recommend this place to everyone!
author: Paul F.

description:
I wanted to love this place. It was my birthday. It was written up in the NYT. La Ciccia is a five minute walk from my house.

The food was OK. Burrata was very good, but I'm capable of scooping cheese onto a plate. Calamari was oily. The pasta was pretty good. The bread was out of a bag. The dessert tasted like dog turd. 

That's a 2.5.

Getting us into hallowed 1 territory: I can confidently say this was the worst service at a restaurant that I've had in years. Our waitress:
-Spoke unintelligently. I told her I couldn't understand her, and her solution was to speak only to my wife for the rest of the meal.
-Cut me off in the middle of ordering.
-Threw food at us as fast as frisbees.
-Interrupted me while waiting in line for the bathroom to tell me to go back to my seat to have my pasta while it was still hot. Fortunately, three minutes later, the pasta was still warm.
-Commented that I'd rather watch the Giants game than have dessert. Which, at that point, was absolutely true. All day I've wished I told her off then.
-Gave off vibes of ice and evil. 

My favorite moment of this meal was leaving. Seriously. 

On the way home, the sushiman over at Ichi Sushi on Mission waved at me vigorously from the window, and I deeply regretted not going there instead. Don't make my mistake!
author: matt s.

description:
We first came here about a month after it opened, and were delighted by each and every dish we had. It was excellent.

Since then, we've been back a few times, and always feel warmly greeted and seated, and the cuisine has only gotten better. Did I mention the wines? Such a list, such a delight.

This is not a cuisine most folks know, if at all. Sardinia clearly is well represented by La Ciccia, such a great place. Enjoy!
author: William M.

description:
Words are inadequate.  

Do you love authentic Italian food, emphasis on Sardinia/Liguria?  Just go.  You'll not be displeased.

P.S. Great wine list.  Explore something new with every visit.
author: Dave C.

description:
When you ask me what my favorite restaurants are in SF, La Ciccia is one of the first ones to come to mind.  

The Octopus Stew is to die for.
Fregula is amazeballs! 
And their pastas and other specials are always top notch. 

I must say, the pizzas are good but not as great as their pastas, appetizers, and main courses. So skip the pizza to save room 
for those dishes.

I also love their wine selection. The people who work there always 
know the perfect wine to pair our meal with, within a reasonable price range. I would definitely recommend going there with a romantic partner.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
We in SF are lucky to have this little gem in our backyards. It's always a treat, and the food is the real deal. It really does feel like a family is taking care of you.

Food is always spectacular, the real deal. Everything everyone says here is correct.

Do note that the place is rather cozy, and there is no fan or circulation. So if it's a hot day, try to sit near the door for some occasional breeze. :)
author: Ches W.

description: My wife and I went to La Ciccia for a date night, and were treated to excellent service, and incredible authentic Sardinian cuisine.  The calamari, burrata cheese, and lamb were all amazing.  I highly recommend La Ciccia for a very romantic dining experience.
author: Kumi W.

description:
squid ink pasta - zesty, lemony, and rich all at the same time. delish. 
seafood stew - tomato-y, healthy tasting, and muy filling. 
gnocchetti w. pork - hearty; for that one guy in your party who isn't into fish. 
pasta with fish roe - my absolute favorite dish there!

i live so close to this place that's it's easy to call in my order and pick it up 10 minutes later. i usually don't dine in, but tuesday nights are slower than most, so I paid the ol' establishment a visit hoping they could accommodate a walk in. And they could!

the service was exceptional, and I walked away from the restaurant feeling semi-ethical i didn't order the veal.
author: Tracy N.

description:
Deserves every one of the four and a half stars.  A unique spot in the Bay Area - with a Sardinian menu that has some unusual offerings (pasta with shaved tuna heart, anyone?) but plenty of familiar-feeling dishes for the less adventurous as well (we enjoyed a lovely gnochetti - tiny shell pasta - with a tomato-based pork ragu, and one of our dining companions had a simple mushroom pizza).  

It's been a while since we've been here and we were happy to see that they've really upped the number of vegetarian dishes - at least a few of the pasta dishes and a couple of the pizzas.  That said, they do meats nicely as well.

Extremely comprehensive (though unfamiliar) wine list, luckily our server was able to steer us to a delicious and reasonably priced bottle, because between the dim lighting, the two point font and the hundreds of Italian wines we'd never heard of, we would have been totally lost.  Service was impeccable - friendly, very knowledgeable, but not hovering or obsequious.  The lovely owner Lorella stopped by to check in and make sure we enjoyed our meal, and we noticed that she greeted most diners like old friends.

La Ciccia combines the feel of an intimate neighborhood restaurant with world-class cooking and an unusual cuisine that you won't find in a lot of places - a winning combination!
author: Katy M.

description:
I had the good fortune to live in Italy (Florence) for a year during college. During that year I traveled all over Italy eating my way through every town, village and city. Due this experience I'm very picky about "Italian cuisine". La Ciccia serves the same sort of food that you would find off the beaten track in Italy.  For appetizers my date and I shared the octopus stew and the grilled Montery calamari. Both dishes were amazing and exemplified the basis to all great Italian food: fresh, high quality ingredients prepared in a way that doesn't mess with  the natural essence of the food. Next I had the lamb served with a reduction of grape must over Swiss Chard sauteed with pancetta. The lamb was perfectly cook and the reduction tasted like a balsamic reduction without the acidic element (excellent!). My date had the Trout which she likes so much she wouldn't talk to me until it was all gone. 

The service was great! In a pleasant atmosphere where you don't have to scream to be heard even during the busiest time.

This restaurant is also a great choice for people with gluten and dairy issues. The kitchen uses no butter in it's cooking and  most all the dairy is from sheep. 

I've read some of the negative reviews and when I hear someone say that this food is "boring" its obvious to me that they don't have a very sensitive palette. Authentic food like this is not for people who need to be clubbed over the head with salt, spice or deep frying. 

I can't wait to go back again!
author: Michael W.

description: Incredible Sardinian food. Definitely in my top ten meals this year. I can't wait I go back soon.
author: Matt G.

description:
I feel like Sardinian food is hard to find!  My friend first came here over the summer and was raving about how great the food was and how cute the place was.  It's definitely hidden, and fortunately, parking around here is pretty easy.  The space is definitely small, so make a reservation!  The place was packed on a Thursday night, but right when you walk in, you're greeted warmly, and everyone working there genuinely seems to enjoy being there.

The wine list is mostly Italian, so we went with a Sardinian wine recommended by our server. I was pleasantly surprised by how much she knew about the wines.

We did everything family style between the 4 of us..
- Mixed greens: simple, but the dressing was a bit heavy for my tastes
- Baby octopus stew: great for dipping bread, rich, lots of flavor. We started to just spoon the liquid like a soup until we realized there was a layer of olive oil floating on top
- Fetuccini: special of the day with lamb ragu and porcinis.  The ribbon pasta held the sauce well, and I really loved the scent of the porcinis
- Linguini: with seafood sugo and squid ink.  The pasta was rich, thick, black, and had great seafood flavor.
- Gnochetti: with pork sugo and parmigianno. I love the pork ragu and cheese combination. I don't like gnocchi, but this pasta was longer and had a better bite, and it was a close contender for my favorite of the night
- Prawns: split open, roasted with pepperoncino; again, sauce is great for dipping bread (comes with 4 prawns)
- Lamb tenderloin: definitely get it medium rare, loved the drizzle of sweet glaze on top and the caramelized greens in the center

Then as we looked through the desserts, we decided to back and get the spaghetti with bottarga, which was the best decision ever since that was my favorite of the night.  The savoriness of the bottarga (reminded me of bonito flakes, subtle) and the spice from the oil was the perfect combination for the spaghetti. The spaghetti was thicker and was the best example of perfectly cooked fresh hand made pasta.  I think this was clearly the most popular dish at our table.

Food was different from the typical Italian places, and everything was executed well.  The setting would actually be really nice for a date, too. My only complaint was the fruit flies that kept landing on our wine glasses, water glasses, etc.  In the end, with tip, it was about $68 a person, and we were all stuffed.  The ?owner also checked in personally at the end to ensure we enjoyed our meal, and I love the family run feel of the place!
author: Marilyn H.

description: I arrived alone without a reservation,and was seated at the bar. That was a great place to be as I could chat with the staff about what was the best thing to eat. I ordered three plates  of the best seafood I have ever eaten in California -  especially the Octopus Soup. Added bonus - a beautiful young lady sat near me at the bar, and though I had arrived alone,I did not leave alone....
author: Blaine Z.

description:
Yes I know, its one of my fav restaurants in SF too. Why? Because its not just about the food- its the combo of the food, the ambiance, the attentive servers and the owners- Lorella and Massimo (that we got to know after eating there a couple of times). 

If you're looking for nuevo or bells and whistles or California-ized or hip and trendy you'll be disappointed. The food is straight up old country style where simple ingredients speak for themselves. This is where you actually order an app, a pasta, a main with wine for a complete meal. The ambiance is unpretentious, simple and cozy. I assume I'm in Sardinia. This place, their spaghetti and bottarga plus Anthony Bourdain's episode makes me want to visit that island! And lastly, Lorella with her genuine passion in taking good care of us. She's professional, warm and always makes you feel welcomed.
author: Nusantara S.

description:
You should eat at La Cicca if:

1)  You adore seafood.  Sardinian cuisine focuses on seasonal, fresh ingredients.  As an island region, seafood obviously plays a big part in this!  They have, hands-down, the best calamari appetizer I've ever had in my life.  The spaghetti with spicy oil and Bottarga is delightfully spicy and fishy.

2) You like Italian food, but are looking for something different.  For me, this is the key thing to note about La Cicca.  There is a lot going on here in the flavor department and your palate can expect some exhiliration.  Think:  baked Sardinian flat bread, Lamb and goat ragu, octopus stew, wild shrimps with fresh tomatoes....

3)  You appreciate good wine.  The Italian wine list here is beyond impressive and borderline intimidating!  Just tell them what you like; they'll help you out.
