4)  You want an upscale dining experience, but still desire the feel of a mom and pop restaurant.  Lorella and Massimo treat you as if you are a guest in their home.  You may even get a hug on the way out!

5)  You don't mind fulfiling the prophecy of the namesake.  With rich ingredients that will leave you tempted to lick your plate clean, you may leave here feeling a "little fat!"
author: Kerry D.

description:
My bf took me here for valentines day this year. I've wanted to eat at La Ciccia for a long time now but it's a small place and it's always busy. Lucky for us valentines day fell on a Monday this year and because La Ciccia is usually closed on Mondays,  other Valentiners wouldn't have known they were open. 

The staff is really nice and they made it a point to make their restaurant feel homey as far as the way they talk to you. For a fairly expensive place they are far from pretentious. I liked everything I had there, but of course a few things were better than others. The spaghetti with bottarga is their signature dish and was more than fantastic. Perfectly cooked spaghetti laden with tons if olive oil and garlic with bottarga. I was informed that bottarga is a dried fish that they grate to mix in with the pasta. It wasn't very fishy at all and it was pretty outstanding. Though La Ciccia serves Italian Sardinian food, it reminded me of the best pasta I've ever had, which was in Venice.

I would recommend this restaurant to anybody that appreciates simple food done extremely well.
author: Regina C.

description:
I grew up in Italy, surrounded by family members who've spoiled me with great food ever since coming out the womb.  I've been carrying those flavors and aromas with me ever since, and I have to say that La Ciccia's end product is nothing short of perfection.  I've tried many Italian restaurants here in San Francisco, but this is hands down the closest taste to home.  A wonderful Sardinian restaurant tucked away in peaceful Noe Valley.

We ordered the baby octopus stew as an appetizer, and I think I ingested a couple of bread baskets in order to soak up the sauce.  I wanted to make sure the plate was spotless so the dishwasher wouldn't have to work so hard.  Need I say more?

We followed up with the squid ink linguine with seafood sugo, and toasted fregola with sea urchin tomato and cured tuna heart.  Both were excellent, but the fregola now holds a special place in my heart, and in my belly of course.  It was unlike anything I've had before; however, its intense sea flavor brought me back to the Mediterranean and the sensational fish I was so blessed to eat everyday.

We didn't order dessert, as the freshly baked bread loaves soaked in octopus bliss from earlier were still lingering in my belly.

Service could have been a tad bit more conscientious, but I'll take impeccable food over half-assed service anyday.  I guess, it wouldn't be a true Italian restaurant if otherwise.

Oh, and did I mention they have an uber-extensive wine list? It's just beautiful!
author: Ati B.

description: Amazing!!! This is an amazing place for foodies that love sea food!! I had the squid ink for the first time and it was delicious. The experience was great, awesome ambiance and the food Excellent!!  Also the corkage fee is waved if you purchase a bottle of wine. Two bottles of wine? Why not! And they have an enormous amount of wine to pick from.
author: Julieta C.

description: It's rare that I give a place 5 stars, but this place rates excellent in everything, food, service, ambiance.  I think i was speechless when I ate the Spaghetti with fish roe. Cooked perfectly al dente. Anyone who knows what authentic tastes like, would agree.   The review below, Thomas C, sorry you really don't know what you're talking about.  I think you would probably prefer the food at Olive Garden..I'm sure they will give you butter there, LOL.
author: S G.

description:
I used to like this place, but success has made a failure to their place.


What's up with the service at this place, it was my fourth (and probably last time) and again we were seated almost 30 minutes from the time of the reservation, the owner just smiled and thanks us for waiting. I'm tiered of this place, don't double book tables, and if you don't know how to run the place, hire someone professional. 

Food was nice, but really nothing too special. The specials were actually nothing SPECIAL. The sardines dish, was the low point of the evening, the semi-freddo felt like an 80's desert. The sarda pizza was nice, but Delfina has a much better one. The pasta dishes were good, and this is definitely the strength of the kitchen, I would stay away from the wild shrimp dish, they were totally dry and over cooked.

So I guess I wouldn't be back.
author: Too M.

description:
This place is my favorite restaurant in SF. I have never had a bad meal here. In fact, I never anything I didn't love here. La Ciccia is a Mom and Pop place that makes you feel like your in their home, and they are the most hospitable people on the planet. The wine list is amazing and huge. All you need to do is tell them what characteristics you like, price range, and they will bring you something you probably have never had that goes perfectly with your meal. 

Quit waiting around and go here now!
author: Tim A.

description: If you can secure a reservation, this restaurant is a must. A small, family run eatery in Noe Valley, this is perfect if you like Italian food, particularly seafood. The menù is unlike any Italian restaurant you are likely to ever have been to, because it is inspired by Sardinian cuisine. Sardinia has an excellent culinary tradition which is rarely celebrated outside of the Mediterranean island: La Ciccia serves generous, delicious portions of an Italian food style you are unlikely to find anywhere else in the US. If you like spicy, try the Octopus stew: you'll want to write about it - believe me!
author: Daniel M.

description:
I've heard a lot about this place and I'm glad I finally got to try it.  My husband and I went with another couple so between the four of us we got to try a good portion of the menu.

To start, I got the octopus soup...it was so warm and comforting (especially in these cold San Francisco summers).  Actually reminded me of some dishes I had in Spain and Portugal.  Also got to try a bit of the burrata which my friend ordered and it was also quite delicious.  

For my main course, I had the spaghetti with bottarga...I think this is probably the single best thing they have on the menu.  The spaghetti was perfectly cooked, just the right amount of al dente, and the sauce was light but flavorful.  I can just eat this all day long.  I also got to sample the linguini with squid ink, which I also liked, and the semolina gnocchi, which I thought was just ok but my friend loved (I'm just not much of a gnocchi person).

As a self-proclaimed "cheese-aholic", I *had* to get the cheese plate for dessert.  I liked all the cheeses but preferred the aged one the most.  The different types of honey were pretty cool as well, and went well with the cheeses.  Hubby got some gelato with a strawberry topping (one of their specials) which he really liked.

The wine list was pretty reasonably-priced, and the server gave us some good recommendations based on our preferences, especially since I'm not as knowledeable about Italian wines, and have never had any Sardinian wines before.  Service in general was pretty good, I had no complaints.

Would definitely want to come back...highly recommended!
author: Arlene M.

description:
One of my favorite episode's of "No Reservations" is when Anthony Bourdain and his wife, Ottavia, head to her Italian homeland, the island of Sardinia. It was one of those episodes where I wanted to crawl into the TV and join the family lunches, dinners, and everything in-between.

Since I'm not going to travel to Sardinia anytime soon, a trip to La Ciccia would have to tied me over. And, back in April, tied me over it did. The sauteed sardines, the roasted calamari, the gnochetti with pork, the freshest barrata, the linguini with tuna heart, the pizza with capers and the pizza with asparagus and prosciutto -- all of it was delectable. 

Save room for gelato.
author: Brooke H.

description:
Flawless and we had the worst table in the house (in front of the kitchen entrance).  Service, wine, olives, octopus stew, calamari, homemade pasta, lamb chops stupendous.  I will be back again and again, and plan to get takeout as often as I can.
BRAVA!!
author: M. J.

description:
Wonderful dinner and even better service.  It's one of those great and increasingly rare places where the people who own it are also involved in cooking, telling you about the wine, and hosting.  They rally care about their restaurant and their patrons.

A couple from Sardinia (small island off the coast of Italy) own the place and it certainly has some old world charm.  The owner came over and poured us a taste of wine similar to a wine we had ordered and told us about the vineyard.  Small gesture but makes a huge difference.

Highly recommend.  It's small and tight inside, but that adds to the enjoyment.
author: Johny X.

description:
The girlfriend and I showed up late Sunday night and the place was still packed. Luckily we had a reservation.

The octopus stew appetizer was fantastic. The meat was tender and the sauce complemented it very well.

We split an order of the Gnochetti pasta for a first course and it was a simple and delicious way to start things off.

The girlfriend had a plate of giant prawns with a delicious citrus-y marinade.

I had the Lamb, which was very rich and flavorful. It was a little difficult to cut, but my teeth sank right into it, so the temperature was near perfect for me.

I tried the special imported Amber Ale they offered, and it was quite good. Reminded me of a few of the Belgian beers I regularly enjoy, but didn't compliment the Lamb as well as it might have with the Octopus. I'll order it earlier next time if I feel like another go.

For dessert, we split (and by split, I mean she got 90%) the Chocolate/Nougat/Almond thing. I don't remember the real name of it, sorry. It was very nice and a lot lighter and more subtle of a flavor than I expected.

I would recommend every dish we had that night.

Everything tasted great and was well-executed, but the prices are very steep. I wouldn't say that it wasn't worth it, but I will say that the prices are the only thing that will keep us from visiting this place weekly.
author: Corry F.

description:
When the moon hits your eye like a big pizza pie...well, you're probably not at La Ciccia, a really sweet-natured, mid-priced Sardinian eatery at the end of Church near all sorts of goodies like Pomelo, Toast and Church Street Apothecary. No checkered tablecloths. No bulbous chianti bottles with candles dripping their wax on the neck. No Lady and certainly no Tramp. No single spaghetti strand with the meatball precariously balanced in the middle. Sorry paisan.

My good friends Jonathan and Sydnie - always in the know about the city's cool eats - took me as they have passed the threshold of being regulars there. Hell, I didn't even know that Sardinia had its own cuisine. It's the island way out in the Mediterranean with only Corsica for company, and you know the French. The smiling co-owner Lorella certainly appreciated the repeated presence of my friends enough to come by twice to make sure we were enjoying our dining experience there. We were.

Everything looked good on the menu, and we shared a couple of dishes - the $21 Seared Lamb Chops in Herb Oil which came with a braised cabbage and the $10 Margherita Pizza. The pizza was simple and tasty with fresh tomato sauce and just the right thin crust. The lamb chops were tasty but only after we sent it back to be cooked a bit longer since it was too rare on the first serve. 

We also tried a couple of their specials, both $14 - a tuna heart that had been cured and sliced carpaccio-style and accompanied by braised Brussel Sprouts, and a homemade macaroni pasta dish served al dente with a meaty lamb ragu sauce. The tuna heart was unique to say the least with the salty taste of an anchovy (fortunate since I like anchovies), but the pasta was a true standout with the hearty, tender lamb the perfect complement.

Since we were so good about sharing dishes, we went overboard and tried two desserts - the $7 Ricotta and Saffron Cake with Candied Fruits and the $9 Pistachio and Roasted Almond Semifreddo. Made with no cream, the cake had a nice, soft consistency as it was swimming in a honey-like syrup. The saffron gave it a distinctly Indian tinge, though Lorella assured us it was genuinely Sardinian. The heart-shaped semifreddo was superb with the ice cream texture just right. We wolfed down both in record time.

Even though the dishes were slightly variable, the presentation was nice as was the subtle, quiet setting. Oddly, the awning is not lit up in the evening, so you may miss it if you are trying to find it the first time since it is on a residential block. Jonathan and I knew we must have hit a good spot since our former, long-ago boss (at different times) coincidentally was eating there, a self-proclaimed epicurean with Italianate preferences....yes, I did say hi.

FOOD - 4 stars...nice, homemade dishes, slightly variable but when they hit, they hit it to the bleachers
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...quiet and subtle, almost too much so though my companions assured me the place is usually packed
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...very personable waitstaff and Lorella is as genuine as can be
TOTAL - 4 stars...a few more visits may sway me to move the rating up
author: Ed U.

description:
I ate here maybe a month ago, and just realized I haven't written a review yet.  

Short version: 
All and all: wonderful service, great food that's a bit differentiated from normal Italian you get in San Francisco, an intimate atmosphere that's good for a date, and a great wine list.  It's a bit on the pricey side, but I'll be back.

Long version:
I went with my girlfriend on a weekday evening; we didn't have a reservation until that afternoon, but they were able to offer us two seats at their counter for the same day, at the time we wanted.  After eating there I can safely say that the counter is maybe the best seat in the house, because you can see into the kitchen and talk to the chef/owner.

That chef/owner -- he's not making Americanized-Italian.  He doesn't even have much interest in it.  He's making Sardinia-Italian, exactly as his family would have in the old country, where he learned to cook, and he's running the small local restaurant he would have owned in Italy.  He left the kitchen several times over the course of the evening to chat with patrons, including both many of his regulars and us, first-timers.  He asked how one of our dishes, fresh Monterey sardines in an oil, garlic, lemon sauce, and I honestly answered it tasted too much of oil and garlic,. and not enough of the pure brine-y sardine flavor I was hoping for.  He gave a fascinating explanation of the dish's origin as what families would eat when the fishermen came back to port with their catches, and then, ten minutes later, brought us two perfectly grilled sardines with just a touch of oil, salt, and lemon, and offered them as an "on-the-house" taste to honor the dish I was hoping to receive... and they were PERFECT.

Everything else we got was solid; the octopus stew was, to me, worth the hype.  We then split a slow-cooked meat and homemade pasta dish that was outstanding.  We may have had a second fish and dried tuna heart pasta dish; I'm forgetting -- but if not, the chef/owner certainly offered us a tiny taste of the dried tuna heart when I asked about it -- briny salty meaty amazing specialty item he imports.  We didn't try any of the main courses or dessert (we were stuffed!)

The wine list is both extensive, very affordable, and has a lot of wines by the glass, which they barely mark up from the bottle prices.  Our waitress was very good with her wine recommendations, and poured us small tastes of the glasses we were deciding between.

Our waitress was charming, from Italy herself.  One minor gripe: she clearly had the old-country / old-generation approach of always addressing the male of the couple (me) first, and relatively speaking ignoring my girlfriend, from asking what "we" are going to order, to tasting wine, to bringing the check.  In most circumstances, that would bother both of us, but when done with a charming Italian accent, it somehow became okay.

NOTE: What is Sardinian food?  Think Italian, with some Mediterranean influence and more emphasis on fish (and a bit less on meat) than Italy generally.
author: Zachary R.

description:
I was disappointed. I had high hopes because people have endorsed this place as their favorite restaurant in all of SF which says a lot. 

So maybe my expectations were too high going in, but I thought the food was just OK. Not bad, but nothing to write home about. My friend and I shared gnocchetti and the pizza special. The weirdest thing was how fast the gnocchetti came out. I think it came to our table within 2 minutes of placing the order - it was just plain awkward.

Also, I don't know if it was just the location of our table but we were constantly getting bumped by waiters as they were going back and forth. Things were falling to the ground. It just generally felt a bit harried. I suppose I would give it another chance given that most other Yelpers seem to love this place. But first impressions not living up to the hype, sadly.
author: Priya N.

description:
we arrived on time for a 6:30 reservation on a tuesday and were seated right away. incidentally reservations are hard to get. the restaurant only seats 45 with a three stool bar. i think a few tables are held open for regulars who are walk-ins but that's just a guess.

this was my second time at la ciccia. i really enjoyed my first visit and this visit didn't disappoint as many restaurants do when you go back. the dishes i had were:

octopus stew- a large portion of very tender octopi in an amazing, spicy tomato sauce. not for the timid as there is plenty of heat.

split a portion of spaghetti with bottarga - when mixed up it develops a thick, creamy sauce that tastes of the sea.

pork - there were three large, large, pounded very thin "cutlets" with a dollop of  tapanade on each one and some very well prepared chard on the side.

all the dishes were delicious with deep, complex flavors. that was the common thread. your taste buds go into overdrive.

we finished off by sharing the cheese and honey dessert paired with a vermentino sparkling wine. simple and satisfying.

there is an exhaustive wine list but we chose to byob. we had a '10 denner "ditch digger". a terrific allocation list only producer in paso. it is a red blend with grenache as a principle component. i thought it would pair well with the food since the predominant varietal in sardinia is cannonau which is just another name for grenache. it worked well. corkage was $35, a little steep i think.

the only negatives were the corkage, ambient noise and the tables are really close together. not "spqr" close but still way too close. at one point a rather "large" woman got up for her companion and with her back to our table almost wiped our wine bottle and glasses off the table with her rather massive posterior. that was a hella close call.

service was great. the staff is spot on, the co-owner/hostess is charming.

a real gem of a restaurant.
author: Sanil S.

description:
This is as good as everyone says it is.

The food was fantastic, the pasta was fresh and the sauce was really amazing. I asked the waiter to choose a wine pairing and he chose extremely well, a lovely Napa valley red that didn't break the bank.

The restaurant while noisy and busy was lively, if you want a quiet date it's probably not the best choice however.

Service was quick and impeccable.
author: Robbie T.

description: Small portions and kinda pricey...but pretty good food.
author: Kim K.

description:
Amazingly tender baby octopus. You'll want to mop up every drop of the spicy tomato-based sauce. 

We also ordered the penne special, which came in a sort of bolognese sauce. The pasta was super thick and chewy - tasted homemade. 

The lemon saffron cake dessert with honey and almonds was one-of-a-kind, tasting almost savory. The textures and flavors were exciting, but it's probably not something I'd order again.

It's all about the octopus, and all of their pastas.
author: Jen L.

description:
This place is soo good.  This is what a neighborhood family restaurant should be.  Intimate, exciting, friendly and low key.  Love this place.

Read intimate, small.  The tables are on top of one another.  Its very tightly packed in.  The portions are big.  There were two of us and we ordered WAY TOO much food, but the left overs were fantastic the next day.  The portions are big but not like the chain restaurants big, but they are big and its rich food so you cant eat that much.

A few things we liked were, the "Prupisceddu in Umidu - Octopus stew in a spicy tomato sauce", this was good.   The 'Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga - Fresh Spaghetti with spicy Oil and Bottarga' was ok.  My BF loves bottarga and when he questioned how they made it, the chef came out and explained how and gave us a sampler of some from the kitchen.  This was pretty cool.  We got another pasta dish with a pork sugo and that too was fantatsic.  Rich and hearty, and then we knew we were too full to eat the rest of the stuff we had ordered. 

We ordered Oratina in Padella Cun Olia Sarda - (Roasted Mediterranean Sea Bream served with Sardinian Olives Sugo) and even though this was fish, it was fantastic reheated the next day as there was no way we could eat it that night.  The olives sugo was fantastic and really brought the dish alive.

I love this place and glad its in our neighborhood even though we don't go back that often!
author: ORLA L.

description: Perhaps my favorite overall restaurant in the Bay Area.  Outstanding, unpretentious, elegant, warm.  Great for an intimate and romantic dinner, in spite of tight seating.
author: Brett C.

description:
Service - 0 stars
Spaghetti with bottarga - 5 stars
Fregola with squid ink - 4 stars
Entrees - good but nothing special

I'm sorry, but this place is way too expensive to receive such poor service.  We were sitting right in front of the door, so it was quite cold.  Two major reasons why I will not go back:
1. We were told by a woman (possibly the owner) that the table in the back of the restaurant was being moved to combine with another table, so we couldn't sit there.  Well...that table sat open for about 15 minutes until they sat another (apparently more important) couple in that table.
2. Later, another table opened up and we asked our waiter if we could move to that table.  He actually told us he needed to check with the owner because they might be saving it for "VIPs."  We'll, my boyfriend and I both looked at each other and couldn't believe what we were told.  These people are so incredibly arrogant...

The waiter rarely checked on us...my boyfriend probably would have ordered another glass of wine had he ever come back and asked if he wanted more wine.

I don't appreciate being lied to.  I don't care if you're the owner.  You can certainly give priority to your favorite customers if you know they are coming in later, but you should realize that you will likely lose prospective new repeat customers in the process.  

While I did like the food enough to go back, it wasn't good enough to put up with that kind of treatment.  There are too many other great restaurants in the city that offer great food AND great service for a $150 meal for two.  

We won't be back.  You shouldn't, either.
author: Michelle C.

description: Time after time, dine in or carry out, La Ciccia is some of the best italian you will find in the city, or anywhere. I have yet to find a dish that I didn't think was great, but the Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga and the Pizza Bianca are life changing amazing. Friendly, chill, and knowledgable service and great Sardinian wines make the food shine that much brighter. Wish it was still a neighborhood secret, as it is hard to find a time to go.
author: David M.

description: Great place! Food is high quality, everything is as Sardinian as possibile! Owners are great. Strongly suggested!
author: Antonino T.

description:
5 Stars.

Read everyone else's reviews

All I have to say is I live 30 seconds away from here by walking.

Lucky Me :)

Ok fine, one note, their Spaghetti with Bottarga, I had no idea it had fish, I just ate it then later found out fish was in it, surprise!
author: Eric A.

description: Delicious upscale but traditional Sardinian food, super helpful staff and a nice atmosphere. Their wine list was extensive but our server helped us pick out an amazing bottle of wine--it was spectacular. A happily non-pretentious ambiance. A Great place for a date or a good dinner out with friends.
author: Uda W.

description: Purely authentic regional Italian that makes me feel I'll be walking out after the meal onto a bright warm street in Sardegna, not a typically foggy San Francisco evening! The owners embody the idea of host, with such beautifully thought out plates and attentive service! The pastas are to die for, haven't yet had a meal that didn't exceed my expectations.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Fantastic sardinian Italian restaurant.

Don't miss out on the 'bottarga!'
author: Orion A.

description:
How to describe . . . ridiculous . . . took my girlfriend for her 50th b-day celebration . . . i'm definitely not a foodie, but this was some darn good eats . . . 

Our reservation was at 5:30pm, but it they opened at 5:35PM, which is forgivable, given that it was right at opening (but man it was cold waiting outside). The place is real small and you sit pretty darn close to other eaters, but that was okay too . . . Don't even think about walking into this place and getting a seat. Reservations on open table are often booked 30 days out and they don't let you book beyond that (so i got up early the morning of 30 days prior to make my reservation. . . 

No olive oil with the bread . . . that was a surprise . . . and i was hoping for a meat-n-cheese type appetizer, but no luck there either . . . maybe it's a regional thing because the food is listed as sardinian, not italian . . . but that was minor in the whole scheme of things . . . 

i had the lamb and cabbage . . . great combination and excellent taste . .. she had a pasta dish that fettuccine with pork and veal ragu . . . it was out of this world good . .. We both agreed it was the best meal we have eaten out . . . our waitress (Petra) was great too . . . we gave her leeway to choose the wine and she picked a winner . . . Twas a very pleasant dining experience. . . 

Great food, great service.  . . great place . . .  thanks La Ciccia

kevin
author: Kevin S.

description:
Yum!

Couldn't get a last minute reservation for 2 at 6pm on a Tuesday so we arrived and luckily they had two perfect seats at the bar. Highly attentive service at the bar. Felt like I was at a table.

In addition to their main menu, they have a salad, appetizer, pizza, and pasta special of the day. 

I wanted to try the octopus stew but my friend is allergic to squid, cuttlefish, and octopus so that was out. (Can't eat an entire app by yourself if you aim to get dessert!)

Had the salad of the day which was a poached shrimp and endive salad. Dressing was amazing...had sort of an anchovie flavor. I mopped up the dressing with some bread. 

Since it was my first time I had to try the fresh spaghetti with spicy oil and bottarga (some type of shaved yellow roe)..... um sooo good. Decent perfect portion. It was enough to be the main given how rich it was. 

Friend had the pasta of the day which was a fettuccine in a tomato based veal and proscuitto sauce... it was incredible. 

Trio of gelato for dessert- fig&goat cheese (refreshing), something & raisen (a bit sweet), and vanilla bean (perfect). 

Wine and coffee were excellent as well. 

Will be coming back to try a non-pasta main! Can't wait. (Will make reservations ahead of time though!)
author: Michelle P.

description:
I seldom come to Glen Park, but La Ciccia's delicious menu and a long wine list drew me in.  I had the Spaghetti Bottarga and Calamari.  The spaghetti was exquisite and was like nothing I ever tasted.  The calamari (non-fried variety) also didn't disappoint.  I also loved my dessert (sottfried??). 

I also had a taste of my dining companion's lamb tenderloin - one of the best lamb I've ever tasted!
author: Kent Q.

description: This place is great. If you want amazing sicilian food, great friendly service, and fabulous wine, this is the place to go. I went with a group of friends, all of which ordered a different dish, and we tried each others food "family style". Needless to say we ALL were very satisfied! The overall ambience was very relaxed and the chef came out to greet us and even gave us a bowl of their famous octopus stew which was to die for!
author: Melisa D.

description: Couldn't ask for a better dining experience. You pretty much can't go wrong with what they recommend. Baby Octopus was fabulous.
author: Mariko T.

description:
a neighborhood place. Apparently a bit famous judging by how busy they are on a Tuesday night. 

Good Italian seafood ... We had octopus stew as appetizer, and I had pan seared lamb, my bf had a dish of Puglia cheese with fish roe on top ... everything was delicious! 

Took 1 star away because of their wine list ... which is pretty good (in the sense, they stay with the region and what kind of food they serve) if you order from wine by the bottle list, not so if you only order glasses, which is very unfortunate. They don't even have one from the wine by glass list that works perfectly with the lamb dish I ordered. Carignano they have works, but a little light. Any decent Aglianico would be much better!
author: bone-dry-cappuccino L.

description: This place has better Italian food then I had in Italy.  Very tasty and fresh, I am not a fan of squid but this was different, they were smaller size and very tasty.  Squid ink pasta was also very good.  Overall experience was excelent, would defently come back.
author: Michael V.

description:
The food here is creative, authentic, unique .Ambiance is simple and intimate.

The wait staff are superb, very friendly and knowledgeable (especially for italian wine selection- which I know nothing about), especially the chef, who went out of his way to make sure we had a good experience. 

I ordered the baby octopus in a spicy sauce which I highly recommend- perfect  for dipping bread into. Also recommend the sardinian flatbread. 

The  fregula with sea urchin tomato and cured tuna heart was a bit  too fish flavored for my taste, but in all fairness, I was warned by the waiter that it was "rich", and was acclimatized after a few bites. However, I dont think I would order this particular dish again. 

Also had lamb which was tender and very flavorful- and that was the winner. 
I would love to come back here again for some more delicious italian cannonau (extensive selection) and authentic Sardinian food.
author: Christy D.

description:
Deliciousss!!

Pezza de Angioni cun Cipudda a su Zaffaranu - (Seared Lamb Tenderloin) best lamb i've ever tasted in my life. 

Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga ,(Fresh Spaghetti with spicy Oil and Bottarga) - quite possibly the best dish I have had in a very long time.

Although this place (deservedly so!!) has a great number of reviews, I couldn't not contribute.
author: Noushig K.

description:
Well executed Italian food though nothing terribly memorable. My friend and I had the octopus stew and one of the pasta dishes. I probably wouldn't drive to SF from San Mateo just to eat here, but if I was in the area and looking for a place to eat I wouldn't hesitate to return.

Service was excellent.
author: Jen K.

description: I visited SF from NYC in early November. This was hands down one of the best meals I've ever had. Each bite was excellent. The entire staff was very accommodating! Wine was delicious. Definitely recommend. Try the Sardinian Fregola with Sea Urchin Tomato and Cured Tuna Heart, so good!! Can't wait to return on my next visit!!
author: Tinamarie V.

description:
Absolutely delectable. We had dinner here last week and everything was terrific. We tried everything from the octopus 'soup' to the burrata to calamari, a couple pastas, and a white flaky fish. 

We split all of the dishes family style: definitely the way to go as we all got to try so much tasty food. 

Service was very casual, fun, and friendly and the wine line is extensive and unique. 

Try it out!!
author: Art A.

description:
5 Stars - dinner here last night was terrific!  The three of us split everything.  We started with  the burrata, which was fluffy and delightful.  The we had the calamari, which was very tender and nicely seasoned.  The octupus stew was hearty, spicy and had lots of octopus (tender).

We split two pastas: the fregua, which was out of this world -- so buttery (even though there was no butter in it) and really delicate seasoning - salt, pepper, other unknown herbs/spices).  And the actual pasta was deceivingly tender and flavorful.  The other pasta was the a squid ink-inspired little pasta balls that were lightly toasted.  Also, excellent.

Finally, we shared the fish special (a white fish from the Mediterranean).  Again, delicate flavor, tender & flakey fish that was perfectly prepared.

Our server was outstanding, providing numerous suggestions and a perfect bottle of wine to go with it all (Cannonau di Sardegna Riserva "La Marina" Cantina Romangia 2005 -- I've got to find this wine to enjoy it at home.  She was so knowledgeable about everything that we thought she was from Sardinia.  But she wasn't.  If I'm remembering correctly, she said she was Slovinian.

Total bill out the door, including tax & tip, was just over $60/person.  Quite a deal for such excellent food.
author: Kevin M.

description: Went here last evening with my monthly food friends! Jim had suggested this place, and what a good suggestion it was! Sardinian food is simply Northern Italian on Steroids. The flavors for each dish were distinct, fully developed and just simply great! The octopus was amazing. Will definitely come back!
author: glenn w.

description:
I actually love this place but the tables are close and it is SO NOISY! The good news is everybody on the table leans in to talk so you can't be overheard anyway.

The food -  I would give it 4 stars. So good. Only took away one star for too much salt. Have a great dinner, go home. Go to bed. But don't forget a glass of water on the nightstand. You're going to need it.

I loved their calamari. It's not deep fried. It's not breaded. It's basically whole and so tender. I haven't had calamari prepared like that in the US and it was excellent. The ravioli is also amazing. We also had the Salume which happened to be proscuitto. I am still craving it. It was excellent and there was plenty.

Thank you guys! Just please do something about the noise!
author: Tracy Y.

description: How have I missed this gem of San Francisco dining? I went here last night for the first time even though they have been established for 8 years. There were four of us and we tried a variety of dishes, no duds, everything was very flavorful and nicely presented.  We particularly enjoyed the grilled calamari.They also have a fantastic wine list and out waiter , who was quite knowledgeable, recommended a 2006 Carignano that perfectly matched out meal. My date and I took public transportation (The J Church runs practically to the door) but we decided to walk from Market and Church to the restaurant. It's about 25 mins, but a lovely walk with beautiful vistas of the city, I will return very soon!
author: Clark F.

description:
The place is non-descript on the outside but the food is amazing, authentic and the closest thing you'll find to Italy in San Francisco.  
Great dare spot and the prices are right.  You cant go wrong at La Ciccia.
author: Roberta W.

description:
Wow, this was my first time at La Ciccia and I really, really enjoyed my visit there. 

The food was super good. I ordered the basil pizza and my boyfriend ordered the seared lamb tenderloin. For appetizer we ordered the oven roasted calamari. The food is as delicious as their names. The lamb was super tender and so tasty, it was one of the best that I've had in many restaurants. The pizza was really thin-crusted and crunchy with just enough tomato sauce. 

I would definitely recommend this place to anyone who wants good Italian food. One warning, if you have reservations, get there a little early to find parking. It's so hard to find parking near there, after driving around for about 20 minutes we finally found metered street parking one block away but still, it's street parking so I'd recommend getting there a little early.
author: Kelly Y.

description:
Service is good, atmosphere is good. We were hoping the food would be good and were really looking forward to it based on the reviews. 

To be fair, you get food you're not going to find at a typical Italian join. The problem we had with the experience was that each of the dishes had one major flavor element that hit you in the face, POW, but not much in the way of complexity.

We ordered the tuna heart with uni, the pork cutlets and the seafood sugo as well as some other items that were less memorable.

Tuna heart/uni dish: heavy heavy heavy fish stock flavor. So strong and overpowering they could have used fish sauce and I would not have been able to tell the difference.

Pork cutlets: (for some reason, these took over an hour to get to our table) I think the only flavor was SALT. It was like eating a tenderized salt-lick.

seafood sugo: this was the winner of the night. It had a bit more flavor complexity and I liked the attention to detail.
author: Aaron N.

description: I love this place, the owners, the staff, and especially this salad with a lemon vinagrette, anchovy, and parmesan. It's for a serious palate, no wimps allowed. Super fantastic!
author: Marianne H.

description: Came here for my birthday and had the most wonderful time. I knew it must be good if I had to make reservations a month in advance. My wife had the Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga (cured fish roe spaghetti) and I had the Pasta Longa e su Nieddu de Seppia (linguine with squid ink). Both were the best pasta dishes we have ever had. They had a wonderful wine list and employees who knew what wine paired best with the meal you chose. It is a small place, but feels like home. The owner was walking around and talking with every guest to make sure everyone was happy with their meals. I will definitely be going back.
author: Evan W.

description:
What an amazing amazing place! We came in late on a Friday night with reservations for 9:30 and the place was still completely packed full with reservations coming in after us as well.
To start, we got the calamari (it is baked not fried) and it was superb! I have never had calamari like that but it was just really delicious and different. For the main course, I ordered the squid ink linguini and my boyfriend got the lamb dish. Neither of us knew what wine to get and, frankly, we were overwhelmed by the humongous wine list. The waitress was so incredibly personable and helpful in helping us choose a wine that went with our dishes. She brought us samples to taste and really knew what she was talking about. I wish i caught her name, but she was blonde and had an accent and we loved her!
I really just wanted to try this dessert called "Ricotta Saffron Cake" even though we were stuffed. We got it to go and I ate it at home and it was unlike any dessert I've ever had! Loved it and recommend it.
We came knowing we would spend a lot but that is okay because we were celebrating. When my boyfriend got the check, he wouldn't tell me how much it was but did say that it wasn't bad at all and less than he expected.
COME HERE! It was so awesome :)
author: Alexandra W.

description:
One of my best restaurant experiences in a long time! I'm happy to add another 5 star review for this gem.

The place had a great energy when we got there at 7:30 on a Friday night.  We were taken to our table and found so many great sounding choices on the menu that we were lost. Fortunately, our server was amazing, and once we told her what sounded good to us, she helped us pick from among them (and suggested a couple others) to form a terrific menu for us to share, and then recommended a delicious, affordable Sardinian wine to go with it all.  Most impressive was her knowledge of the food and its preparation; I love it when a server understands the food that well!

Our menu included the calamari (delicious, subtly flavored) and the octopus stew (as good as its reputation; the octopus was melt-in-your-mouth tender and we sopped up every bit of the sauce with the bread!)  We followed that with the spaghetti battarga (delicious and creamy), the lamb (on a bed of cabbage with raisins and I forget what else, but it worked together perfectly) and finished off with the ricotta and saffron cake (refreshing with just a hint of sweetness).

The only downside is the place is so popular that reservations in advance are a must, and we rarely plan ahead!  But we'll make an exception for La Ciccia!
author: John R.

description:
It's been almost two months since we were here, and so of course I've forgotten many of the details that a review should include.  The main two things, however, were:  1) get the calamari appetizer, notable for not being breaded and for being whole little squids whose taste was incredible; and 2) you should really go there because the food is just excellent generally.  There's nothing I can remember that we regretted getting.

Great service, too.  The only downside is that it's pretty popular, and so when we were there, it was sorta crowded with plenty of people standing around waiting for a table.
author: moosedog i.

description:
La Ciccia.. love it or hate it. There are no politically correct dishes to please picky tastes. You will not find food you are used to so get prepared to try new things, if you are not open minded then not even try you will be extremely disappointed. The wine list is one of the most extensive I ever seen. I recommend you to try only sardinian wines since this is a Sardinian restaurant. The food is what I call "Nouvelle Sardinan", traditional Sardinan dishes with a modern touch. 
My favorite: 
The Baby Octopus
Sea Urchin Fusilli
Ricotta almond honey cake
Wines
Argiolas Costamolino
They also have an incredible Sardinian Passito for your sweets
author: Niccolo P.

description: After reading the reviews here I expected to be blown away by this small restaurant in Noe. While the calamari was great, the famed octopus stew was too spicy. I enjoyed the squid ink pasta though have had much better. The spaghetti with roe was interesting - though not as enjoyable as I was hoping for. It left a bizarre aftertaste. Service was fine. Nothing amazing.
author: Cristina C.

description: At the far reaches of the City, this small, intimate restaurant is serving fantastic, non-traditional Italian food.  The cuisine is Sardinian, and the flavors are rich, the textures are hearty.  Really looking forward to going back and trying more of the dishes.  Some of our favorites: Calamareddusu Arrustiusu (Roasted Monterey Calamari Basil Oil), Prupisceddu in Umidu cun Tomatiga (Baby Octopus stew in a spicy Tomato Sauce), Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga (Fresh Spaghetti Spicy Garlic Oil Salt Cured Fish Roe), Fregua cun Arrizzoni e Sumini (Fregola Tomato Sea Urchin Smoked Pancetta) and of course, the Pezza de Angioni a sa Saba (Seared Lamb Tenderloin Tagliata drizzled with Saba).  As you can see from the names, you are in for a different meal here...and you won't be disappointed.
author: Steven B.

description:
I came here for my birthday dinner while visiting San Fran in April. Our dinner was perfect..absolutely delicious. I had the squid ink pasta which was by far, the best I've ever had. They have an extensive wine list and our server suggested an affordable bottle that perfectly complimented our dinner.

The ambiance is very comfortable, the service was excellent, we never felt rushed, and the staff treats you like you are part of the family. I also highly suggest making a reservation here, they are on open table. 

I plan on making a yearly trip our there to visit my friend and this will a must for us. Can't wait to come back!
author: Lexi -.

description:
worth the hype.  

so good, but unpretentious.  They sell t-shirts on the menu, hilarious.
author: J S.

description: Nice restaurant. Expensive, but not too expensive. Pizza is okay, but light. Nice interior. Nice location in Noe Valley.
author: Denise C.

description:
Sorry to say but this place is the essence of bland. I ordered a highly recommended Salmon entree. It was very, very, very tasteless and bland.

I could have walked to Safeway and seasoned something better myself.

I don't think I'll be back, but if so, I will try something different.
author: Lem B.

description: I dream about the octopus salad. Staff is very knowledgeable about wine. They were very clear about what contained wheat. Exceptional service.
author: Therese M.

description: Fantastic sardenian restaurant. Great service, amazing food and wine list. It is on my SF top 10 list
author: Sarita V.

description: Many restaurants decline over the years.  Not La Ciccia.  Almost 7 years from my original review and still Top of the List of my favorite restaurants.  Went there last Saturday to celebrate our wedding anniversary.  Everything was as good as always.  Lorretta and Massimiliano love what they are doing and share that love in every dish!!
author: Geary L.

description:
La Ciccia is the some of the best food you will get anywhere in the city. I will go as far as to say there nothing that isn't phenomenal on the whole menu. I don't think I really figured out what great pasta is supposed to *feel* like much less taste like until I went here. The service is always great--feels family run with class.

Particular standouts:

-Octopus stew
-Pork gnochetti (I find this perplexingly good each time I have it)
-Spaghetti with botarga
-Sea bream (aside from perfectly good fish, there is some kind of crack like delicious substance in the cabbage that accompanies it)
-Lamb chops

PRO-TIP: Don't mess with the extensive wine list, just tell the waiter what you like and you will not be disappointed. The gelato selections rotate and are delicious, if you get lucky, there may be a fish roe flavor: if you're at all adventurous, go for it.
author: Jim L.

description: Quaint Sardinian restaurant tucked away at the top of Church in Noe Valley.   The ambiance and service are fantastic and the Italian wine list is extensive, but as a vegetarian note that there isn't a single entree on the menu that works.  I asked them for their recommendation and they took the homemade ricotta ravioli traditionally cooked in a meat sauce, and adjusted the sauce to be a tomato base with seasonal vegetables.  The dish was pretty good, but I sense not quite as good as the seafood based dishes my friend was enjoying.   Also the complimentary bread could have been better and didn't come with anything (olive oil/butter).  All in all it was a great experience but vegetarians be warned that this place is very limited in terms of true veg options.
author: Elana R.

description: This cute little restaurant was really good. It was a make-up Valentine's Day dinner well waited for! We had to get the octopus stew - which I literally wiped up dry with the bread. It was so tasty and balanced with the right spice and kick to it. For the 2 pasta dishes, we ordered the squid ink linguini with seafood and the cod roe spaghetti. Both were delicious but definitely on the heavier side. Saffron almond cake was amazing for dessert. Next time I would love to come with more people to try the other pasta/dishes they are serving that day as well as the other appetizers including the grilled calamari. One little boo-boo was I was trying to (very quietly) take snapshots of my pasta to of course commemorate my belated Valentine's meal but the owner told me "Here is your dessert. Enjoy. No more pictures." So sad, I was just trying to log the goodness of my meal...
author: Jamie T.

description:
Amazing authentic Italian dishes from Sardegna. Really fresh ingredients that speak volume in their simplicity.
What Italian food is supposed to be. Skip this place if you are not open to the culinary integrity of the owners, and are not willing to embrace their mission.
author: Valentina G.

description: Innovative food using only the best of ingredients. Every time I'm in San Francisco I eat at this neighborhood Sardinian restaurant and I've never been disappointed.  The special trout salad was amazing. Gnocchetti with Pork ragu out of this world! Speck with oyster and sea urchin...DECADENT! Also enjoyed delectable ice creams from the chef of goat cheese/date and masala/raisin.  Can't wait to return! Oh yeah, the wine selection is fresh and exciting. Do yourself a favor and let the staff or owners pair for you.
author: Lori P.

description:
We came here on a friday night when we couldn't get any reservations at Locanda - serendipity! The taste is really like what you get in Italy, especially the pasta. The fresh linguine was the best we've ever had - it was as close to al dente as fresh pasta can get. We loved the squid ink linguine, oven roasted calamari and sardines. I wanted to love the octopus stew but the calamari blew it away. Ditto for the sea urchin pasta. The meal was nicely capped off with ricotta and saffron cake and gelati.

I'm usually wary of squid cos of a bad incident when I was younger but I couldn't stop eating the oven roasted calamari! It was perfectly cooked and perfectly seasoned. It's hard to explain the wonderful flavours - just try it! You won't regret it ;-p

We love sardines and it's very hard to find them here. They tasted great. The only small problem is that there are pinbones so you have to chew carefully. All 3 appetizers had great sauces that we were mopping up with our bread :-)

The squid ink linguine was amazing. This is the only place I know that makes it with lemon zest (we're guessing; some lemony flavour) which makes it very bright tasting and easy to eat. Yum!

The sea urchin pasta was nice and creamy but I'm not a big fan of the tiny pasta grains. I was hoping for noodles. Good but the squid ink is better.

Reservations required cos it's very popular. Very reasonable prices. About ~ $100 for 3 people, excluding tip. We'll be back :-)
author: pj n.

description:
There is nothing more to say about La Ciccia then BOMB!

 love there wine selection and the food is always amazing.  Pasta dishes are excellent and I love the fact that they source local ingredients. 

The dinning room is very comfortable and cozy.  Great place for families or a special date.

Will be back soon!!!!
author: Jason S.

description:
This was a cozy yet elegant restaurant. While I must admit that none of the dishes I had would supplant any of my existing traditional favorites for Italian fare, they had some very interesting flavors that will probably keep me coming back.

The octopus stew was delicious. It was spicy, flavorful, with peaks of saltiness and seafood flavor. Perfect to dip bread in.

The Spaghetti al a Bottarga was interesting but I would've preferred some additional richness to it.

The Rigatoni was cooked perfectly and the ragu was decent. The flavors weren't very distinguishing or memorable, but was still very palatable.

If you're into wine (unlike me) you'll probably get a lot more out of the experience since they have a very extensive wine list that seems to get rave reviews.

If you're looking for a place that serves cuisine that's off the beaten path, I would recommend this place.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
came here hungover for dinner...

I can't remember the pizza
I can't remember the dessert
I can't remember the apps

BUT it gets four stars because it's a warm neighborhood resto that actually has Borttaga with freshly made pasta. I'm all in. I was craving it for days after.  

If you've never had roe pasta, be prepared it's going to be salty and it's going to be fishy.. but for us japanese or sardinians, it's just heaven to find it at a restaurant in sf. 

Large Sardinian wine selection.
author: Hannah W.

description:
Molto bene.  Specializing in seafood, this Noe Valley gem is definitely a winner.  Although the dining room is cozy (read that reeeeeally small -- as in you are sitting closer to your neighbor than to your dining partner), the super friendly staff and home cooking will make you feel as if you were invited into an authentic Sardinian home for a Sunday family meal.

La Ciccia is committed to using locally sourced seafood, and appetizers include grilled fillets of Monterey Bay sardines served over fresh field greens and octopus stew with a deep, rich broth. Other options range from perfectly al dente spaghetti bottarga (spaghetti with cod roe) to pizza a sa sarda (tomato sauce, mozzarella, pecorino, capers, and oregano) with a slightly charred thin crust .

The extensive wine list features numerous selections by the glass, allowing you to rely on the expert advice of the staff to pair a different Sardinian wine with each dish.  Although the rapid pacing of the dishes makes it hard to have a leisurely meal, service is friendly and efficient.  

Save yourself thousands of dollars on airfare.  Dining at La Ciccia is as good as a trip to Sardinia.
author: CJ G.

description: Haven't had such good Italian food for a long time. Every dish is good. Definitely will come back again.
author: Lydia L.

description:
Perfect! that's how I can describe my dinner at "La Ciccia" (= the fat, in italian).  Let me tell ... my mother is from Sardinia, and so is half of my relatives. I had occasion to sample typical Sardinian food a countless number of times, many of which on Sardinian soil. 
 
A little premise ...
For those who ignore it, Sardinia had been some centuries under Spanish domination and their cuisine, as well as their language,  have been heavily influenced  by this experience. As far as food is concerned, you can notice it particularly on the fish or seafood dishes.
Not so in their meat oriented dishes, which are really particular, even within an italian culture. For instance, they use a lot goat and suckling pig meat. Pecorino cheese and the (not-so-good -looking) cheese with worms are others among their culinary flags. 
End of the premise ...

 I already knew that I couldn't go wrong with this restaurant, but my high expectations have been even surpassed by the exceptional quality and original combination of flavours I got.  Heaven made food ... literally! The baby calamari with slightly spicy sauce were so wonderfully tender and juicy. The home made pastas, namely rigatoni with goat meat and funghi porcini ragù and the spicy linguine with cured tuna roe  were arguably the best pasta dishes I got in SF so far and easily comparable to the best I had back in my home country.  
I disagree with some yelpers on the bread: I find it fantastic.  Moreover this is an example of typical Sardinian bread, as typical as the flat one. 

Actually, I wonder if they have ever made ricotta bread, another speciality of the region (Nice childhood memories :-) ) ... guys,  you should really try that one... I'll ask the cook, I bet he can add it to Ciccia's already  phenomenal menu.  

And what about the desserts? another impressive demonstration of cooking mastery: goat cheese-figue, malaga (marsala and dried grapes) and olive oil ice-cream ... wow ... ricotta/lemon/saffron cake  ...
double wow  (though I could not taste the saffron at all, but still amazing taste and consistency).

Add a good prosecco wine ...100$ (for two) but an experience to repeat as soon as possible. I guess you can hardly get better than this as far as rich flavours are concerned. 
Impeccable and friendly service.

I'm in love. period.
author: Andrea L.

description: Took my wife here for her birthday.  It was our second time (first was with friends).  The food was very good.  It's not the best Italian food I've ever had but it's very good.  When my wife asked about a specific wine the waiter brought a taste before selling her an entire glass which is always a nice touch.  The place is small which adds to the atmosphere but that can be a little annoying because you're getting bumped by waiters during your meal.  Very good but not five stars in my book.
author: Peter B.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place.  This continues to be one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. We had a great dinner with fabulous service, and always a delight to talk to Massimo, Chef/owner.  

What we had: 
Prupisceddu in Umidu (Octopus stew in a spicy tomato sauce) 
 * I ALWAYS get this and it is never disappointing. Octopus always tender, you can cut it with a fork, and the tomato sauce perfectly spicy and fresh. 
Burrata (stretched fresh cheese) 
 * YUMMMM.  It was a special. 
Fregula with seafood in black squid ink (small round pasta, like couz couz)
 * Tasty and a little fishy, in a good way. 
Pezza de Angioni  (Seared Lamb Tenderloin)
 * The lamb was tender and melted in your mouth. 
Dessert was 3 types of sorbets : goat & fig, fish, and...can't remember the other...but all 3 were good. 
The wine was perfectly recommend and will always take the wait staffs advice. They know their food and wine. 

We went to celebrate a birthday and the b-day person had never been there. He loved it. 

A must go here in the City....but make reservations and be on time.
author: Jacqueline A.

description: It is a very small and cute restaurant, I originally came here because my chef had told me that I MUST go and try it before it becomes too popular. The chef/owner is very friendly. I was a little disappointed with the pasta, hence the 4 stars, but I suppose everyone has their preferences. The secondis, primis, pizzas, and dolces are fantastic.
author: Carrie P.

description:
There's a certain thrill to walking out. It's a declaration of independence, a demand for excellence. You tried something because everyone said it was great, but you know better.  King Kong was a TERRIBLE FILM.  So I left - just as the giant penis-worms were devouring the obnoxious supporting actors.

I also walked out of La Cicca; after being seated right next to the drafty door, my date and I were invisible to every staff member for 20 minutes.  No introductions or wine offerings, nothing.  And this is a classy joint.  Maybe they figured we weren't going to drop much dough because we are young, but hey, we deserve some doggamn wine too!

I will ammend my reveiw when - and if - I ever get the opportunity to actually experience their food.  But their service certainly leaves something to be desired.  Pomelo across the street is better.  That was my lesson for the night.
author: Mari C.

description:
All I can say is "whoa!"  This is such a great find (well, for me. It seems like the secret is already out, though.)

I was looking for a nice place to take the little lady for her birthday and I had a few criteria that must be met for the restaurant.

1. Good wine selection
2. Small, quaint and family restaurant-ish.
3. Great food
4. Something different

Item #1: was met easily by looking at their website.  I expected an awesome wine list when I walked in, but imagine my shock when I was handed the menu.  It's a fairly standard sized menu.  I'd say 11"x17" with your conventional Italian restaurant of appetizers, salads, pasta, main courses and dessert.  Now, flip it over and there are literally over 100 wines listed in three columns!  Bring your magnifier, because you'll need it to read the massive wine list!  Yeah, I'd say item# 1 was met, and then some.  They have a large selection of Sardinian wines, which I discovered pair fantastically with the food.  Don't guess on the wine.  Ask your server for a recommendation, since you're not likely to know most of the wines on the menu.

Item# 2: The pictures on the website don't do it justice.  The place is small, with a nice window seating area, small bar and cozy feel to it.  You don't feel like you're going to accidentally eat your neighbor's meal, but it's definitely cozy and quaint.  A great place to celebrate your significant other's birthday.

Item# 3: Neither of us had ever had Sardinian food before.  It has a definite Italian look and feel to it, but the cuisine is truly unique.  There are a lot of coastal type dishes featuring fish, shellfish and other yummy critters that inhabit the local waters.  I was impressed to see them proudly display that they use local produce whenever possible.  Be sure and pay attention when they tell you about the daily specials.  If I had thought ahead to stretch my stomach a bit (more,) I would have ordered them all!  I ordered the seared tuna and she had their braised lamb.  We had their homemade linguni pasta, a garden salad featuring an awesome beet reduction dressing, and amazing soft mozzerala, tomato and Sardinain flat bread appetizer and fresh fruit sherbet and an Amaretto almond cheesecake type dessert.  What a phenomenal meal!

Item# 4: I've never been to Sardina.  I've read about it and even read about Sardinain native wine grape varieties.  Never had any Sardinain food either.  Whether you're a super adventurous eater or like to stick close to the beaten path, you're sure to love the food here.  you've probably never heard of most of the things on the menu, so don't be bashful about asking your waiter.  Everyone was super friendly and made us feel like we were visiting their home.  They made sure we felt at home and made sure our wine glasses were refilled.  This was a truly great dining experience and very different from your typical homestyle Italian , but close enough that you don't feel like you're jumping into the deep end.

If you're on welfare, this probably isn't the place for you.  If you like to eat, drink wine and breathe occasionally, you'll love this restaurant.  It's really hard to put into words what the experience of this place is like.  Get over there and try it for yourself.  La Ciccia is a smash hit!
author: Dave T.

description:
I was really really really excited about coming here. I'm sorry to say the reality just didn't match up.

The service: was great.

The atmosphere: was fine, but very crowded. I had some awkward moments with nearby tables while trying to get in and out. It was also pretty loud; maybe we were in a bad spot.

The food: Ugh. Here's where it didn't live up. So others in my group ordered the tripe, which had an odd and disturbing smell. Then we had the spaghetti with the bottarga, which I was really excited to try, but to me it had a bad fish taste. And I like fish. Then we had pizza, which was really, really fantastic. Then we had desserts, both of which were totally underwhelming. So . . . out of everything, the pizza was the only great part. And then as we were leaving, I smelled that weird disturbing smell off of someone else's plate, and it wasn't even the tripe (I think it may have been the pasta with squid ink, which I was really glad I hadn't ordered when I saw it). 

I would go back for the pizza and to try a different pasta dish, except that it's super crowded and busy, so maybe not.
author: TamaleGirl G.

description:
I woke up this morning unsure about dinner reservations. By noon, whilst talking to my dear colleague, I figured where I'd take my husband for dinner on his 40th B'day!

We went to Sardinia!!!!! :))))

Well, 'ever heard them say, "If you can't take Mohammad to the Mtn, take the Mtn to Mohammad." That's exactly what I did. I'd have loved to take my husband to Italy, but since I couldn't, I took him to 'La Ciccia'.

Our dining experience at La Ciccia has surpassed all/any Italian dinner experience thus far! This cosy and lively restaurant won me over from the get go! The cheerfulness of the staff, their professionalism and attention to detail is amazing! 

The food is terrific. We started with the oven roasted smashed potato, which was way too filling and hearty, along with really good bread. My husband had the octopus soup. To say that the potato just melted away is an understatement.....it was divine :)  I can't say the octopus soup was great (because I'm vegan), but I trust my husband's highly opinionated palate :)))  

What a wine list!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Unbelievable!! My husband had the Sangio Sagrantino Merlot Montefalco Rosso Agricola Arnaldo Caprai - 2005, which took his breath away. And I had their Moscato di Sorso Sennori "Tres Montes" Cantina Romangia 500ml-2006. I opted for a glass to begin with, but shortly after, I was "smitten," and I asked for the bottle :P

For the main course, the order was: Cambara a sa Catalana for $23 
(Wild Shrimps served with fresh Tomatoes and Onions Salsa).

For dessert, we enjoyed the 'Truta de Arriscottu' for $7 (Ricotta and Saffron Cake served with honey and Almonds).

What I liked best is that the joint owners check in with each and every guest, and seem to have a warm and personal relationship with those who frequent their restaurant. 

It's such a find and so good!! Puh-leeeeeeaaase do go there!

P.S: I'm saying it's a "full bar" because I'm almost tongue tied by the wine selection.....it's full!!!! :)

P.P.S: I'm also saying that it's wheelchair accessible because I feel a wheelchair can make it's way through their door and propelled to a table.
author: Me Iz S.

description: solid, unique, generally fair portioned dishes.  Avoid the prawns (4 for $26.00) but get the traditional flat bread.  I'm not a bread person but this was incredible.  Pasta is very fresh, and flavors are moderated well, without trying to impress.  This is not a tomato-sauce kind of Italian.  The wine selection wasn't the best but neither the worst.  The service is incredibly nice and HINT...they can make a pizza for you although it's not mentioned on the menu.  Also, I had one of my most memorable lamb dishes here.
author: Kriszti D.

description:
La Ciccia receives fantastic reviews, and I won't put them down but I will say this place is FISHY. If you like authentic italian fish with the heads and bones and all that, then dig in. Me? 

I like a big ole bowl of pasta that you stuff in your face and then go home and fall asleep with a Paul Rudd comedy on in the background even though you meant to meet up with friends. That's my kind of Italian.
author: Christina C.

description:
Hidden jem at the end of the J line.  

Substantial wine list, charming staff, great food and all the usual stuff, but the ambiance really does it for me at La Ciccia.

It's a excellent date spot, intimate and warm, with cozy little nooks and window seats.  The lighting is dim and moody, the music soft and the plates perfect for sharing.  It's not a first date locale as much as the ideal location for a first anniversary.
author: Quinn S.

description: I went to La Ciccia last night for the first time, after reading a lot of hype online about it, as well as hearing friends give it raving reviews. Overall it was a fantastic evening, and the food was both tasty and exciting. I love seafood, and this definitely met all of my expectations, and was even a bit too adventurous for my taste. The wine selection is really great, and our server helped us pick the right bottle for our meal. We started with the calamari appetizer and the baby octopus stew and both were amazing. The sauce on both dishes were so good we were sopping it up with the bread. We also ordered the olives, which were great. The calamari dish was my favorite thing that we ordered, and I've never had octopus cooked so well before. For my entree I ordered the spaghetti bottarga and it was really good, although it tasted kind of bitter (maybe from the olive oil?) My BF ordered the sea urchin dish and I didn't like the taste at all, although that's entirely because I don't like sea urchin. He thought it was delicious and rich, and finished the entire dish. For dessert we ordered the saffron and ricotta cakes, but I didn't particularly like them, they lacked a real identifiable flavor. We also wanted to get just one scoop of gelato but were told that it's a gelato trio, so it wouldn't be possible. I would definitely go there again, although I don't think most people that I know would be able to find something 'safe' enough on the menu. My one complaint is the lack of personal space. The restaurant is too small to fit as many tables as they do, and everyone is pushed together and the servers can barely walk in between them to take everyone's order. I'm sure space isn't an issue at the tables near the windows or against the walls, but being at a table in the center of the room kind of feels like being in the middle of rush hour traffic.
author: Regina L.

description:
We dropped by on the off chance we could be seated on Saturday night...and yes, immediately as if we were long anticipated VIP's we were ushered to 2 seats at their cozy bar.

Homemade sardines over mildly spicy crouton/toasts that I paired with my all-time-favorite pinot nero, we were off to a culinary ride I didn't want to end.

An absolute must-have is their baby octopus stew that forces you to grab the nearest slice of bread and douse in the spicy tomato based drippings, I really didn't want to ask for another basket, but, I felt too exposed on the bar stool to use my fingers!

On recommendation, I had the bottarga pasta and as promised, I really died and went to Sardinian heaven...the musky, smoky flavor of the dried mullet roe paired with the fresh pasta nearly caused an embarrassing moan to leave my happy lips. My companion enjoyed the evening's special pasta of baby squid and fresh tagliolini tossed in light garlic and olive oil...warm comforting and a palate pleaser. By accident, our server inadvertently brought my companion the tagliolini with tuna, capers and olives in a rich tomato sauce which we were welcomed to enjoy on the house while they prepared his correct order--what a treat!

No, we couldn't move forward with any main course but did top off the evening with the ricotta and saffron cake...sweet, fruity and refreshing.

Ahhhhh, now that we KNOW what awaits us along the mediteranean sea by way of Noe Valley, we'll be sure to secure a reservation in advance!
author: Susan A.

description:
Good food, but the service was so bad that I won't return.

Living in Italy for a year has made me pretty picky about Italian food, and this place does a nice job (octopus salad is hard to pull off, and they do a great job).

The service was a big problem beyond even our waitress, who was condescending about wine even though she blank-faced me when I asked about Valpolicella wine.  The bus-boys would hover behind you while you tried to finish your meal.  Things were brought out in the wrong order.

There are many great Italian options.  La Cicca is mediocre.
author: Whitefaced M.

description: Superb meal, warm and knowledgeable staff--plus a small dining room equals the best in southern Italian cuisine--with a Sardinian twist.
author: Jack G.

description: My boyfriend and I went here for his 40th birthday dinner and the food was mind blowing. The wine list was extensive, and the service was impeccable. We had the sea urchin pasta with shaved tuna (best thing ever), some spaghetti with fish roe, octopus appetizer and prawns for our entree. We will definitely be back!! One of my favorite SF restaurants.
author: foodbot c.

description: Loved every dish, fabulous, delicious, and creative. The best squid ink pasta I've ever had. The only downside of the restaurant was it was steamy-hot inside, I walked out the front door every 15-20 minutes to cool off. But we'll be back.
author: carol d.

description: Great food, innovative and excellent.  Service was sub-par.  Started out really well and then the waiter left us alone between courses for over 20 minutes.......
author: Hardev G.

description:
I came here tonight with a group of seven to celebrate my brother's birthday; unfortunately, after tonight's experience I don't know if I'll be back.  When we first got there, the hostess took our coats and stored them for us, which we appreciated.  The hostess (possible owner) was extremely polite and we were very excited to try the food, which we had heard such great things about. Unfortunately, that was the best service we experienced tonight.

After sitting down to review the menu, our waiter came several times asking for our orders. While the attention was initially appreciated, the service soon deteriorated to some of the worst I have ever experienced. 

When our waiter Antonio asked for our orders the final time, his curt manner made everyone feel rushed and uneasy. I placed my order and was helping my mother, who was having trouble seeing the menu, remember what she ordered. I realize he was likely busy, but instead of waiting he made snide remarks and rolled his eyes. Everyone at the table saw this and was uncomfortable. Everyone else in our party had unpleasant experiences while ordering as well. This was supposed to be a celebration. If he were just rude I would not have been so upset, but when my father asked for a good wine pairing for his dish -- not an unreasonable expectation at a nice restaurant with an exhaustive wine list -- he simply suggested a "red wine." There is never an excuse to be rude, but it is especially aggravating when someone is rude and incompetent. I felt as if he was looking down on us the whole time, which I did not appreciate. I tried to ignore him and enjoy the time with my family, but throughout the meal he was defensive and rude. I didn't complain, but the server certainly overshadowed the entire meal.

That said, the food was quite good. It did taste authentic and was quite rich. I liked that they had food that was very Italian, but is absent from most traditional Italian restaurants. In addition, the busser was extremely polite. He really went out of his way to make sure our meal was enjoyable. I got the hint that he realized how rude the waiter was. I didn't like that you had to pay for olive oil for the bread, but understand this is common. They did give us a free dessert for my brother's birthday, which was very appreciated. 

After such poor service I will not be going back.
author: Maxwell W.

description: Lovely place! The food and prices are very competitive of what you normally see in San Francisco. Loved the Noe Valley neighborhood! Had the octopus stew with two pastas and it was perfect.  Great wine list.
author: Rebecca P.

description: I had the spaghetti ink...it was unbelievably delicious.  Yes, the sauce was BLACK, but a great flavor with a touch of lemon.   For the appetizer I had the sauté squid.  I have never in my life had squid this tender.  It was delicious!  The place is very small and very busy but worth going.
author: Beverly J.

description:
It's been a few months since I've eaten here so the memory bank is struggling to remember what the taste buds absolutely loved during a 'dinner in the city'.  Needless to say that most of reviews of La Ciccia are spot on from the thoughtful service throughout the evening to the fantastic recommendations of Sardinian fare (octopus stew, perfect calamari...(memory bank failure again)). 
 
This is exactly what a neighborhood restaurant should be....proud to serve new and regulars and provide memorable service and quality and tasty cuisine.  Feels much like eating in Italy where you are welcomed into a family business for the evening.

Another nice feature is the 'bring your own wine' corkage program...bring own wine, pay corkage fee of $15? BUT if you buy another bottle on their list, the corkage disappears magically!
Our server recommended the best Sardinian wine that did not break the bank and with the waived corkage it was practically free!  Nice touch.

Highly recommended for locals, out of towners looking for the off the tourist path place that will be remembered.  Just be sure to write your review sooner than a few months after.  

Another visit is needed to 'refresh'.
author: Randall F.

description: Amazing Sardinian food. Favorites were: Calamari, Octopus Stew, Sea Urchin and Tuna Heart past and Calamari Ink pasta ( great lemon flavor). Ordered so much pasta that we didn't have room for a main course, so we'll definitely be back to try those.
author: Eric K.

description: I arrived with my friends 20 minutes before our reservation, and there was no place in the neighborhood to get a drink. La Ciccia has a bar, and they saw us waiting out in the cold but didn't offer us to come inside and sit at the bar. I feel with this out of beat location, they should at least accommodate people into the bar before they start serving dinner. The pizza is fabulous, but the flat bread that i was expecting to be soft was a hard version. They have excellent pasta, and the Marsala raisin ice cream is very good. The wine list isn't bad, but needs more selection of California wine. The corkage fee for $35 dollars is outrageous, but if you buy one bottle there, then they waive the corkage fee. The service was good, and the staff was friendly. Overall, I would go back, but not for another 6 to 9 months. Not much going on in the neighborhood.
author: Mark L.

description: Great food. Definitely going back again. But do make reservation next time!
author: Matthew Y.

description:
Had a delicious dinner at La Ciccia. The owners were so incredibly nice, and the restaurant was small and cozy. I tried all of the pastas (which were amazing), and the salume / ricotta cheese they had on the menu that night were superb. I also thoroughly enjoyed the lamb entree (definitely over the fish of the day, which was salmon.)

Although I really enjoyed my meal, it wasn't quite mind-blowing to the point that I would want to frequently spend this much on fresh Italian food. Quite pricey....
author: K. D.

description:
Well I had really high expectations of this place as it was recommended to me by a couple of people.  The first thing I noticed was it was one of the darkest restarants i have ever eaten at.  The only darker one I can think of is Tommy Toy's where you can't even see your plates.  So since my eyes are going (bifocal time) I could not even read the menu in that light.  The appeteaser came it was tomatoes with Mozerella and it was actually quite good.  Our entrees dissapointed though.   I thought I could get some pasta with a red sauce but nothing like that on the menu.  My GF had some seafood dish and she wasn't thrilled either.

Anyway, this was awhile back so I don't remember the particulars but we won't be going back.
author: Mark M.

description: Great food! Excellent restaurant for business dinners. Order one of everything and enjoy the distinct flavors. The lamb is the best dish on the menu. Be sure to start with the baby octopus stew and the sautéed calamari.
author: Cole W.

description:
