I was really excited to try La Ciccia last night after a fellow foodie friend highly recommended it.  I am not sure if he overhyped the place, if we mis-ordered, or if it really was just okay.  It was good, but it wasn't amazing.

We went with a friend of mine who really wanted to try the anchovies which had a good flavor, but I couldn't handle all of the tiny bones.  The best thing that we did have that night was the burrata.  I should have had that for my whole meal - it was delicious.  My friend raved about the pasta with the tuna heart so I tried it but I will admit that I did not love the consistency of the fregula and did not feel as though the dish had any spectacular flavor.  My husband had the special rigatoni ragu; he didn't seem exceedingly impressed by his dish either.  

We did, however, have a pretty good dessert:  ricotta and saffron cake served with honey and almonds.  Our server was great:  very attentive, and recommended some great wines by asking us what we usually like to drink (and brought us drinks that were on the money).  

I wanted to love this place because the ambiance was great:  quiet, charming, and quaint but I thought it was just ok.
author: Ashley C.

description:
A friend took us here and it was great. I love little restaurants that are still being run by the owners. They are personable and friendly. 

Food/wine/desert all well done. 

I had the seafood linguine with squid ink and the daily sorbet. Really wish we didn't leave the leftovers on our table. sigh... 

Definitely go back again =)
author: Chon Q.

description: This is real Sicilian food which as other reviews have called out is distinct from traditional Italian. Think more seafood and brininess. If you can nab a seat at the bar this is a great way to just enjoy amazing food, conversation and wine. The bartender will act as your server, muse and sommelier.
author: James H.

description:
You know how at work-related events you start asking people random questions to see what sticks when it comes to small talk?  I asked this nice Italian lady what she thought was the best Italian restaurant in the city, and she said La Ciccia.  I was embarrassed to hear that, since I live a few blocks away, and had never been, so we decided to try it right away.  

We just walked it, and although we didn't have a reservation, we were warmly greeted and seated at the bar, which turned out to be awesome, because it got us a great view of the kitchen, so we got a show too. 

We had several items, but I have to say, sea urchin pasta was one of those dishes that I just had to make some moaning voices after each bite.  I think my husband was getting embarrassed, but I could not help it!

My husband, the voice of reason, steered me away from dessert, but they all sounded incredible.  

This is a familiy-owned restaurant, and you can tell they love what they do.  Everyone was super warm, and we received just the best service, I think even better than normal, since we were at the bar, and we had the luxury of having the bartender right there all the time.  

Yay for the bar at La Ciccia!
author: Vivian P.

description:
First time of trying Sardinian food.  I loved it.  Went there with a friend two Fridays ago.  The place is quit tiny but cozy.  We ordered the Octopus in spicy tomato broth, fresh pasta with shrimp eggs, and Pan Seared Ahi served with Sardinian Olives Sugo.  
The Octopus was cooked with a great flavor however the texture of the dish was little over cooked.  I love the pasta with shrimp eggs the most, only the portion was little small. (Maybe I am a big eater)  The last but not the least was the Ahi.  I thought it would be a whole fish with bone in.  The staff claimed that customers complained about too much bone, so they start to serve with only the fillet.  That makes sense because if someone chok on the fish bone, there will be a lot responsiblities on the restaurant side.  
Desert was ok, we had the Ricotta and Saffron Cake served with honey and Almonds.  

Services were great, the waiter constantly come back to check on us.  I will definatly go again.
author: Jade P.

description: Everything about this place is aces, except for the fact that you have to book reservations a month in advance.  I'm not even going to say I know what real Italian food is (I've been there and it differs from town to town, and I probably didn't even eat at the best places the towns had to offer), but I would say that this is as real as it gets in SF.  It's different than the standard heavy cheesy creamy pasta dishes you generally find - instead you get smaller dishes with awesome ingredients, lots of seafood, simple yet flavorful.  If you find simple food boring and don't know how to appreciate the nuances of delicate Sardinian cooking, you'd do very well ordering the Mama's Trio at Macaroni Grill (a place I also enjoy, but under very different circumstances).  The wine list was filled with uncommon wines, big plus.  Great service.
author: Victoria G.

description:
A couple weeks ago, I was really craving some good ole Italian pasta. We were set to eat in Potrero Hill, but later decided to eat in Noe Valley due to the insane traffic on 280. Needless to say, it was an excellent choice. It was my first time having Sardinian food, but I'm intrigued to try more. Sardinia definitely differentiates itself from Italy with their use of fresh seafood in their dishes.

The scene:

La Ciccia is a cute little Sardinian restaurant filled with loud conversations and an impressive selection of wine. They have a limited menu filled with pastas, pizzas, and seafood; but, it's one of those places that makes a set amount of dishes and makes them well.

Service is outstanding. When we received our bread (although cold) prior to our meal, we asked a busboy if there was olive oil or butter to go with it. He kindly informed us that Sardinians do not use butter in their dishes and that if we want olive oil, it'll cost us $2. We were shocked they'd charge anything for oil, so we declined the offer. Just a few moments later, the owner of the restaurant stopped by and gave us a little dish of oil for free.

The food:

I was craving pasta, but everything on the menu was a little out of my comfort zone. They had pasta with unusual ingredients such as bottarga (cured fish roe) and squid ink. The waiter urged that I'd try the fresh spaghetti with spicy oil and bottarga and I did. It was incredibly delicious, especially with the homemade pasta.

Fresh spaghetti with spicy oil and bottarga - I couldn't believe I ordered a dish with cured fish roe and liked it! The flavor combination in this dish was amazing. The salty ocean-ness from the bottarga combined with the spiciness of the chili flakes. Put that together with the fresh, al dente spaghetti, and you have a home run.

Fresh rigatoni with lamb ragu - If I didn't get the bottarga spaghetti, I would've ordered this dish. K ordered it and literally could not put the fork down. The sauce was rich in tomato and lamb flavor.

Fregula with seafood and squid ink sauce - It was my first time ever having squid ink. I was surprised the ink itself really had no flavor. The dish was no doubt, unique though.

Ricotta and saffron cake served with honey and almonds - The cake, similar to a sponge cake, was extremely light and crumbly. It's the perfect dessert if you're completely stuffed from your main dish.

Selection of 3 ice creams (fig and goat cheese, olive oil, and cherry and marsala) - By far, the most interesting flavors of ice cream I've ever had. All very unique and light in flavor, nothing overbearing. I couldn't get enough of the fig and goat cheese as well as the olive oil ice creams.
author: Sam L.

description:
I had  a great dinner here with a friend.  The service was excellent.  They ran out of a few items on the menu, which I took as one more sign that everything is fresh.  

Dining here is much more of an adventure than most Italian restaurants.  

One word of warning - there was a very cold and strong draft at the back of the restaurant where we were seated.  If it is cold night, try to get a table towards the front and over to the side, out of the draft.  They must have had the back door propped open to keep the kitchen cool.  I can't think of any other explanation for it.

It's a small place - probably best for parties of two, three, or four.
author: Bay G.

description: Great food, lovely, humble harding working owners with a talent for running an Italian restaurant, that has lure in locals and guests from near and far.
author: L V.

description:
This is a dream restaurant.  It's like your mother's cooking, if your mother was italian and actually knew how to cook.  It's a small neighborhood place, the owners are super friendly, it's cozy and intimate, and the food is just to die for.  I wish all restaurants were like this.  It made me want to go to italy and just eat eat eat.

We had the seafood salad, and the seafood was crispy and delicious, with just enough spice so that all the tastes shine through.  Then we had the spaghetti with cauliflower.  The pasta tasted home made and again it was simple with good ingredients, just enough of everything.  For our main course we had lamb chops and sea bass.  The lamb chops were just amazing.  I'm not much of a cooked fish person but my husband said the sea bass was great.  Then we had the sardinian cheeses, each paired with a different honey, two sardinian honeys and one infused with saffron by the restaurant owners.  Again, delicious.  

We also had a wonderful sardinian wine that was just right to go with all our different dishes.  This is now one of my favorite places in the Bay Area.
author: cecilia g.

description:
La Ciccia is now one of my favorite restaurants in SF.  The food was incredible and fresh, the service was very attentive and friendly, and the atmosphere was convivial and felt like joining in on a family party.

For dinner, we had the octopus stew (hit the spot), sauteed sardines (so flavorful), the shaved tuna heart pasta special (al dente and so deliciously seafood-y), cauliflower (yummy), and the seared ahi tuna entree (as fresh & tasty as it gets).  We asked one of our servers, Antonio, for a wine recommendation from their lengthy list, and he selected a perfect red that went really well with all of the seafood - pretty rare for red wine.

Now that we finally tried this neighborhood spot, I'm sure we'll be back many many more times!!
author: Jennifer D.

description: So good! I've heard a murmur or two over the past year about this place, but now that it's made the Chronicle's Top 100 it's going to be even harder to get a table. Oi! The good news is that it's totally worth booking in advance. Their wine list is extensive and has some really interesting Italian varietals. Their specialty is seafood, but as a vegetarian I've never been disappointed. I love that the decor is really minimal-- it seems very small town, in the middle of Noe Valley off of a side street. And along with the small town feel is a chef that takes the time to visit your table, asks about your meal, and finishes the conversation with a "Grazie." And bonus points go for the menu thanking diners for not using their mobile phones at the table.
author: Kathryn M.

description: Certainly enjoyed the food.  A broad selection, excellent flavors and nice sized portions.  The wines were of old world descent; being a bit rustic but good in acidity and fruit.  Would definitely go back and try additional dishes and wine selections.
author: Michael T.

description: Authentic Sardinian cuisine, amazing wine list,  charming owner. Been here a few times; the best dish I've had here is the semolina gnochetti with pork ragu and pecorino. This is probably Wakako U's favorite Italian spot in town. 'Nuff said...
author: Brett W.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm!!!!!!!!!! ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE! 

Everything on the menú from the appetizers to the dessert! Try everything!
author: Ana M.

description: It's hard to score a reservation because this seems to be a very popular local spot - it was pretty crowded for a Sunday night and we bumped into friends who apparently live nearby and are regulars.  Excellent friendly service across the board - definitely can see why it's a neighborhood spot.  We started with the octopus stew which came with a great spicy tomato broth but was a bit too mushy for me.  We both loved our pastas though - the special linguine with seafood and the spaghetti with bottarga were both excellent.  We were in a rush but hope to come back again and enjoy the relaxed, friendly atmosphere over a longer meal next time.
author: Vivian W.

description:
After hearing rave reviews about this restaurant from a chef friend, we decided to check it out last night even though it's a trek from where we live. Despite the high expectations, I am happy to report that we were not disappointed by the dining experience! 

This cozy and intimate Noe Valley restaurant is run by an Italian husband and wife team. The chef (husband) is committed to using local and organic ingredients whenever possible and the restaurant offers an extensive wine list with over 150+ Italian labels to choose from. Despite how busy they were on a Friday night, the waitstaff was still welcoming and attentive. Our meal consisted of salumi plate, flatbread and seafood salad to start, followed by the sea urchin pasta and gnocchetti with pork sausages. Everything was delicious and we couldn't have asked for a better meal last night. 

If you're a fan of seafood and Italian, you will love this neighborhood gem!

TIP: Corkage is $25 but La Ciccia will waive the corkage if you buy a bottle from their wine list.
author: Alice W.

description:
Love the place ... we called for an impromptu table on Sunday night & had one of our best dinners in SF yet! 

The food was terrific (octupus, sardines, Bottarga pasta) and our server recommended some excellent sardinian wines to go with our selections. 

Highly recommended!!
author: Ajay G.

description:
We had a wonderful dinner at La Ciccia. Despite living nearby we had yet to try this place but now we will be returning. 
We had the octopus stew and the calamari both of which were great. The stew has just the right amount of kick. 
The spaghetti with bottarga is definitely worth a try and the pasta was cooked perfectly. The lamb was also very good. We ordered way too much food so didn't have room for dessert on this visit. 

Our server recommended some wines by the glass that paired nicely with our food. The service was great but the restaurant feels pretty cramped as it's a small place.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
This restaurant is so special. Authentic, soulful and refined food at very reasonable prices.

Everything I tried was delicious, including roast Sea Bream, spaghetti with bottarga, and the fusili in a tomato sauce with sea urchin and cured tuna heart. The wine list has many affordable options. The only downside is a rather limited dessert selection which pales in comparison to the savory options.
author: Halle L.

description:
OCTOPUS SOUP. Or, Prupisceddu in Umidu (Octopus stew in a spicy tomato sauce). Some stuff was pretty 'regularly good,' like the pork loin. But the octopus stew was just perfectomundo. How? Undercooked or overcooked octopus  texture and consistency become rubbery. But this was perfect. It was delicate and intensely flavorful.

What's bad? They put 'EVOO' on the menu. In italics. I hate that. And they say 'thank you for not using your camera, cell phone, or computer at the table.' It's 2012, fellas. Grow up.
author: Klevin D.

description:
Three of us had a great meal last night. As always the owners were super-friendly and welcoming. We arrived right when they opened at 5:30 since our friend had a plane to catch, and I was worried because the place was empty or nearly so for a while, but by the time we left around 8 it was full.

Ordered all three special appetizers. Housemade prosciutto was delicious and nice on the flatbread. Stuffed grilled squid were great. Braised chicken gizzards were the best I've ever had, right up there with goose gizzard confit in Perigord.

Then had four pastas. Fregola with fresh ricotta and tuna heart was amazing, reminiscent of risotto, but richer, kind of overshadowed the linguine with clams, mussels, and saffron. Fresh maloreddus (similar to cavatelli) with pork sugo and aged pecorino was great. A special of some sort of fresh macaroni with a sugo of goat, veal, and prosciutto with myrtle berries was delicious and the spicing was new to me.

Unfortunately at that point we were stuffed. This is one of the handful of restaurants where every time I eat there I wonder why I don't go more often.

They're doing a family-style single seating dinner on New Year's Eve:

http://www.laciccia.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=blogcategory&id=15&Itemid=34
author: Robert L.

description: This is the best Italian I have ever had in my life. Amazing and true Mediterranean style Italian fare, executed perfectly. This put bottarga permanently on my list of must haves when it is on a menu, and no restaurant has since lived up. Sauteed sardines are just as they would be in Sardigna. Quaint dining room operated with an Italian sensibility. Killer wine list. Go now.
author: senator t.

description: I went to La Ciccia based on Yelp reviews.  I didnt know the place nor did several SF locals that I asked.  Well, it didnt disappoint.  Great food, great wine list and perfectly prepared.  Give it try.  A hidden Gem.
author: T S.

description: Automatically gets a 5/5. The menu is absolutely superb, especially the wine menu. The baby octopus stew is amazing. The tomato sauce is excellent with the bread. The calamari is well seasoned. That sauce has so much flavor of garlic, parsley, butter, and white wine. I think it's those ingredients with other stuff. Other than that, the flat breads are good. The sea urchin needs a little bit of work though. The taste is not quite there yet. Only gave it 4 stars because there is always room to improve on. Other than that, great staff and great location. It's a must to go place.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Burrata: awesome
Octopus stew: awesome
Calamari appetizer: awesome

Ricotta and orange zest ravioli with veal ragu: awesome
Squid ink linguini: awesome though a bit musky
Pork pasta: ok

Ricotta saffron cake: awesome

Everything here was so so tasty and well done! And the waiter was really nice :)
author: L B.

description: We had the "Jewish artichoke" as an appetizer. It was really amazing. From the description on the menu I expected it to be battered and fried kinda like an onion blossom at the Outback. Instead we got a delicate half artichoke with the outer leaves removed. The artichoke leaves tasted crispy and amazing, almost like gourmet chips the heart was great as well. We shared the lamb ragu, crab and artichoke pasta, and steak. Everything was wonderful, but I especially liked the crab and artichoke pasta and whatever was at the base of the steak (radicchio and puréed sunchoke?) fancy donuts for desert with wildflower honey, yum!
author: Jess M.

description: Tiny restaurant with good food, esp. if you love seafood. I had Pezza de Angioni a sa Saba (seared lamb tenderloin drizzled with cooked grape must, delicious, $26) . The olives for appetizers were like opening the ones I get at Trader Joe's and putting them on a little server tray, not so impressive but nonetheless delicious, and the cooked cabbage was tasty but nothing to write home about. However, the dessert: the raisin and rum gelato was outstanding, and the moist pannetone was mouth-watering: the best pannetone I have ever had! Delicious but pricy food here at this cozy little Noe Valley restaurant. :-)
author: Elizabeth W.

description: This place is just amazing.  I cant even begin to explain how good it is.  I have been to so many places for Italian food, and I truly believe this is the best in the city.  The service is always incredible.  Its a small, simple, family owned place with a wine list that is insane.  The octopus stew is a must.  I get it every time as well as the  pasta dish.  Besides when I was in Tuscany, it is the best I've had, and I have to be honest. I rarely eat pasta because I don't usually enjoy it.  I will warn you that the parking here is atrocious, but I'm not going to take any stars away for that because I don't feel this has anything to do with them.  Don't drive-just cab it or take a bus and make your reservation ahead of time.  It's always packed here.  You will be glad you did!
author: Coraly S.

description:
I thoroughly enjoyed this place. Service was very quick and friendly, dishes were authentic and delicious. The place seems always packed, and the restaurant itself is pretty tiny.

Grilled calamari - perfectly cooked, sauce was addicting. We used the bread and soaked up all the sauce. :)

Spaghetti with Bottarga - no fishiness at all, nicely cooked al dente pasta. If you stick to this dish, it is mild and spicy at the same time. If you start eating something else that is more flavorful though, this dish can become somewhat bland. Be careful!

Seared lamb tenderloin - amazing! Great flavor, and such tender slices of lamb. Pretty big portion! 

Ricotta and Saffron cake - didn't realize how strong the saffron flavor could be! Even still, very tasty and light. The honey and almonds were perfect matches for this cake.

This place is a gem, hidden in the outskirts of noe valley. Glad to have tried this restaurant!
author: Carol L.

description:
This quaint Sardinian restaurant oozes romance and serves up some delicious fare to boot. We had the most tender baby octopus in a complex tomato sauce, and the sardines to start. Second dish was the fresh spaghetti, cooked al dente with bottarga. We finished off with the lamb tenderloin. Everything was tasty and nicely cooked and the recommended wine from their extensive list paired well with our choices. 

I want to try the cheese and honey dessert next time, Bourdain really enjoyed it when he visited Sardinia.

Service and pacing was excellent.
author: Derrick V.

description: I love this restaurant!!! My boyfriend brought me here to celebrate our 2 year Anniversary. Its a small restaurant and staff are super friendly and knowledgeable. When we arrived we got seated right away and our servers were excellent. We got the Octopus stew, its really good and its my favorite! It is tender, not too spicy and we couldn't stop dipping our bread on the soup. We also had Spaghetti Bottarga, it was good as well. We noticed on the menu that we cannot use cell phone, or camera in the restaurant. We asked one of our server if we can take a picture for our anniversary, she was super nice and didnt hesistate to take a picture of us. In addition, when we ordered gelato, they put a candle on top of it. I can't wait to go back and order the Octopus Stew! =)
author: Katherine C.

description: We returned to La Ciccia again and had a great meal. Once again I can not begin to tell you what a wonderful experience this place is. The owner Chef  visited our table several times and discussed the preparation of our food. The quality of the ingredients and skill preparing them was apparent.  Seafood is all I order here, maybe some day I will tire of it and order a meat dish but not yet.
author: Mike P.

description:
My honey took me on a surprise bicycle date last night.  Except it wasn't a complete surprise because I had guessed that La Ciccia was our destination and spent the whole day drooling over the menu.  So I was delighted when we rolled up to this warm, unpretentious neighborhood restaurant.  I had never had sardinian food before - its superb!  The combinations of flavors and textures were sometimes surprising but at the same time comforting and unfussy.

The octupus was tender and tasty but the sauce didn't the blow me away.  Our main course, petrale sole, was simple and impeccable.  The fregula, though - holy cannoli.  I was a bit concerned about the tuna heart aspect, but the little slivers of savory , flavorful cured tuna perfectly complement the slightly lemony ricotta and toothsome pasta.  It's unique and delicious and I insist that you order it.  The ricotta-saffron cake was also fantastic - light and moist, the coolness of the ricotta balanced by the warmth of toasted almonds and honey.  

Now I can't wait to visit Sardegna.  Or at least bike over to La Ciccia again very soon.
author: Rachel D.

description:
Make a note: this is Sardinian food. Sardinia is an island, so you shouldn't be surprised to see that the majority of the menu is devoted to seafood. But, if Italian seafood is your plan, then you can't do much better than La Ciccia. 

Great service, slightly cramped quarters but interesting and fresh seafood. I'm a fan of anchovies and sardines, but the pasta with cured tuna heart took that flavor to a whole other level. It was tasty, but something I couldn't eat more than once a year...intense. The shrimp with garlic and tomato was also delicious and cam with an unadvertised mound of creamy polenta that was a perfect vehicle for the sauce. 

They have a very extensive Italian wine list, with some great and unusual finds. La Ciccia is definitely worth checking out, but bring your appetite for seafood and someone who won't mind that your breath will stink like garlic for the next 48 hrs.
author: Arjun P.

description: My husband and I had such a wonderful dinner here last night! Everything we ate was a magical concoction of flavors and the wine we picked out was amazing. Our waiter was attentive and helpful, and so was the rest of the staff. I'm a huge fan of this place, and I can't wait for my next visit.
author: Sheila T.

description:
Read the reviews, and got excited. Italian? Seafood? Sign me up. Those terms, plus 4.5 stars on hundreds of reviews get me in the mood to make my O face at dinner.  Got to make my O face alright, but at La Ciccia, O stands for "overrated".

Right off the bat, they committed the first cardinal sin of hospitality: seated us, then left us sitting for a long period without getting a drink order. I don't know if it was 5 minutes or 15, but when you're sitting empty handed at an expensive restaurant, few things cast a pall over a meal like that. It's simply inexcusable. The next inexcusable thing is their drinks menu. All unrecognizeable Italian reds, plus a handful of Sardinian beers. The wines seem to be decent value, with lots of $40-50 dollar bottles.  The beers, in case you're curious, START at 14 bucks and go to 22 (!). For ONE bottle, normal size, of beer. Seriously. Inexcusable. Again. Some of us simply don't care for a big belly full of acid and sugar that comes with wine, and gravitate to cocktails. Lacking a liquor license due to the California nanny state? Fine. Stock some decent beers and we'll make do. I mean seriously, who the fuck decides to offer 20 dollar bottles of beer? Everybody knows Italian beer sucks. Get a goddamn keg of Lagunitas back there. The quality will double and the value will quadruple. Ive honestly never even seen such a thing.

Well now we're seated at least, with a drink in hand. Even if it is a 10 dollar glass of wine I never wanted in the first place. 

Bartender chick brings a basket of bread out. Sliced. Like out of a bag from Safeway. With nothing else. She pulls her disappearing act again, so I have to wait another several minute stretch to ask for a bit of olive oil. Turns out, that's another 2 bucks. Well that's pretty lame, but the Safeway sourdough in the basket needs some help. So I suck it up and order a side of olive oil. Now I know it's only two bucks, but having to pay for that puts me in the same mood as having to pay for a blanket on a plane. That mood can best be described as " Wow, fuck this business, I'll never patronize it again!"

  Food comes. Went with all the favorites from fellow yelpers. Roast Calamari, Sardines, Octopus stew. Every single thing was SO FUCKING SALTY we could barely eat it. Now I know you're wondering at this point where my taste buds lie. Let me assure you that  significant fractions of my caloric intake come in the form of M&G's bacon cheeseburgers, Sinaloa carnitas tacos, and Phuy Hyung Pho. So me and salt are old and dear friends. But THIS PLACE, La Ciccia, is like trying to kill us with the stuff. 

By this time, I'm so grotesquely bloated with salt and wine that I honestly just cant wait to get the bill and leave. The bartender chick looks at me like I'm deformed when she clears my barely touched plates.  That's right honey, 4.5 stars on Yelp may bring in the customers, but lots of us will wait to make our own judgements. If that means leaving 50 bucks worth of food on my plate rather than have a hypertensive coronary, then that's MY call.

Like a previous poster said so eloquently, the best part of my experience here was leaving.
author: Alex D.

description: Truly one of the most outstanding meals I've ever had. We started with the Oven roasted Calamari that was to die for. While I don't like sourdough bread, I had to bare with it in order to soak up all the leftover juice in this dish and the Octopus stew. Octopus stew will win over anyone and everyone, tender and juicy.  We shared the Spaghetti with Bottarga and was not disappointed. There is such a robust meaty/cheese flavor that just sticks with each bite. Didn't have room for any desserts but we will be back as there were so many dishes that I need to try. Great ambiance, but we sat towards the front. I don't think I'd really like to sit in the tables towards the back, close to the restroom, too dark and kind of weird.
author: P G.

description:
La Ciccia is a family owned "Italian" restaurant, and you feel that immediately upon entering the door.  The dining room is intimate and charming, and you can tell that many of the customers are regulars.  

As an Italian, food is everything to me. Most of my memories with family and friends is punctuated by the perfect dish, new flavor or experience.  Food is obviously important to the owners of La Ciccia, as I could taste the love of their country in every bite. During the course of the meal, the streets of  San Francisco faded away, and I was transported to the coast of Sardinia. 

Our  appetizer was the perfect beginning to the evening. Five squids, (their bulbs the size of endives!) were laid out on a platter and drizzled with olive oil and seasonings.  For an entree, I had the fregula with squid ink and my boyfriend had pasta with shaved tuna heart.  Forgive me for not providing details, but the food was so good that we ate it too quickly!  Dessert was spectacular as well. We ordered a sampling of three gelati, which is made special for their restaurant. That evening we had one scoop each of mulled wine, goat cheese and saffron gelato.  The flavors were surprising, unique and sublime. 

The bread served at the table is heartier than what you would expect at an Italian restaurant. It's good for soaking up sauce, but not as satisfying for nibbling before a meal.  Do as the regulars do and order the Sardinian flat bread. 

The staff was extremely friendly and even the owner came by to see how we enjoyed our meal. My boyfriend and I feel extremely lucky to have such a wonderful restaurant in our neighborhood, and look forward to eating there again!
author: Lisa R.

description: Went there a couple weeks ago, and I just don't get it. The service was fantastic, the atmosphere adequate, but the food was nothing special. The octopus stew had great texture, but the flavor was bland. Their pasta with sea urchin was tasty but heavy, and A16 has a dish similar to it (with squid ink pasta) that's far more engaging and fresh. The saving grace of the meal was the lamb, which was unbelievably tender and delicious. Still, for the price, there should be some magic.
author: Mike T.

description:
Hate to drop some hater-ade, but i think some perspective is in order.  Nothing we had was anything you couldn't easily make at home.  Maybe that's not what you look for at a restaurant where dinner for three with wine runs $250, but it is what I look for.  Nothing innovative is going on here.  There is far better italian to be had in SF (literally dozens of places come to mind in fact).

The place is a small hole in the wall with cramped tables and constant draft running through it, which is fine, i am not downgrading the experience for that, but just so you know.  I like holes in the wall with drafts when the food is good. The food was average. I will say though the service was excellent and the owners really do seem to love their little spot and their customers.  So there's that.  

Apps: decent, nothing out of this world.  Had the prosciutto special.  Can get same from any store, but it was tasty.  Octopus stew was good, but not remarkable.  A spices tomato broth with little octopi in it.  Different, but once you get over the "otherness" its something you could easily make at home.  

Pasta: had the rigatoni veal and goat ragout special.  Meh.  Sauce was too dry to balance the al dente-ness of the pasta.  Again, you could make this at home no problem.

Mains:  Pork and lamb.  Here they fell flat.  The lamb was uninspired and bland at points. i barely ate a third of it.   The pork was done in the style of a veal cutlet, super thin, breadcrumbs on top, and ok.  Again, could do all this at home.

Dessert: Can't really remember, something rice pudding-ish and a second chocolate dish.  Actually was tasty, but not enough to make the rest of the meal better.

Wine:  They have a deep list, but the two bottles we got were meh.  A white that held its consistency for about ten minutes and then just basically fell apart, and a red which was moderately corked which we debated sending back but decided wasn't so bad that we had to pull the obnoxious customer lever.  These were both recommended by people at the restaurant.

Conclusion: its a decent neighborhood spot, which I think is what they always intended, but it does not follow through on the hype its gotten in recent months.  I don't see the need to go back with all the other italian options in town.
author: EZ R.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in the bay area, lucky for me it is just a quick walk from where I live.  The food is spectacular and you will immediately think that you have been transported to the Mediterranean.  The restaurant is full of Italians, which is quite an endorsement in itself.  Go to this restaurant, you won't be dissappointed.
author: L G.

description: If you are a fan of cured meats, than you can't miss this place.  Chef/Owner Chris Cosentino has done a great job.  For those who like unique menu items and something different will not be disappointed, I just found that the menu might have tried too hard to find unique ingredients instead of focusing on some core items with a few unique twists.
author: Joshua D.

description:
Owned & run by a lovely husband and wife team.  Fantastic food/drink/service.

Been here several times in the past 3 years.  Cozy so best for two at a time.

More to come!
author: FoodieGal I.

description:
This place was tight to death. 
We arrived a little early for a reservation and they sat us right away. We were a party of three it was a partner's belated birthday dinner. We were told about the specials and we looked over the menu. The Birthday boy got the order first and the rest of us followed suit. The first thing to come up was a very flat bread w/ crumble cheese and rosemary on it. It smelled great but looked tasteless. I was soo wrong. It was really tasty! Then our wine came and they poured a nice healthy glass. Then the dishes: thin sliced lamb with a grape mass sauce and peas for the Birthday boy. The other two of us had the Shrimp with red sauce and mash potatoes. There were also sides of baby Octopus and some squid which were super tender and some giant sardines which I didn't try (never had it never will).  

all in all it was a grade A meal. it would have been an A+ except the portion were for regular sized people and 2 of us liked to eat so we went for Ice cream afterward at Bi-Rite.
author: Thomas T.

description:
From the moment we walked into this neighborhood gem, we were treated like family by the wonderful hostess Lorella who also happens to own the place with her husband. The food was truly superb, but honestly, they could have fed me mud, and I would have still loved it because the service and individualized attention were absolutely priceless. You must try the Sardinian flat bread as well as the squid ink pearl pasta. We also had the freshest ever giant prawns and sea bream. The place came highly recommended by a Neopolitan friend, which was instantly a good sign!
The wine list at the restaurant is phenomenal, and they gladly let you have tastes. Possessing extensive wine knowledge, I've never even heard of some indigenous Sardinian grape varietal wines they serve. What an adventure! And, I absolutely have to add how impressed I was by Lorella's genuine desire to seat us at the best available table. Literally, she adopted us for the night, and it felt great. We felt loved and truly cared for!
author: Marina S.

description: We've heard a lot about La Ciccia and wonderful it was, but it's hard to get a table unless you plan in advance, and we tend to decide to eat out the night of, so we've never been. However, after visiting Sardinia last year, we just had to La Ciccia since the couple that owns it are from Sardinia. Well, it did not disappoint! We've eaten at a lot of Italian restaurants and this was extremely authentic. They have some very interesting dishes that aren't for the faint of heart - Fregula with Sea Urchin Tomato and Cured Tuna Heart - but even that was good. Everything was fantastic, but you must try the Octopus stew in a spicy tomato sauce (but leave some sauce to dip your bread it - delicious!). It's a tiny place, but it's so worth being cramped!
author: Scott G.

description: Great service.  I thought the food was hit and miss when we went.  Neither of us were that into the octopus, and while my date loved the pasta it wasn't my thing.  But had a nice experience nonetheless given the quality service and fun atmosphere.
author: Amjad S.

description: I'm lucky to be right next door to La Ciccia! Its sicilan, so look for anything with seafood and broth. I'm sure they have good pasta etc., but the right thing to do is order their seafood.
author: amit s.

description: Great fresh ingredients. Flavored well, not heavy but just right. Very subtle nuances. We didn't have reservation, but came early. Got seated right away. Service was top notch.
author: B C.

description:
A couple months ago I was dining at my favorite Italian restaurant and ran into one of the former (Italian) waiters who had moved on to another joint since my last visit.  I asked him where else I should go for variety and a new experience; he recommended La Ciccia.  Finally made it there last Saturday.

Put this place on your list.

My dinner buddy and I shared the Sardella a Schiscionera (sauteed sardines).  No complaint about these, but they were the least outstanding part of the meal.  I prefer the grilled sardines at 54 Mint.

I stole a few bites of my friend's Malloreddus a sa Campidanese (semolina gnochetti).  Good stuff, not quite to the level of Ristorante Bacco's gnocchi -- but maybe that's an apples-to-oranges comparison, as the latter is made from potatoes.

My main course was Pezza de Angioni cun Cipudda a su Zaffaranu (seared lamb), served with an unusual (for me) bean/pea concoction on the side.  The sauce reminded me of a milder, subtler version of good ol' American BBQ. Delicioso and satisfying.

The wine we chose wasn't available, which was just as well since I mistakenly brought my Sicilian cheat sheet and the extensive wine list is largely Sardinian (so I was pretty much shooting in the dark).  The waiter suggested a slightly cheaper substitute and it was excellent -- sorry to say I don't remember bottling details.

Dessert was a sorbetto trio-- blueberry, black cherry, and strawberry.  Wow, such intense, distinctive flavors!

The décor is simple, elegant, pleasing.

Overall a wonderful dinner.  Too bad we talked politics -- I'm swearing off that forever!
author: Francisco G.

description: weary of the same and a desire for a new experience...sardinian cuisine never tasted and a first...trek across san francisco to noe valley...street parking moderately difficult...reservations and a very small table ready...quite cramp for a group of five...restaurant cramp and dark in general...bread and water served..plain ol' soft white bread roll...an order of the 2009 giunco white $forty-two to sip while waiting for others...sardine fillet special to snack...four fillets sauced and cooked to perfection...full of flavor and wiping plate with the plain bread given...tender octopus stew quite delicious...plenty of baby octopus to share...more bread dipping enjoyment...more bread!...pizza and salad the least favorite...finding salad ordered quite too bitter for taste...pizza more bready and toppings light...bottle of the 2005 lamarina, a light dry red reserve at $forty-seven to wash down the appetizers...finishing an appetizer heavy dinner with fresh spaghetti with spicy garlic evoo...quite the excellent pasta slightly drowning in delicious extra virgin olive oil...peers having same or different pasta dishes...a hearty pasta ending, but completely satisfied by the diversity of the meal...a third ordered being a 2006 sileno red, a robust fully body red reserve at $forty-seven...a cheers to a great dinner and a great small dessert, but forgetting the name...$seventy-five per person dinner for mentioned above...
author: Hen A.

description:
what a gem in the Noe Valley.

this is an excellent example of a great authentic Italian restaurant. we were pleased with almost every dish especially with the baby octopus stew and the tuna heart fregula. they were effing out of this world.

the service was spotless, efficient and attentive.

also, do try the ricotta with saffron cake!! you won't regret it.
author: Sung C.

description:
If you've never had Sardinian fare, you must try this great restaurant. But if you want Italian style food with a regional flare, super fresh ingredients, a very comprehensive wine list and the warmest service you can find, La Ciccia is a restaurant you will want to add to your dining repertoire.  The owners Lorella and Massimo always ensure your visit will be a memorable one.  Lorella will recommend the "Prupisceddu in Umidu" (Octopus stew in a spicy tomato sauce) or the "Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga" (Fresh Spaghetti with spicy Oil and Bottarga) or one of their Italian style pizzas (no garbage american pizzas here) made by their award winning pizza recipe.  Massimo, the chef will ensure your order is served to perfection.  

There are so many Italian restaurant to chose from in The City but if you want a truly authentic, regional, delectable italian dinner, La Ciccia is a gem you shouldn't miss.  Tell Lorella, I said hello!
author: Ralph C.

description: Wonderful place. Packed with character and a really nice staff. Fantastic food that you won't find anywhere else - well worth the effort to get that elusive 8pm Saturday reservation.
author: James C.

description: Neighborhood gem! La Ciccia has some of the best authentic Italian food I've ever had. To be specific, it's Sicilian (Sardinian) style of Italian cuisine. My wife had the sea trout and I had the goat stew. It was superb...both dishes were not overly seasoned--you can actually taste the meat. They have an extensive wine list as well. I high recommend this place. Btw, the owners and the wait staff are mostly Italian..another plus.
author: Al G.

description:
I LOVED MY FOOD or OUR FOOD and I LOVED the SERVICE and I LOVED the WINE, so OVERALL a 5 star experience!!!!!! =]

We went for the seafood salad and octupus stew for appetizers. The seafood salad was simple and tasty with the lemon dressing bursting RE-FRESHNESS! But what we fell for was the octopus stew, baby octopus in spicy tomato base... y u m! So tender and flavorful, it took baby octopus to a whole new level!! ;)

My friends had the lamb, delicious! If you like lamb meat, this is a must try,  I wasn't crazy about the veggie that went with it though. I had the linguini with clams and saffron, WOW, complex, um um GOOD!!!! Also shared one order of the sardinian flat bread, tasty as well, quite addictive actually as a snack ;)

Dessert, we had a gelato trio (marsala raisin, ?????, goat cheese & fig), my friends seem to love marsala raisin the most, but goat cheese & fig won my heart, probably because I dig goat cheese & fig :P And we also tried a ricotta chiffon cake, two small round cakes with shaved almonds on top and around, very light and fragrant. Oh and we tried Palacio for dessert wine, strong, full of flavors,I felt it was on the elegant side for a dessert wine! 

The chef came out twice to talk to us and even poured the palacio for me, hehe.. delighted!

Like many other 'hidden' gems, La Ciccia is not for groups. But DO bring the special someone here, it is absolutely lovely. Would love to go try the fish when it's in season. 

p.s. our server was very sweet, he sang the birthday song a second time in Italian upon request ;)
author: J W.

description:
Still fabulous.

I had the specials, burrata with cherry tomatoes on flatbread with a lovely balsamic, rigatoni with meaty ragu and a variation of margherita pizza.

Skipped dessert (no time).

Unpretentious wonderful service.
author: Poppy C.

description: Finally got to try bottarga. Delicious and salty. The apps were divine. Octopus was tender and the sauce was vibrant. Mozzarella was unbelievable. I could have eaten just that all night and been happy. Wine was delicately paired and the wait staff was on it as we were on a tight schedule and off to see Book of Mormon. Great night!
author: Mojo M.

description: There must have been a last minute cancellation because we made our sat 8p reservation at 715p. Score! We've been meaning to try this unassuming neighborhood joint for literally years. Worth the wait. We started with spicy octopus stew and an artichoke fava bean appetizer that both delivered, as did the wafer thin flatbread. we shared a first course pasta - it was a homemade small oval shaped pasta with sausage and it also was outstanding. straightforward, but clearly homemade and delicious. We inhaled the pasta. for entrees, i had seared sea bass and bf had lamb. yes, and yes. closed with gelati trio. another win. the service was also really solid. Waiter helped us pick a wine that was perfect. We'll be hitting this place again.
author: Steve S.

description:
3.5 stars.

AMBIANCE:  When I arrived at 5:45pm on a Friday the place was practically empty, but fast forward an hour or two later and MAN this place was bumpin.  The space is cozy and cute, but man, tables are really crammed together.  I was seated maybe a foot away from my neighbors... awkward!  I was also bumped quite a few times by staff as they walked back and forth from the kitchen.  Acoustics are not the greatest-- as the restaurant filled up it got harder and harder to have a conversation across the table.  

SERVICE:  Very friendly.  I loved how transparent our server was re: prices of items too.  Usually I feel like restaurant staff will tell you everything about a menu item except for how much it costs.  Not so at La Ciccia.  Highly appreciated.  Our server was also so patient when I was choosing my drink, and allowed me to sample a few to help me decide.

FOOD: 
- Burrata and crispy flat bread ($13):  A special of the day.  I wasn't impressed, but I'm also not a huge cheese person.
- Stewed baby octopus ($12):  The soup was very flavorful, but the octopus wasn't cleaned very well-- I got several pieces that were gritty and sandy... it was quite unpleasant.
- Fregola with seafood sugo and squid ink ($17):  I liked this dish.  It included lemon zest or something citrusy that really brightened the entire dish.  Very flavorful, and the seafood sugo was soooo tender, even after reheating the next day.  Portion size was ginormous... definitely a shareable dish.
- Fuseli with sea urchin and tuna heart ($17):  JF's dish.  Very fishy (from the sea urchin) and RICH.  I tried a bite-- definitely preferred my own pasta dish.
- Ricotta and saffron cake ($8):  Hands down my favorite dish of the night.  The cake was light and airy, and can you believe this, JUICY.  How is that possible?  Whatever voodoo Sardinian magic they used... man that cake was so good.

OVERALL: Cute neighborhood restaurant.  If I lived in Noe Valley I'd probably swing by every once in a while, but as is... it was nice to have visited, but not sure when I'll be returning.
author: Susanna W.

description:
Ciccia in Italian basically means "plumpy" and once you begin your dining experience here, you will fully embrace your true plumpy nature.  From the baby octopus stew to the ravioli of the day, we embarked on a Sardinian culinary safari tonight.  And everything was delicious.

Our meal began with a white wine from La Ciccia's extensive list.  We took the recommendation of the owner and weren't disappointed but we were surprised by the wine--in a good way.  We started with a frisee salad, some salumi, and the off the charts amazing baby octopus stew.  Following this, we had a pizza with mushrooms, prosciutto, mozzarella and rosemary olive oil.  Add to that the ravioli stuffed with potato, pecorini and mint and topped with a goat ragu.  

We had the lamb, tuna and mussels, and pork tenderloin as our second courses.  The lamb may have been the best preparation I've ever had.  Paired with the side of spicy wilted spinach, it was nearly perfect.

For dessert, we tried the trio of gelatos: marsala, almond, and goat cheese and fig.  Each of us had a different favorite, but they were all wonderful.

La Ciccia was an unknown restaurant to me before tonight, but now I will happily recommend it to anyone.  Thanks for a fantastic meal.  And thanks to my friends Renee and Yasu for inviting me!
author: Todd X.

description: Great Sardinian food.... yes people, this is not Italian food! But, it's awesome, go enjoy yourself.
author: Mike J.

description: Wow amazing cusine if you like Italian food from Sardinia. Very very good service and selection of wines.
author: Greenfolia U.

description: Highly overrated. The way the waiter raved about every dish had us salivating and then came the extreme let down. Mediocre at best. Can barely remember what everyone had and it was less than a week ago. The squid was the best thing but nothing extraordinary unless fried, tough and greasy is your benchmark. Five mushy shrimp. Am glad to not know how much that set my dad back and at least we didn't have to pay for parking. I would give this 2 stars if it wasn't so touted. .
author: D D.

description: Great wine list and reasonable priced, good Sardinian food, great atmosphere-neighborhood restaurant, wonderful service, easy parking. Sardines were great, squid ink pasta awesome-ordered 2, uni pasta ok- a bit disappointing, gelato - skip- overall great and fun night for a date:)
author: jane j.

description:
This place is unapologetic in its AUTHENTICITY. No americana. 100% pure Sardegna.  And it shows in flying (quattro mori) colors.

Therefore no ice tea.  Or the "someone's about to get wacked vibe".

If you've been to Sardegna you know what I'm talking about; this place is as good as any of the local restaurants there (save for lack of access to all the ingredients). If you prefer an american-italian place, stay away.  We need your seat.

Everything there is amazing.  Skip the pizza (it's OK, but more importantly you'd be wasting an opportunity for some amazing food you can't find anywhere else), but I've had nothing but great dishes from the rest of the menu.

And to the owners: please don't americanize the place. No ice tea or whacking of guests. Ever!

P.S. the wine list is INCREDIBLE but, more importantly, the co-owner knows her wines.  This is a place where you should let her suggests wines to pair with your meal, as she takes pride on this and you will explore some great unfamiliar wines knowing that you won't get shafted.
author: Mike B.

description:
Cozy and cute.

Perfectly executed everything.

Unique dishes, interesting wines, and really great service.

Bottarga spaghetti is amazing!
author: Melanie C.

description:
Loved it.. Sheep heart special? great !!... Octostew.. great.. 
Everything ... great.. Baby squids... great.. but not enough salt for me.. which brings me to 
2 caveats .. no salt on table.. hey I would like the choice if I want more salt.. the other  typical of  servers trying to sell more wine by constantly rushing over to refill wine glasses.. hey slow down there nelly.. don't make me drink another bottle of wine.
author: Jason C.

description: We were all a bit disappointed after getting recommendations and reading reviews.  Appetizers were great starters...grilled calamari, seafood stew, anchovies and burrata salad.  Pastas were a bit disappointing and lamb dish so-so.  Nice fruit sorbets. Nice neighborhood spot.  Service was very good.
author: Cincia H.

description:
I ate dinner here last week. I had heard rave reviews from several foodie friends. Well, this place is solid. Very little/nothing to complain about. Except perhaps that the place is a bit cozy and the tables are small. I give it a 4.75 stars. I will be back.

They have a good wine list with many reasonably priced Italian options, but I brought my own wine.

My friend and I had a ton of dishes. Everything was well prepared and tasty. No complaints at all.

First we tried the special appetizer. Chicken livers and gizzards in a hearty, creamy sauce. Not for everyone, but we loved it.

Next we had the fresh sardines. Really simple, but fantastic. Just so fresh and clean.

Fresh octopus in spicy tomato sauce. Perfect. 

Semolina Gnochetti with Pork meats Sugo and 9 Months Pecorino- Very hearty and full. Perfectly cooked pasta. Went well with my 1997 Corino, Vigne Gianchini, Barolo.

Dorado with olive tapenade and roasted mashed potatoes- Superb/

Got the cheese plate too. Selection of Sardinian Cheeses served with Sardinian honeys. Wonderful. The cheese and honey were a great contrast. 

Even had a dessert. Ricotta and Saffron Cake served with honey and Almonds. I was getting a bit full by this time. 

Overall a wonderful experience for a pretty reasonable price considering all of the courses we had.

Service was prompt and courteous. Courses came out when I expected them. No delays and not rushed either.
author: TJ M.

description: I've been waiting to go to La Ciccia for a long time, and I was finally able to get a table last week. My wife and I had a great meal there, but it was just short of 5 stars. The baby octopus stew was as good as advertised -- tender octopus with a soup/stew that was spicier than I had expected. I really liked the kick, and used all my bread to get every last bit of it. The gnochetti was also delicious -- good texture, well-cooked -- and the pork ragu was meaty and not too heavy. We also had the lamb loin that was very well cooked, but could've used a little bit more seasoning. The lamb also came with broccoli, which I am not a fan of, and it was a bit unfortunate that the waiter told us that the vegetable would be a surprise, even though he mentioned multiple vegetable options that day. The service is what probably dings them down a star. The service was very nice, but got less attentive as the meal went on, especially when we had to wait a long time to get the check. The meal was great, so it was unfortunate that it ended that way, but I would definitely go back if given the chance.
author: Pilan C.

description:
This is probably my second fave restaurant in SF. I don't mean best cuisine of all time, just my fave place to actually go to and have a nice quiet dinner of delicious food, fantastic wines, and excellent service.

Pros:
-Fresh pasta offerings - I've had the tagliatelle with shaved tuna heart and even though it smells like sewer it tastes like heaven.
-Great appetizers - seafood salad or sardines!
-They welcome you like they know you when you walk in
-The wine recommendations are really spot on for the food, and they often recommend sardinian wines which are yummers
-Even the dessert is good, which Italian desserts often are not
- It is in a cozy end of church and 30th which is perfect for quiet dinner with a friend or a cozy date but not a first date.

Cons
- you probably won't love this place like I do if you dont like seafood and especially oily "garbage" seafood like sardines and the smellier oilier fish. 
-you probably also won't like this place if you want to be someplace hip and happenin' with a vibe or scene.
author: Andrea S.

description:
Went here last night with my girlfiend.  Parking is a bit tricky -- I had to shark for about 15 minutes before I found something a few blocks a way.  So if you have a reservation, make sure you plan to get there a little early.  Making a reservation is key -- this place was packed to the gills on a Saturday night.  It was so crowded I couldn't even get in the front door to meet my girlfriend at our table without pushing through throngs of people.  The tables at this place are close together, and the overall space is small.  Because of this, it was super loud.  If you're a highly sensitive person and loud conversation bothers you, this isn't a good place for you.

On to the food and drink: Being completely unfamiliar with almost every wine on the extensive wine list, our waiter suggested a couple of things based on our tastes.  I asked for something a bit spicy, and he nailed it.  There is a $25 corkage fee if that's relevant.

They brought out some sliced bread which was obviously fresh but not that tasty.  With no butter or balsamic, it was barely worth eating.  We ordered a beet salad with some kind of cheese -- which tasted like beets and was okay (I'm not a huge beets fan).  We also ordered the calamari appetizer, which was fantastic -- one of the better calamari dishes I've ever had.  At this point, we started dipping the bread in the calamari dish juice because it was so scrumptious we didn't want to leave all the sauce uneaten.

For main dish, I had the seared ahi with a light olive sauce.  It was pretty good, but not phenominal.  My girlfriend had the lamb, which was literally the best lamp I have ever had in my life.  It was cooked just right, it was juicy, and there was lots of it.  If we ever go back, I am getting the lamb without hesitation.

Overall, I can easily give this place a 5 stars based on the food.  However, I'm knocking off a star overall for the ambiance -- it was just a little too crowded, too loud, and there were too many times that I got inadvertently jostled during the meal.  A fine meal overall, and we'll return again.
author: Alex P.

description:
I'd give this a 4.5. I was so excited to get a reservation here and overall, it was a good experience. The food is very good.

We arrived early as I figured it would be hard to find parking, but someone was pulling out just across the street, so we ended up being 10 minutes early. They were able to seat us right away. I take .5 off for service. We were seated right away, given menus and water immediately, but it was at least 15 minutes until they came to even get our drink order. They were good about coming back to refill our wine and water throughout the night.

We ordered a salad (special that night) and the flatbread to start and it came out very quickly. My husband said the salad was fine, but nothing special (I don't know why he even bothers to get salad!) and the flatbread was good, but it was huge. I feel like we just ate the top layer and it's not really something you can take with you :) My husband preferred the regular bread they served. I ordered the octopus stew, which as everyone else has said, was excellent. The octopus were perfectly cooked and the sauce was divine - loved the little kick it had. Great to use the bread to soak it up.

It was an oddly long wait between the starters and the main though, especially since the starters came so fast. Finally our dishes came, my husband ordered the gnocchetti (sp?) and I ordered the spaghittusu which is also a house specialty. Both were very good. I enjoyed mine, but it was a bit rich/heavy after what else I had eaten and it got very oily at the end so I left just a little. We were way too full for dessert.

Another issue with the service - dishes are left long after you're finished. Even after they were removed, it took a while for the waiter to come back around to see if we wanted dessert, and then finally, to bring, and then bring back the charged check.

Overall, the food is very good and it's an authentic Italian environment where the staff is speaking Italian to each other. Service was far from appalling but as listed above, could be improved a bit. While the menu isn't that big, I think we'd come back for the specialties I had and really enjoyed. Definitely recommended.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Wonderful regional Italian cooking with dishes you likely won't find elsewhere.  From their briny deep-flavored tomato octopus stew to their fresh handmade spaghetti with bottarga, and their crispy rosemary Parmesan flatbread and fresh grilled calamari.  This is a delicious rare piece of sunny Sardinia transplanted to San Francisco.

Not to mention their hot Italian waiter whose job is to upsell you.  ;)

Well, great food, nice eye candy, English menu, less attitude than being in Italy!  What's not to like?
author: Hoola H.

description:
A friend raved about this place when it first opened and he's never lead me astray so I had been meaning to check it out .  Then I heard some people did not enjoy it because of the fishiness of a lot of the food.  I was intrigued.

We shared the octopus stew, a pasta with bottarga, a pasta with tuna hearts and the cod.  Nothing was as fishy as I thought it would be and everything was delicious.  The octopus was very tender which surprised me.  I'm used to Korean dishes with octopus and it's usually pretty damn chewy.  The spicy tomato sauce was light but flavorful.  The bottarga and the tuna hearts were much more subtle in flavor than I expected and went really well with the freshly made pasta.  

I think I would order the exact same things the next time I go.  The service was excellent and the place was packed all night.  I know he can do it so I tried to convince my friend to make me some homemade pasta but he said it was too labor intensive (happy birthday!).  Hmph.
author: Seong P.

description: All the way to the restaurant I was talking shit about people who think Italian food is only about pasta etc, and the best thing we ordered that night was the spaghetti!  Everything was really good though.  I had the lamb with gnocchi, which was prepared very well.  My partner in crime had the prawns in an amazing garlic tomato sauce.  The octopus soup lives up to the hype.  The highlight as I've mentioned was the spaghettiusu with red pepper oil.  Wow, fresh pasta with a garlic/butter/oil/pepper sauce...might be the best pasta experience I've ever had.  We also had the saffron ricotta cake which I'm still dreaming about.  Amazing texture and potent saffron flavor.  Can't wait to go back for round 2.
author: Mark A.

description:
Great meal.
Certainly not your usual Italian.
Quaint but enough subtle chatter to keep it from being boring.
Service and staff were friendly, prompt and unobtrusive.
The octopus stew was just spicy enough and quite hearty.  So tender.
The pastas were subtle in flavor but quite enjoyable.
Loved the rigatoni with veal ragu.
Sea bream was excellent.
May be the best Italian I've had in SF.
author: John O.

description:
I love Italian food but I've never had Sardinian cuisine.  It's Italian yes but it doesn't consist of thick tomato sauces, an endless bowl of pasta and parmesan cheese piled high. Sardinian cuisine consists of seafood cooked with complimentary seasoning and light sauces that breaths freshness through the dish.

I was how much I liked the octopus stew that featured octopus in a spicy tomato. The spiciness complimented the freshness of the octopus. You must try the spaghetti with bottarga caviar; it was out of this world! It's tossed in a spicy oil dressing that was light and as I slurped it down, it didn't feel like I d used a stick of butter as a chap stick. Instead of thick crusted pizza, they serve it brick oven style keeping the sauce light, the pizza sarda was a generous helping of pecorino, capers, onions and oregano. The tender lamb chops were seared perfectly and inside had a nice color. For desert we had the selection of sardinian cheeses with honey. There's complimentary bread but try the flat bread and dip it in the sauces of each dish, I was skeptical about their wine list but it turned out to be quite extensive. 

Quaint restaurant you could walk right by without knowing but pray that you don't. The decor is very minimal with very dim lights making it perfect for a romantic date.  Our waiter was friendly and helpful in explaining how each dish is cooked. The chef even came out and talked to a few guests. If you love Italian and want to experience another region of Italian food, this is must try!
author: Lola L.

description:
Years ago I lived next door to this place and it was under different owners and was CRAP. Visiting the old hood and learning about this new(ish) jem makes me SO BUMMED it wasn't there when I lived so close!

I'm scared to write this review, because right now I'm able to get a spot at the bar most of the time and enjoy the surrounding people who have had reservations for weeks and/or are warm Italian staff members who know their stuff and are incredibly kind.

The food is spot-on every time. The homemade pastas are thick, rich, delish. The fish dishes are authentic and celebrate basic flavors in sophisticated ways. I love wine but don't know Italian wines at all... they have a large Italian wine menu and have made amazing recommendations based on my tastes and the meal.

I love you, La Ciccia! Gracie!
author: suzi p.

description:
I love when I can finish a meal thinking "I'm happy to come back." That was the case with La Ciccia. A really great place for date night, I just enjoyed a really satisfying meal here. 

The restaurant is very small, cozy, and although the seating is a pretty tight squeeze all around (for service and for the table guests) it adds to the charm. Without a reso, you are definitely in for a wait, but conveniently you can walk across the street to their wine bar La Nebbia- the service from the bar staff is exceptionally welcoming. I had my eyes set on 3 things on the menu at La Ciccia before we even ordered, and I was happy when the bartender at La Nebbia re-affirmed my choices. 

The Calamarusu to start, was fantastic. 5 whole Monterey squids grilled perfectly, soft and tender, and finished with basil oil. I could eat 2 rounds of that if you let me. Pasta Longa e su Nieddu de Seppia- the linguine was cooked to al dente and tossed in the rich, sea flavor of squid ink. Loved it. Last, the dish I was most looking most forward to was the Fregua Sarda cun Arrizzonisi e Cori de Tonnu; toasted Fregola pasta with urchin, tomato and topped with shaved cured tuna heart. Anything urchin has a special place in my heart, and this dish unfortunately didn't play out as well as I had hoped. The sauce was lush and sweet with uni, creamy and perfect with the slight acid of the tomato and the gaminess of the the tuna heart, but the fregola wasn't ideal to me in holding up to the sauce. Textures were all soft, and to me the sauce was screaming to be paired with a noodle pasta that brought bite and texture. But all in all, flavors were simple and delicious, and I'm looking forward to the next visit to try some other dishes on their menu.
author: F S.

description: This restaurant is phenomenal! Sardinian food is nothing like typical Italian food. We had the baked Calamari - it was the filet mignon of the sea prepared to perfection. Next we we had the Fregula with Fresh Ricotta and Cured Tuna Heart. This cannot be described - only experienced. The smell is rather pungent, but the taste is smooth and delicate. The waitstaff is intimately informed about the dishes and will describe everything in detail as well as compare/contrast dishes so you can choose something exactly right for you. The wines were wonderful as well. This is perfect to impress a date or your out of town guests.
author: Dusty S.

description: This restaurant should not be under Italian food!!! We went and were really really disappointed!! It is located about 20 mins from the city and the food was sooo bizarre and the normal food that we did order wasn't very good!! Waste of time!
author: Aurora O.

description:
We took my girlfriend here for her birthday and she is now a big fan!  I know they list no cell phones, computers, or cameras operated at the table on the menu, but since it was her birthday, we respectfully asked our waiter if he would take a picture of all of us at the table and he was happy to oblige.   Our reservations for five were for 5:30 and the place quickly filled up within the next hour.  

We had a variety of their food, from a Marghareta pizza, to wafer-thin cheesy bread, to linguini with octopus and ink and everyone loved their tasty, yet smallish portions!  We shared a dessert of three scoops of exotic gelatos.   For five entrees, two appitizers, and two or more glasses of wine the bill was around $126.00 so I consider that not a bad deal at all.

We will definitely return!
author: ruth r.

description: Great food and one of the few remaining places where you get authentic food and genuine non-jaded service
author: M S.

description:
If you have any relationship with the real Italy, especially with southern, island Italian culture and cuisine, you will be so beyond happy here.

My family (all Italian) now live all over the country. But when we are all home, this is exactly the food that my Grandfather makes. Simple, unique, tasty. Filled with seafood and flavor. 

This is a very authentic Sardegnian place. No bread with olive oil for dipping. Leave that at the Olive Garden.  An all Italian wine list. Casual but warm service. A menu laid out traditionally (starter, secondi and main) A decor that could be right out of that tiny place at the end of a cobbled alley. Just know, this is not Northern Italy. It will be Seafood. And salty. And more rustic than refined.

If that sounds like something you'd be interested in, it's a five star experience. If you come looking for something else, you won't be happy.
author: Sir M.

description: The low rating is really because of the poor service. Our server was extremely condescending. Instead of educating us she was abrupt and curt when we inquired about their veggie options. It's also pretentious which left us thoroughly underwhelmed. No matter how good your food is, don't roll your eyes at your customers. We will not be returning.
author: riddhi g.

description: Skip the appetizers. Get the signature spaghetti with garlic and fish, squid ink pasta, and sea urchin rotelli. And pork snitzel. They are out and out great!
author: Steven W.

description:
Baby octopus in a spicy red sauce - so tender it virtually dissolves in the mouth; pasta with cured tuna heart that makes you want more even if you are full; and, pasta with heirloom tomato, onion and smoked trout sauce that is rich, deep and complex - this was last night's dinner along with a couple of beautiful and expressive vermentinos suggested by the staff - it all adds up to one of the most enjoyable meals I have ever had.
A great place.
author: Jim C.

description:
This is a great neaighbourhood restaurant. I generally don't like eating Italian food outside of Italy (after living there for 6 years) but this is really wonderful Sardinian comfort food.

La Ciccia is not a fancy restaurant. The food is delicious and honest; the wine list has many perfect choices for the food (ask if you don't know what to choose) and the service is reliable and unpretentious. The fish dishes are particularly good.

This is the real deal.
author: Rachel B.

description:
Really cute space. It's not too small but it is a narrow area which made it kinda crowded while we were eating. 

We started with the grilled calamari appertizer which was great. Tender with a good amount of garlic.

I started with the cauliflower purée. I think it could have been better with a bit of salt, but I didn't add any and it was still good. The portion was pretty big so I'm not sure I needed a full main course...but of course I got one anyway!
For my main course I had the pizza special--goat cheese, mozzarella, pancetta and onion with red sauce. The pizza was excellent! Good crunch in the crust, flavorful savory toppings. 

I'm taking one star off because initially when we asked for olive oil with our bread they offered oil for an additional $2. It was some special dipping oil I suppose but we were thrown off.
A return visit is in order since the food was truly yummy.
author: Lu E.

description: Came here for a special birthday dinner and La Ciccia did NOT disappoint.  I've got to echo all the other reviewers and say that the spicy octopus stew is a MUST.  But next time I'll get my own bowl because I don't wanna share!  With the stew, bread and olives (when you order olives, you get a LOT of olives, they don't skimp like most places!) and a couple bottles of wine... honestly I was almost too full for the pork gnochetti and the prawns but they were both delicious.  The sommelier really knew what he was talking about and gave us some great suggestions and did NOT try to upsell us to the expensive stuff.  The staff was super nice and even when we were the last couple there and were feeling guilty that we'd be eating so slowly, they did NOT try to rush us at all and even brought us a complimentary dessert when we finally finished.  Very warm, homey environment here with excellent customer service (upon arrival, they asked to hang my jacket and purse and since we were initially seated in a middle aisle, they kindly asked if if we'd like to move to a wall table!) and delicious, comforting food, I will definitely come here again!
author: Suzanne V.

description: Sardinian food?  It's like Italian food (actually it IS Italian food) but with more focus on the seafood.  Solid 4 stars.  Place gets packed so make rezzi's.  Def get the octopus stew and the sardines.  The fish roe spaghetti was also great.  Huge wine list and heavy pours by the glass.
author: Toby C.

description: So warm and inviting. Feels truly like you are walking into a Sardinian kitchen. The restaurant is small with maybe ten-fifteen tables. The wine menu is completely Italian wines. Our waiter was attentive and helpful, and so was the rest of the staff. I'm a huge fan of this place, and I can't wait for my next visit.
author: Sanfrancisco O.

description: This place is ridiculously awesome.  Not a bad dish on the menu.  The fregola with squid ink is the best.  Go eat here now!
author: schmoo l.

description:
Came here for a lovely dinner with J & T (thanks again guys!!). I'm all for regional italian cuisine. I'm all for any type of italian cuisine actually. For the appetizers we had an array of things, but nothing for me really stood out in that category. And the same goes for the entree. I had the slow roasted pork. It was ok, but not great. 

My favorite thing of the entire evening was the Semolina Gnochetti with Pork meats Sugo and 9 Months Pecorino. Now THAT was a damn good dish!! I'm craving it right now actually. 

Great regional wine list and for me, La Ciccia is the first place that I have been to in California that didn't have a single CA wine on its list. Nice! 

I don't think I'd come back here though. Just wasn't that impressive to me.
author: Jen D.

description:
Warm and cozy during the recent thunderstorms.  

The food is of high quality, staff is a bit odd - maybe from the thunderstorms?  I walked in without a reservation - table for two on a Wed night at 7pm?  I did not think it that strange ofa  request... but they did despite the fact that another table was vacant the entire time we were there and the bar seating was available too.

The food we had a very flavorfull and very Italian.  Menu is always changing with what is fresh, in season and available.  The Lamb was beautifully prepared with lentils, while the pasta with fish eggs and tuna was lovely.  

The staff was a bit pushy with some of their suggestions and we felt a bit rushed to order.

Overall I'm always pleased with the food - but maybe just having a strange night.
author: Annette M.

description:
We return often and have the pasta with fish roe called battarga I believe. There is a wide range of dishes
Everything is very tasty and served with pride and finesse. Semi freddo desserts always a winner
author: Josephine G.

description:
http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/VitalityProject/sardinian-diet-hold-secret-longevity/story?id=8875605

I can tell the reason that LOTS of people love this place.
@ this La Ciccia, all people are very friendly to me. The service is excellent.

The cheese, called pecorino sardo, is made from the milk of grass-fed sheep, resulting in a product that is high in Omega-3 fatty acids.

Sardinia is also known for having another kind of cheese -- one that actually is infested with live maggots.

That cheese may contain bacteria that are good for the gut.  However most of Americans don't understand the fact that how the Beneficial Bacteria from the Fermented Food: IS GOOD FOR HEALTH.  Like Kimchee and Sardinians' cheese will cleansing the intesternal system.

The Food is very authentic.  The flavor is real Sardinia or Sicilian.  I love the Sicilian coffee that very strong flavor but not bitter and the pizza was the best Italian Pizza I've ever tried.  The owner couple are very generous enough to gave me free coffee and dessert.
The gelato ice cream and blood orange sherbet were so good.  Certainly the ethnic restaurant is always worthwhile to try.  I will go back to the place with my date.
author: bluemoon p.

description: Service was outstanding, food was a little better than mediocre, but considering the price there are too many other better options.
author: Carmen V.

description:
What a charming and intimate Sardinian restaurant! Massimo and Lorella are the sweet husband and wife owners, who pour their heart and soul into the food and wine served here. I admired the passion with which they spoke about their food and they spent nearly 2.5 hours after their closing time to accommodate us. 

Sardinian food is extremely rich, and although the dishes were presented very simply, the flavors were amazing. I started with the heirloom tomato salad, which was so good I couldn't even spare a second to speak. We also had the calamari, which was so tender and came in a delicious broth that made for a fantastic sauce for dipping bread in. For my main entree, I went with the tasty Semolina Gnochetti with pork sugo and pecorino, which was the perfect amount. I didn't feel stuffed, even after trying to eat half of my dining companion's braised boar while he wasn't looking.
