For dessert, we enjoyed a variety of gelato, which after spending an afternoon at a chocolate festival, completely maxed out my sugar intake for the rest of the month. Damn, we're only at the beginning of the month!

I let the wine connoisseur I was with handle the wine choice as he is a regular and is familiar with the incredible all Italian wine list with over 180 labels. His selection paired well with the dishes we had. We also managed to try two other amazing reds, a prosecco to start and a dessert wine to complete our evening. 

Let's just say I was happily full by the end of the night. Just call me La Ciccia - "cute chubby girl" - because that's what I felt like after such a decadent meal.
author: Connie C.

description: What more can I add.  Terrific, real Italian food.  Great service.
author: Matthew C.

description:
I came here with my mother after a particularly hard day, yes, I go out to eat to put a good note on a bad day. Anyways, it is very small inside, and very loud. The service was impeccable, and everything we had was incredibly fresh. 
We had the salume plate, which was delicious, but on the steep end....($11 for two kinds?). The octopus stew was out of this world! So tender and delicious with just enough spice...YUM! I actually had to get more bread to sop up the sauce, and there may have been some discreet finger licking..... 
I had the gnocchetti, which were good, but I wouldn't order them again. The mother had the sole, which was delicious, but not dream worthy. 
Overall, we stuffed ourselves like piglets, and yes, the food made my day much better. I will definitely be back for the octopus stew, and look forward to trying some new dishes.
author: Bianca L.

description:
Complex, interesting flavors - not like any other Italian food I've had.  The octopus  dish was excellent.  The sardines were very fresh but the least flavorful dish of the night.  We got the daily specials for pasta (one with goat, one with mussels), and they were both delicious.  The waiter recommended the sea bream and pork loin for mains: the pork was especially good. 

I never knew honey had such a range of flavors until I had the cheese plate.  It included a saffron honey.  Good, attentive service.
author: Sumomo O.

description:
Ate there last night.  It's a small, cozy restaurant with a great ambiance.  They have a fantastic Italian (& Sardinian) wine list.  Lorella was very friendly and helpful in pairing a great wine to go with our food, and she took time to come and converse with all of us.  Our server was very good and friendly.  He did forget one first course that we ordered and we got the wrong item on that, but it wasn't a big deal -- but that's the only reason I'm knocking one star.

The food came out HOT, and it was fast.  They use lots of pecorino cheese.  Had the octopus appetizer, and it was cooked perfectly, very tender.  The lamb was outstanding, one of the best lamb dishes I've ever had.  We ordered a pizza to share, and that was also very good.  In all, everyone was very pleased with the food and overall experience, and they have so many wines to discover that we'll definitely be going back as often as possible.  The prices are reasonable as well.  $25 corkage if you bring your own wine, but I recommend asking Lorella what she thinks you should drink and you won't be disappointed.
author: Todd A.

description:
One of the my favorite restaurants in the SF. Charming owners Lorella and Massimiliano work every night to bring you authentic Sardinian cuisine and service. I've had so many fantastic dinners here that I would give it the elusive 6th star. Must try if you're visiting or live in the city. The wine list is one of the best around for Italian wines and I've yet to get a bottle that didn't have a great story and a reasonable price. Given that Massimiliano is a sommelier who worked for Italian importer Winebow, it's not a surprise but the wines are surprisingly excellent. 

Must try dishes: Spaghetti with freshly shaved Bottarga, Wild Boar Stew, Seasonal Soups, brussell sprouts, desserts (esp. house gelato's), pizzas.
author: Phil M.

description:
La Cicca is my favorite place to eat in Noe Valley. I was taken their on my birthday by my Fiancé and we have great time. We loved the food, ambiance, and staff. I recommend the lamb dish and the spicy octopus stew. No matter what you order their though you will enjoy as the quality of every dish is superb. 

5 out 5!
author: Tom M.

description: Clearly the best Italian restaurant in the city.
author: antonio c.

description:
This was more like a 2.5, but I like to round up.


This tiny restaurant present with a nice face. It feels like it's a secret that Noe Valley wants to keep with itself. The place contains maybe about 15-20 tables and is very cozy. The decor is easy on the eye and makes the place romantic for a nice dinner out. I wish the interior could have made up for the food of the place.

Let's start with the appetizer. It was a sort of minced beef dish in a creamy tomato sauce. I held my opinion until we left La Cicca, but it might as well have been dog food. That's right. Dog Food. It might as well been taken from a can, scooped out onto a ceramic dish, served to us, and then billed for $15. The other calamari appetizer was good, but the dog food dish stayed with me for the rest of the meal. I regretted listening to the server since he recommended the DF dish, but honestly, I can't remember what the rest of the meal tasted like but it ok. 

Pros: The server was nice. He answered question quickly and was very nice. The food came out pretty fast. 

Cons: $15 dog food. Over priced for the taste. 

We will have to come back here to double check the rating, but I hesitate to spend another $70 on this food.
author: Chris D.

description:
The food was good.  Nothing outstanding, but nothing bad either.  The goat stew was good, as well as a pasta with bottarga.  Appetizers were very good -- burrata, prosciutto, etc.  Mediocre ravioli, slightly bland roast fish.
The problem was the service.  We had one of the most rude waitresses I have ever experienced.  For context, we were a table of 5 middle-aged women and a younger woman.  We're all very pleasant people and all very kind to waitstaff.  This waitress must have had a bone to pick because she made our whole dining experience unpleasant -- from initial very rude tisk-tisking about using a smal light to see a menu (it was dark for 60+ year old eyes!) to interrupting conversations and a total unwillingness to explain anything on the menu or spend anytime with us, it was bad.  We had to ask for water 3 times and the third time she said "I know, I know, I'll get your water!!" as if she was completely annoyed at us for asking for it.  It's really a bummer because everyone else there seemed really kind.
author: Laura S.

description:
Yum yum yummy! The octopus stew as an app was so good to sop up with a basket of bread. The pasta special with 3 kinds of meat and rigatoni was delish. AND the lamb entree was perfectly cooked with the right touch of spices. Loved the cooked onions on this dish.

For 3 people... we had 2 apps, 2 pastas and 1 entree. We shared it all with a $41 bottle of wine and had a lovely meal for $148. Add in a $35 tip for great service and great recommendations and it was a good evening out for about $200.

I'd totally come back here again. I loved the neighborhoody feel, great menu and great service.
author: Allison J.

description: Full on a Wednesday night - food exquisite, wine recommendation perfect.  Although I never find anymore reasons to venture into the city anymore as an East Bay convert (Oaktown!), La Cicca is worth the bridge toll and headache of venturing deep into SF that I don't even know what neighborhood I'm in.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Best Italian meal I've had outside of Italy.  There isn't much I can add that others haven't covered but I can echo most if not all of the accolades.  We tasted almost everything on the menu and it all exceeded my expectations:

- Octopus Stew - I am still dreaming about it.
- Pizzas - I wouldn't normally order a pizza (unless it's a pizza dinner) but these pies were AMAZING. So fresh, so simple.  
- Burrata & flatbread - woah
- Sardines - beautiful, melts in your mouth and not overly salty as sardines can be
- Gnochetti Ragu - So rich and pasta perfectly al dente 
- Bottarga - BEST DISH OF THE NIGHT!!!!
- Lamb - better than any filet I've ever tasted. Couldn't have been better
- Gelato - Do yourself a favor and order

And the wine list....beautiful and interesting (and reasonable).

I'm sure there was more (oh yes) but these stood out.  I already have a reservation for next month.  Swoon.
author: Kira B.

description:
Delicious food is apparently to be had in Sa Sardegna, that 'other' island further west of Sicily, Italy. La Ciccia (chi-CHIA?) is doing a great job presenting the cuisine (at least my Chinese-self thinks so) with a VERY sincere staff. It's not quite the in-your-face-bold-flavors that I've come to define as Italian food, but I'm digging it!  
**Update 9/19/06 - thx beth l., who solved my linguistic quandry - "SEEsia" is how they say it**

The only mini detraction was the slow foodservice. This small restaurant recently got uber props from Michael Bauer and I think they're overwhelmed. We had 8:30pm reservations and could not be seated a minute before. It was nearly a 1/2 hr before our appetizers of thick cuts of fresh mozzarella w/roasted veggies (a bit pedestrian) and a pesto/potato/pancetta pizza came out (mmm WOW).  

I had the evening special of lamb chops w/a chopped mint/olive oil drizzling - medium rare per chef's choice - MMM SO TASTY. The 2 galpals across the table from me, finished their baked sea bass, and braised tuna entrees before I'd even looked up (I GUESS it was good). Thus I only got to try a small bite of hangar steak of the buddy next to me; also chef's choice medium rare, also YUM.  

It was something of a belated bday celebration tonite, and our waitress brought out a lemon zest & saffron ricotta dessert, w/a candle for my friend. I nippled on the trio of cheese plate (who loves cheese? ME!) and AGAIN those 2 on the other side gobbled their chocolate ice cream/cake before I could taste it. GRRR.

Though the entire meal went over 2hrs, the staff was sooo so nice, and helpful throughout.  When the bill arrived, I was happy to see that all those appetizers, drinks, entrees & desserts didnot add up to a tough-to-swallow-total.  And the bday cake had been COMPed.  Now that's HOSPITALITY, people!  It's a dying form at restaurant establishments. 

Wow - I'm still salivating, at the thought of our dinner this evening!  Definitely get reservations, perhaps dine on a weeknite or early hour, but dine there sometime soon!
author: CINDY K.

description: The Gnochetti with pork ragu and the pizza were decent.  The octopus stew was horrible, the fishiest thing we've ever had.  The wild shrimp dish was very pedestrian, and the braised vegetable was way overcooked.  The service was kind of slow and not very friendly.  We asked for more water 4 times before we got someone to refill our glasses.  There are lots of better Italian restaurants in the neighborhood.  Would not return.
author: TopCat W.

description: i came here w/ 4 friends yesterday and was able to try a lot more stuff.  the fusilli w/ uni and tuna hearts is absolutely delicious.  the sea bream w/ tapenade was also fab.  don't come unless you love fish and seafood!
author: Helen T.

description: One of my favorite real authentic italian place. The chef is from Sardina and cooks speciality from that island. Never got disappointed with them.
author: Antonino S.

description:
One of the best in the City. If you can't afford plane fare to Sardinia then visit for dinner any night but Monday. Try the sardines, the lamb, any of the pastas, the seafood salad and when they are serving it the tripe.
I almost forgot the pizzas. You will receive the warmest welcome and incredible wine. The chef is a genius.
author: Randy D.

description:
A solid four stars. Very small, so book well in advance. Parking can be a bit difficult as it's adjacent to a residential area.

Starters: grilled calamari, salume, and octopus stew. The calamari was pretty good, not too rubbery. The sauce is good to mop up with your bread. The salume was sliced super thin and spread over a large plate. Good with the table bread as they charge $2 for EVOO and will not bring you butter. In fact, he said Sardinian cuisine doesn't really use butter. My favorite was the octopus stew. Very tender, almost meaty baby octopus in a flavorful slightly spicy tomato stew. Delicious.

Entrees: I had the petrale filet. Soooo good, very delicate and flaky. Cooked to perfection and served on a small bed of greens. My friends ordered various pasta dishes, which were all pretty good. I just can't get myself to order pasta at an Italian restaurant, even it it's home-made.

For dessert, we quickly split a trio of gelati: Saffron, goat cheese, and malaga (kinda like rum raisin). They were all pretty good, although the goat cheese one was a bit odd and kinda sour. I liked the malaga the most.

We didn't have any wine, but if you flip over the menu, your eyes will cry when they see the 7pt font wine list completely covering the entire back side. lol! Looked like a pretty good selection, but only a handful available by the glass.

The prices were very reasonable. For the four of us, it came out to just under $150, including tip.
author: Kenny J.

description:
We started off the night with their famous Seafood Salad and it was totally amazing. It was so light and refreshing while at the same time tasty with its awesome dressing. We used their nice bread and dipped it into the salad all the way till we finished it off real good. 

Then it was time for the main course. We made a mistake and didn't order any pasta but went straight into Secondi. I guess it was a mistake. I ordered the lamb tenderloin which was cooked perfectly and it was served with a side of seasoned onions. While the dish was good the lack of carbs made it a bit overwhelming as I didn't have anything to clean my palate along the way.

Wifey had the whole sea bream, which was cooked perfectly with bone, head and tail on. The meat was so tender, delicious and fresh. There were no side dishes to the fish, it was served plainly.

We paired all this with a Sardinian wine selected by the owner of the restaurant and bought for us by a friend who had recommended this place! Talk about treatment!

It was a Isola dei Nuraghi which was 100% Carignano. It was not overwhelmingly complex so my wife didn't suffer eating her fish but it was not too simple either and complemented my lamb perfectly. 

After all this, we had room for desert since we had foregoed our Primi, and we were glad we did that in the end. We shared a trio of ice cream which was amazing and another dessert which had a frozen core and a thin layer of cake around it.

Overall, we had great food and wished if we could come back one more time before our SF weekend getaway ended. We'll be back to this place on our next trip to SF for sure. This time, we'll go with an empty stomach and do the full ritual of Antipasti, Primi, Secondi and Dolci all the way to the end.
author: Volkan S.

description:
La Ciccia is a smallish Mom and Pop place at the terminus of Church Street in Noe Valley.  It's reputed to be Sardinian, although I haven't the background to say whether or not that is so.  I will tell you, instead, whether or not I liked the food.  

I started with a signature dish of al dente pasta with bottarga and cauliflower.  The bottarga gave the very rich plate a nutty, bitter taste of some interest, but the cauliflower was cooked to the point that it added neither taste nor texture to the dish.  A  too large, puddle of olive oil was at the bottom of the bowl.  

Branzino was described as oven roasted.  What came was steamed or poached.  The fish was nice enough but bland.   If a restaurant is sufficiently confident of its seasoning as not to provide salt or pepper on the table then the chef had best be on top of his game.  Not so here.  The fish needed something.   The fish came ala carte, making it expensive.  Peas with onions and mint another ala carte plate, didn't  taste of the fresh veggie.  The onion was overcooked and added nothing and the mint was a sprig of mint.  

A disappointment.
author: David D.

description:
Went there for dinner tonight.  Service was great and most of the food was very good.  The octopus that everyone raves about was really good and the shrimp main meal was phenomenal.  However, the gnochetti and the ... forgot the name... the dish with the tun on top (frugula?) was good...but not great.

Impressive wine menu and warm, loving service.
author: David H.

description:
I second the motion of a yummy dinner from Allison J's review.   We don't get to Noe very often and it was a nice change.  Easy parking, great neighborhood feel, excellent service, and delicious food.

Definitely recommend sharing a few dishes so you can sample more dishes.  The pasta dishes are small so get a few of these if you are sharing between more than 2 people.  

We finished our dinner with a cheese dish and chocolate dessert.

We will definitely go there again.
author: Gina C.

description: I can't come up with a reason to not give our meal and evening 5 stars.  We arrived on a Saturday evening over Thanksgiving without a reservation and were suprised to be able to sit at two of the 4 bar spots.  Our server and the staff (its a small restaurant and a small group) were authentic (from Italy or Sardinia), professional and aimed to please. The meal, however, was the real head turner. Our waiter reorganized our menu choices to keep the types of food balanced and each dish was outstanding, all the way down to an exquisite arugula salad!
author: Kelly W.

description: Decent place but I don't quite understand all the hoopla. Decent octopus stew, nice wine, cute little place, overly solicitous waiter wouldn't leave us alone to talk instead interrupted loudly continually. Food was good. But not awesome
author: John C.

description: My favorite restaurant in this part of the world. Food quality is top, service and authentic Sardinian atmosphere makes it unbeatable.
author: Axel M.

description:
I wish I could give more than 5 stars!! AMAZING, AMAZING, AMAZING!!!
we are from Italy and restaurant in the bay area is as authentic as this one.

we have been here on several occasions ans recently we had the pasta with bottarga, the propisceddu and the lamb...needless to say it was the best meal ever. the perfect end to it arrived with the fig and goat cheese ice cream: it was tart from the goat cheese, sweet from the figs, the perfect combination.

I will never stop raving about this place and, if I lived closer, I would probably go there every week.
author: Anna R.

description:
I'm really sorry to be giving La Ciccia 2 stars. I really would love to give it more because I love the "idea" of the restaurant but honestly everything tonight was so "blah" and "whatever" that I wouldn't recommend any friends to go there. 

I was impressed because the restaurant was crowded - on a Saturday night, the tables were all full and there was a steady stream of customers coming in. We were looking forward to eating here b/c the owners are from Sardegna and our best friend studied there and is of native Italian origin so we figured we'd love it and while the ambiance was totally there and the watistaff were all super warm and friendly, the food just... wasn't and when it comes down to it, the reason why I eat out is to get better tasting food than what I make at home and all the food tonight was pretty bland and in general it was "whatever." A totally non-memorable meal.

Here's the rundown: 

Wine list - definitely gets an A - lots of variety and plenty to choose from in all price ranges - we had a bottle of a great Prosecco followed by a native Sardegna red (didn't pick it, so not sure what we got) - both bottles together cost $80. 

Apps:

1. We ordered a special "ricotta" cheese made with cow's milk which was bland and tasteless - it came with "crostinis" but when we got the plate, it was a dollop of cheese in the middle with two toasted crostinis and olive oil drizzled around it - all around this didn't taste like much, it needed some roasted red pepper or sun dried tomatoes to give it a little "oomph" - alas... 

2. We also ordered the Seafood Salad which was fine - the fish all tasted good and seemed fresh. The flavorings here were bland as well but it was fine I guess. 

3. Prosciutto slices - I don't eat ham but my husband says it was decent, but unremarkable.

Main courses - 

The restaurant is a tad loud so I'm going to say that maybe the waiter didn't hear but one of our guests ordered a special homemade squid ink tagliarini but the waiter didn't hear her properly and put in the wrong order, we were told it would be just a minute to get the right dish and it took between 5-10 minutes... not great, but hey, these things happen. 

The wild boar stew looked very meaty - basically it looked like a plate of meat with a tiny dollop of cabbage next to it - would've been good to get some veggies in there... 

My husband had lamb chops (based on the recommendations we saw on Yelp) but he also felt it was very mediocre.

I had a Fruega (spelling maybe Freuga?) - it was a larger size grain-type of pasta in the couscous family - it was okay taste-wise, not the most delicious thing I've ever had but I like the consistency of the pasta grain even if the taste was mediocre. 

I think one of the big reasons why I'm giving it 2 stars is because my expectations were set fairly high from reading the other Yelp reviews here so think of this as a favor as I set your expectations on the low side :) - otherwise I'd probably give it 3 stars, but definitely no more than that. 

I liked the fact that this was a neighborhood restaurant and really liked the friendliness of the staff, with the chef, maitre d' amongst waiters who were friendly and stopped by our table to say hi, I just wish the food tasted better...
author: Heather F.

description:
The very next-best-thing to dining in Italia!  Super gracious, charming staff and everything our group had: pastas, seafood stew, bass, was fantastic.  We also sampled a few appetizers, all very tasty & beautifully presented.  If you love Italian food, this place is the real deal.

This is THE place to take people who've eaten in Italy and ever since complain that they can't find the real thing in the states.  My conscience doesn't allow for it, but word is that the lamb is super-yum.
author: Kayse G.

description:
I'm not a fan of italian cuisine - but I l LOVE it here!!!  Everything I had was excellent! Such an exquisite -almost- home-made like food! It's not the 'fancy' presentation type of food, but REAL essence, good taste italian dishes.

Sigh..  still dreaming about it...
author: N. C.

description:
So it seems like people like this place.  And why not, the people working there were very nice, the food was OK, the Limonatta desert was pretty amazing.

Buuuuuut, Oh whoa is the two-top that sits in the middle of any noisy restaurant.  Go here as a party of three or more.  Two's are sitting in the middle of the restaurant.

Annnnnnd there's cozy and then there's  the realtor's definition of 'cozy'
This place has bought into the realtor's definition.
Perhaps if there was anything to mediate the noise, i.e. some kind of acoustical solution on the walls or ceilings.  I have good hearing, BUT I couldn't hear the server tell me the specials, I asked an re-asked.  It's 2 days later and my left ear is still ringing from the jack-asses we were sitting next to.  

I have my father's voice.  I.e. My voice can carry and I have difficulty whispering.  I understand people can be loud.  So I can't completely blame the jack-asses we were sitting next to, but I can be pissed that there was just over a foot of room between us and them.  

We got reseated at the bar, and the experience picked up, a little.  The restaurant is barely wide enough to accommodate people sitting at the bar, plus there's not a lot of seating up there, so you feel a little awkward.  Also there isn't a bartender back there to chat with, this space is used more as an extension of the kitchen with staff rotating in and out.

If I hear that they've done something to mediate the noise, I would like to come back to this place, but not before then.
author: RiCH K.

description: Bottarga Spaghetti, the star of the menu me, could earn five stars by itself.  The octopus stew and sea breem are exceptional as well.  Casual and cozy atmosphere.
author: Duke K.

description:
An excellent neighborhood restaurant, and a fine "only in SF" establishment. They stick close to Sardinian cuisine and all dishes have Sardinian, not Italian names. The menu is small and well-crafted. The wine list is bigger than the food menu, and offers only (?)Italian wines at all price ranges. Our server was the lithe Petra, she's from Slovakia but lent the evening a gracious euro flair. 

Family owned and operated, we were very happy to find this place. Try the tripe. Go on, I dare ya. . .
author: jim b.

description:
Ran out of sardines...what?  remember to breathe.  anchovies were substituted...not bad, but would have loved the sardines.  The food is great.  Very Mediterranean - cannot complain.  The corkage rule is so very fair.  How can you NOT love a place that waves the corkage if you buy a bottle?  The gem: the spaghetti bottarga.  I could have ordered another.  Baby octopus - divine sauce.  Flatbread; pork loin; fresh fish...I can't go on...I'll need another "fix".
The desserts were the only "ehhh" about the meal, but we were all too full to notice.
author: Sonia C.

description: Amazing food, service, atmosphere. This ranks in the top 10 of SF restaurants and you should make sure you eat here very soon. One of the most ethereal pizzas (unsung hero) in town. One of the most interesting wine lists around.
author: Mariangela S.

description:
There are tons of hidden little gems tucked into the 7x7 square miles that makes up SF. Within those gems are some true diamonds amongst cubic zirconias.

That's how I feel about La Ciccia. 

A few weeks back, I took a friend there to celebrate his new found happiness. We needed an extra ordinary special place that can accommodate our fine palate, and with a little something extra added in.

When I walked in, I was instantly welcomed by the staff. It really made me feel like I had some family in Sardinia! The server gloriously told us the daily specials, and had my mouth watering before she even finished telling us the specials!

The decor was very quaint, but not stuffy looking. It was a very comfortable setting, and had a very nice European feel to it.

We had the sardine appetizer, and I must say, it was delicious! I'm somewhat of a sardine snob, and I was genuinely impressed. 

What really impressed me was the Botarga pasta; as a successful internet entrepreneur, I am used to eating lot's of pasta while wined and dined by my clients. Too often, have I eaten overcooked fluffy pasta that the American's think is "Just Right." The pasta at La Ciccia, to me was perfect. Not too heavy, and just enough portions.

Will I come back? No doubt. I just need to find someone special to take there. The application process is long, but well worth it.
author: Stanley C.

description: This was our first visit to La Ciccia. We arrived at our reserved time and we're quickly seated. The food is quite well prepared and very flavorful. My wife had a delicious calamari dish which I helped her eat. I had sardines to start then a lamb dish. The sardines were delicious and unique. The lamb was very tender and there was plenty of it. It was flavored quite prominently with oregano which was a bit strong for my palate but the overall taste and preparation of the dish was good. I had a glass of wine recommended by our server. It was very nice and again rather unique to my palate. All the wines are Italian and the list is extensive. Espresso was delicious as was the ricotta based desert. Overall a very nice dining experience.
author: Guy R.

description: So here is the deal. You have 4 seats at the bar that are NO RESERVATION. This is great- it gives the place a local feel. However if they are NO RESERVATION keep them that way. If someone calls from their car and says they are coming- guess what that is a reservation! You are loosing customers and money by no longer allowing true neighborhood fans to walk in and take the seats on a first come first serve basis.
author: Rebekah P.

description: We sat right next to kitchen entrance and there was a cool draft that was rather annoying.  We had their octopus stew, spaghetti with bottarga, prawns, cheese dessert plate, and a bottle of Vermentino.  The octopus was pretty good, but not outstanding in my opinion.  The spaghetti was quite good, but should have been served hotter, the prawns were wonderful, the cheese plate was so so.  The place is reasonably priced and a fun experience.  Not sure why it was so hard to get in though as I think the SF Bay Area have many restaurants of similar quality.
author: art m.

description: I wasn't sure how to review this place. A few of the dishes (gnocchi) and the wine was superb, the other dishes (notably the squid ink pasta) were almost inedible. If it was a little more consistent I would consider this the best Italian place in the city, so its a shame. I do love that the owners are usually there, and its a very warm feeling neighborhood spot.
author: Rebecca C.

description: It's not often you can say this about anything, but this place lives up to the hype.  Fabulous, original food at reasonable prices.  The only downside is the tiny size of the space.
author: Xu D.

description: This is my new favorite Italian(ish) restaurant. People actually speak Italian and foods are better than I've had in Italy. I had the octopus stew which was so amazing, I was cleaning the bowl with the bread. Pastas were also very well done with flavorful sauces. Will definitely be making this one of my regular spots.
author: Malej H.

description: Wow I really wanted to love it here since I live two blocks away and saw it on Check Please Bay Area.  Didn't love the food at all- very fishy and I love fish so that is funny for me to say.  Hated the octopus and I wish I would have loved it like everyone else on yelp.  Must be an acquired taste.  Also found the service to be mediocre at best.......(One great example- one waiter spilled wine all over me and my dining companion while clearing plates- and we didn't even get a sorry......just a wipe down with a dirty rag, and took two times waving down our waiter to get a refill).  Also, my friend who was a vegetarian didn't want any of the octopus appetizer but the waiter came over and started serving her a portion- when she said, 'no thank you, I don't want any',  he said 'oh sure you do, of course you do, and heaped it on her plate anyway....' Very pushy.  Won't be back soon.
author: Anne E.

description: We loved our dinner at La Ciccia last night. Didn't have reservation and called to find a lovely "buona sera" and the generosity to hold a table for us as we were driving to Noe.  It's Sardinian which was fun in itself, the menu in their dialect and different accent on flavor.  The bread, you can taste the handbaking. Freshest olive oil, ravioli special with veal/prosciutto ragu was perfect.  Try the anchovy dressing light on the greens salad, more crisp tasting.  My girlfriend loved the prawns and very knowledgable pairing of Sardinian wine.  We were really satisfied, and then were talked into dessert and really enjoyed the goat cheese and fig gelato, the daughter (?) is too charming.  By the way, next to us the urchin soup was making folks crazy...in a good way.  I'd send anyone here.
author: mike m.

description: Mmm.  It was good.  We went late and were lucky to get a spot at the bar.  I love places that are passionate about their food, and La Ciccia was definitely that kind of place.  I'd been wanting to go here for a long time and finally made the effort to get out to Noe to try it.  It was worth it.  Ambience was good - small and intimate.  Food was overall excellent.  The bread was disappointing (although tasty drenched in the extra sauces), and the fish we ordered as the main was a bit bland, but the octopus stew, calamari, and the pasta with urchin were all great.  I wouldn't have ordered the pasta with sea urchin and tuna heart on my own, but I ended up really liking it. It had a lot of depth of flavor, and I'm still thinking about it today.  Good wine list with some reasonably priced Sardinian wines as well.  I'll be back.
author: L C.

description:
The consensus of the 25+ prior reviews is this is a 4-star eatery, and in this case I'm inclined to grade on the curve.  We wandered in to La Ciccia last night, quite by chance, as another restaurant we were intending to try appeared to be defunct.  Crowded yes, but there was an empty table back by the kitchen, and except for the constant annoying clinking of the chain screen separating the kitchen from the dining room, this was just fine.  

To digress on the chain curtain for a moment, who in their right mind would use chain to separate a kitchen and a dining room?   The constant clinking was not just for our benefit, as you could surely hear it halfway to the front door.  I didn't check the restroom, but wouldn't be surprised to find wind chimes there.

Self-righteous indignation aside, the food here is great, and especially good for seafood fans.  Orata was offered in both a fillet and whole fish, and having opted to look my fish straight in the eye before consuming it,  I was treated to a succulent and flavorful fish that was mine to de-bone.  At $25, this was a bit pricey compared to my wife's $13 seafood pasta dish (also delicious), but darn good nonetheless.

La Ciccia has an extensive wine list, and if you aren't deep into Italian wines, much less Sardinian wines, the staff provides wonderful guidance.  Even better, the by-the-glass list is also substantial, with at least 15 different selections that should satisfy most tastes and food combinations. 

The Sardinian cheese plate for dessert was delightful, with a dollop of saffron honey on the side to add an aromatic sweetness to the savory fare.  Other people were raving about a ricotta and saffron dish, which I think Mr. Cranky described in his review below (Mr. C deserves honorable mention for most comprehensive review of La C to date).

Service was excellent, and the proprietor was warm and engaging.  This is the kind of place that draws you back.  I'd suggest making a reservation, with a specific request not to be seated next to the chainmail kitchen door.
author: Hugh B.

description:
I think I had one of the most delicious meals. I'm not a fan of Italian food, but man, this charming little  restaurant, could have possibly converted me. 

We dine with two other friends and we decided to order various amount of dishes so that we can all share. Call it family style dining. 

We ordered the flatbread with olive oil, seafood salad, clams, botterga pasta, seared ahi tuna, and had the raspberry and vanilla mousse cake and a vanilla ice cream with  fresh strawberries dessert. 

I absolutely loved every single dish. I was amazed.I was ooohed and aahhhed. I didn't want to leave this place. In fact, I want to return as soon as I can so that I can basque in the delicious dishes once more! It was that good of a meal.
author: stacy k.

description: We had a hard time finding this place so make sure you know the address because it looks like it's in a townhouse.  We had a wonderful meal and I had the special which was the Goat Rigatoni.  It was not gamey at all and sort of like pork.  The pasta was perfect al dente.  My husband had the veal scallopini and the portion was surprisingly huge.  He loved it as did I.  We would go back.
author: Carol M.

description:
I hate reading poor reviews for places everyone else loves, I always think the person must be grouchy or have some kind of a hang-up, but here goes anyway... I think this place is over-priced, it's not bad but they need a reality check. It's really kind of unremarkable.

The lamb and the ahi tuna mains were fresh and the best things we had. The lamb was very rare but if you're ok with that quite delicious. They both could have been served hotter.

The starters were meh: The grilled sardines were fresh but on the large side and could have been grilled another 5 minutes to make them crispy. The clams were served in a soupy, oily broth and while fresh were also unremarkable.

The waiters were cold and snooty. It was like being in France, they're ok if you don't mind being patronized, but don't let them think you think you know anything about food.

There's not a lot of ambience. I think the place gets good reviews because Noe Valley people like the idea of dining somewhere posh and authentic. I've been to Italy a dozen times (though not Sardinia, admittedly) and this didn't do it for me. To it's credit, everyone else seemed to be having a swell time.

$160 with tip for two mains, two appetizers and four glasses of wine. Not outrageous but I won't go back. Had a better meal at Lupa round the corner.
author: mefloquine x.

description: La Ciccia is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. We go here for special occasions and always have the best Sardinia seafood dishes. I would highly recommend for out of town guests you'd like to impress with a classy, romantic night with superb food and great wine.
author: Melody H.

description:
I chanced upon the place on their opening night.  Though, as Beth mentioned, the staff seemed pretty overwhelmed on account of the place's infancy, I definitely concur that the owner and all the staff try their darndest to make sure you're enjoying your food and the experience of dining there.  

I ordered the sea bass, my boyfriend the tuna.  Both were good.  We were actually already pretty full from our wonderful appetizers.  We had the salami plate that came with three types of bruschetta and a rice pilaf type of dish with porcini mushrooms and prosciutto.  Both were really, really good.  In fact, next time I go I'm planning on ordering different appetizers, tapas style.

The wine we had was also really good.  And in fact, two glasses were on the house for our patience on opening night.  

At the end of our meal, the chef came over to our table to thank us for coming and to see how we liked our meal.  That was a nice touch.  It underscored our sense that this place really cares about their clientele.
author: Helen C.

description: Everything here is delicious! It's the next best thing to eating in Italy. Can't wait to go back. The squid ink pasta was so much better than I had anticipated.
author: Jim T.

description: Now that Incanto is closed, La Ciccia is the last  Italian fine dining spot left in Noe Valley. I love their tuna hear pasta. The gnochetti with pork is also very good. I am a big seafood lover, so a lot of their dishes appeal to me. Plus, they have a good wine list. Be prepared to drop some cash, fine dining is not supposed to be cheap.
author: Gwen V.

description:
Once again, La Ciccia hits the mark.  My wife and I have been coming here since they opened 5 years ago, though this is the first review I've done of the place.  We brought a couple with us, and now they are as big of fans as we are.

The cuisine is original, incredibly fresh, and expertly prepared.  The servers are extremely knowledgeable about their vast collection of delicious Italian wines.  The pizzas, gnochetti, and now, the pork loin and seared lamb, are our favorite dishes.  But nearly everything on the menu we've ever tried is outstanding.  We've had amazing prosciutto platters (which are huge!), steamed whole fish, and creative stews in the past.  We also marvel at the intimate setting and family-like atmosphere created by the staff and owners.  They are a delight in what is a true gem in Noe Valley.

The word is clearly out about this place, given the volume of glowing reviews from all major culinary publications. This place simply can't miss.
author: Chuck D.

description: This could well be my favorite restaurant in SF.  The food is tasty, well-prepared, and unusual in a good way, the wine selection is excellent, and the service great.
author: Michelle K.

description: Stunning ristorante di Sardegna, one of San Francisco's best Italian restaurants, a revelation from start to finish. Exuberant welcome featuring a unique menu of spectacularly authentic wine and cucina, supremely delicious and satisfying. Massimiliano Conti and Lorella Degan have established a charming neighborhood restaurant, a veritable sine qua non feast of delights, superb house-cured prosciutto bathed in delectable olive oil, irresistible pasta offerings including pasta with lamb stew or saffron couscous with carcioffe, enormous mussels in tomato bisque, incredibly delicious and stunningly spectacular pork loin, understated desserts and incomparable wine list. Try the superb Carignano Shardona, a gift from Bacchus to Olympus. This tiny restaurant is one of the City's great restaurants, the owners and staff bring their love of Italian food and joie de vivre presenting a cornucopia of delights, superb ethnic Italian giving pleasure beyond description. Viva Sardinia, Viva la Ciccia!
author: Thomas C.

description:
It's rare to find perfection in terms of service, food, and ambience, but I think La Ciccia has it all. My boyfriend said he would give this place 5 and 1/2 stars if he could. 

The hostess (who I think is one of the owners) was so warm and welcoming and as soon as we walked in she was ready to seat us. 

To start we ordered glasses of Prosecco and pinot noire, and the octopus stew. The stew is unlike anything I have ever tasted before (I've never had sardinian food). The taste was just beyond what I can describe...so delicious! I am not a seafood lover usually, but this dish has the perfect mix of ripe, tart tomato, spices, and buttery octopus. I loved it. My boyfriend and I dipped our bread in the sauce and savored every single bite. 

For entrees: we ordered the gnochetti, and shrimp with squid ink. The gnochetti is actually semolina pasta cooked al dente and served with meat sauce. It was beyond savory...I've never tasted a pasta dish so delicious, and I don't usually like al dente pasta. The shrimp dish was the *only* mar on the evening...it wasn't exactly what we were hoping for for a main course. But it was still pretty good. We got our leftovers packed up to go.

For dessert we had the gelato...again, the flavor is just STAND OUT. It's the kind of restaurant where you just truly TASTE every single bite because it is so flavorful, so full of real ingredients...nothing processed, nothing reheated, nothing halfway done. There were 3 flavors of gelato - rum & raisin, hazelnut, and goat cheese & fig. All were divine. I got a cappuccino along with our dessert...perfect touch.

All in all, just the best dining out experience you can imagine. I can't wait to go back!
author: Latte Queen W.

description:
Sardinian cuisine excellently prepared and beautifully presented. Interesting Italian wine list. Excellent service. Next best thing to visiting a restaurant in Italy. We were invited to stay inside the restaurant until our J streetcar arrived because of rain. Reservations are a must. We saw a number of disappointed drop ins.
Top ratings to the roasted calamari, the octopus in spicy tomato stew, a sea bream special and the lamb tenderloin.
author: Richard T.

description:
This place is a neighborhood staple. I've probably been here around a dozen times, and the experience is always consistently wonderful.

If you aren't familiar with Sardinia, it's a island province of Italy. As a result, the food centers around seafood, with many of the fresh ingredients integrated directly into the sauce of their pasta dishes, not to mention served on their own, for example, in their extremely tasty warm seafood salad starter.

I generally ignore the entire menu and just listen to the specials for the day and choose from that. I'm especially a big fan of their pastas, and some notable dishes from the past: spaghetti with tuna heart or bottarga, or most recently, one that integrated tuna, tuna heart, and sea urchin in the sauce--really amazing.

The service is what you would expect from a neighborhood favorite. Lorella greats everyone with a warm smile and knows many customers by name (just go there twice and you too can become a regular). Her husband, Massimiliano, is the chef, and while more reticent than his better half, will often make the rounds among customers during some part of the evening.

If you're a drinker, their winelist has some varietals that I've never seen anywhere else.
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
#1, This is NOT an EYE-TAL-EE-UN restaurant, it features the food of Sardinia, and is does that well. The menu is in Sardinian and English and the dishes are what you'd expect of a Mediterranean cuisine: lots of fish and seafood. We started with the Sardines and they were a perfect 10. Just a hint of vinegar, like spanish anchovies (boquerones) or Japanese saba, full of flavor. Another appetizer was the octopus in tomato sauce, and it was quite good, though not as perfect as the sardines. For the pasta course the Fregua (large semolina like pasta) with squid in black ink sauce was another 10, a perfect blend of flavors - words cannot describe. A seafood fettucini with sole was a delight and had just the right balance of seafood flavors.

Other highlights were the Lamb with red cabbage and the braised pork.

The selection of Sardinian and Italian wines is extensive and fairly (for a restaurant) priced.

The wait staff was friendly and very accommodating and the chef came by to welcome us and thank us for coming.  Our waitress was a charming young woman from Slovakia who had the perfect balance of friendliness without actually intruding into our party.

And finally, the price: 5 people, three courses each, 1 bottle of wine and (we were stuffed), 1 shared dessert (excellent hazelnut gelato) only came to $245 - under $50 each!!  A real bargain - and they even comped the corkage on the wine we brought with us.
author: R D P.

description: I almost don't want to write this review, as I don't want the place to end up inaccessible, with a line around the block - but they deserve it. It's outstanding food, cooked well, and served thoughtfully. The staff is unobtrusive. Overall, I came away with a need for Sardinian food I have never had before - and one I am finding difficult to fulfill now that I have moved out of the area.
author: Sergei S.

description:
When I think of great Italian food in the City -- this is the place that comes to mind...and as you can see, it's not really Italian, but Sardignian.

Unusual seafood, excellent wine selection (the owner used to be a sommelier), delicious elegant entrees and piatti primi (first plates). I loved it. 

The pizza seems somehow misplaced, but then they inherited a pizza oven and are apparently putting it to good use (the last place was a pizzeria)

fresh, fresh, fresh and original

Okay. Update: my review is based on my one visit and my sister and her husband's many visits (they live nearby and he's a chef). They love it. I loved it. BUT my friend's friends (a couple) went there for a b-day celebration more recenly and said everything sucked--the service and just mediocre food. Don't know what to think of this. I guess I shall go back and investigate (still sounds like a yummy idea to me)
author: Liza B.

description:
I finally got back to La Ciccia with a friend a few weeks ago, and we had a great time. The food and the service was great; the sardines as an appetizer was fantastic and our entrees were very yummy. Only ding on them was that they neglected to inform us that they were out of the pizza until they were supposed to serve it (as opposed to when we ordered it or when the sardines came out), but since we got there a bit later, I guess it wasn't a huge shock. 
The experience was very good otherwise, and  I would recommend the place for a great dinner
author: Hans H.

description:
Good; wish I could give them three and a half stars, as this just isn't a four-star place. But I may need to give them another chance; I've only been once.

The decor was plain, the volume was high, but there was clearly heart and soul in the place. It felt like a labor of love. Hope they'll consider finding a way to turn down the sound.

Food was tasty if not spectacular. We started with a dish consisting of tender calamari floating in some kind of light, oily sauce and herbs. Also had the fregula with red sauce, clams, and saffron, which I found a little fishy.

We probably won't go out of our way to go back here since there are so many other places to try, and it didn't wow us, but it's a good option.

Update, 8/24/2007: Our second visit. Still too loud! But the lighting was better than I remembered. Service was great, very personal, and our waiter let us taste three different wines before making our by-the-glass decisions.

Proscuitto: A+! You get tons of it, too. Spaghetti with cauliflower and bottarga: B-. I appreciated that the pasta was homemade, but it was also too gluey. And there's waaay too much olive oil in this dish. Gnoccheti with pork sugo: A+. Outstanding. Delicious little nubbins of pasta, tastily spicy meat. Side of vegetables (sliced, sauteed squash and carrot): B+. Fine, though nothing special.

Something of a mixed bag, but an upgrade to four stars.
author: Tara M.

description: Great Sardinian restaurant. Not a regular Italian restaurants that serves Alfredo and Marinara. Go for Sardine (of course) and  Bottarga.
author: Josh S.

description:
This is a Sardinian style Italian cuisine that is wholesome and hasgenerous portions. The y use very little salt or garlic.
The wine list is very good. About three quarters are red wines, with about 30% of these being Sardinian. Recommendation: order a bottle of wine from the wine list; don't do wines by the glass. Could not find a white that I know, so we went with our fail-safe Barbera.
Illica, a food server, read off the specials with everything having prosciutto and pecorino cheese; we were salivating.
The lentil soup is super; the sardine appetizer was delish. They had pasta specials, but we went with the whole branzino fish (which they expertly filleted).
The Sardinian cheese and honey dessert was very nice.
The hospitality and service are excellent and well-coordinated.
p.s. ciccia means belly fat
author: Rosquete B.

description:
I came here to catch up with an old coworker on a weekday night and got the earliest reservation possible at 5:30.  My dinner partner got there late but it didn't seem to matter as there were still plenty of tables when she finally got there at 5:45.  Little did I know 10 minutes after she walked through the door, every table would be full.  That's a good sign!

I had already done my homework and perused the yelp reviews before I got here so I knew exactly what I wanted to order.  I got the octopus stew that everyone raved about and yes, it was delicious but also very unexpected.  I had never had octopus drenched in tomato sauce before.  I think it makes this dish a lot more approachable if you're not into eating these little 8 legged creatures - the tomato sauce really tones down the oceany taste of the octopus.  For my main course I had the spaghetti with the spicy olive oil and bottarga.   I had to look up what bottarga was and according to Wikipedia, it is a "delicacy of cured fish roe."  It sounded unappealing - I don't usually like roe (I hate how they squish in your mouth, it weirds me out), but I thought everyone else on yelp seemed to like it so why not!  Turns out after I took a bite of this al dente (like the real kind you get in Italy) spaghetti and bit into the roe shavings dusted heavily onto the spaghetti, I instantly recognized the flavor.  So much for novelty!  Either way, the bottarga spaghetti is a very simple but great tasting dish - the mild spiciness of the olive oil is a nice compliment to the heaviness of the bottarga (which by the way isn't fishy or roe-y at all).  The portion sizing was just right for the appetizer and the spaghetti.  It was not too much but not too little - I managed to finish both dishes without feeling like I had to be rolled out of the restaurant.  

As for the little details - the restaurant is very narrow and the tables spaced fairly close to each other.  It's not very loud at all however which I appreciate - I don't like feeling like I'm at dinner with everyone in the room.  Parking might be a bit of an issue in evenings when you're competing for spaces with the local residents coming home from work but I managed to find a space just fine.  The food comes out pretty quickly and the service is pretty friendly.  One of the restaurant owners even came by at the end of our meal to ask us how it was.  Overall, I think SPQR still might be my favorite Italian restaurant in the city but I think if you're looking for decent traditional Italian food served Sardinian (note Sardinian = lots of seafood) style, this is the place to be.  I also think this is a good place to go if you don't really like seafood but like Italian food and want to be tricked into liking seafood.
author: Jean A.

description:
We were looking for something warm and comfy on a frigid night, and found it here. Choice ingredients, lovely service... The dishes have some serious personality. Our trys: green salad with sweet balsamic onions, pumpkin puree soup, crostini each topped with more balsamic onions, tomatoes and mushrooms, tagliolini with crab meat, and the potato pesto pizza dripping in pancetta, olive oil and mozzarella. Mmmmm... All divine--we couldn't help but wonder where their tomatoes came from. "Heaven?" I asked my guy. 

It's our new fave in the nabe (and quite possibly in the city) for homespun Italian.

Update: Go EASY on the balsamic onions. Sweet, but um, deadly... Yeah.
author: Genevieve R.

description:
excellent food. excellent (probably sardinian, if not italian) server. like 100 feet from the j-train stop.

had sardinian flat bread, sauteed sardines, octopus stew, seared lamb tenderloin, and best of all - and you must get this - spaghetti with bottarga.

for dessert, had a riccota and saffron cake, and gelato in 4 flavors - bottarga, goat cheese and figs, sapa, and saffron.

don't miss out.
author: Tom L.

description: Authentic Sicilian Cuisine prepared with love. Excellent service. The dining room is a bit too cozy, but on a cool night (like most in upper Noe) it's just right
author: Richard L M.

description:
I used to spend all my summers in Sardegna.. 3 months of fun, the best sea you will ever see , great people and awesome food... later i got a job, moved to the US and the dream ended..

This is the first Italian restaurant in San Francisco that really impressed me: the people were extremely nice,actually FROM Italy, which helps in an Italian restaurant;the restaurant is clean, simple and beautiful and the food was just amazing.

We had:

-Prupisceddu in Umidu: which are octopus in a yummy spice sauce
-Malloreddus a sa Campidanese: we call them "gnocchetti", little gnocchi, but it's actually a specific cut of pasta typical from Sardegna.
-Spezattinu de Proccu a Sa Vernaccia: a pork spezzatino

We ordered the Pani Guttiau, which is a Sardinian bread that it's just amazing.
The semifreddo was our desert:to D I E for.

Everything was delicious, tasted authentic, tasted just awesome.

The wine list is the dream of every wine-geek out there.

Also... i saw in a couple of reviews people complaining about not having the olive oil and balsamic vinegar with your bread.. just to let you know , that just means that La Ciccia is a real Italian Restaurant and not an American version of an Italian Restaurant.
Last thing: Sicilia and Sardegna ARE PART OF ITALY.People from SICILIA and people from SARDEGNA are ITALIAN. Sicilia and Sardegna ARE TWO DIFFERENT ISLANDS.

ah... you totally need a reservation, we didn't have one, but i think we were able to sit without reservation only because i'm Italian.

Quie timet s'abba non andet a mare!!!
author: Fra L.

description:
After reading a review in the Chronicle, my friend and I decided it was worth a trip to Ciccia for dinner....especially since it was a 15 minute walk from my Mission sublet. 

Ciccia was definitely worth the walk. Amazingly enough, we were seated immediately (okay, it was a Wednesday night) and were greeted with a huge wine list. We decided to split one of the bottles that was featured. It was amazing...warm and spicy with very little tannins. What kills me is that I can't remember the name:(

The food was great as well. I had the salmon and my friend had the sea bass. We decided to forgo an appetizer in favor of the bread, which was tasty. We split the strawberries over ice cream dessert, which is incredible for the strawberry fans out there. 

Overall, not a bad place. A little on the pricier side, but definitely worth it.
author: Jenn G.

description:
Went here purely because it was mentioned in an article about bottarga.  I'm always on the lookout for a great Italian restaurant, and this is definitely one of them, but I was pleasantly surprised at how different Sardinian cuisine is from your classic Italian.

Appetizer: Sauteed sardines.  A little undersalted, but definitely fresh and the leftover oil went well with the bread.

Pasta: I got the spaghetti w/ spicy oil and bottarga, she got the one w/ cured tuna heart.  Both were absolutely delicious.  Super fishy and salty, so not for the faint of heart, but I would eat these again and again and again.  Pasta was perfectly cooked.  The tuna heart had the sharper, more distinctive taste.  The portions are relatively small, but to be honest, we we were happy and sated after these and the app.  I am so tempted to just order these two pasta dishes next time I come.

Main: Seared lamb tenderloin w/ grape must
Lamb was served nicely rare/med. rare, and was definitely the most tender lamb I've ever had.  Grape must was the thick, sweet + sour sauce that went over it.

Dessert:  The head chef, Massimilian (what a name! and the friendliest smile), came out to see how we were doing.  I told him how much we loved the pasta, and he recommended we try the bottarga gelato.  Double-take.  How could we not?  In the end, it didn't taste much like bottarga, more like a salted caramel.  Grape must over the top again.  Still yummy.

Wine list looked extensive.  Maybe next time.
author: Alex K.

description: The best Italian food in the city. Hands down.
author: Juan T.

description:
I went into this restaurant "cold" - not knowing anything about it.  Wow. I felt like I was whisked to Europe as soon as we sat down and the feeling persisted with our servers and ambiance.  The food is incredibly delicious - the seafood salad was a standout.  Note that it's slightly saltier than regular Italian food as it's Sardinian.

I hope to be back again, and again, and again to try more dishes.
author: Celeste S.

description:
An excellent restaurant:
Pros: the food i homemade a fresh. All pasta is al dente (firm to the teeth)all the sea food is great tasting-even though they may seem intimidating. Plus, the sauces they use-alone- could make a shoe taste good! If you like Italian food with a little kick and seafood taste you'll love this place. In addition the service is polite and genuine.

cons: it's kind of far from a lot of things. I you'd like to go there there's not much else to do in the IMMEDIATE area. Although lighting is nice there are blinds on the windows and the seating is a little tight (so don't bring a HUGE party here). 

Overall this restaurant is GREAT I'd highly recommend it to anyone who wants to try something new from Italian cuisine. To be honest if I could I'd give it 4.5 stars
author: Josh L.

description: deliciouso, wonderful meal tonight, wine, service all excellent...we'll be back if we can get a reservation, might have pizza bianca at the bar.
author: Kate S.

description:
Authentic  Sardinian food. I recommend any of their specials. Last week  they had homemade tagliatele pasta with shaved tuna heart. It was fantastic and you won't get much more authentico than that.

They also have an extensive wine list. Many good bottles of white around $22 - $25.

Make sure to get reservations if you go. It is a small place and popular at that.
author: Adam W.

description: Everything was stupendous.  We shared the burrata on flatbread, octopus stew, and pasta with bottarga then each had entrees.  The octopus stew and pasta with bottarga were standouts.  Just intensely flavorful, rich, and satisfying.  I love burrata, but the flatbread generally is not that exciting.  It's more like a cracker than bread.  All of the pasta is fantastic - it's fresh, chewy, and perfectly al dente.  I thought the entrees were excellent, but I think there are so many unusual dishes here that your stomach space might be best spent on something you've never tried before.  If you need recommendations, the wait staff is wonderful (usually the owner is on hand to welcome you and checks in throughout the meal) and very helpful with suggestions.
author: Pearl L.

description: If I could move here, sleep on the tables and eat Massimo's food each nite for dinner I would. They've inspired travel to sardina, introduced me to new wines, taken great care of me when I've needed it, and taught me how to be a better cook. And when you're there give Laurella a huge hug from me. Tis an honor to know them! Enjoy this spot! I always do. Tip: Have Phil sing you a little song! ;)
author: David M.

description: Eat here! And order the spicy octopus stew, the branzino and the gelati. Everything was wonderful-the bread is incredible, as are the olive oils that accompany it. The restaurant is small but I did not feel too loud-my friend and I had a table tucked away in the corner by the entrance and we enjoyed a lovely evening.  Don't miss it if you are in Noe Valley. Well worth the money.
author: Lydia B.

description: My girlfriend and I went for Valentine's Day and had a wonderful meal.    We let our waitress select our menu and her recommendations were awesome across the board, including the calamari, octopus stew  in a tomato broth, bottarga spaghetti, and lamb.  It's hard to pick a favorite dish because everything was excellent, including the service.  I highly recommend La Ciccia for a delicious authentic Sardinian meal.  The prices are reasonable for the quality of food (3 course dinner plus wine for two was ~$150).
author: Shaun D.

description: My mouth is drooling as I write this review just thinking about the food at La Cicca.  We went with a group of 4 people and every dish that was ordered was a hit!  My favorites were the octopus stew and the squid ink pasta.  The service was great and attentive.  I can not wait to go back!
author: Tammy S.

description: La Ciccia is a great, cozy Italian place run by a sweet husband and wife team.  It's exactly the kind of thing you come across unexpectedly and fall madly and truly in love with.  The pasta is amazing - I'm assuming home-made -- and cooked to al dente perfection.  We had a great bottle of Sardinian wine (suggested by the knowledgable waitress) and some roasted sardines to start.  The ambiance is casual and, like I said, cozy.  It reminded me of places in Italy.  A+ super yummy.
author: Lizzy W.

description:
I thought there weren't any good old fashioned down home Italian joints left in SF. This is a little bit fancier than the classic type -which makes it suitable for dates and such as well as just good grubbing- but the prices are about as reasonable as it gets PLUS there's the added flair of it being Sardinian, a region of Italy that doesn't get as much exposure cuisine-wise, prolly since it's an island.

Everyone who says the octopus stew is a must have is right!
author: Pete W.

description:
La Ciccia is one of those places that makes me glad to live in San Francisco. 

We are regulars here and have been so since the first week they opened. We come for the warm welcome we get when we arrive, the excellent service, and the visit and chat with Massimiliano, the chef.

Oh, and because coming to La Ciccia saves us plane fare for having to travel to Italy to eat. Because La Ciccia is nearly as good as anything I have had over there.

This food is authentic, hearty, simple, and soulful. I was originally seduced by Spaghetti with caulifower and bottarga (roe), which used to be a regular dish on the menu. I mean, cauliflower, how basic can you get? But this dish was perfectly prepared, and the spaghetti was unusually good. When I asked about the spaghetti, I was told they get it from someone who makes it fresh for them in South City. I don't know if too many restaurants that go to the trouble of getting pastas like spaghetti fresh - most renditions are dried and right out of the box. But La Ciccia sweats the details, and the results are always good and sometimes glorious.

For example, the raviolis I had last week. They were a special, and possibly the best first course I have ever eaten, either in Italy or here in the US. Pasta gloriously silky smooth, sauce beautifully spiced, dish as a whole just perfection. I asked Massimiliano why it wasn't on the menu all the time and he said, "well, it's a lot of work." I had to laugh at that, but the results showed. The ravioli were preceded by a lovely lentil soup, not as spectacular, but hearty, and a huge portion, too. What a beuatiful meal, as good as any I've ever had over in Italy.

There have been many highs for us over the last couple of years at La Ciccia. The wild boar. The octopus appetizer so lavishly praied in other reviews. Pizza a sa Sarda. The gnochetti. The pork stew. Fish. Very few lows - about the only dish I have had here that I did not care for was the Margherita Pizza. 

We don't go out for Italian food very often because I do it pretty well myself at home. But it's a pleasure having this wonderful little place open in our area to give me an easy way out when I don't feel like doing it myself. There are some wonderful Italian restaurants in this City, but we keeping coming back to La Ciccia over, and over, and over again.
author: David G.

description: 4.5 stars overall. It actually feels like a popular, buzzy neighborhood restaurant in Milan here -- the tables all full and  packed in tight and the resto is vibrant with a variety of interesting people from all walks of life, from academics to hipsters and a few tourists, Italian and otherwise. The staff is extremely nice and helpful but the resto is so busy that we had to wait 25 minutes for a table to free up despite reservations and while they never forgot about us and met all of our needs, it could sometimes take awhile to get your wine, etc. The food gets 5 stars, with the appetizers and desserts particularly being star -- delicious and inventive. I *loved* my rich seafood soup with seawood, mussels and clams and the oven-baked calamari was tender and tasty. The pasta noodles and sauce were not the best I've had in San Francisco/the U.S., but were very good. Meats and seafood cooked just right.  Not the place for a quiet romantic dinner, but great for foodies and a fun meal out. We will definitely be back.
author: Kate A.

description:
I really wish I could have loved this place.  La Ciccia is this adorably cosy Sardinian restaurant tucked alongside a slew of new restaurants burgeoning at the end of Church, but something was off that night.  I'm not sure whether it was the cramped little table that our waitress bumped into every time another waiter passed by to go to the kitchen (which was quite frequently) or the lack luster pasta/main dishes or both, but it just didn't do it for me.  

I wasn't too impressed with my hanger steak, which was doused in a dark brown porcini sauce or the side of the gluttous mochi-like mashed potatoes (taste was fine, the texture...eh...not pretty).  The dessert of gelato covered in sweetened strawberries was just mediocre.

However, the super tender calamari in a soupy mint & garlic sauce and their chianti from their eclectic wine menu were both delicious.   My bf loved his mint-encrusted lambchops, which I had to say was pretty dman good and this means quite a bit coming from a girl who doesn't like lamb.  Perhaps I ordered the wrong items on the menu.  

Overall, I thought La Ciccia was a decent restaurant but nothing spectacular.  Ambiance was so-so (think bright and cheery).  Service was fairly good; the maitre'd and head chef graciously checked in with us at the end of the meal (very classy).  I probably won't come back here for a full meal, but I might stop in for some wine and appetizers.
author: Melissa S.

description:
Went for the family style pig dinner and enjoyed it immensely.  The food was plentiful and delicious, the wines were all complementary and addicting, and the service and atmosphere were cozy and enjoyable.   Special kudos to La Ciccia on the organic vegetable starters and one of the mains, roasted Wilbur; the skin was crunchy and the meat was tasty and tender.  We even met a lovely couple, Nick and Sarah--regulars who joined our table.

Can't wait for the next family din din, but I also love going for the regular menu too.
author: Kimberly Q.

description:
If I lived in the neighborhood I wouldn't yelp this place at all. I would say stay away, don't tell anyone! cause I would be eating here atleast once a week and i don't want any more competition for a table.

everything we had was delicious, i rarley every get to say that. Massimo and Lorella, the owners were really sweet and inviting, their wine recommendations were spot on and the whole evening was lovely.  we didn't try the pizza, but the pastas were spectacular, don't miss the spaghetti with cauliflower and bottarga.
author: Kai H.

description: The cuisine at La Ciccia is not to be missed. Every dish is amazing, although my favorites are the burrata and the spaghetti con bottarga. Service is simple, yet friendly, warm and professional. The owners are very welcoming and sweet. An added bonus is the fact that dinner for two here doesn't break the bank. I've dined here twice now and am eagerly looking forward to a third. La Ciccia is a unique gem well worth the trip.
author: Kadie C.

description:
This was arguably the best Italian food I've had in San Francisco. Having lived in Italy for several years, I tend to be a bit snobbish (but justifiably!) about going out for Italian. This Sardinian restaurant is worth every penny, every moment, it's just worth it. The food was spot on for authenticity, and everything was cooked to perfection. 

We started with the octopus stew and the seafood salad - two entirely different takes on seafood. The stew was clearly cooked for forever and taste just oozed out of it, and the salad was this fresh mix of wonderful. The pasta - gnocchetti sardi, or maloreddus in Sardinian - was phenomenal, and by the time we got to the secondi - two servings of lamb and pork chops for me - we were stuffed. Definitely get some of the delicious pane guttiau and just enjoy yourselves with the wine list. It is extensive and fun!
author: Nicole R.

description:
I admit, I've never had Sardinian food til La Ciccia. But great food is great food, and the care and thought put into each dish is extraordinary. It's got this home cooked feel, but that doesn't mean you can replicate it in your own kitchen. Their pastas (esp fresh pasta) are great, as are their pizzas.

Go.
author: Lauren C.

description: Been back a few more times. But, it's so hit and miss. And when it's a miss, it's a big miss.  I still like the margarita pizza and the salad, but I've just had too many bad other dishes to go back.  Plus, I have to update my prior review of service.  The last time we were there, we complained about a dish that had been recommended and mis-described by the waiter. The owner came over, not to apologize, but to defend the dish and it was soooooo uncomfortable.  I just do not understand the high praise for this restaurant.
author: N O.

description: Best in the area for Italian food n cozy dining
author: cecille p.

description: I can't say I really enjoyed my meal here.  The food was definitely different than most Italian restaurants, but I'm not sure that the differences did much for me.  I suspect Sardinian food just isn't my thing.  Nevertheless, I could tell the food was good for it's genre and the service was good, so giving them 4 stars.
author: Colossus W.

description:
La Ciccia is the best restaurant bar none in Noe Valley.

Within a couple of weeks of the restaurant opening we dropped in on a whim not knowing what to expect given that most restaurants in our neighborhood are mediocre.

We were pleasantly surprised by what we found. Straight ahead, unpretentious, and delicious Italian food. I've been lucky enough to travel to Sardinia, and given it's geographic isolation from the rest of Italy (it's the ball that the boot has kicked into the middle of the Mediterranean) it has generated a unique cuisine that is different than any other region.

The octopus stew is a must to start with, simply prepared but cooked to perfection. They typically have a lot of specials and to my delight they often have wild boar (stew or over pasta) which has always been excellent. It is hard to find a restaurant that prepares whole fish, but you will often see a fish with head and tail on zooming by the table. My Sardinian friend tucked into one of these on his own and highly approved of both the fish and the restaurant as a whole.

They do a decent thin crust pizza too. If you are sick of the lack lustre pizza choices in Noe Valley, you can't go wrong calling in a take-out order of their pizza. 

The husband and wife team run the restaurant to perfection - she runs the front and he runs the kitchen. No matter how busy the restaurant gets, you can always enjoy a nice conversation about the wine or food with them. On a couple of occasions after enjoying the Sardinian wine, they have pointed out where it can be found in the city for purchase.

Authentic food that has never disappointed, check it out.
author: Brad Y.

description: Great place for some real authentic pasta. Love the simplicity of the decor and the complexity of the dishes.Looking forward to my return.
author: Michael B.

description: The ambiance is casual and satisfying as long as you don't get a table far in the back.  The wine list is largely regional and the sommelier knows what he's doing.  But most of all, the food is outstanding.  This is not frou frou dining; all the dishes we had were homey and satisfying and packed with flavor.
author: James L.

description:
Yelp's rating system defines "5 stars" as "As good as it gets!"  That says it all about La Ciccia -- the food, the waitstaff, and most of all, Lorella & Massimo (the owners).  You can come here on a quiet weeknight or on a busy Saturday evening, and the quality of the service, the food, and the hospitality never changes: you're always made to feel like you're a special guest in their home and their kitchen is turning out dishes just for you.  

What more can you ask for in a restaurant?
author: Carlo A.

description: La Ciccia is an excellent restaurant.  The food is as good as it can be and the service is excellent.  My wife took me there for my birthday.  It is a bit pricey, but is well worth it.  The only problem is that it is hard to get a reservation.
author: Mike M.

description:
pasta with bottarga--too much oil and very salty. fresh pasta but unfortunately overcooked
rigatoni with bolognese (specialty of the day)-the sauce was good but i've had better
octopus stew-octopus was very tender and it was a good balance of spices. hands down the star dish of the night
prosciutto-one of the best i've had outside of italy

overall, i would come here for starters but there are definitely other places in sf that serve better pasta-- cotogna to name one.
author: P F.

description:
We had a mediocre experience here, but take this review with a grain of salt (we only went once).

First, don't get seated in the back of the restaurant near the kitchen. The bright flourescent light from the kitchen reflects off the light blue semigloss paint in a really unatmospheric way. This may seem nitpicky, but it felt like we were eating in a hospital waiting room.

The food was all pretty decent, but nothing was awesome. We had a seafood salad which had squid, octopus, and some shellfish in a nice oily sauce. The tuna in tomato sauce was pretty tasty, but you'll want to order it in a set with pasta--it was literally just just a small bowl of some chunks of tuna in a little tomato sauce. The pizza was pretty good, the thin crust was nicely blistered in a hot oven.

Service was okay, but they were very crowded even on a weekday night. You'll want to make reservations. Overall, our experience was okay, but it definitely wasn't mind-blowing, nor was it a particularly good value. We'll probably try it again sometime to see if we maybe just had a bad night.

Summary: make reservations for the much nicer looking middle part of the restaurant, order salads and pizza, and be prepared to ask about the wine list, which has very few mainstream names!
author: Andrew H.

description:
Fresh sardine appetizer. Yum. Bottarga pasta with cauliflower in just the right portion - delicious. Whole seabass, impeccably fresh.

In more detail, this is typical coastal Italian. Lots of olive oil on everything, and it's not a bug but a feature. The bottarga in Sardinia is mullet, not the stronger Tuna kind sometimes found in Sicily. In all, this is how you actually eat in Italy - simple and fresh.
author: A. P.

description: Cozy, if not a little loud, atmosphere.  Specials are creative (give it up for fish roe gelato!) and entrees are simple and satisfying. I'll be coming back.  I suggest reservations, though.  The place was busy even at 9:00 PM.
author: M W.

description: I was so disappointed, and worse was so embarrassed that I made the suggestion based on yelp's recommendation.  The salad was good, but each of our four main courses was sub par.  It was flavorless and mediocre and way too expensive for what it was.  What's worse they insisted they were booked when I called for a reservation, and while we were there (for our entire meal) there sat several empty tables.  The service was minimal.  The owner was nice enough to ask us how things were, but when we told her we didn't have a great meal, she started arguing with us.  It was over all one of the worst meals I have had in recent memory.  The food was unmemorable and over priced, but the service is what was really awful.  But I blame yelp and those who suggested it.  Are these comments filled with family members, because I cannot figure out the disconnect.
author: Laura B.

description:
it could have been the fact that i went with a pair of regulars who have a reservation every Thursday night, but the service was so cozy and familial  that i felt right at home!
