Both of the owners Lorella and Massimiliano (who's also the chef!!) were frequently buzzing around the restaurant personally making sure that everyone was having a wonderful time.

Absolutely go with whatever wine they suggest to you, they knows their stuff.
author: Spatial K.

description: Wow!  What a place.  Went there this week to get the low-down on some hot spots in Piedmonte where my wife and I are headed shortly.  The food, the service, the ambience all were TOP NOTCH!  I can't wait to go again.  The specials were fantastic and the nightly changing Salum plate melted in our mouths!  Bravo!
author: Cr G.

description: Going back tonight for a third or fourth time. three words: spaghetti with bottarga. the one and only problem with this dish is that it forces me to reveal my true piggish nature - there is no way i can get by with just one serving of this for a main course, and it's all i ever want to get, so i am forced to get two. tonight i think my husband and i discussed splitting three (aka 1.5 each), which i hope will be enough. it's never really enough of that stuff, truth be told.
author: Erica W.

description:
We've eated here maybe 3 or 4 times, and the food is always beyond amazing!

If they've got wild boar, just get it, it's just about the best thing ever!

great service, wonderful wine selection, just love it.
author: Steve H.

description:
Only been here once, but it was thoroughly enjoyable. The owners are very friendly and take care of you. Kind of a loud restaurant, so if you have hearing aids, forget it.
  The food is a bit more "peasant" than a typical Italian restaurant, so be prepared for something different. However, sometimes basic is awfully good, and that is the case here. The chef and owner are very sincere about the Sardinian heritage of this food. He even told us that his mother calls (from the mother country) to check on him to make sure he isn't deviating from the old recipes!
  The bread, fish, everything....excellent. Would definitely go again if the occasion presents itself.
author: Mister K.

description:
I was extremely impressed by this place. Being an Italian, my hesitation toward 'Italian restaurant food' is quite strong, especially here in the States. 
Further, being Sardinian, finding a place that offers authentic Sardinian fare is rare-which only heightened my curiosity of this place.

La Ciccia has a very 'intimate' character (e.g., small). That's a good thing. It's a perfect place to bring the significant other (be it of the night, year, or other...) here.

I started with the salumi mix: exceptional.
Then the malloreddus: it is really hard to find a red sauce here that tastes like it was made in Italy!
Then "l'orata' (I don't know what this fish is called in English): fantastic!

All of this was finished off with gelato con fior di latte, olio di olive, e peppe nero! yeah, olive oil and black pepper gelato...odd, but oddly great!

The prices are a bit well, pricey (excuse the redundancy)...but I can assure you, it is all worth it!
I shall be returning quite frequently.
author: Dan L.

description: Found this place in my search for bottarga after watching Anthony Bourdain go to Sardinia and deciding that I must have some. So glad that I did, what an amazing place. Everything was delicious and the service was excellent. I want to go back as soon as possible.
author: Martha D.

description:
Outstanding food, excellent service, and a fantastic selection of Italian wines will keep us coming back for sure.  I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.  Some of my favorite wines are from Sardegna, and now I've found the food to match.

The sardine appetizer was nice, the pastas are fresh, and the fish (Oven Baked filet of Petrale Sole with Sardinian Olives Tapenade) and lamb (Seared Lamb Tenderloin served with Mushrooms) entrees were excellently seasoned.  The food is not over-salted, allowing the freshness of the herbs and ingredients to come through.  For wine, try the Cannonau!  And the Ricotta and Saffron Cake served with Honey and Almonds was quite nice.
author: RON J.

description:
Been to Italy at least once a year for the last 8 years and this is some of the most  authentic food I've had outside that boot shaped country!!  The wine list is amazing, the owner sold wine throughout the city for years before gracing us with his food masterpieces!  

The biggest drawback is the lack of ambiance.  It, well....it...um...feels like a bathroom, bad blue shiny paint, bad bar area, but that is overlooked once the first dish hits the table.  Rumor has it the owner has been asked about the ambiance..."ambiance, I didn't come here to have ambiance, I came here to make the best food in the City".  Says it all!
author: Brye L.

description:
I have never tried Sardinian food until La Ciccia and I have to say it was an amazing first.

A group of us went to La Ciccia for my 21st birthday and we did the whole 4 course dinner. We ordered 4 or 5 dishes for each course and passed around the table - everything was excellent. It was the best (non-fried) calamari and sea bass (whole fish) that I have ever had.

At first when you walk in you have to wonder how they do so much business - the place itself is rather small but they must do at least 3 turns a night (maybe 4 on the smaller tables). The decor is lovely, very simple and calming which I like in restaurants. Places that have a whole lot of decoration going on tend to distract me from eating my food. 

The service was impeccable. Our waiter was very knowledgeable of the menu and also very suggestive. He helped us make some excellent choices when it came to the wine.

You definitely get your money's worth with this place.
author: Kayla H.

description:
Awesome food, awesome service, awesome wine list. Unbelievable octopus stew. Everything is very reasonably priced. This place is always packed for a reason... The zucchini was a little overly greasy for my taste, but I suspect it was just the authentic method of preparation. 

My only minor gripe is the ultra-bright fluorescent light emanating from the kitchen and reflecting off the ceiling. (Makes the space feel a little warehouse-y.) If it were my restaurant, I'd paint the ceiling in flat black, put in some task lighting in the kitchen, and set out some candles on the tables. It would just make it that much more intimate.

But what do I know? They pack the place every night, so no need to listen to me! I'll certainly be back for the food no matter what they color they paint the inside.
author: Jason Y.

description:
We were not familiar with Sardinian food previous to this meal, but we had an early dinner after seeing our accountant who lives nearby.  Good thing because at 6:30P on a Friday night, the joint filled up very quickly.  

Both had the a delicious heaping bowl of lentil soup (could have had that for dinner and been satisfied) if only the bread came with olive oil or butter on the side (olive oil was $2 extra) it would have been perfect.  

My hubby had the lamb shanks with beans (so rich that he took a bit home for lunch the next day) and I had the shrimp with onions and what I think was braised cabbage (veggies of the day) a bit oily, but still yummy.  All washed down with a bottle of Barbera vino.  If I am in the neighborhood, I would go back.  Very laid back, casual service.
author: Sfgpgirl G.

description:
My husband and I have been here in the past and had good memories about the quality of the food... tonight we went and we were surprised and disappointed.

The good: they seated us at 5:30 on a Saturday without a reservation.  The staff were all super nice and professional, and everyone went out of their way to connect with us.  The timing of the service was good.

The disappointing: my potato and mushroom soup was very bland.  My husband struggled with the bones in a sardine dish.  My lamb ragu pasta was good for the most part, but a few pieces of pasta were so al dente they were crunchy.

The parents perspective: no changing area in the bathroom.  Waitstaff didn't blink an eye about breastfeeding at the table.  One waitress offered to hold the baby so I could eat with both hands.

In general, we felt that the meal was ok, but more expensive than we would have expected for the dishes we ate tonight.  We like the owners and staff a lot, but I don't know if we will venture here again for a while.
author: Hypercycloid ..

description:
Excellent local sardinian food.  The menu had very creative options.  We started off with some house olive oil, directly from the owners farm. It was buttery!  

We then shared a pizza; flat bread and simple, just like Ive had in Italy.  I;m going to make it at home and modify it by adding more basil, adding garlic and a tad more sauce.  The sauce was tasty, not sweet, not sour.

I enjoyed an Italian couscous with muscles.  The portion was perfect for dinner; a little salty for my palate.  The clams fell out of their shell.

My bf enjoyed the boar stew and loved it.  Again, just the right size for dinner.  It came with a side of smashed potatoes that I am sure had thousands of calories as it was dripping in oil. A bit too oily and salty for my palate.  Apparently, the potatoes are famous as the next table asked for them immediately.

We shared a dessert that I can only describe (the name escapes me).  It was like a chocolate gelato ball the size of a softball, dusted in powdered chocolate with a toblerone like nougut on the inside.  It was much better than I expected!

Their wine list is extensive!  The barbera by the glass was yummy, not as jammy as a zin; but fruiter than a cab.

Make reservations on OpenTable.
author: Liz L.

description: I went to this restaurant with my friend. And his one liner summarizes our experience very well "The wait staff deserved to serve better food":) The atmosphere, the staff were also so friendly and warm. I was surprised that I was underwhelmed by the food, as I had heard good things about it. My friend ordered a Pizza and I ordered a prawn dish. The food didn't really have much of a flavor and overall was disappointing. I am tempted to go there again as so many people love it, but given the price tag I cannot afford another disappointing food experience
author: Lisa C.

description:
This is a great small neighborhood joint, very lively compared to Incanto down the road.  The octopus stew is amazing, I usually have issues with the texture but it was perfect!  Mister B and I shared two starters, a first course, two mains, and still had room for their sublime pizza la sarda.  The fregula with mussels was interesting texturally, and the petrale sole was so tenderly roasted it was unreal.  Mister B had his way with pork as usual, loving every minute of the slow braised pork with sardinian olives.

No room for a real dessert, but they brought out  what I think was the saffron cake to celebrate our anniversary.  Lightly delicious and just moist enough!

We also got a bottle of wine, so we really went all out for this meal.  Still, with tip we paid less than $180.  Not bad for a bunch of great leftovers, as well as the bittersweet anticipation of heading back again soon...
author: Aimee B.

description: This is my favorite restaurant.  Nothing else comes close in regards to seafood and wine.  Family-run with love!
author: Garrett P.

description: Buono, molto buono.  I padroni sono simpaticissimi e gentilissimi e si magna benone.  Ci hanno lasciato noi due (gli ultimi) restare, parlare, rilassarci molto tardi l'altra volta, fino a mezzanotte, senza dire niente, ne'anche una parola.  Proprio una bella esperienza ogni volta che vado.  Salute, La Ciccia, e tante grazie : D.
author: Michael G.

description:
Food:  DELICIOUS, ONE OF A KIND, ORGANIC INGREDIENTS USED ONLY, UNIQUE IN FLAVOR, ITALIAN CUISINE DEVOTED TO SARDINIA LIKE YOU HAVE NOT EATEN BEFORE.  

Ambiance:  Nice, cozy, intimate dining with minimal decor but simply elegant.  Good for a romantic date.  This is a small restaurant, probably accomodating 50 - 60 people dining at most.  BE AWARE:  Seating is tight.  I wish they would give more ample seating space b/c I was sitting back to back from someone.  It's hard to hold an intimate conversation and is limited to what you can talk about b/c tables are arranged very closely.  The bar is small but the Italian wine makes up for it.

Staff: Great, friendly, waiters/waistresses; Very knowledgeable of the menu.  The hostess went around asking people and we were among them if we enjoyed the food, what was our favorite dish, what we thought about our experience eating here.  I thought it was nice getting a chance to talk to someone who worked at the restaurant, it made it more personable.  

Food:  LOVED IT!  My husband and I LOVED EVERY BITE.  This is different italian food that we all are not familiar with but so worth to try  something new!  To describe the taste just does not do justice reading this review.  YOU MUST TRY IT!  It is very different but yet so very tasty and divine.  Portions are medium size and affordable.  Between my husband and I, we started off with 2 appetizers; one was their special for the evening the other was Sardella a Schiscionera  $9 Fresh Sardines Sauteed in EVOO, Garlic, Parsley and Bread Crumbs), then we each ordered a First Course - Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga $16 (Fresh Spaghetti with spicy Oil and Bottarga) and the special for the evening which consisted of Ravioli mixed with beef, sausage, fresh sardines sauteed in EVOO, and we shared a main entree Tonnu in Padella Cun Olia Sarda $23 (Pan Seared Ahi served with Sardinian Olives Sugo).  We each enjoyed our glasses of red wine - Karana an Italian wine which was very close to Pinot Noir.  They asked if we wanted dessert but we were stuffed from the last dish that as much as we wanted to have dessert, we passed up on it.  Although they did bring out a quant little dessert with a candle just to a nice sweet ending to my husband's birthday dinner.  LA CICCIA IS TO DIE FOR!  5 Stars all the waaaaay!
author: Lyn D.

description: Our last night in San Francisco and couldn't have dined at a better spot!  Loved it all--the darling owner who makes a point of coming to the table to check on you, the knowledgeable server, the warm ambiance and best of all, the amazing food.  Our party of 4 decided to share all dishes and started with the Burrata and asparagus appetizer special--simply scrumptious.  For the second course we settled upon the fregola with creamy pink-tinged ricotta sauce and the semolina gnochetti with pork meats.  The fregola was cooked to perfection with a consistency similar to a perfectly cooked al dente small pasta--the sauce was a creamy delight.  The gnochetti sauce was spicy but not overly so. For the main course we went with the lamb tenderloin--it was perfection--incredibly tender, melt-in-the-mouth and served with a saute of spinach sweetened with balsamic vinegar.  We declined dessert as one of our party was celebrating her birthday and we had dessert waiting at home.  Our server brought our check along with a little roasted almond semifreddo cake with a candle in it!  Perfect touch and enough for all of us to have a bite and enjoy!  Thank you La Ciccia. We can't wait to return on our next visit to San Francisco.  If you're lucky enough to live nearby, be sure to try this place.  BTW, the extensive wine list is nothing short of incredible.
author: Mia S.

description:
I'd never had Sardinian food before La Ciccia. It's an interesting mix of mostly Italian flavors with some Moroccan twists, like more use of potatoes. I've enjoyed all my dinners there.

It's run by a husband (chef) wife (runs the front) team. The first time we ate there it took a long time to get a table, but the second visit was much better. Service was good too.
author: Emmy B.

description: This is a true italian place to it's soul and service. Ambience was a little too dark for my liking and the pasta quality was pretty good. We had the squid ink pasta and it was my first time. Nothing scary about it in fact it was pretty good. The cheese plate was really interesting. Pairing with the cheese and the different honey was definitely something i was intrigued with. A good authentic italian dinner place. Don't forget to make a reservation as thye have limited seating
author: Meredith C.

description: We love San Fran! This place was close to our cute little studio we rented. The service was outstanding. Our waitress reccommended the octopus as an appetizer and we dove in. They were amazingly  tender and we could have eaten the broth all night. So flavorful. We just kept sopping it up w/ our bread. The pasta was perfectly chewy and the sauce was yum. We also shared the lamb main dish and it was cooked perfectly.
author: Kimberly O.

description:
Had a wonderful meal here, the most authentic and interesting Italian restaurant we've been to in SF.

The octopus stew and fresh sardines were amazing, we sopped up all the sauce with bread. We also had the spaghetti with bottarga and the lamb stew and they were both absolutely delicious. The pasta is cooked al dente which is always a great sign. The gelato trio (goat cheese & fig, bacchio, and marsala) was also delicious, especially with the espresso.

The staff was warm and helpful, seemed genuinely interested in making sure we were having a good meal. Dishes came out at a good pace and our our water and wine glasses were always filled.

We'll definitely be back to try the rest of the menu.
author: Minjia Q.

description: There are some big reviews here.  The food (Sardinian) was a bit challenging, even for me (or perhaps it is what my compadres ordered) (roe, sardines, all not my favorite) (though go figure: I love caviar).  But the mains (tuna, lamb) were great, as was the wine (all picked by our wait staff team).
author: Laurel B.

description:
I have to say- WE ORDERED THE WHOLE MENU, literally! Everything was perfect and delicious, I stuffed and stuffed, even though I was already stuffed!
So, we started with their "special" of the evening, the arugula salad, I didn't give it a taste because I don't like arugula, even though I will try anything once! But it looked very fresh and crisp, and I know everyone else enjoyed it! We also had the grilled sardines, grilled calamari, and calamari in some sort of decadent tomato sauce! All was incredibly delicious and fresh, extremely fresh! I don't particularly like sardine's but I tasted them, and enjoyed them! We then proceed to order two of their pizza's off the menu to share, which were AHHHH-mazing! I ordered their special of the evening, which was rigatoni with a sausage ragu, if they sold that in a frozen box, I would eat it (I don't eat food out of frozen containers), I shared with everyone, and I believe everyone enjoyed my dish the most, so if it is a special that evening order it!!! Another dish was spaghetti with a salmon roe, which was also very interestingly yummy, it had a rather fishy taste, not something I much enjoy, but it was good! Another dish that was ordered was the pork chops Milanese style, which were scrumptious, and the salsa and greens that came with it were also lovely! One dish that wasn't particularly the best was the shrimp and mashed potatoes, it was good, but definitely could be better. I much enjoyed the sauce used for those shrimp, but then again I am not a big shrimp fan!
Do eat at this place!

Cheers! They also have an amazing selection of wine, and we had some great bottles, only I did not take notice, and can't tell you what we ordered! BTW- it was packed on a Wednesday, do make a reservations!
author: yana Z.

description:
Wow second time I have been to La Ciccia, bellissima! The gnochetti are unbelievable. First time having the squid ink pasta and it is like a luscious ocean on your palette. The waiter picked a crisp white wine that heightened the rich flavors of the home made sauces and pasta. The chef was gracious, with his love for Sardinia not only apparent in his dishes but also through his family, his wife is the lovely host, and authentic restaurant. With the perfect name La Ciccia, la mia ciccia è felicissima!
Ci vediamo a presto!
author: Natalie L.

description:
We were able to book a 7:45pm reservation at the last minute on Friday night.  The neighborhood is residential, quiet, nice!  Hard to find parking but nice.

The restaurant is small, our table was right in front of the door, but it did not matter.

The food was excellent, we had the squid and calamari appetizer.  The rigatoni with pork sauce and the tuna.

The service was a bit slow, we did wait quite a bit before our entrees so we were so tired we did not order dessert at the end.

But the waitstaff was very cordial, knowledgeable and with no attitude.

We did recommend the place to friends and we will come again.
author: Sailing A.

description:
My god this place is to die for. It's a small quaint amazing Italian restaurant with great food, great service, and a HUGE wine selection.

So we walked in with a reservation, and we had called ahead because we were running late. They said it wasn't going to be a problem which was awesome. We got to the place, and were immediately seated, and they took our coats. We sat down and the waiter immediately offered water. He then left, which gave up some time to go through the menu. As I looked through the menu, everything looked good. Then I flipped the menu over to see the wine list. My god the list was HUGE. There had to be over 200 wines they were offering. You can definitely find something in your price range.

We settled on splitting the spaghetti to begin with following the braised pork for me and the lamb for my date. The spaghetti had this spicy olive oil that made it soooo good! The braised pork was perfect. I didn't have the lamb, but my date loved it. In the end for desert we have this double chocolate mousse with cherries and a cherry reduction. It was to die for. 

Overall everything was amazing. Next time we go back we want to try the pizzas.
author: Diana R.

description:
Skeptical at first, now a believer! Comfortable setting, friendly service. Bread came out first and was a disappointment for both of us, served cold, and got me worried it set the tone for later disappointments. That such a first impression was erased and forgotten by end of the evening is a testament to how much we were wowed by every dish that came out afterward. 

Couple notes:  The bread came cold without any butter in sight. We asked about it and learned from the waiter that there is no butter in the restaurant! Chef/owner came out to say 'hi' to patrons later on and proudly reiterated no butter used in his cooking, which I suppose makes for healthier fare. Another note: Just about everything we ordered was spiced with chili flakes (couldn't see the flakes themselves, but when we asked the waitress, she explained that was what was used). We like spicy and were pleasantly surprised by the little kick we got in every dish in this non-Asian/non-Latino cuisine. The spiciness though was not overpowering and we were able to taste the other layers of complex flavors coming through. 

Food itself:  The baby octopus stew is as good as everyone says. The spaghetti bottarga (fish roe) had a wonderful consistency, texture, and flavor - creamy but without the guilt. The fregula (Sardinian pasta in the shape of 1/4-inch balls) dish had different flavors come out in every bite depending on what you happen to pick up on your fork - a pleasant surprise in every bite. The ahi tuna dish had best chopped olive sauce I ever had, sweeter and quite unlike any olive tapenade I ever had. The best dish may be the lamb, sooo scrumptious, again prepared differently than I've ever had. The grape must sauce was wonderfully sweet. The desert we had was a gelatto trio of olive oil/fig; goat cheese; and dark chocolate. The chocolate was a substitution for what was supposed to be saffron gelatto which presumably they ran out of, but it was honestly the richest dark chocolate we've had and couldn't get enough of!

Our La Ciccia experience was a wonderful adventure with unique tastes in uniquely prepared food, freshly simple yet flavorfully complex at the same time. Friendly service with owners coming out to greet patrons in a cozy ambience. Definitely would come back again for a romantic dinner.
author: Freddy S.

description: This is definitely as good as it gets for great Italian food in the city.  We went here for my birthday and had an amazing time.  For appetizers, we had wonderful grilled calamari... probably the most tender I've ever tasted.  We also had the sardines which were great, but I'm not really a fish person so they weren't my favorite, but that's not to say they weren't prepared wonderfully too.  For second course we had pasta.  The pasta was cooked to perfection!  Fresh and al dente I really enjoyed it!  By the time the entrees arrived, I was so full but just had to keep going.  We had the lamb, seared ahi, and pork tenderloin.  All were fabulous.  I really don't think I have any negative comments about this place.  I can't wait to go back!
author: Jen F.

description:
Holy shit was this a good meal.

Small, intimate, casual, sleek, sexy, yummy.
A friend and I decided to venture out in her Noe Valley neighborhood for a bite to eat, and this place looked pretty inviting, so we popped in, and to our disappointment, this place was booked through the night :(

The lovely hostess/owner (forgot her name) asked us if we had reservations, and we sadly said no.  As she looked around she pointed to the bar area and said a couple was just finishing dessert, and we were more than welcome to eat dinner at the bar, so we did!

This food is Sardinian, an island off the coast of Italy, and although the food is Italian -inspired, it is NOT your spaghetti and meatballs kinda place. I speak Italian and couldn't decipher the menu by any stretch of the imagination. 
Much more simplistic, fresh entrees, many fish options, and flatbreads.
Wine was fantastic, had a montepulciano blend that was really really good.
We shared a salad, each had a glass or 2 of wine, each had an entree, and split a dessert and our meal was around $80. Not the cheapest thing on the block, but HOLY HELL was this food good.
I seriously took the owner aside and told her I hadn't eaten like this in a long while. 
A great place for a date.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I have this funny thing when tasting something really good. I start humming. It's like a reflex of involuntary mmmmmms. And I can tell you La Ciccia is high on humming.   

Every time I ate here the food was authentic, surprising, and delicious. Yesterday for instance I hummed at their home made pasta with tuna heart. Made and served with Sardinian passion. 

This makes La Ciccia clearly not your ordinary North Beach choice. Instead, this place is more like that great restaurant run by Primo and Secondo in the movie Big Night. Main difference: they do get the audience (and my stars) they deserve.
author: Michiel D.

description:
When this place is on... Oh, is it ON!  When this place is off... I'd say it's so-so.  But even so, la ciccia never fails to disappoint.  As someone noted below, sometimes the tuna dishes are hit or miss, probably depending on the preparation.

A couple of staple desserts I ALWAYS get at La Ciccia...

1)  The Cheese Platter- As one of my friends put it, each little taste of cheese is a "party in your mouth."  Pair that with the different varieties of honey, and it's a RAVE in your mouth.  
2)  Chocolate tartufo-  I don't know what's in this thing, but I'm sure if you checked an ingredient list it would read "heaven."  Seriously.  This is the best chocolate dessert I've had in my entire life.

Oh, and anything pizza at la ciccia is always a must.  Especially if there's capers involved...
author: Christina G.

description: I came here with a few friends the other night. We had excellent service the whole time we were there, with a personal visit from the owner at the end. The quality of the food was excellent, and the waiter was very helpful in selecting a wine to pair with our shared entrees. Although I got plenty to eat in the end, I did think that some of the entrees were a bit small for the price. The seared lamb, while delicious, consisted of seven small pieces--probably enough for some or even most people, but not for me. Still, it was a great experience overall. I highly recommend the ricotta with honey and almonds for dessert!
author: Alex C.

description: This is as good as SF neighborhood restaurants get.  It's got wonderfully creative food as fine as any expensive restaurant downtown.  I could eat the local Petrale Sole all week.  So delicate and delicious with their personal style topping off a spectacular fish.  Forget about the greasy flat fried sole of Europe...this was a delicious and delicate meat with  gorgeous flavoring.  I finished with the cheese plate complemented by infused honeys.  Some were homemade and others purchased but nonetheless a gorgeous finale to the meal.  I can't wait to go back.  Oh and the interior is so quaint.  They've even added fresh flowers to the bar and in the bathroom.  I felt like I was visiting my fancy aunt's home.
author: kenner k.

description:
Yes, 5 stars, why?

Family owned and operated, attentive and more importantly knowledgeable staff, great food, a wine selection that makes you wonder, where and the hell are they storing all this wine, there's no space and, well, ok, the place is real close to my house.  

The place is small so I wouldn't come with a large group, maybe 4 cause. Since the place is small, could be loud too.
author: Will C.

description:
Seafood salad ($12): tasty but should've been named squid salad. 
Home made tagliolini with tuna ($13): yummy but portion was stingy. 
Seared lamb chops ($21) & wild boar stew ($22): delicious but side dishes were weak.

Service was professional and knowledgeable. But with a limited and overpriced menu, I won't be back anytime soon.
author: D'Andy C.

description: Amazingly friendly service from the whole staff. The food was so delicious and unpretentious. It's always nice to taste flavors you haven't before. I thought I had had great Italian food but I was wrong. Go now.
author: Ramin R.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to La Ciccia last night with another couple and we had a wonderful dinner. We had never been before (or had Sardinian food before), but after seeing all the good reviews on Chowhound and Yelp! we had to try it for ourselves.

 Our table for four was already waiting for us, despite it being dinner time on Friday and the restaurant being packed. The service was prompt, friendly, and very helpful (great wine recommendations!). We were also able to find parking right in front of the restaurant---so I knew luck was on our side.

For wine, we started with the Vermentino di Gallura Cantina Pedres Thibalas, which was delicious. We also had a Cannonau, which I had never had before and really wanted to try. It was great -- very dry -- nothing at all what I expected from a Grenache.

For appetizers we shared the charcuterie of the day, which was a smoked prosciutto. We also shared the octopus stew (Prupisceddu in Umidu), which was fabulously delicious and very different. The octopus stew may have been my favorite dish of the night!

For a pasta course, we shared the linguine, which was fresh, lemony and wonderful. Though it was pretty simple, it was probably my favorite dish of the night after the octopus stew.

For my main course, I had the lamb and my boyfriend had the shrimp. The lamb was tender and flavorful and went great with the cauliflower salad it was served with. The shrimp were also great--served in a squid ink and garlic sauce with a little bit of chard on the side.

For dessert, we shared the almond, honey and saffron cake. It was very light and flavorful -- not too sweet -- to finish off such a great meal. It was a also a generous portion, ideal for sharing.

Anyway, it was a wonderful dinner! We had so much good food and wine that I can't imagine you could go wrong. We will definitely be back -- my only regret is that we did not try the pizzas!
author: J S.

description:
This is the most amazing meal!  We have been there twice and each time is wonderful.   We started with an appetizer of clams and calamari which was so tender and the broth was just so delicious, we had to ask for a second basket of bread!  We had used some of the bread earlier for a taste of olive oil from the first crush of the season and it was fruity and full-bodied.  One of the specials last night  was home made pasta (like linguine) with tuna heart!  It was delicious!  The tuna heart was just shaved over the top of the pasta and added just  enough richness.  I had the wild boar stew which was sublime and my husband had the pork loin which was equally delicious, with fresh herbs like fennel and oregano sprinkled over the top while roasting.  Sadly, we were so stuffed, we didn't have any room for dessert.  The wine list is mostly affordable and packed with many, many choices and the waiters suggestions is always spot on.
The service is always impeccable and the staff and owners make you feel so welcomed.  It really is a family restaurant serving top quality food without being pretentious.
I cannot say enough about this place.  We have decided to make La Ciccia a regular visit at least one time per season.
One other mention: Even though the place is small, and the tables tight, you are never once knocked around or even bumped by the bustling wait staff.  The only problem you have to worry about is the pompous wannabe oenophile sitting at the next table boring the hell out of his dinner party.
author: Mary D.

description: Awesome Italian restaurant that features delicious Seafood and great pastas.  Can't wait until they come back at the end of July.
author: Jim J.

description: Great selection of Italian wines and had the most amazing dish - larger cous cous served with calamari, fishes (tuna, etc) in squid ink. Loved the quaint atmosphere and really appreciated that families brought their kids here!
author: Chihee K.

description: Oh how I wish this place (or its carbon copy) were in north Atlanta. I bet it would take HOURS to get into on any night! Rather than rave, I'll list some of the items we enjoyed: A simple salade,  Risone con Carciofi e Pancetta. Cornetti (never had Italian croissants before), Pesce Spada ala Siracusa, Sardi a Beccaficu Palermitani, and Cioppino were the elements that took us far, far from our Southern USA roots. We dined leisurely for 2 hours. The wine steward was amazed that I am allergic to alcohol, so he brought two glasses of a medium dry white (I still don't know what it was) gratis, because he insisted it was a 'crime to have no vino' with our meal. I sipped mine slowly over the better part of an hour, suffered no ill effects, and enjoyed it immensely. I don't think I'll ever see entrees like these in Atlanta unless I try to cook them, but I don't think I'll find any fresh sardines in any market here.
author: George C.

description:
First visit (2006, I think)

I really want to love this place. I love Sardegna and all types of Italian food, and in general it's hard to screw up with quality ingredients. However, La Ciccia failed on a more than a few counts. The lamb was overcooked and the "fresh" peas that came with it even more so, and both together in a watery broth was far less than appetizing. The gnochetti did taste of fresh pasta, but little else. The cheese plate was OK but could have been more interesting. Great sardo wine list, points for that. The service was very friendly and prompt - too prompt actually - we felt rushed through the meal. I'll wait a while and give it another try... 

Second visit (early 2007)

2 strikes, you're out. Scallops included unadvertised bottarga - if you're going to use fish eggs, make a note of it. Fresh pasta had great texture again, but no taste, again. Wild boar stew was brown sauce with chunks of meat - I've had my share of cinghiale, and this did not measure up. And where is the contorno (veggies?)!?! 

Third visit (June 2006)

OK, I said two strikes, you're out, but I have a soft spot for Italian food in general, and an even softer spot for Sardegna and for the owners for making a go of a very specifically Sardinian restaurant. Reviews by other Yelpers have improved recently as well, and so I buckled under and made a third visit, this time with a group of six. 

This is a pretty small restaurant, and we were seated a smallish, rather wobbly table, but we squeezed in and it didn't prove to be a problem. The owners and staff are certainly super friendly, warm and engaging, which helped start the evening off in the right direction. 

We had a pesto pizza as sort of a pre-appetizer, I think mainly because Fosco got a little drunk on lo spritz at my place beforehand - and the pizza was certainly tasty, but if you're sticking with purely Sardo cuisine there's no need to reach for a pizza at La Ciccia. Once we sat down we ordered a bottle of red Cannonau ("La Marina", I think, but don't hold me to that) and the octopus stew and tuna carpaccio appetizers. The wine (on recommedation) was fairly priced, excellent, and a great representation of a relatively unfamiliar grape (from Sardegna of course). Octopus in a tomato-based sauce was tender, very fresh & tasty, and the tuna carpaccio was excellent great too. 

For mains we ordered spaghetti with seafood ragu, lamb chops, whole branzino, more octopus, and the Fregua, whatever that is. The seafood ragu was good - a ground-up mixture of various "sea fruits", although the tomato sauce tasted a bit like the octopus starter. The lamb was perfectly cooked and delicous, but we put that down to the quality of the meat more than anything, and the olive tapenade didn't really add anything to the dish. Branzino looked nice but it was across the table and so I didn't taste it - branzino is great fish, and the preparation was traditional but fairly plain. Unfortunately I can't remember the fregula, as we were moving through our third bottle of wine at this point, having switched to an *amazing* Carignano (del Sulcis "Buio Buio") - again, a great recommendation from the host. 

Somehow we managed to fit in a cheese plate and a glass of local Moscato - lovely stuff. 

Overall, La Ciccia is much improved from my first two visits. There were some very tasty dishes, but the menu shows a little bit of repetition, e.g. the octopus & seafood ragu similarity. Some of this is due to the narrow focus of the restaurant, so perhaps we just needed to do a better job of ordering. Or just quit complaining and enjoy the food. Wine was excellent. Service was great - again, super friendly, competent, and not rushed. 

I'd give La Ciccia 3.5 stars if I could -- and I'd be happy to return with the goal of adding another star! 

Viva la Sardegna!
author: Bowen D.

description:
We had a reso and were seated promptly, parking around here sucked, but once you park and come into this place, you feel like you are at someone's house. It's a very cozy space and it gets REALLY LOUD in here. During the course of our meal, my friend and I were yelling at each other just to try to carry on a normal convo and I started losing my voice and getting hoarse! The table next to us was like less than a foot away and I heard their whole convo, without trying.

The servings are really small and not really worth the prices. We started with the octopus stew which was ok. I then had the pasta with sugo and my friend had the lamb chops. My pasta was ok, again, small. But my friend didn't even finish her chops. She said they were chewy and she makes them better at her house. 

We ended the meal with a chocolate tartufo which was good but didn't convince us to come back.
author: Vivian L.

description:
Delicious home style Italian food directly from Italia!!! It's such an awesome little gem in the middle of cute Noe valley. What a great neighborhood restaurant. I can't wait to dine here again as the service was amazing and the food was tasty. I had the tiny gnocchi pasta, flat bread, and asparagus. The gnocchi and asparagus were incredible but the flat bread can definitely be left off the menu.

It's so nice to find a local place that is unique and offers Italian food off the beaten path. Plus, the prices are so good you want to order more just to taste it!  I look forward to dinning here soon.
author: Josephine L.

description: I've had numerous friends and acquaintances recommend La Ciccia for the past couple years, and tonight I FINALLY made it in. Fantastic experience! Great service, phenomenal wine list, food that was perfectly seasoned, prepared, and presented. A real culinary gem yet still a relaxed atmosphere. We'll be back again, often.
author: C. M.

description: Have been back a couple times since my original review, and the raves still stand.  It's a relatively healthy menu they have here, so if you are a big carnivore it might seem a little light on the red meat and heavier on the seafood.  It's still very good food.
author: Dave N.

description:
The food at this place is great.  It's traditional Sardinian food.  I have been there three times overall.  My partner and I took our parents there, and they all loved it as well.

The owner was a little rude once though.  She gave my dad a hard time when he asked  for butter with his bread.   She told him that they don't serve butter in Sardinia.  He didn't care.  He wanted butter.   She made a nasty face and brought him out some oil/vinegar.

This one experience should not deter you from going there.  I have had a server wait on me who was AMAZING.  She knew the food well and was very friendly.  I highly recommend trying their food!
author: Eric S.

description: Tiny restaurant with outstanding Sicilian Italian food. Pizzas, pastas, and delicious meat. White pizza is creative and surprisingly delicious with raddichio, pecorino, and an Italian salami as toppings. (Caution: restaurant was unbearably hot. Had the food not been amazing, I might not have been able to stay.)
author: E T.

description: Very nice place. Great food! Actually my husband asked me to write a review here because he is not that type of person who does it. I liked everything about this place except it was very noisy for such a tiny place with only few tables occupied I had hard time talking to my husband. We had a spaghetti with some kind of special seafood sauce, which I found the best for dipping bread into (not spaghetti itself). Ahi tuna was incredibly well prepared, just as fish could be done at best. So, food was great, but the whole atmosphere with its noise was upsetting, which could be overcome or easily disregarded after a glass of wine (maybe two).
author: Elena Z.

description:
Really enjoyed this little Sardinian restaurant at the end of Church St.  

Service = super friendly and extremely knowledgeable about the menu and wines. We had three different people come by our table at different points: a waitress who was very professional and well-informed. The owner, who acted as our sommelier, and the bartender who came by to check on us a few times. 

Wine list = interesting and well-priced. We had glasses of prosecco to start (refreshing), a bottle of Vetliner from the Alto Adige with our appetizers and first courses, and a bottle of La Grola (made by the bartender's father) from the Valpolicella region with our mains. All were well-suited to the items we ordered.

Food = unique and nicely done. For starters we ordered the mix salad with balsamic onion dressing, a special of mire poix in white wine sauce, potatoes with caramelized onions. Next came a brothy lentil soup and margherita pizza. And for our main courses we had sea bream in broth with an olive and caper tapenade and house-made raviolis in a wild boar ragout. We finished with the cheese platter and saffron honey. 

In closing, this is a reasonably-priced neighborhood restaurant with warm and pleasant ambiance.
author: Sarah B.

description:
This was definitely one of my finer dining experiences. The cuisine and the wine list are both very enjoyable and varied. The wait staff was very friendly and knowledgeable. We ordered an anti-pasti with salami, a wild boar stew, and a piscine dish in between, and challenged the waitress to find a wine that matched all three courses. And she did! Well, ok, the La Marina Monica de Sardegna wasn't strong enough to beat the wild boar, that symbol of Roman virility, down, but it tried pretty hard.

This place is tucked away at the outer reaches of Noe Valley, but it's worth hopping onto the J for. I would like to think that the large Italian family that was loudly celebrating their latest acquisition of a prostitution ring, or the offing of a troublesome consiglierie, is a fixture, specially imported like the absolutely delectable olive oil, to enhance our bland San Franciscan yuppie lives ("Look, honey, I can see the bulge under his left coat pocket!")
author: Sameer S.

description:
Five friends hit La Ciccia on a Saturday night for dinner. We were all impressed with the food, service and ambiance.

Everybody on the staff was so effen nice! We had reservations and were seated right on time, despite the fact that the place was packed. They were very accommodating, allowing us to order a few starters and a bottle of wine while we strategized the rest of the order. We were not the easiest table to deal with, but they answered all our questions with a smile and set the tone for a really enjoyable dinner.

All the food was really well done. Very interesting pastas that aren't customarily servied in Italian joints, interesting combos/flavors (pasta with cauliflower and fish roe? YUM!), great meat preperations (wild boar stew? tender and savory!), squid, octopus and a whole fish were all impeccably prepared. We also had some  delicious desserts (trio of homemade gelatto, ricotta cake); light but incredibly flavorful.

Also, some excellent Italian wines. The staff was very knowledgeable and directed us to perfect selections every time, including introducing us to some Sardinian wines that were robust and earthy with great finish.

I absolutely would not hesitate to go here again. Perfect for a date (though perhaps a bit rowdy at the height of the dinner hour on the weekend), with family or friends.

La Ciccia: If you are reading this, next time you remodel can you please paint the walls a different color? Grey-blue is never an appetizing color.
author: Arkay K.

description: Cozy ambiance, phenomenal service, and amazing wine list.  Food was good but maybe I don't have a palate for Sardinian cuisine.  The broth for the octopus stew was good (reminded me of asian lotus root soup), but I found the octopus itself to actually be *too* tender.  The gnochetti with pork sugo and pizza a sa sarda were better but neither blew me away.  Reasonably priced and close by, though, so I'm sure I'll be back at some point.
author: Melinda C.

description: I would call this maybe 3 3/4 starts, but I rounded up. Took parental-type items here and it's a fun place to break up the monotony of say, north beach italian. This is a Sardinian place and you'll get a fun array of interesting items like a slow braised octopus in a red sauce - super flavorful and tender. Like butter. Whole baby squids. So cute. Didn't try the tuna heart, but would be really interested to try. The wait staff was great and authentically italian. The wine list is worth talking about too - hard to find italian varietals and a ton of sardinian ones. The aforesaid waitstaff was pretty well versed in the wines...nice to see a place so regionally focused.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
La Ciccia is my favorite Italian restaurant in San Francisco.  I've moved out of the Bay Area, but every time I am back, I make sure to dine at La Ciccia.  

Although there are a number of excellent Italian restaurants in the Bay Area, La Ciccia's food is incredibly unique and distinctive.  I had never had Sardinian food before coming to La Ciccia, but my experience with La Ciccia has made me fall in love with its rich flavors.  The bottarga pasta, in particular, was a culinary revelation for me, and the sea urchin tuna heart is also excellent.  They also had wonderful roasted sardines several months ago, which my date and I enjoyed as a starter.  

The restaurant also shines in its hospitality and cozy atmosphere.  The last time I went there, for instance, there was a slight delay in preparing our table.  Although we had only waited about ten minutes, the hostess (who I think may be the co-owner) became very apologetic, and gave my date and me free wine while we waited.  After we were seated, we both enjoyed the salume of the day, which was delicious and very generous in terms of proportions.  I then had the aforementioned battarga pasta, while my date had the gnochetti.  Because the portions for the salume were so generous (the waiter said that it was designed to be shared by two people, but it probably would be more than enough for three), my date and I did not order desert.  The waiter, however, apparently still apologetic about the very slight delay before we were seated, gave us a free desert as well, which was a delicious semifreddo.  The waiter came again and asked if we had enjoyed our meal.  I remarked that I loved the bottarga pasta.  The chef then emerged from the kitchen with a wrapped piece of bottarga, which he gave to me, along with instructions about how to use it in a pasta dish.  The hospitality of La Ciccia was so extraordinary that I almost felt guilty, as if I was not sufficiently clear about how wonderful the food was.  In conclusion, La Ciccia is a wonderful restaurant:  it has provided some of the most memorable meals that I have ever had, and I will definitely continue my tradition of going there every time I visit the Bay Area.
author: Randall S.

description:
Wow, this place was great.  The service was fantastic.  And the food...oh...the food!  If you like strong fish flavors, then get the pasta with bottarga (Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga).  That was incredible.  I will definitely get that every time I go back.  And the bean/lentil soup was fantastic, too...a creamy puree that definitely tasted like it included some sort of animal fat (but didn't).  I ordered the side of cabbage because I love cabbage and my fiance wasn't planning to have any.  He's not much of a cabbage fan.  But when I said he had to try it, he ended up eating most of it!  It's braised with tons of olive oil and spices that turn it into quite a tasty dish.

I know I'm raving, and only gave it 4 stars.  But I was starving and so I'm taking that into consideration.  I'll definitely go back, though, and will up the stars if it's as great the second time as it was the first.
author: R R.

description: This restaurant has amazing Italian food.  They never disappoint and give you the best food every time.  They have great customer service and have such amazing flavors.  All of there dishes are delicious.  I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Cindy B.

description: The pasta here was perfectly cooked and with very intersting and flavorful sauces that we usually don't see in Italian restaurants since Sardinian food isn't very mainstream.  But just a warning:  If you order the bottarga or the sea urchin finished with tuna heart, you're going to get a good dose of fishy flavor.  Not fishy in a bad, spoiled way, but fishy the way anchovies are fishy.  It isn't for everyone and I needed to have my pasta with a nice white wine with some bracing acidity to tone down the fishy smell.  The wine list is really good and our server was super knowledgeable and chatty about the wines and made sure we liked what we ordered.  I want to come back here and try some of the other dishes.  One other thing to note is that their salad is on the sweet side, due to the balsamic vinegar that they use.  I thought it needed a good squeeze of lemon to balance...
author: Priscilla C.

description: Such a wonderful neighborhood restaurant with owners who care so much about their customers.  The employees are knowledgeable about the wines and the food.  We always enjoy  the evening specials.
author: Lesley K.

description:
It's just about unanimous, right? This place rocks. The food is spectacular, and the crowded floor plan is forgiven as soon as you're seated because the staff is so nice and knowledgeable. They always recommend a perfect wine! 
We'll be back again and again!
author: Heather G.

description:
My Sardinian friend introduced me to this restaurant featuring ingredients from his home land, and boy was it a pleasant surprise!  I assumed it would be your typical Italian fare, but I was mistaken.  Dishes like the Pasta with Bottarga, the Fregula and the Tuna Belly Sauce are not to be missed!  Appetizers are always delicious, and any sauce you might encounter is so flavorful that you can't help but wonder how it's done.  Desserts are also good enough to stick around for, if you have room!

Votes are nearly tied in the "Good for Groups" poll.  I've eaten here with groups of six to eight a number of times and have never felt cramped, even though the dining room is relatively small.  Wait staff is always friendly and knowledgeable about the dishes and wines, and the wine list is extensive and never fails to please.
author: Tim D.

description: We had a fantastic dinner here tonight.  Our waitress was awesome; she suggested doing 2 plates per person and we thus ordered 8 items that were all very good; most were surprising and novel as well.  The prosciutto was divine; the octopus soup and calamari were super tender and yummy.  The bottarga pasta was a bit salty for me; but my wife loved it.  The tuna heart fregula was a truly novel and delicious taste.  The goat pasta was good although the goat was a little mild.  The shrimp and lamb entrees were delicious.  We'll be going back to this family restaurant.
author: David A.

description: This was a perfect place for my birthday celebration. All I can say is YUMMY! I can't wait to go back and try all the other delicious items on the menu. As an Italian, I am always wary when people recommend Italian restaurants but this was great. Lots of fish and seafood pastas and plates. The wait staff were friendly and attentive. I really wanted to order one of each thing on the menu.
author: Theresa W.

description: Yum. Cozy neighborhood restaurant. The food was amazing and the wine our fantastic server recommended was perfect.
author: Sharon H.

description: Yup... pasta was perfect.
author: michael k.

description: Killer food!  My favorite hidden gem in SF, with my singular favorite dish in the city... I dream of bottarga sometimes.
author: Adrian M.

description:
The appetizers, pasta and pizza are AMAZING!  By the time the entrees came, I think I was too stuffed to fully appreciate them.  When I come again, I'm going to make a family-style meal sharing several appetizers, pastas, and pizzas, and, of course, wine.  Bring your reading glasses to be able to read their very extensive and very good wine list.

The husband and wife team that run this small place are wonderful.  Ask about their favorite wines, and you'll get a very interesting and helpful tour of Italy.
author: B D.

description:
So it turns out I grew up in Italy and as such I fool myself into thinking that I know what good and bad Italian food is.
La ciccia:

good.

a bit too pricey for what it is.

a brave idea - food from Sardegna is even hard to find in most of Italy and it's great that you can have some here.

In general, a pleasant experience, although not a place I'd visit on a regular basis.
author: Fred A.

description: Let me preface this review by saying that I have finally found a cuisine that I don't enjoy, and that is Sardinian food. That isn't too say that I don't think the dishes here are well executed, I just didn't enjoy my meal. First of all, the owner (doubling as hostess) is lovely and gracious, and our server was very friendly. Can't complain at all about the service. Hubby and I went for our anniversary dinner and decided to make a trek into the city. I started off with the spaghetti with bottarga, and hubby had the special salad for that day, which was smoked trout. Now, I had no idea what bottarga was, so I looked it up online because so many reviewers raved about this dish. It is supposed to be the whole roe sack, dried, and then grated. That was not what this was... my spaghetti came out with fresh yellow roe on top and was very odd. I have to say, the spaghetti itself was cooked perfectly al dente, but the dish was just weird. Hubby hardly touched his salad, only saying it was "interesting" (not a good sign). We ordered some flatbread, which I expected to be more doughy like Paratha or something, but it was like a cracker. It was drizzled with olive oil (everything is drizzled or drenched in olive oil, understandably considering the region) and had aged pecorino cheese on top. But every time I tried to crack off a piece, the cheese flew off and it was just plain cracker. Oh well. I ordered the prawns for my entree, and hubby got the ravioli special. I knew I was in trouble when a busboy brought by a wet cloth napkin and set it beside me saying "for the prawns". Well, there were 4 big prawns, split lengthwise, all perfectly intact, and drenched in olive oil. As I attempted to dislodge them from the shell, olive oil was flying everywhere and got all over my nice pants and cashmere sweater. I gave up after 1 prawn. Not worth it. Plus, the dish was so pungent. Everything was so fishy smelling. I just didn't feel like things were fresh. I'll just spare you the rest. Again, service was great, and I think that everything was probably right on for the region, but I just didn't like it. I give 3 stars as a benefit of the doubt for the regional food and because service was very nice. Food (for me) would be a 1-star. But more power to you if you enjoy this kind of cuisine.
author: Goldi J.

description:
I love the food and service here. The owners are real deal Italians from the old country.  The husband is the chef and the wife is the host. She totally knows what to recommend to you once you become a regular and don't tell you "everything is good tonight" when you ask for a suggestion. 

There are very few authentic Italian restaurants owned by real Italians in SF.  La Ciccia is one of the few you can take your opinionated Roman friends with confidence. Their menu has seasonal items to die for.
author: tuncay c.

description: The best compliment for La Ciccia is that it reminded us of eating in Italy. The menu is a little bit adventurous/scary, but everything we had was pretty safe and very delicious...perfect al dente gnochetti/pork pasta starter, creative sopresseta/radicchio white pizza, and tasy thin pork tenderloin with onion marmalade. Wonderful atmosphere, nice staff and great wines. It's right up there with Bacco and Poesia for best Italian in the area.
author: Peter H.

description:
Where exactly is Sardinia?  I admit I am geographically challenged at times. oh, its an island...and it has its own cuisine!

Eating at La Ciccia was my first experience of Sardinian food- not your standard Italian fare.  They give hearty single glass pours and have an extensive wine list consisting of obscure Italian wines.  Using a 6 pt font, the entire Italian wine list fit on the back of a one page menu.  I felt like i needed bifocals.  However, there really is no need to read the winelist- just ask the knowledgeable bartendar or waitstaff for a recommendation and they will definitely find your match.  

After our waiter, Matia, with his thick Italian accent, told us the specials- all from sardinia, obviously- we were sold.  one of each please- are we sharing?  yes we are!  We ordered the swordfish carpaccio, the crostini,  the sardinian gnochetti, wild boar ragu special, the sardinian sea bass, the pork chop special, the sardinian cheese plate and the strawberry dessert.   Each dish was expertly cooked and had its own distinct flavor- the swordfish carpaccio with a few sprinkles of salt allowed the taste of the fish to shine, the homemade seminola pasta was perfectly al dente, the sardinian sea bass flaked off the bone and there was no mistaking the strong boar flavor in the ragu.  The flavors of each dish were delicately balanced- none of the dishes were overambitious with too many competing flavors.  

Balanced, simple Italian-influenced cooking at its best.  La Ciccia is one of my new favorite restaurants in SF where one doesn't have to drop the whole paycheck.  i'm definitely going back for more. And next time i'm trying the tuna heart...from sardinia.
author: michelle d.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. You must go here. It's worth a drive across the city. Small, unpretentious little restaurant with authentic Italian food. Love the pasta.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
This place might very well be my favorite restaurant in the city and worthy of my very first Yelp review! =) There isn't much I can add that hasn't already been said, it's a must-go if you love pasta and seafood.

Keepin' it short.
author: Isaac P.

description:
Nice ambiance, if a little warm. Friendly waitstaff with great wine pairing recommendations and knowledge of the menu.

Pasta, billed as fresh, had the texture of dry pasta. The sauce, however, had great flavor.

Odd side dish of beans with the perfectly cooked lamb loin. It needed a vegetable and perhaps a potato puree.
author: Simone E.

description: Wonderful Italian cooking, with interesting and original touches that go way beyond the standard trendy Italian menus you see everywhere these days.  We had the special trout salad, which was fantastic - the bitterness of the greens and fishiness of the trout perfectly balanced by the orange, and the spaghetti with bottarga.  2 fish entrees, the flat bread, wines by the glass recommended by our waiter, and gelato for dessert.  Great service, everything perfect.  Only downsides are that the space is tiny and parking can be a bitch.
author: Ritch G.

description:
This is currently our favorite restaurant in SF. Its walking distance to where we live, so we have been here quite often. Love the food, the owners are very sweet and hospitable.
Recommend the Appetizer of squid with mint.
Its is Sardinian food, so sea food dishes are amazing. Pizza is the best thin crust in this city.
Wine selection is outstanding, and the lady of the house is very helpful when it comes to picking Sardinian wines. However they just ran out of favorite sardinian wine :(
author: Aneela A.

description:
I have been here innumerable times, and have never had a meal I didn't love. The octopus is tender, the pasta chewy, the wild boar ragu succulent. Pizza is amazing, and the owners and wait-staff couldn't be sweeter. I am always greeted with hugs and smiles (though do occasionally feel rushed to get out at the end of my meal). 
The wine list is deep and complex, full of surprises and new friends.
Also, the Prosciutto di Parma is porky perfection. I can't imagine not liking this place.
author: Celia s.

description:
Outstanding and authentic food.  Deep, rich Mediterranean flavors.  Wine recommendations perfectly matched to the food.  Small, cozy neighborhood feel.  Warm and attentive service.  A husband and wife team who are there every night.   I guess I kind of liked the place.  

My friend is a conservative eater and she loved her meal.  I stuck to the specials -- fennel and fresh sardine salad; fresh pasta (like a thin linguini ) with an octopus and sole ragout.  I was surprised by the richness of the flavors (the food was not overly rich though) and each dish was executed perfectly.

I'm picky about restaurants, and there are only a few that I eat at regularly (mostly neighborhood restaurants that care deeply about their customers and their food -- e.g., woodwards garden, delfina, universal cafe).   I've definitely found a new one to add to the list.
author: Jim K.

description:
I might have had too high expectations for my first visit to La Ciccia and that's why the 2 somewhat bland pasta dishes that we've tried and the very limited desserts list came a bit short.

But nothing was really bad either, the service was good and friendly and it doesn't hurt that you can park easily in the neighborhood.

I'll give them 4 stars for now and will be back soon to see if they hold.
author: Tommy D.

description: Very fresh and delicious cuisine.  And unusual dishes which you don't often find in the states. Definitely make a reservation.  This place is almost always busy-a testament to their food, because the location is less than ideal and the parking can be difficult, but the food is in fact worth it.
author: sarah b.

description: this is the best autentic italian/sardinian cucine in san francisco. i am sardinian and i feel at home every single time i am there and make me less nostalgic of my mother food. good food,good service and no mention the host/owner/cook. thank you max and lorella to be such a good host and friends.
author: J P.

description:
I'm not really sure why everyone has been telling me how great this place is. I'm wondering if those in love with their overly oily, greasy, relatively flavorless food and mediocre service hasn't been to Italy and therefore isn't used to the type of food that we call Italian. 

My special tagliatelle pasta with mushrooms was overcooked. The pasta was mushy, drenched in oil, and the mushrooms were overdone and had lost their flavor. My girls wild boar dish of maccheroni was marginal, not great, and definitely not worth the drive out to 30th when so many other places could satiate our Italian needs and much better. The octopus starter was good, but didn't make up for the rest of the food that really was nothing but blah. My server didn't know anything about the wine list, so I'm glad that the bottles I ordered were good considering I'm not too familiar with Sicilian wine at all, just Italian and French. We were offered no olive oil, balsamic, or any other accoutrement with our bread, just "Are you ready to order?" and no helpful comments about the menu in any way shape or form. Some of my friends are diehards for the place, but they're alcoholics (no judgement, as I'm in the club as well) anyway and I'm thinking that they're just drunk before they get there and cold Domino's pizza would probably suffice for the evening in their state. 

Maybe I've just become a true food snob, but this place is not up to par and the atmosphere is nothing to speak of. I would pass, without remose. We had five people, and the bill was 350.00. Not worth that, or an even hundo if you asked me for what we got. Big disappointment.
author: Danielle S.

description:
sardinian cusine. wow, ive always said italian and african american diets are very similar to a korean diet but.....

sardinian cuisine? 

walking past the kitchen, i swear it couldve been mama lee cooking in the back.  

how did i cheer myself up after a bad day? blow a few hundred bucks on a couple bottles of OUTSTANDING sardinian wine. sounds like a plan. i forget the names of the wines, but i will note them later.... and might as well blow a bit more chunk of change on some very interesting dishes that seemed so familiar, yet this was the first time trying them. 

some highlights.

pork loin, wrapped with suckling pig.... sliced thinly. yes it was freaking awesome.

fegulla, sardinian cous cous. oh man texture texture texture. and flavors? bacony, buttery, savory. you cant ask for more. 

fresh pasta (TEXTURE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!) with cured, shaven tuna heart. WHOA MAMA, not for the faint of heart. my korean palate can handle this. it might be too much for most, but MANALIVE this was badass. 

the staff was beyong friendly. the owner chef came out a few times to to check up on things and even though it was a packed house, he took the extra time to discuss some of the dishes and recommend a second bottle. must note, he didnt upsell, but rather recommended an EXCELLENT pinot noir that stood up to these strong bold flavors but was also fairly reasonably priced. 

all in all i will most definately be coming back here. it reminds me of my mothers cooking strangely enough, with big bold flavors of the sea and land, great staff and shit, its down the hill from my place.
author: Euge L.

description: A warm restaurant that shares their rich love for Sardinian culture and cuisine.
author: Andy C.

description: LOVED LOVED LOVED the gizzards, the capicolla, the pizza bianca, and the sea urchin sauce on pasta. Owners were very sweet and came out to say hello and check on us. Turns out the owners are the chef and the hostess/waitress.  Love their new decor, much more comfy and chill.
author: Marina N.

description: Fabulous food, friendly, knowledgeable service.  The interior is pretty DIY for a restaurant of this caliber, but the quality of the food will quickly make you forget the weak decor.  Honestly, pasta has never been this good.
author: Lester B.

description: Loved the food, the place, the waitress- so full of life, personality and authenticity. It did really feel like a trip to Sardinia. The wines are good, but you have to go with a $50 and up bottle to really get something decent.
author: Tudor H.

description:
My wife and I are still stunned by the overwhelming generosity of Yelpers. Five starts is defined "as good as it gets." Shouldnt you save Five Stars for just one or two restaurants? Apparently we live in a world where everything is "Amazing!"  It seems people in San Francisco are only critical of Republicans, chain stores, and L.A.
Anyway...

 La Ciccia is pretty decent. But it's not "beyond belief" - a definition of "amazing."

The location/site is surprisingly modern, and a bit mundane. Far from charming, IMO. In fact the decor could be for any restaurant, nothing about it feels authentic to Sardinia.

And the food is good. And well-portioned. But the food is DROWNED in olive oil, which tends to suppress other flavors.

Service is good. And yes owner/chef comes out to greet you. BFD. When he came to our table, it was more like he was gloating. Actually he was; He said, "The lamb is really tender, isnt it?
author: M T.

description:
I don't know what to think.

 Seems like discrimination.

We made  reservations through Open Table based on all of the wonderful reviews on Yelp.  We arrived 15 minutes early for our reservation, and we ended up waiting over 30 minutes to be seated.  I would have been ok with the wait if they had not seated 3 parties (that arrived after) before us. I was in shock.  We were dressed appropriately, but how does one explain this.  The woman kept telling us to wait and that they would be with us, but then why did she seat other parties ahead of us if they arrived after us? 
Of course, only after we decided to leave and politely inform them that we were going, did she say that our table was ready.  The nerve.
I was born and raised in San Francisco, but it is so sad to see that the old San Francisco I know is changing, only catering to what they perceive to be the right kind of people.
So in the end we left and went to a place that I know I would not discriminate against me, Blowfish Sushi to Die For.  We had great service, great food, fun people watching and a nice place to sit and have dinner.
author: A R.

description: Neighborhood Gem restaurant with amazing food, good wine and friendly service. Southern Italian Seafood and flavorful dishes abound. Everything was amazing. A great value for the price as well. The baked calamari  and sardines appetizers were perfect. Excellent wines as well. Will be  back, possibly the best Italian in town.
author: J B.

description: My favorite restaurant in San Francisco, and outside of Italy. I hesitate to post a review because it will be even harder to get a seat. But what makes this restaurant great besides the wonderful Sardinian food is the hospitality that Massimiliano and Lorella give to everyone who walks through their door. I feel like I'm eating at their house.
author: Laura F.

description:
Mamma Mia ! Wow what a great find. Happened by one nite in SF most unusual combinations of Italian flavors. I enjoyed the s
Spaghettituso con alio and sardines. Service was great and priced right. Want to go and eat now!
author: Rose M.

description: Delicious melt-in-your-mouth italian goodness, Welcoming owners who make you feel like you're invited over for dinner, Vegetarian-friendly, Same day or next day reservations available on Open Table, Extensive quality wine list, Great value.  It's by far our favorite restaurant in SF and we go regularly.  Check it out - spoil yourself.
author: Redwood T.

description:
La Ciccia is without doubt our favorite restaurant in the Bay Area.  It touches all the bases.  

First, the food is outstanding.  Chef Massimo prepares a tight menu using fresh ingredients with great flavors.  We usually bring our kids and eat family style.  It is Sardinian fare, which you simply don't find anywhere.

Second, the wine list is eclectic and deep for a restaurant of this size.  If you like to try interesting Italian wines, this is for you.

Third, the service is excellent.  We are always treated well; indeed, we are welcomed like family every time we come back.

They are getting popular, so make sure you call for a reservation.  Also, give yourself a few minutes for parking.  Sometimes, we find a spot right away, other times we have to drive around.
author: Robert S.

description: Good italian food. Great place for date.
author: D Z.

description:
This restaurant is the best Italian (Sardinian specifically) you can get in the City.  They have a wonderful menu, cook authentic dishes (After having lived in Italy for 4 years this was like a travel back to Italy) with the special touches Italians make when they cook.

It is definitely an excellent value for the quality of food.  If you have not tried this neighborhood restaurant, you are missing out on a wonderful culinary experience.  Their wild boar is great (which I believe is seasonal).
author: christina a.

description:
weird

the food was ok  - nothing particularly creative or spectacular to write home about. everything was al la carte so it ended up fairly pricey.

we decided the service was bizarre after a few odd incidents. the finale was - when i asked the waiter who happened to bring a solo dish of spinach to the table if our entrees would be far behind she snapped that she only had 2 hands??!! 

now that is fine dining service.......makes you feel very welcome.
author: debora s.

description: We went to La Ciccia to celebrate our anniversary, and had a great night. The octopus (daily appetizer special) was really great, we shared the great gnocchetti with pork meats and and pecorine, and had a good lamb )although enormous portion). The 2000 Barolo "Bussia" Azienda Agricola Prunotto worked well ith the 1st cource and main, although maybe a little too "hard" in my taste, especially considering the age. The really great service means that they deserve 4 stars, which I dont give easily.
author: Kaj HeGe H.

description: Overall I wasn't too impressed by this place.  The Matre'd is really nice and the service is very personable and it's a cool little noisy place which was fun with the group I was with.  We had a sliced meat app which was just OK.  The meat was a little chewy but tasty.  We had the seafood salad which was ok.  For main dishes I had the sea bass which was pretty tasteless.  The pizza was ok but I don't like sheep cheese so it had a funny taste to me.  The steak was a little chewy and the best thing was the spaghetti with clam sauce, very tasty.  The waitress also picked a nice bottle of wine.  Their wine selection is pretty good.  Overall, the food was just OK but it's a fun place in a mellow area.
author: Mitch A.

description:
Delightful seafood and sturdy pasta. The entire party enjoyed the wonderful food at La Ciccia. We started with the grilled calamari and the octopus stew. Both were superb - tender and flavorful. Then we had the pasta special of Angus beef with rigatoni, spaghetti with bottarga, linguine with fish, and grilled shrimp with cauliflower. Everything was delectable; we enjoyed every morsel. Dessert was a trio of gelati - chocolate almond, marsala raisin, and goat cheese and fig. It was a wonderful ending to a delicious meal. 

The dining room was cramped but cozy. They definitely pack it in. While walking to our table, my purse almost swiped the glass off another patron's table. That would have been bad. The service was good and unfussy. We'll definitely be back. La Ciccia is a gem in Noe Valley.
author: J W.

description: Dropped here without a reservation and sat at the bar my friend and I shared the margharita pizza and it was heavenly just like the pizzas i've had on my trips to Italy srevice was outstanding - attentive, friendly and knowledgeable I will definitely be coming here soon for a sit down dinner    It is small but I really like the ambiance here !
author: lyn m.

description: This place is A-MAZING!! I went here when my brother was in town, and it is the single best place in SF for an Italian (ok, it's Sardinian) meal.  The wine list is fantastic.  Buy one from them if you decide to bring your own and they'll waive the corkage fee.  The Octopus Stew is unlike anything I have ever had.  The Octopus was so tender & it really melted in your mouth.  Basically EVERYTHING here is good.  The chef came to our table twice to talk to us during our meal.  Overall, the service was great, food was outstanding.  I will definitely be back.
author: Gillian M.

description: My friend took me here for a birthday dinner and the food AND service were both excellent. We were treated like family even after coming 30 minutes late for our reservations. (oops!) We had the clams and mussels for appetizers which were delicious especially the broth it came in. And we tried the octopus soup which was like butter! (And I'm not a fan of octopus either.) And then we had the linguine with crab that was soooo tasty, followed by the awesome lamb. I normally get full pretty quickly, but I made myself eat it all because it was just too good not to. :)
author: Clogozm C.

description: Warm and attentive service, excellent big-tasting food and generous portions. Unusual ingredients such as sphagettini with shaved tuna heart and ravioli with chicken gizzards make it that much more special. And the Sardinian red wine is quite tasty.
author: Yogi B.

description:
Based on the good reviews here on Yelp, I went to La Ciccia last night with some friends.  I'm happy to say we were not disappointed.  We wanted to do family style, so the waiter recommended we do two appetizers, first and second courses (for three of us).  Here's what we had:

Sardines, Octopus Stew
Spaghetti Bottariga, Rigatoni w/ Lamb Ragu (Special)
Tuna w/ Olives, Lamb Tenderloin

The highlights for me were the octopus stew and bottariga.  The sauces for both had a nice heat to it that didn't overwhelm.  The Rigatoni and Lamb Tenderloin were outstanding as well.  The pasta (rigatoni and spaghetti) had a great chewy texture to it and held the sauces really well.  I don't have fresh pasta all that often so it's a bit surprising when its the highlight of the dish.  Must do it more often.
