The sardines were good but it was a bit difficult to eat around the bones - while I'd normally just eat them they were a bit too hard in sardines of this size.  The tuna was tasty as well but didn't really do it for me the way the rest of the dishes did.

We even split two desserts - the ricotta and saffron cake and a trio of gelato they had for a special.  I enjoyed the cake but thought the gelato was much better.  

All this and two bottles of wine made for a great and satisfying evening.  

Oh yeah, and the service was excellent as well.  Very friendly and helpful in making recommendations for food and wine.  I'm marking this as a go to restaurant next time people visit from out of town.  Highly recommended.
author: Mike U.

description:
I am Italian, although not from Sardinia. I am therefore surprised that some people speak of "Italian" food as big bowls of pasta with thick tomato sauce... That is NOT "Italian" food, that is bad Italian American food, what you get in the majority of restaurants in the US. And I am afraid that this is the comparison term, but alas on the positive side, for those who find the food here blend. 
This is excellent, simple, regional food. No French or Californian novelle cuisine, no fusion, no Alinea or Schwa, so if this is what you are looking for, do not come here (prices, fortunately, are accordingly much lower).
But this is truly good Sardinian food, which means it's also good ITALIAN food. Excellent pastas with seafood, excellent meat, salumi, and dessert. I can't speak for the "secondi di pesce" (what you would call here fish main courses) because I came here only once and didn't try it, but I am pretty sure I would find them as good. I could try a variety of things because we were four people, and I liked everything, especially the pasta with bottariga and the one with tuna.
The service was very good. I very much doubt people are discriminated for racist reasons, and people should always think twice before accusing of such a shameful thing (and wondering about their own rudeness or lack of understanding instead). 
Come here if you are interested in authentic, good Italian food from one of the best Italian culinary traditions. Don't come looking for cannoli (which, if authentically made, are hard to find anyway) or what you are used to in Italian American restaurants. It's not worth it, in every sense.
author: Sara P.

description: Never had Sardinian food before.  It's like a country cousin of Italian food and totally yummy in a different way.  Bourdain just reminded me that I had to review this place lest it slips my mind.  The fresh spaghetti with spicy oil and Bottarga sticks in my head as sublime genius and in itself worth the long trip back to Noe Valley.  This is really a 4.5 star place in my opinion.
author: Chris C.

description:
La Ciccia takes over the space of a pizzeria whose demise goes unlamented.  The interior has been redone in a simple but comfortable manner.  Though the gray haze pouring out ot the front door when I entered was disconcerting, I was assured that the kitchen "incident" that had provoked it was under control.

The menu consists entirely of Sardinian specialities; or at least that is what they told me.  Having never been to that part of Italy, I can not vouch for its authtenticity.  However, most of the items on the menu (except for some pizzas) were new to me.  They most definitely reflected the best of rustic Italian cooking -- a few simple flavors melded together to create a wonderful dish.  If you like Incanto, a few blocks away, you should definitely try La Ciccia.  I am not sure whether it as good (that will take more visits) but its approach to food is very similar.

Prices are reasonable ($17 for most entrees) and the wine list is modestly priced.  The wines are all Italian.  Some are recognizable but many are from Sardinia.  I had two glasses of Sardian wine.  The white was quite good while the red tasted a bit "fishy" but went well with my tuna.

The service is friendly.  Joe Bob says check it out.

SFD

Update: I have been back here severl times since my first review and it continues to impress.  I have given it 5 stars.
author: Peter H.

description: SKIP THIS RESTAURANT.  I did not like it.  I'll spare you the details.
author: Chad K.

description:
I was very excited to see some hype about the opening of La Ciccia in the Chronicle and Daily Candy, if for no other reason than it might bring some attention to the sometimes sleepy Noe Valley dining scene (excepting the wonderful Firefly, of course).  The space La Ciccia occupies is fairly tiny and the lights are too bright -- I suggest the owners soften them to create a more romantic vibe.  We started off with some salads and one of the terrific pizzas.  I was expecting a Neopolitan style pie, charred a bit around the edges, but was nonetheless quite pleased with the slightly doughier but tasty version created here.  Entrees were not quite as delicious as the appetizers, but were promising.  The chocolate dessert (can't remember its name -- starts with a T, I think) was excellent.  Wine list is impressive and quite reasonable.  Actually, all of the prices at La Ciccia are reasonable.

The owners are a husband and wife pair from Sardinia.  I believe the husband toiled away at several SF restaurants before setting up his own shop, including my personal favorite Italian, Antica Tratorria.  The wife takes care of the front of the restaurant in a very maternal way, checking in on tables and serving the wine.  She makes eating here a very warm and cozy experience.

Bottom Line: room for improvement on the entrees, but all in all, a wonderful homey new restaurant in Outer Noe Valley.
author: L G.

description: Not sure if it's Sardinian food or just La Ciccia's food but I wasn't too impressed with the dishes we had. I think they had boned up on the service bc it was quite gracious and not too slow. The decor is pretty sterile. I kind of felt like I was eating in some diner that was attached to a motel. Good wines though!
author: Helen K.

description: Very delicious Sardinian food, which means they specialize in seafood. The home-made pasta dishes were marvelous. Good service, cozy neighborhood find.
author: Esme V.

description: We were one hour late due to we did not read the address carefully and we drove to the other side of the town.  It was full house, lady boss seat us in front the bar still.  I am not a pasta lover, but I can tell it was freshly hand made.  It taste totally different  with the dry pasta. I love the white fish and squid ink pasta.
author: Jeni S.

description: Italian restaurants in SF vary widely compared to Italian restaurants on the east coast. The one thing that they lack here is that "Someone's about to get wacked" vibe. La Ciccia, while it has a high quality of food and service, does not have that vibe. The menu also reflects this in that if you're hankering for lotsa pasta and cheese or something like Eggplant Parm, forget it. There are enough other "gourmet" as opposed to "everyday" Italian restaurants in SF that you can go to a different one every week for a year. Oddly, they dont serve iced tea, nor did my soda come with ice, but I suppose that's what they do in Sardinia.
author: Greg H.

description: I love the pasta here.  It's a small place but I love the feeilng of it.  The service wasn't bad but not great.  Great date spot.
author: Luci B.

description: This is a wonderful Sardinian Restaurant and extra special as it is family owned. We went for my husbands b-day dinner, just the 2 of us - and it was a wonderful experience. The food was delicious as was the vino and dessert! The service was great and helped up make up our minds on what to order...and were not dissapointed! I had the Pan Seared Ahi served with Saffron Onions (amazing) and my husband had the Seared Lamb Tenderloin served with Mushrooms (wow!) the dessrt was a lemonchello like ice cream with this unique crunchy exterior - cleansed the pallet! Prego! This is a gem! Can't wait to go back!!
author: SF N.

description: Was excited to go & try this place, heard about it on Check Please Bay Area.  The place was crowded & noisy & the menu selection very narrow - no non- meat choices.  The food tasted good,  but didn't make up for the unsettling environment.  The service was polite but not great.  Pricey.  Not worth returning.
author: Sarah F.

description:
3 Stars seems wrong but 4 Stars is too much. 3.5 Yelp Stars

They have great service - nice and friendly staff. The cook came over to our table often to check on us and gave us an extra dish. Its definitely a local restaurant filled with people from the neighborhood.

I do want to note that its raved here for the wine but our server didn't even ask us if we wanted wine or any drinks. Maybe the server was really busy or his English was limited, or we looked underage(yeah right!) but we were definitely overlooked on the beverage part. 

Food was good but not great. My favorite was the fresh pasta with sea urchin. Their seafood is really fresh. I thought the octopus soup was too salty. Pizza had a nice crust. Did not like the ravioli and ink.
author: Sylvia H.

description: I guess people like it. The waiters were really, really nice. The wine list was extensive. The place was packed with trendy, well-off people. I just didn't like the food.
author: Sylvester G.

description: I guess all the outstanding reviews are turning La Ciccia into a "destination" restauant.  Friday night I tried walking in without a reservation and they were booked for the rest of the night.
author: Reality Check S.

description:
Who should dine here:  This is one of the best examples of a quality neighborhood place, that really takes pride in its food.  If you live in Noe/Castro/Glenn Park area check it out.  Worth a trip from further out if you like authentic Italian (not north beach Italian).
 
1 Star - Lacking/Turn Off
2 Stars - Needs Work, But fixable
3 Stars - Adequate
4 Stars - Near perfect, rough edge here or there
5 Stars - Can't get much Better
 
Ambience/Atmosphere: 3 stars.  The atmosphere here is what you would expect for a neighborhood joint.  Its not hip, its not really exciting, just comfortable and inviting.  A great feel for a weeknight dinner with significant other or friend.  They have done a good job of adding a touch of elegance.  There is a small bar (about 3 or 4 seats), if you are flying solo and want a quick dinner and a good glass of wine.  
 
Service: 4 stars.  I was actually surprised by the service.  Our waiter was excellent.  He knew the menu, and had a great deal of expertise on the wine list (a rarity at a place like this).    He really did everything right, he was there when we needed him, and there wasn't a single time when I felt something was lacking, was taking too much time, or needed attention.  The chef came out half way through our meal to give us a try of the wild boar stew (I had originally ordered this, but since it takes an hour I switched), which was a nice touch.   
 
Food: 4 stars.  I think the food rivals Incanto as some of the most authentic Italian in the city.  It is different from Incanto in style, keeping tightly to its Sardinian roots.  We started with the lentil soup and a special, crostini's done three ways.  The lentil soup was really tasty (from what I understand, didn't reach over for a taste), and the crostini's were awesome (although the one with Octopus was a tiny bit fishy. the others were chopped porcini mushrooms and traditional tomato bruschetta).  For mains we had a pasta in white wine sauce with porcini mushrooms and the lamb chops.  The lamb chops were incredible.  Had a fantastic rub/herb oil on them, and were cooked rare.  The meat melted in my mouth, very good, and highly recommend.  I didn't try the pasta, but my dining companion mentioned that the dish was very good (there was nothing left when he was done, so I am taking this as a positive).   The deserts were a mixed bag.  We had a barely pudding (kind of like a rice pudding) that was weird, mostly due to texture.  However, we also got a chocolate mousse cake that was really great.  It was very rich, but not heavy.
 
Wine: 4 stars.  Like Incanto, La Ciccia knows how to build a list around its menu.  All Italian, which it should be, given that it is an Italian restaurant.  We had a fantastic Barbaresco for only $49.  I felt the list was priced well and the variety was really great.  At some point they may want to cut out a couple of the regions and add a little more focus, but other than that they have done I think the best job I have seen on a wine list for a restaurant of this type.  For most people the names on the list will seem unfamiliar so I would encourage you to ask for some guidance. 9 out of 10 times I bring my own wines to restaurants, I can say I will probably not ever do that here. 
 
Overall: 4 stars.  Lets just say I was extremely pleased as well as pleasantly surprised by my visit to La Ciccia.  I will definitely be returning in the near future.  Well done.
author: Scott P.

description: 3.5 stars. The wait staff was super attentive and made us feel right at home. The seafood was good. After reading many reviews, I had the sardines appetizer. It was tasty, but nothing too special. Their pasta special, on the other hand, was exotic and pretty good tasting - pasta w/ sea urchin and shaved tuna heart (yum!). But the rest of the meal was just OK. I would come back to try something else on their menu.
author: Fanny L.

description: Is a Sardinian restaurant without horse on the menu, truly authentic??  Maybe not, but with this couple cooking and hosting you as if you were in their home, you cant help but love this place.  Great Sardinian dishes like Spicy baby octopus, great Bottarga pastas, comforting lamb stew.  I have never tried the pizza but the pizza isn't that good in Sardinia anyway! The wine list is phenomenal..
author: George M.

description:
This restaurant is a true gem.  The food is excellent and unique.  I have never tasted anything quite like it.

The dessert of Ricotta with Saffron and Sardinian honey was AMAZING, just like the rest of the food there.

I do, however, agree with what some other people have said about the staff.  They were a bit odd and came off slightly snooty, but I think it was more from a lack of English language skills that genuine hostility towards the customers.
author: Stephen R.

description: The food and atmosphere was all amazing.  However, I must give this restaurant two stars because of the service.  I had made reservations for two on my wifes birthday at 9 PM.  I had even spoken to the owner - twice- about them.  When we arrived, she had no reservation, and treated me as though I were lying about reservations.  I had to show here the two calls I made to prove I was not lying.  We ended up waiting 45 minutes for a table (luckily my wife is easy going).  The owner offered us wine, but made it seem as though it were complimentary due to their error.  Alas, it was not, and we were charged in the end.  Talk about adding insult to injury.
author: Richard H.

description: The owners are wonderful, the food is outstanding. This restaurant is a right on winner. You won't be sorry ----
author: Marty R.

description: Went over the weekend with my family, you definitely need a reservation, otherwise it's hard to get seated. I wasn't particularly impressed at all. I tried the Costisceddasa de Angioni Arrustidasa (seared lamb chops) and the Spezattinu de Sirboni (braised wild boar) and it looked and tasted just like mom's stew (although it seems like they're authentic Sardinian dishes). The service was great and friendly, the owner was there and greeted us, and the wine selection is indeed extensive, but I don't think I'm coming back...
author: Stephanie L.

description: Hands down the best Italian restaurant in the city (though technically, it serves a Sardinian food)!  The uni pasta, colossal shrimp, octopus stew, squid ink pasta are just some of my favorites.  I love how the menu changes every few months.  The restaurant itself is small (but not too small) and intimate.  A very sweet spot for date night!
author: Sandy W.

description: Really enjoyed my dinner at this wonderful Italian spot.  Food was delicious and fresh.  The service was wonderful and left me feeling incredibly welcome.  I loved the giant baked prawns!
author: Johnnie T.

description: Yes, I am giving it 5 stars. I do have a tendency to be generous if I like a restaurant, but this place really deserves it. We ordered the traditional flat bread, oven roasted sardines, spaghetti with clams and shaved tuna heart (sounds weird but SOOO good- just adds a necessary depth of flavor), whole roasted fish, an Israeli couscous like pasta dish with squid ink, and an assortment of desserts- trio of gelato, including goat milk with fresh figs, a saffron flavored gelato, and also hazelnut, as well as a sheeps milk ricotta cake with honey. All items were out of this world! The bill came to a little over  $50/person and that included wine and coffee. So, not cheap, but a lovely place for a special meal, and you get the added bonus of authentic regional Sardinian food made by a chef from Sardinia.
author: Sonal B.

description: I really liked this place.  The service was fantastic and the food was really, really good.  Holding off on the 5th star until another visit, but I can easily see it getting there.  We had a great tuna appetizer special and I had the macaroni with lamb ragu.  Seriously good. Extensive wine list, we had a good bottle of primitivo at a very reasonable price.  Highly recommend.
author: Jen S.

description:
Massimo and Lorella, I love you guys.

Food, wine, service, authenticity, comfort.. are all on it.

It's been a couple moths since I've gone and I'm starting to get the shakes.
author: Nick H.

description: Cute little neighborhood Italian restaurant!  I really enjoyed a signature pasta dish w/ the shaved, cured tuna heart - trust me, it tastes much yummier than it sounds.  The trotter was a bit much but if you don't mind your cholesterol level spiking or have a Lipitor to chase it down with, go for it!    The wine selection seems quite extensive.  If you have a smaller party (e.g. 2-3, sitting at the bar is fun and cozy.  I actually prefer the ambience of the bar over the main dining area - you'll get to watch the food action!
author: FoodJunkie S.

description:
We took a chance and walked in late one night (not a chance on the restaurant, just chancing getting a table - difficult to get a reservation!). Have been trying to come here every time we visit from Los Angeles, but they've either been closed for the summer, or not serving lunch, or closed Mondays... Well, it was well worth the wait, as the meal was incredible! Calamari and Octopus apps - simply awesome. Spagetti with bottarga - a must, their signature dish, incredible. Linguine with squid ink - blew my mind in the best possible way. And the dessert...Ricotta and saffron cake...aaaahhh sooooo goooood!!! 
The couple that own the place are just lovely, and so completely on top of what they do. At first glance, it seems like "simple" home cooking in a small restaurant, but it is so much deeper than that. Truly wonderful. A meal I will remember for a very, very long time. A million times THANK YOU!!
author: lili s.

description: I have not traveled to Italy, but I am guessing authentic regional cooking and WOW, it was wonderful..
author: Bleep S.

description: La Ciccia was a "destination" restaurant for us when we lived on the peninsula. Now that we live in Noe, we're lucky enough to be able to walk there whenever we want. The food is homey and made with love. Two of my favorites are the seafood salad with out-of-this-world dressing, and pasta with tuna heart. The wine list is extensive, and the waitstaff never fail to recommend the perfect wines for us. Finally, Lorella manages to make everyone feel at home with her gracious hospitality.
author: Lee S.

description:
Ok Ok Ok --- this is the place! 
Oh so authentic and fresh. Husband and wife are cooking/serving the most real food you can get. Ingredients are a mix of local seafood and Sardinian imports that are absolutely amazing in taste and texture! But you are in a real "local" cuisine temple... If you are not ready for it you are going to be very disappointed. 
Keep your fancy dates that want bread dipped in olive oil at 54 Mint or some equivalent show places. 
This one is for real food lovers, ready to discover what true Sardinian cooking is. 
Example: My freshly made pasta was made of sea urchin and grated tuna heart (yes, tuna heart grated on top of sea urchin pasta)...is you can handle it, go for it, this is one of my best diner so far this year. 
The wine list is also absolutely stunning. I believe I bought the last Negroamaro Salento "Patriglione" Azienda Agricola Taurino 1999, but if they have one hidden in the back beg for it (I believe the owner wants to keep it for herself)!
Unique place. Real Chef. Amazing Service. Just play the game and don't ask them for spaghetti meat balls with grated Parmigianino because they are going to rightfully kick you out. 
Love it!!!!
author: Fraise T.

description: I was here recently with 3 friends and as always, since I had suggested it, I was hoping they would like it. They loved it!  The food is so good and not your usual Italian fare (though there is nothing wrong with Italian food!). It is heavy on the seafood/fish items which was ok with us. This was my second time here and I liked it as much as the first time. Service was very good with a charming waitress (am I allowed to use that word anymore?). The guy who greeted us could have been friendlier. He acted as if we did not have a reservation - we did, via Open Table. However, we got a nice table and had a great evening there.
author: Tom B.

description: We stopped in here without reservations on a weekend night (pretty early) and the place was fairly full, but they got us a table.  Everyone was extremely friendly, and the owner came out to make sure we were enjoying our mozarella (which we were).  The food was very classic, good flavors, nothing extremely complex or gourmet.  We had a good food and a good evening.
author: Erik C.

description: Fabulous food, great wine selections, great service! The octopus soup and the flatbread are a must.
author: Dominique B.

description:
Great neighborhood restaurant with good service and wine list.  
Tables are squeezed into the small space but clearly it's a popular destination as the room was packed early.  The special ravioli was delicious, much better than the other pasta we ordered off the regular menu.  Minus 1-1/2 stars for a $2 charge on olive oil if you ask for some to go with your bread.  that just rubbed us the wrong way.
author: koelegir l.

description: Love this place! Great flavors, super service. Loved the baby octopus and fresh sardines. Always at the top of the list of places to go when we don't know what to have for dinner.
author: marc S.

description: This place is amazing!  Lorella and Massimo make you feel right at home when they serve you their fabulous fare.  Take a date or go with friends, either way, you'll have a great time!
author: Hayden M.

description:
So warm and inviting. Feels truly like you are walking into a Sardinian kitchen. The restaurant is small with maybe ten-fifteen tables. The wine menu is completely Italian wines.  We asked for suggestions for and the waiter poured us a few reds that he thought went well with our meals.  (Waiters, all male, seemed to all be Italian with thick accents, they were all dressed in hip jeans and tight button down black shirts. Definitely not bad to look at ). Both wines were very good and did pair well with our food. 

The menu is small but has a great assortment of dishes. And they seem to always have additional specials. To start I order the Clam and Calamari for an appetizer which came in a delicious tangy broth.  My boyfriend ordered the seafood salad with lemon sauce (clam, prawns, calamari, and mussels) the seafood salad was served warm and was also delicious. For dinner we decided to by pass the entrees and just order pasta. I order the Sardinian Fergula (basically Israeli Couscous) with mushrooms and pancetta. It was great and very savory. My boyfriend ordered Gnocchiette with pork meat. The sauce was perfectly flavored with a peppery hint.  The portions were perfect and we left feeling very satisfied. At the end of the meal the chef stopped by to inquire if the meal was going well. I always love when the chef makes a point to chat with the customers so this little extra definitely made me smitten.
They also seem to do take out (at least the pizzas) so I will be making pilgrimages back when I am too lazy to cook.  I would suggest making reservations on weekends as the restaurant was definitely full.
author: Courtney R.

description: I can't believe I've lived in Noe Valley for a year and half and haven't visited La Ciccia sooner.  1st of all, La Ciccia means belly or baby fat in Italian.  Love it.  They are incredibly friendly and welcoming - the chef popped out to check on us and see if we liked our dishes.  And the food is fantastic.  A radiccio and sopressata pizza.  Fall-off-the-bone tender ribs with a great tomato sauce.  And the prawns are simple and delicious.  Topped off with a scoop of hazelnut gelato served drizzled with aged balsamic vinegar.
author: Kelli R.

description: An amazing neighborhood find! Truly authentic cuisine from a very niche part of Italia -- this may be a new venture into Italian food for a lot of diners. The service was friendly and fun, as is the vibe of the entire restuarant. Highly recommended.
author: Daniela F.

description: A great, family run, Italian spot that's not a destination but perhaps should be.  As things stand, it's basically a neighborhood spot in a quiet part of Noe Valley.  It's easy to become a fan, regardless.  Great Italian meats and cheeses.  A range of entrees that includes pastas, pizzas, and heartier options.  I went with the pizza special -- a white pizza with fontina and radicchio.  Excellent.  I probably shouldn't have had that last piece, however.  We shared a blood orange sorbet for dessert that was absolute heaven.  The service is very friendly.
author: Jason H.

description: The worst thing about this restaurant is that it's so close to my house. The temptation to eat here every night may land me in the poor house, morbidly obese, or with my ruptured organs showered all over the shocked and unsuspecting patrons of this fine establishment. Not that I wouldn't crawl on bloody stumps through the desert just to get a taste of that braised octopus, because I would. I had a warm, fuzzy feeling from the first moment I walked in to make a reservation. I gave the stout Sardinan matriarch my first name, and as soon as she heard it, the rest of the conversation took place in Italian, hers heavily Sardinified and mine just plain rusty. They were (deservedly) booked solid the whole weekend, despite this, she managed to conjure up a spot for two out of thin air. Thank God. We powered through multiple dishes involving two of my very favorite things to eat: tentacles and squid ink. We had planned a variety of post dinner activities, but our meal lasted no less than three hours. We didn't even notice the passage of time, and neither did they. The lack of salt on the table seems to be a contentious issue, but after a while I gratefully ceded my urge to micromanage the chef's affairs, and gladly capitulated, trusting that I was in good hands. And yes, we were so stuffed that we refused the dessert menu, but they, undoubtedly having noticed my ecstatic raving throughout the evening, were not about to let us get away without trying the semifreddo, which they comped. Guess what? It was to die for. In fact, had I burst like the Infamous Mr. Creosote, it would have been just fine, because I would have died happy, and not totally destitute.
author: El G.

description: I've been wanting to come here since it opened but had not yet had the opportunity until finally a friend booted me into action.  And I am so sad that I've missed out this whole time.  Had some lovely prosecco and the seafood salad to start.  The "salad" is warm and overflowing with perfectly cooked squid with a tasty broth that cries out for extra bread to mop it up.  For our second courses, we shared the pizza a sa sarda with amazing whole milk mozzarella and a pasta special topped with a lamb ragu.  I was still thinking about the lamb the next day -- that's pretty significant for someone who is usually thinking about what to eat for her next meal.  Service was lovely, a little slow at one point, but the server apologized profusely for that.  I can't wait to return. :)
author: Nat K.

description: Move over, matzoh! My new favorite unleavened bread is Sardinian flatbread, which is good enough reason to try La Ciccia, though I was dismayed to find out their flatbread is not made on the premises, but imported from Sardinia. The food is very good. The restaurant is nosier than I prefer and the noise makes it difficult to hear the nice waiter explain the night's specials. They sounded like "raviolis something something something goat something." Turned out to be raviolis with a goat meat sauce, which my nonmarital spouse said was good. I had the pizza margherita, which I enjoyed. Still not as good as that in New Haven or NY, but what can you do? We both had mixed greens with sapa onions. Very nice dressing.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description:
Fantastic!  Set with a modern feel, the atmosphere was very crisp, yet inviting.  The servers, all Italian, and all very friendly.  And, well, the food...the reason you go....was fantastic.   Some of the best I've had in SF.  The Wine selection was truly wonderful, and they are excellent at pairing.  The reason it only gets 3 stars....while we had a wonderful time and enjoyed the meal, I felt rushed from course to course.  We like to lounge as we dine.  Plus, it was Very crowded - it seemed as if they were trying to get us out to fill the table with their next customers.  That said, you won't be disappointed eating here.  True, high-quality, authentic modern-Italian  cuisine
.
author: David L.

description: Wish I could eat here every week, holding back on the fifth star until I've had more things on the menu.  I just wanted to second the emotion of all the La Ciccia lovers.  This place has deceptively simple, scrumptious authentic (so I hear) food with a wine list chock full of very affordable delicious Sardinian wines that go amazingly with the food.   I feel like this is a place you either "get" or don't and maybe that accounts for other peeps bad time there.  I have only had lovely service there.
author: Shona M.

description: I've been going to La Ciccia since it opened. Unlike some of the other reviewers I'll spare you the unfunny and uninteresting details of my life - I'll keep it short and simple: La Ciccia has a great wine list, an inspiring menu and wonderful service.
author: LeeAnn G.

description: Good food - get the homemade salamis/antipasto.  Creative Italian wine list (i.e. Sardinian gems).  Cramped space unfortunately.
author: babsie g.

description: This was my first time having Sardinian food and I loved it.  The octopus stew was my favorite - so very flavorful.  The bread was also pretty damn good too.  It's a cozy place, so be prepared to have an intimate dinner...with the next table.  I very much appreciated the service - warm, attentive, and relaxed.  I only had seafood this time, but I plan to try the pastas and pizza on my next visit.
author: Eric C.

description: One of the best meals of my life! La Ciccia made me feel like I was back in Sardinia. The atmosphere is warm and the food is outstanding. I can't wait to return.
author: T J.

description:
soooooo goood.  the pizza in particular is absolutely delicious.  

and ask for wine recommendations - they have a lot of very interesting and unfamiliar (to me anyway) wines.

i would give five stars except the service can be a little iffy. 

make a reservation because it can be hard to get in.
author: Liz S.

description:
a tide of heady aromas greets customers at the door. warm, earthy scents that swiftly deliver a feeling of calm and heightened expectations.

a very small, cheerful restaurant, with intimate seating arrangements. dim lighting. banter coming from each table.

the hostess and waiters were convivial and attentive. they had opinions on each dish, and were very familiar with the wines on offer.

a few highlights: the warm seafood salad, a simple bowl of delicately steamed octopus in a briny, tomato-based broth, if i remember it correctly. there were shrimp, crabs, clam. the pasta longa cun ventresca - minute pieces of densely flavoured tuna with capers served in what is essentially a puttanesca over linguine.  the intensely salty spaghittusu cun allu ollu e bottariga - a spaghetti with roe - almost overwhelming in its simple muscularity. a real treat.

a very pleasing experience, all of it. i will definitely make a return.
author: christian svanes k.

description:
Happened to go to this place kind of by accident.  Was lucky to get seated.   (packed). 

What a pleasant surprise.  The menu has lots of choices.  I had the Lamb stew.  The broth was fabulous.  The lamb was maybe a tiny bit overcooked.  

My friend ordered the pizza.  At first I thought.  A nice fancy place and you order something ordinary like Pizza.  Turned out to be a winner.  The tastiest sauce and cheese I have ever had on anything resembling a crust.  The cheese was imported directly from Sardinia which is where the owners are from.  Superb.
author: Ralph M.

description: This restaurant was so delicious and authentic, that it inspired my husband and I to go to Sardinia for our honeymoon. We went there on a Wednesday night for my birthday. It felt like a special occasion indeed! Some of the dishes were a little too authentic like the tripe with suckling pig. I loved the pig but could do without the tripe. The pizzas were thin, fresh and smelled of Italy. The fish baked and served whole was the highlight, seasoned very simploy with sea salt, lemon and oregano.  If you have ever traveled or lived in Italy you must go here. The husband and wife owners really add to the whole experience. The wife served us a nice barolo and made food pairing recommendations. The head chef/husband spoke to us in italian and made sure we were happy.
author: Lauren E.

description: Food is excelent, staff is friendly and attentive, wine selection is great!
author: Stas R.

description: The range on the menu is just right and it is all delicious. Service is excellent and the wine selection is huge. The pasta us cooked perfectly, so I definitely recommend these dishes. Tough to get a table on the night before 9pm, so book in advance if you don't want a late evening dinner.
author: g i.

description: I write this reluctantly...because I am still so happy that the awful Pizzeria which once lived there is gone and this space is born again, with a great new energy. We live up the street and really, really want to love this place, but we don't...3 visits, just satisfied, not longing to go back, and can barely recall what we ate. The fish with olives was good, the pasta with pork  was better, and the lentil soup was satisfactory. The wine list is quite impressive, especially if you know and like Italian wine. I love the friendly and warm staff, but the language barrier prevents you from truly understanding them, getting decent input on anything but wine.  It's very loud, but high energy. I will keep trying. Oh, and not kid friendly.
author: elena l.

description:
a gem in noe valley. 
food is distinctively sardinian; simple. loads of fresh seafood. reminded me of mediterranean cuisine. 
not very fancy but comfortable in a very sanfranciscan setting.
author: Bennet A.

description:
Where do Italians go when they want to eat good authentic food from the Old World? They go to La Ciccia - which means fat.  However in this context the slang means "Friend/Buddy" as you would use "Chico/Muchacho" in Spanish.  And this is what the restaurant promise -  a friendly atmosphere with simple but fresh dishes.

We have been to La Ciccia numerous time.  We always order the warm Seafood Salad with Lemon Oil Dressing as appetizer.  It is so tender with a slight hint of citrus infused in the olive oil.  Recently we tried the Pesto pizza which is crispy around the edges and firm in all the right places.  The first time we were there my BF got the Lamb chops and he knew immediately he would love the place.  It was cooked to perfection - nice sears on the outside and juicy red in the middle.  I did not try his plate but he was raving about it.  This time he ordered the fresh pasta di seppia with some kind of fish bits - the special of the evening.  The pasta was very fresh and tasty but he did not care for the tomato fish bits - he thought the sauce was too authentic for his Northern Italian palette.  I ordered the gnocchetti Sardi (not at all similar to their potato gnocchi cousin) - one of my favorite dishes.  These gnocchetti are the specialty of Sardinian cuisine - made from semolina flour - smaller and firmer.  Our friend got the Baked Giant Prawns - she liked it a lot BUT it is a mess to cut into to get to the meat.  Definitely not a date dish.  She had prawn juice squirted on her nice top.  Once we ordered the Sardinian Flat Bread but in the end we realized it can never be as good as home-made.  They get these flat breads from Sardinia but the taste is not the same.  Can't tell you why but we did not like it - I've been to Sardegna and have tested them right off the griddle.  There are no words to explain the simplicity of such a humble bread.

I also recommend the red wine Carignano del Sulcis "Buio" - a lovely dark red colour and a fruitful nose with an excellent drying finish.  I promise you will not go wrong.

Dessert - maybe next time....
author: Veritas V.

description:
I happened upon this restaurant by chance, and went there with a group of 5 friends. We made a reservation (recommended!) and arrived at 8:45pm to find the dining room full and lively. 
The decor is beautifully done - a lovely sky blue paint on flat walls with art hanging tastefully throughout. There is also a dark wooden wine bar, where the owners store a very comprehensive and widely ranged wine list. Both times I've been to this restaurant I have been impressed with the wine. I was also taken with the staff - their depth of knowledge and professional friendliness  - unpretentious, informative, nice (in some cases funny). 
The owners came by our table both times we dined there to receive comments on the food, as well as to "check in" with their guests. One of the owners is the chef. They are both native Sardegnians and that is the flavor the food.
The Food.
Well, the food is really outstanding. I had the boar stew in one sitting and it was absolutely delightful - rich and flavorful, not heavily salted as some chefs are wont to do, with excellent texture to both the broth and the stewed vegetables and the boar itself.  The flavor medley was perfect - I did the "Happy Tummy" dance before I knew it. (yes, its something I actually do, kind of bouncing up and down in my chair - its honestly a completely spontaneous reaction to really great food. Completely spontaneous and inevitably slightly embarrassing.)
I would recommend this for any occasion - except for larger groups. We had 5 in our group and I think it was probably the most I would bring there at once, simply due to the size of the restaurant which is NOT big. It feels cozy rather than tight, but I imagine the two are probably 1-2 seats away from each other.

I recommend this place over pretty much any Italian-style restaurant I've eaten at in the city.
author: Megan B.

description: this place is simple. it just wants to serve you really good food and let you eat it.
author: Fzarond K.

description:
My Italian friend tells me La Ciccia is one of the most authentic Italian restaurants in San Francisco, That's because he does  not know about Stefano's yet (three blocks down on San Jose & 30th).

One thing that he warned me about, though, was the fact that he had noticed the wine was way overpriced. He claims very inexpensive Italian wines are sold at 6 to 8 times the price. The corking fee here is $25. If you don't drink, your pocket might not suffer all that much.

Otherwise, they are warm and make you feel welcome.

Owned by a couple, with the husband cooking and stepping out of the kitchen to provide a personable and friendly service with the clientelle, La Ciccia is a must Sardinian experience for anyone who has ever thought they had had all varieties of Italian food.
author: Nena G.

description:
We came here on Valentine's Day and our reservations weren't until 8  so when we showed up about 45 minutes early because we were so starved I was pleasantly surprised to find that the hostess happily seated us early even through they were completely booked. The place is really small and intimate, which I like, but they could use a little more decor. We ordered the octopus stew to start and it was delicious. For the main plate my husband ordered the lamb which I thought was yummy even through I'm not a big fan of lamb. I ordered the raviolis which were great. The waitress was really attentive and the owner came around to check in on each table. It was a really pleasant experience. The only thing I would change is their website, it could really use a make-over.

PS If you like wine, they have huge list.
author: Natalie F.

description: Great for the seafood lover, very good but somewhat limited options for the vegetarian. I enjoyed the leisurely service/pace. Interesting wine list with mostly things I'd never heard of.
author: Amy E.

description: Wonderful Sardinian cuisine in a homey setting.  Die Die Must Try!
author: F G.

description:
I love this place!  Brought my in laws and 4 y.o. daughter here on Saturday at 6pm - the place was bustling all night long!  In laws said it was worth the trip from the East Bay 'burbs (that's saying a LOT from them).  Let's start with atmosphere -- warm and welcoming, I felt like I was dining in someone's home.  From the owner, Lorella, to her staff, everyone seemed committed to making sure diners were really enjoying themselves.  Lorella stopped by several times to check on our 4 year old, even giving her the Italian names for the dolls she brought with her.  The waiters were savvy about handling a child, keeping an eye on her milk, making a simple pasta for her because we asked, and even double checking the ice cream flavors for her dessert. 

Pacing was perfect!  We ordered family style so we could work our way through the courses.  Everything was fantastic:  aged prosciutto (don't know if they cure there or bring it in), a yummy cracker bread, lentil soup, seafood salad with tiny, tender octopus in an amazing broth that we used to mop up the bread; ravioli with lamb ragu had a lemon zest which gave it a bright and floral hint that truly elevated the dish; pasta with sole was handmade pasta cooked perfectly with a lovely, briny sauce; main courses of halibut over spinach was moist (and big!) and a slow-cooked pork with olives that also included a few pork ribs was meltingly tender.  The food sparkled because it was simple and well-prepared with fresh ingredients and an eye for balance.

Very extensive wine list.  With essentially zero knowledge on Italian wines, they were happy to help, and they made excellent pairing suggestions.

It's not a big place, and it is probably best for groups of 4 (promotes sharing).  We did see a really large party there that night, so with reservations, that seems possible.  The owner even commented that she deliberately kept reservations lighter on this particular Saturday because she knew she had a big party (I'd say there were at least 10 or 12 at the table), and she wanted to make sure the ktichen could do a good job for everyone.  What a concept!  

A gem of a neighborhood restaurant that is worth a drive across town or further.  Trust yourself in their hands -- they love their food and their diners, and they will give you a wonderful evening.
author: Cindy C.

description:
I had dinner last week and it was probably the single most outstanding San Francisco Italian meal I have eaten. We did not have a reservation, but were served at the bar, facing a sheer screen that looked into the kitchen. Best seats in the house! We could watch the procession of dishes and it looked like the chef was practically making love to each dish.  Our waiter was a hoot, and knew every ingredient in the food. He volunteered the menu he had for his birthday recently, and we ordered the octopus stew (fantastic - lots of whole baby octopus in a tomato sauce), the lamb ragout on homemade penne, and the standout was the seafood special made with black pasta (ink included).  Pay attention to the specials and ask to have them repeated. Be bold - try something new! This is not the place for vegetarians or those high maintenance whiners who want to have the dish re-created to suit their tastes. And remember Sardinia is an island...seafood and some sheep running around...so go with the classic seafood choices.
Lorella, the manager, knows every wine on the list, and there's more than 100. The price range is about $19 to $40 per bottle - very reasonable for the quality. She paired it perfectly with our menu. She pays extraordinary attention to detail. The water pitchers were wrapped with napkins, a waiter's corkscrew and napkin were at the ready on the corner of the bar, personal salt and pepper shakers were offered - no details missed. We were among the last customer's, and the chef asked if we would like to sample a seafood special he was working on for the next day. He made us feel like family.
The J Church stops on the corner, and parking wasn't too bad in the residential area surrounding the restaurant.
author: OffToRio B.

description:
I had a great meal here on Saturday night, I think this place is a hidden gem.  I started with their seafood salad which was amazing - lemony light succulant and the calamari was crisp not chewy. For dinner the Safron Fragula (hearty grain thingy) with artichoke sauce that was earthy and delicious.   My companions Lamb was also very very good.
My friend was only going to take a bite of my dessert (the Lemon Tart special for the eveining) but I had to fight him for 1/2! 
We asked the server to recommend a a Red Sardinian wine (when in Sardinia...) and were pleased with her selection.
My only complaints - our service was spotty our server seemed preoccupied and could go away and not return to check on things for what seemed like a looong time.  And for such great food you would think that they would offer great bread to soak up the amazing sauces and juices but it seemed like your garden variety bought at safeway bagette with no flavor and the texture of cardboard.  
But I would still go back
author: Lisa B.

description:
yum. yum. yum.. 

And I'll be back. Food was excellent, and the wine list was fun.
author: Misha M.

description: Great service and great food. My wife and I have been here about 8 times, so you know it's good. We often share food to make sure we can sample everything. At this point, I always start with the Seafood Salad with lemon dressing. Hey, this is not a green salad through which a few shrimp have swam. This is all seafood, enough to share if you're going to have dessert too. Speaking of the dessert, we love the Tartufo (sp?). It is not on the menu yet, but a frequent special. It is like a chocolate snowball. Picture chocolate ice cream frozen hard in a ball, then rolled in cocoa. Yumm
author: Wayne S.

description:
I have been a long time acquaintance of Massimo and Lorella, and although I see but little of them, I consider them dear friends--and how could I not?  They are incredibly gracious, hospitable, self-deprecating to a fault and generous, and their love for the world of food and wine comes through in every joyous gesture.  At La Ciccia, they've become for me a corporeal embodiment of all that makes a neighborhood eatery great.  A genuine sense of warmth pervades here and makes you feel shame for not eating here more often.

The cuisine here attempts to pass itself off as "simple"--or maybe this is just the chef's sense of understating things.  The simplicity is just in the presentation: the intensity and complex soulfulness of the flavors belie easy categorization.  The seafood salad is an oratorio of tentacular delight, where a charmingly light herby nage binds together a multitude of sea-faring voices that are perfectly crispety and crunchety alongside a stray slice of carrot that finishes with a slight tingle of heat.  For the more nautically adventurous, the octopus brings a serious, briny punch to it's tomato sauce, with just the right amount of chew to know you've vanquished the underwater devil.  The tripe is so good, that you can convince a vegetarian that it's ok to eat.  

Flatbreads/pizzetti here are excellent and you should avail yourself of them for the bready portion of your evening.  The pasta's however, deserve particular mention.  As far as I'm concerned, there are damned few places to get perfect pasta in this town, and La ciccia is one of those places.  The kitchen cooks the pasta to utter perfection--just chewy enough to truly appreciate the flavor, just soft enough to draw in a good bit of sauce.  True to its island heritage, many of the pastas find their melodic core in flavors of the sea, but these are beautifully counterpointed by the right amount of herb, fat and acid that it never feels heavy.  The pasta with shaved tuna heart has the perfect level of oceanic funk, that lends depth to the al dente strands without overpowering with a feeling of fishiness (as is the case up the street at Incanto).  Afraid of bottarga?  Don't be--it's so deftly done here that even my non-pescatorial girlfriend was pleasantly surprised and went back for a second helping.  If there's a special pasta of the day that involves "anything but the hooves", well then you should go for it--the layering of flavors from these strange cut-lets and gristly bits adds such an incredible richness to the ragu, that it's downright erotic, for those enamoured of food-porn.

On the wine-side, the list here has one of the coolest selection of italian goodies out there, many of which will challenge the knowledge of even the most die-hard of Italian-philes, and the prices are great.  Lorella's taste is impeccable, so by all means, tell her what you're vaguely looking for and let her (and perhaps Massimo) come up with that somewhat odd and unusual but delicious something from somewhere that you won't find elsewhere.  Muller Thurgau from freaking basilicata?  charming-lass-in-a-summer-frock sort of loveliness.  Be adventurous and your life will be the richer.

The girlfriend is prodding me to add something about the desserts: simple, delicious, and worth saving a little room for.  I mean, who would have thought that a little pistachio ice-cream could be so damn good, never mind that Chocolate hand-grenade of pleasure.
author: Kosuke I.

description:
This is not a review as such because many local yelpers have done such a great job reviewing the seasonal offerings of one of the truly great neighborhood restaurants in California and the entire West Coast.
The attention to the quality and authenticity of ingredients, cooking techniques and taste and texture development is extraordinary.  The result, no matter what the noise, street parking or occasional slips in service, is real food both distinctive and delicious.
The wine list is an inspiration since it is dominated by Sardinian wines which are new experiences for 99% of us.  I tasted 6-7 wines with my friends over the course of a 3-hour dinner and was impressed with the unique tastes that pair wonderfully with the chef/owner's cuisine.  Even if most of the ingredients do come from California, Chef Massimo has learned to adapt them to Sardinian cuisine in a powerful way.
It is interesting that some yelp reviewers give this restaurant low marks.  Most rave about La Ciccia.  Viva la difference;  however, this is a restaurant that should not be missed on a trip to San Francisco.  For the cost of a cab ride from downtown, it is well worth it since prices at restaurants downtown are not to be believed.  Ask me because I dined another night in one of the famous venues and got nose bleed from the bill - and the food was not even close in taste and umami.
PS  I arrived early and sat at the bar reading my newspaper.  A smallish man with very dark hair and intense eyes brought over a taste of wine and a small dish of something that looked like a fish carpaccio.  It turned out to be a slightly pickled onion looking for a future home as an ingredient in the appetizer offerings.  Then the fried Sardinian olives(in Sardinian olive oil) arrived with another Sardinian wine.  Both times he asked what I thought about the onion and olives as well as the wines.  Then I knew I was meeting a chef who was passionate about his food and interested to learn what others thought.  Chef Massimo is a very special member of the SF food scene and deserves the rich patronage of lovers of real food.
author: Shel E.

description: This is a great little neighborhood restaurant!  Very quaint, yet never felt stuffy or crowded.  Our server was very helpful, especially with the wine.  She asked what I preferred and gave me an excellent cab.  I had the gnochetti and slow braised pork; my friend had the basil pizza and we were both stuffed.  Everything was delicious.  The desert was the topper to a wonderful meal.  Parking is difficult as usual on the streets of SF, but overall a great dining experience.  And great to bring a date as well; will definitely try again when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Keith M.

description:
We've been meaning to try this new neighborhood place for a while now, and finally hoofed it down there. A great experience! We started with their mixed greens with balsamic onions, which was tasty, and ordered two white wines by the glass ($8?) which were also excellent.

Our charming waiter had a rather thick accent, but we were seduced by the delicious-sounding specials. We weren't brave enough to try the tuna heart appetizer (see Ed U.'s review below), but I had the homemade macaroni with lamb ragu special, which was very flavorful and had what was (for me) a perfect portion size. Dreamboat had the other homemade pasta special, which featured porcini mushrooms and some other vegetables. Both were great.

Service was gracious and speedy. As others have mentioned, the owners and servers were very friendly and helpful, and sincerely seemed concerned with the quality of our experience. 

For dessert, we shared the pistachio and almond semifreddo, which was light and had plenty of pistachio flavor. Too often, you need a microscope to find the pistachios in pistachio dishes!

Overall, a very pleasant evening. We'll be back.
author: kelly r.

description: This place is the real deal - home cooking like you wish was being cooked in your home.  Why ask why.  Just go there and then you'll know.
author: Carolyn S.

description: Everything was wonderful, especially the pizzas and the octopus stew. They were very friendly and gave our obnoxious birthday party of 20 wonderful service. I can't wait to come back here.  The prices are very reasonable, as are the portions. Although I love pasta, this is by far the best style of Italian food I have every tasted.
author: Renee L.

description: There's obviously a chorus of praise for this little gem of a neighborhood restaurant, and I honestly have no other desire than to join in.  This place is not mind-blowing good, but it's honest and solid food, where you can tell easily that the owners really care about the place and making good food.
author: P B.

description: As I am moving to this neighborhood next month, we decided to look around and try a spot, we ended up here.  Great wine list, had a fantastic borollo.  Started with the cheese plate and head cheese.  They sure know what they are doing with honey and cheese, the headcheese was pretty but we didn't finish the plate, a little bland.  Also tried the spaghetti w/ cauliflower (too chewy and oily) and octopus (very rustic, so if you are squimish, don't get it).  Finally a pizza came out, this was the best flavor of the evening.  I would like to try it out again, the wine list and GREAT service will keep me coming back.
author: e w.

description:
can i tell you how much i love this place?
massimo and lorella - that should be enough, but their wine list, you seriously need the old fashioned "readers" to scour through his vast selections, he has sooooo many that the type gets smaller and smaller.
and the food - thank goodness it is far away otherwise i would be the one called "la ciccia". e v e r y t h i n g is so delicious. 

i wish i -could- go every night. 
AND
I

L
O
V
E 
bottarga ------- 
this place, is real, has heart and has soul in every aspect, every morsel
author: Ceri S.

description:
I'm italian so good italian (not Amercanized) food is hard to come across.  I came here with my Grandpa for his birthday and we were both blown away!  The food was amazing the owner is so sweet. The menu changes daily and the wine was fabulous!!  

Grandpa was off the boat so you really have to be good to wow him with your italian food.  He loved it so much he's going back with 12 of his italian friends from NY just to show them and their east coast italian food up.  

We finished the night with some pecorino and fig gelato.  I know, how can that be good?  Well it wasn't good, it was amazing.  LOVED LOVED LOVED everything about this place!!
author: Carina A.

description: This is a great neighborhood Italian restaurant.  It has a wide variety of flavorful dishes, chatty service, and comfortable style.  It's worth a visit even if you don't live south of market.  Make sure to order the Spaghittusu cun Cabefrori e Bottariga.
author: eli c.

description: Previously reviewed in April 08...still really awesome.  I dreamt about the food and woke up craving my meal the night before.  The service is great and staff very attentive.  Owners always on hand to great customers and make sure everyone is attended to.  Had the Squid appetizer which was like the warm squid salad...hmmmmm delicious...and the Monterey sardines are always good...and carpaccio.  Main dishes the Boar, Lamb and pasta w/shaved tuna hearts or something like that.....all bloody good!!!!  HMM HMM HMM
author: May M.

description:
Finally a good italian restaurant. Take the word of an Italian who is quite picky about Italian food outside of Italy.

I highly recommend it.

The food was yummy.  The ambiance was not overly done.  So we felt comfortable that we were paying for good quality food.

We shared the Inzalaredda de Mari cun Ollu e Limoni (Seafood Salad with Lemon Oil Dressing).  I was in  heaven. 

I chose the Spaghittusu cun Allu Ollu e Bottariga (Fresh Spaghetti with spicy Oil and Bottarga).  Very happy.  A super simple pasta to make, if you have the Bottarga.

My wife had the Tonnu in Padella Cun Cibudda e Zaffaranu (Local Tuna sauteed with Vermentino and Saffron Onions). Very yummy indeed!

We also got the Pani Guttiau (Sardinian Flat Bread baked with Cuor d'Olivo and Pecorino), good, but it really could be skipped.

We didn't get dessert cause we were STUFFED. 

They also served us veggies, peas with carrots, very nice. 

Service was good, very friendly not overly stuffy.

Although we are not wine drinkers the entire back of the menu was full of Italian wine (in font 8, I think).

Everyone there was drinking wine and they seemed to make a big deal of it! They chef was touring the tables and commenting the wines. So I assume it is a good place to do so.
author: Peppe R.

description:
Nice ambiance, very nice hostess/owner, great fresh pasta.
We were early for our mid evning reservation, and so had to wait for our table.  The hostess was very attentive, came out more than once to check on us, thank us for our patience and finally brought out prosecco.  Really, she didn't have to, as we were early, but it certainly warmed us to her.  The evening went on like this, attentive, friendly service.
We started with the octopus stew - very tasty, slightly spicy wine/tomato sauce.  Then we had pizza, good, the crust on the chewy side.  Pasta was the best - I had the spaghetti with shaved tuna and roe.  Just so good.  And hubby had the wild boar stew, which came with a side of mashed potatoes (yum).  I found the stew a little heavy, but hubby loved it.
Overall, a very, very nice meal.  And I'm looking forward to the next one.
author: H K.

description: AMAZING lamb.  My fiance and I came here for our anniversary and were blown away.  I rated it a 4 instead of a 5 because there is not a lot of seating, was very crowded, and you can't get in there on a Sat unless you make a reservation several days in advance.  Ambience was nice.  Servers were great.  Every single bit of food was fantastic.  Fiance had seared ahi and it was good, but not as good as my lamb.  Don't be afraid to be adventurous when you come here!
author: Ilovenap S.

description:
Wonderful experience! The best italian [ sardinian ] food in the city.
If you go there start with the octopus or the sea food salad, follow by lasagnette or orata in vermentino sauce or wild boar stew.........
Outstanding wine list, only italian, also by the glass you have a lovely selection, barolo barbera nebbiolo vermentino pinot biano etc....
The service? 10 stars for the service, in a such small space they move very well and they are so friendly, my server was perfect with such a positive power, he actually picked the food and the wine for us, trust me we liked everything!!!! I don't remember his name name but he was so funny, he was make fun of his hair, actually is pony tail( he is bold), i'm telling you, he makes our night special, thanks to la ciccia and our server" with a pony tail "! Almoust forgot! Please save a room for the delicious ricotta dessert.
author: robert l.

description: Loved La Cicca.  Has a wonderful cozy,neighborhood feel and amazing food. Had yummy homemade proscuitto and salami drizzled with olive oil .  For dinner I had a pizza with Rocket and proscuitto.  My husband had the wild boar hand it was very rich and perfect for a cool fall night (even though it was 80 degrees in the middle of a fall heat wave).
author: melissa o.

description:
i love this place.  you go inside and it's bustling and warm, and full of good good vibes.  lorella is such a wonderful host.  the food is delicious.  it's like stepping into sardinia.  

the owners know what their doing, and do it because they love it, and this comes through in everything about the restaurant.  another thing to mention is that i always hear other diners speaking italian when i go there.  good sign.  

go here!!
author: Kate D.

description:
what a neighborhood gem....
love, love. love this place. not only for the food, but the owners, lorella and massimo. they are such wonderful, warm people and their staff is incredibly helpful and courteous.
their wine selection is incredible but can be a bit overwhelming. if i can't decide, i will ask for a recommendation with my meal and they have never steered me wrong.
the food is wonderful. had the best thinly sliced smoked tuna and swordfish i've ever tasted... all the pizza's are awesome, and if you can't decide, the lamb chops are always a safe bet! the salad with the sapa onions is always a staple on my visits... the seafood salad is a pleasant surprise.
author: connie a.

description: Super Delicious food, outstanding service, good wine.  The food was so good I woke up the next day wanting more.
author: Tammy W.

description: amazing place , truly a place that caters to people who know their food . Very warm and cozy .
author: Evan M.

description: I guess la cicia means belly but that may be up to debate,  at any rate your wallet muight hurt a bit but your belly will be happy you went.  This aint no pasta pomodorro.  It's damn good Italien is what it is in the quiet but up and comming area for restuarants at the end of Church street.  I don't know waht happend to sinor Bowen's meal but I have been there wuite few times and was allways verry pleased with my meal Four Stars!
author: James S.

description:
One of the best Italian places in the city.  This place actually made me take a trip to Sardinia to find out if the food from this region really is this good.  (and i wasn't disappointed).  

The restaurant is small, low key and the chef/owner/staff provide AMAZING service.  The food is divine.  I've been here a number of times and have never been disappointed.  The pastas are incredibly fresh and the meals are created and cooked to perfection.  

Enjoy! (i always do!)
author: shani h.

description: Exceptional.  So reasonable and wonderful Italian food.  Wines are great.  Intimate setting.
author: Lisa K.

description: This place is truly exquisite!  Yes, it is a bit crowded and urban, but afterall it is located in San Francisco.  Everything we ate was fresh, unusual, fantastic, so much so, that we couldn't resist but pick up an appetizer when we had to retrieve our credit card the next day (left behind in the jouissance of a truly enjoyable meal).  The couple next to us couldn't believed that they'd spent $60 when they could have spent $150 and we were similarly baffled by the unsurpassed quality of our dining experience.  The owners and staff are delightfully european and in general the place exudes authenticity.
author: Felicia F.

description: Quaint and simply fantastic!  Not only is the food great, the wine list is incredible.
author: Justin L.

description: I can't believe i didn't discover this place sooner.  First, it's wonderful to live in a city where you can find subspecialized ethnic cuisines...how many Sardinian restaurants can you find in St. Louis? Second, beyond the curiosity factor, this place is a gem.   Food is novel (to me) and beautifully prepared.  Wine list is also novel, all Italian and mostly Sardinian, lots of reasonably priced selections.  Decor is subdued, calming, elegant.  And with all these strengths, the service may be stronger yet: bright, friendly, appropriate, knowledgable, gracious.  I can't say enough good things about this place.
author: John F.

description: when the food hits your eye like a big pizza pie...  all i have to say is that everybody should frequent this place.  the atmosphere is intimate, the service is family-style-friendly and attentive, the food is DELICIOUS and the wine list a wonderful accent on the entire experience.  go here. order a lot. its not expensive. thats amore!
author: Kevin J.

description: This place just opened last Monday so it is a brand spanking new addition to Noe Valley. Yay! Have to say, I was pretty impressed, though I must admit, they did seem a bit overwhelmed (but overwhelmed because of how busy they were, which means there are a lot of people there enjoying their food!) at times. Apparently this is their first restaurant ever, so they're still learning the ropes, kinda. I think they'll do quite well though with a little practice (and patient customers). They were so friendly and seemed to genuinely care about our dining experience. We walked in without a reservation, so they asked us to wait a few minutes at the bar. No problem. Then they poured us 2 glasses of champagne "to accompany the wait". :-) Not 10 minutes later, we were seated at a fine table, and ordered a glass of wine and the mozzarella and red pepper appetizer (which, btw was delicious). Unfortunately, we did have to ask where our wine was, but I almost felt bad, because it was so clear they were working their hardest and had simply forgotten given the rush of people they had not anticipated receiving. Our server was extremely apologetic and very helpfuul when we had questions about the menu, and wound up bringing us 3 desserts instead of the 1 we ordered, to apologize for the wine incident (it arriving late). The desserts themselves were average, I'd say, but the accompanying blood orange gelato was out of this world. My friend is allergic to oranges, so I got to enjoy the whole thing myself (sorry Diana!) All in all, I was very happy and will definitely be returning in the near future.
author: beth l.

description: I think this might just be the most authentic Italian food you can get in SF. The pizza is perfect, and the pasta dishes are amazing. Granted, Sardinian (and Sicilian, which it reminds me a lot of) food is different from other Italian food. But then again, every region (or town for that matter) in Italy has it's own cuisine. Just think if this cuisine as the super-concentrated, sun-kissed (and somewhat more seafood-focused) version of Italian food. And La Ciccia turns out as perfect a version as you can find with raw materials that aren't grown in Italy. Not to mention that the owners are as hospitable as any Italian family you can meet. My highest recommendation.
author: Don J.

description: I was hesitant to even write a review because I don't want this place to get mobbed and I'll never get a table again. It's already pretty small. I absolutely LOVE this restaurant. It's my favorite Italian restaurant in the city by far, and one of my favorites ever. But it's not Italian food like you may be used to; it's Sardinian, not your standard red sauce face. Sardinian food definitely has it's own unique style-- but it's really delicious. The husband and wife team that run the place are so incredibly nice (they make you feel like family) and the service has been excellent every time I've eaten here (10 times now probably). I've never had a bad experience. The octopus is amazing, the charcruterie of the day is always great, and you can't go wrong with any of the entrees. I've had the lamb, whole fish, the pork with olives and they've all been mouth-watering. The flavors are so complex-- it seems like all the dishes have a lot of time and care put into them. Try it, just don't spread the word.
author: Pete B.

description: One of my top three favorite neighborhood restaurants. Great food, reasonable prices. The place is always packed. The Sardinian wine list is a gold mine.
author: Colin D.

description: This is one of the best restaurants in the Bay Area.  The space is tiny, the menu is small, the wine list is larger, the hearts of the owners are giant.  Please don't ever tell the Michelin people about it; it's still possible to get in with a couple of days' notice and you will treasure every bite.  The octopus in tomato sauce is the very definition of comfort food.  The vegetables shine; always ask what the vegetable specials are.  They will also accommodate some changes to the vegetables they serve with the meat and the fish.  Great wine recommendations from the wait staff always, at prices you can afford, or otherwise.  The chef even told me the recipe for his pork stewed in white wine and olives.  It came out pretty darn good when I made it (of course it took me six hours).  Do yourself a favor, and make this one of your regular spots.  Or do us, the current customers, a favor, and don't.
author: rtln s.

description: I loveeee La Ciccia, it's like the best Italian food in the whole Bay Area. They're so authentic, Sardinian food, unlike other regular Italian restaurant or fake Italian American style. I love everything that they served. Too bad, the fish was sold out when I got there around 8.30pm on Sunday. Love the al dente pasta, the crispy bread, salami, arugula salad, octopus, prosciutto pizza........Mmmm, yummie. They're so tasty and so different. The husband owner is the chef in the kitchen. They're so friendly and nice place, not too big or small, classic Italian familia.
author: Clemencia S.

description: Love La Ciccia.  Super friendly and helpful servers and excellent food. The octopus is incredible, as were the sardines. The fregula with squid, fantastic flavor and texture and the lamb sugo pasta rich and delish.
author: Amy F.

description: Liked the wine list, the octopus stew, and the unique flavors, like a pasta in a squid ink sauce and the vegetable specials.
author: SF P.

description: After arriving at most restaurants and being seated they bring water and bread and butter.  At this restaurant there  was the water but no bread.  After asking for bread and it was brought I said "Do you have any butter, olive oil or some sort of tapenade  for the bread?" Eating room temperature bread without any butter, olive oil or tapenade is not very good, if not difficult, and rather dry.  The waitress looked shocked that I asked.  She then said olive oil was $2 extra.  Since we did not want to eat dry bread while waiting for our order we said alright.  The olive oil came in a small saucer the size for a tea bag.  We thought that was  ridiculous.  I have talked to many people about it and all were astounded.  Next we will be charged for laundering the napkins and pay for the soap to wash the dishes.  The food at La Ciccia is good and the hostess was very nice but there are alot of good food with nice hostesses restaurants out there.  I won't go back to this one for the simple reason of paying $2 for a small saucer of olive oil.  It wasn't even great olive oil. There is that saying penny wise pound foolish.  To make an extra dollar they lost money on two future entrees.
author: Sally F.

description: Sardinian food, you say? Yes, odd and quirky, but also fun and rustic-as-all-hell. We piled into the front booth on a windy Friday evening. The service was friendly, knowledgeable, and (with the exception of the interminable wait for the check) well executed. First, I need to tell you about the menu: if you were thinking of impressing your date with how well you navigated the menu and conversed with the waiter in your best Junior High Italian, fahgeddaboutit! My Italian skills were no match for the menu written in Sardinian dialect. I kid you not. Therefore, it was a little tricky to get my footing, but pretty soon we were able to sort out the pasta dish (nice and delicate) from the pizza (very solid, though not in A16 territory) from the lamb stew (solid but waaay overseasoned.) The apps were also good -- fresh porcini mushrooms lightly sauteed in olive oil and garlic, and a calamari salad swimming in a tangy vinagrette. Overall, a nice dinner and not too rough on the platinum card. I felt the dishes were a little off-balance and there could have been a bit more pizzazz in some of the flavorings, but we were sated and happy we dined at La Ciccia. Probably doesn't pass the 'would-we-go-back' test given the tremendous choices in this city we are so fortunate to live in, but would certainly recommend it if someone was chomping at the bit for a VERY authentic and unpretentious dining experience a la Sardiniese. Ciao, tutti
author: Jonathan T.

description: Amazing service.  Husband is head chef, wife runs the tables.  They treat you like family.  Chef routinely comes out to talk to customers and ask for feedback.  Great hospitality.  Great experience.
author: Paul M.

description: This evening I dined at La Ciccia with my mom. They served my mom the wrong entree, but she liked it so much that she kept it. Later on they gave her a side dish her original order just to see if she liked it. We shared an excellent salad and then she had the lentil soup while I had the octopus soup, which were equally as good. My mom ended up having a pasta dish with a sausage ragout, while I had a wonderful rare lamp dish. At the end of the evening the owner stopped by our table. Because of the mix-up in dishes, she not only waived our $75 bill, but gave us a $50 gift certificate. I recommend going to this restaurant because they have both excellent food and unquestionable customer service.
author: John S.

description: the best italian food in SF.  that gnocchetti with the pork sugo is amazing.  and the fish was so delicious as well.  even the simple dressing on the house salad is divine.
author: a g.

description: Delicious!  I've heard friends rave but only tried it for the first time tonight.  It is a small but very personal little place.  The food is authentic Sardinian fare - wonderful wine list and perfectly cooked seafood and pizza.  Oven roasted cauliflower that was exceptional.  The staff was helpful, cheerful and personable without being overly solicitious.  The chef is friendly and I enjoyed talking with him about his cooking technique for the wonderful cauliflower dish.  I can't wait for the next visit!
author: FiFi S.

description: I took my mom here for dinner while she was visiting from out of town. We went there because it is close to my house, and we peeked in and saw that it had great ambiance. We walked in without a reservation, we were greeted warmly at the door and shown to the bar, where we were served a yummy glass of wine during our wait. After a short wait and ordering, every dish that was served to us was better than the one before. Great ambiance, great friendly service, and really really yummy food!!! I love this place!
author: Stephanie S.

description: some unique pasta dishes that were new flavors in my mouth, and tasty
author: Peter L.

description: One Word-Flavor.  It is found in all the right places and especially at La Ciccia.  This homey, cozy restaurant offers perfectly seasoned, richly flavored cuisine from Sardinia, that other Italian island.  On my last visit we were greeted by the most pleasant woman with a soothing Italian accent.  Although reservations are almost a must now, she found us that not-so-romantic spot between the restroom and the kitchen, but who cares, the food made up for it.  So did the servers, even though we had a trainee in-tow with ours.  We split a special fresh spaghetti with Porcinis.  To-Die-For!  Lightly scented with fresh thyme and covered with sauteed Porcinis and onions.  Very simple, very fresh, very good.  Then on to the pizza.  My tell for a perfect Italian dining experience is the pizza.  I love the pizza at Delfina and also at Cafe Gialina in Glen Park, so you know where I am coming from.  We chose the Pizza Sarda I believe was the name.  It was made with a simple tomato sauce, oregano, Mozzarella, Pecorino and capers (although I found only one).  The crust was a little chewy but the overall flavor was perfect.  We also had a side offering of sauteed baby globe artichokes with chili flakes.  They were as good as I would make at home. Overall the experience was fantastic and I plan to return again and again, especially since it is a 5 minute J-Church ride away.
author: Joel C.

description: Went here last night and had a lovely time! First off must say the service is really wonderful. The owner's wife was so sweet and attentive and it really made our experience - so many new "hot" places have such terrible service and this was so not the case here! We also really liked their food. You kick things off with some bread dipped in olive oil - try not to fill up too much on this though - the olive oil was really good so we went a bit overboard I think. We then had the Salumi which was fabulous and one of the highlights of the meal. Then, the clams and mussels - the bread is really great to soak up the wonderful buttery juices.
