Then - a special of the day, shortribs with another fabulous sauce to dip the bread in (can you see what's happening here, we are really filling up on bread!). And then their wonderful pizza - we went for the first one, the Sarda, which had a great sprinkle of capers, just the right amount of flavor and saltiness without being overdone. At this point we were absolutely stuffed and still had our entrees coming. 2 of us had the wild boar stew and 2 had the lamb chops. There was absolutely nothing wrong with our entrees but we couldn't eat much of them. The lamb chop has a lot of fennel so you have to be a fennel fan - if you want the classic seared chop that's not what you're getting here. But they come with a great zucchini and squash medley, and it's a generous portion of chops as well, 3! The stew was quite good. What I would do next time is just come for a ton of the apps, pizza, etc. and skip the entrees, because I really enjoyed all the starters. Corkage is $25 but they waive it if you buy a bottle so not a bad deal! Their pricing is quite reasonable across the board. Another great addition to Noe Valley - it's really turning in to quite the foodie neighborhood!
author: Sarah R.

description: I am so happy we live close to this place.  Great unique Italian food.  Their pastas are all made with fresh pasta and perfectly tasty.  Their Pizza had perfect crust and fresh ingredients.  Great wine list, all Italian, and not outrageously expensive either.  And the owners were so nice and friendly.  We were a group of six and closed the place, and the owners were so nice, coming over to chat, making wine and food suggestions, wishing happy holidays, etc.. Will definitely be going back many times.
author: N G.

description: simple yet refined dishes. extensive wine selection and great, friendly service. tight quarters though....
author: aj s.

description: Hands down the best Italian in San Francisco.  All the food is fresh,  flavorful, inventive, and not overly seasoned.  The service is unpretentious, yet knowledgeable, considerate and attentive.  The wine list leaves nothing to be desired.
author: Green G.

description: We love this place. A restaurant that gets it:  friendly, gracious wait staff, a real knowledge and love for the food they offer, and no rush to turn their tables.  A bit too noisy--carpet would help--but one of the best kept secrets in the city.
author: Mykonos O.

description: We had dinner here last night and it was delicious!  Started with the salumi and seafood salad for appetizers, and then pasta with lamb ragu and wild boar stew for main dishes.  Service was excellent.  We will be back!
author: Clarice C.

description: mmm, la ciccia.  this place reminds me of going to a restaurant in italy.  they have a great friendly, family feel here - the decor is not over-the-top fancy, but the food is nothing short of delicious.  their pizzas and cured meats are really nice, as are their pastas.  the mediterranean flavors also pair very nicely with their fabulous and unique selection of wines - this is definitely a place where you can't go wrong, so try something you've never had before. . .who knew sardinian food could be so good?
author: Erin C.

description:
When I don't know much about cooking in a particular country, I frequently want to add a caveat to my reviews/opinions of ethnic restaurant quality. Sure I liked the tacos, but I know nothing of how the Mexicans think tacos should be prepared so perhaps my opinion matters less than someone's who knows. However, an argument could be made that it doesn't matter. After all, so the argument goes, whether or not John Doe likes the food--in all of his cultural ignorance--is far more important than how true its preparation and presentation are to the way it is done in the mother country. This question can best be answered by looking to the culture from which the food originates. 

Unless you've dined in Italy with Italians it's difficult to imagine how particular they are about food. They are particular about how food is prepared and how it is served (e.g., pasta is cooked until it is al dente; seafood pasta never gets cheese on top). There are very specific rules about what dishes are served together and the course in which they are eaten (e.g., pizza is not ordered with a first or second, the pasta course is eaten before the meat course, coffee after dessert).  Even the time of day in which they are eaten is strictly defined (e.g., milk is served at breakfast not dinner, cappuccino is never ordered after 11 am).  These are absolutes; there is no room for culinary relativism in Italy.  Food is perhaps the most dear and seriously considered thing in an Italian's life.  To answer the question above, In the case of Italian food--Sardinia *is* part of Italy--the resounding, emphatic answer is YES IT MATTERS!

So, on to reviewing La Ciccia without the caveat.  La Ciccia judged by the Italian standard receives a solid five stars. From the Salumi to the Octopus Stew to the Branzino, La Ciccia is authentic and outstanding. What's more, the front of house staff are friendly and helpful: traits not always encountered in restaurants in Italy.   Over the last two years I've ordered everything on the menu and consistently found it to be excellent.

If you are looking for outstanding Italian food then look no further than La Ciccia. Whether or not you agree speaks to just how "educated" on Italian food you are, and how much further you have to go. :-)
author: Rich M.

description: This is my favorite Italian, well, Sardinian restaurant in town. It is down-to-earth, not pretentious, just offering nice foods. The service is very nice and friendly, too. The quality of food is a little volatile, but it is ok. The average is still high. It is always crowded, so make a reservation a way ahead.
author: Charlie S.

description: Whenever anyone comes from out of town, I take them here.  I'm not even going to go into details, it's the only restaurant in San Francisco that is fantastic every single time I go, and I've been nearly a dozen times now.  You need a reservation these days.
author: MIchele G.

description: Not just another average Italian restaurants, the favors at La Ciccia are rich and intense. Went there early on a weeknight, just before 6, not crowded yet. It's small, just a dozen tables or so, simplily decorated. We started with a tender octopus dish in a soupy smoky tangy roasted red pepper/parpika sauce, and a generous house-cured salami plate with some Mortadella, sopressata, Prosciutto di Parma. Had pizzas, thin italian style, pesto pizza with fresh cheeses and porciutto and ricotta topped with arugula. Wine list was a good size, Italian wines. Service was friendly. Prices are reasonable.
author: Kirk W.

description: I don't live in SF anymore, but right before our move back east, I had the privilege of eating here.  This place is AMAZING!!! We had the seafood salad, and octopus stew to start with (both dishes were delicious and oh, so tender).  For the first course, i had the night's special, spaghetti with shaved tuna heart. I still dream about that dish!!!  We then ordered some pizza margherita, a tender lamb dish, broccoli rabe (done perfectly), and a fish dish (sorry, it's been awhile). Everything that night was absolutely perfect- food, wine, service, and company!!  It's unfortunate I haven't found anything comparable here in NYC (without sacrificing an arm and a leg for dinner)....  i miss SF....sigh.....
author: Angie L.

description: great place with great owners.  the food is authentic and fantastic.  definitely a hidden gem!
author: Ellen R.

description: Awesome, authentic food.  Try the braised octopus and stews.  Got to have a reservation though.
author: Ed T.

description: WE LOVE THIS RESTAURANT!!!! The food is delicious, the service and welcome you get when you walk in the (albeit cozy) entryway is unparalleled, and the wine list is exciting without overwhelming.  I'm very confused by the recent tepid review from the Chronicle; we've been going to La Ciccia since it first opened and have always had great experiences with friends and family there.
author: Heather C.

description: Great food (especially the fish!); great people.  Wine list is interesting and cool.  Only way to improve -- more options for vegetarians.
author: jay V.
